translated: This is because the light of the sun enters through the holes above the mountains.

analyzed: tathā ṛk ādi amṛta upajīvinām amṛtānām ca dviguṇa uttarottara vīryavat tvam anumīyate bhoga kāla dvaiguṇya liṅgena
translated: Similarly, for those who subsist on nectar such as Soma and the immortals, the strength is inferred to be twice as much in each case, by the sign of the doubling of the time of enjoyment.

analyzed: udyamana saṃveśana ādi devānām rudra ādīnām viduṣaḥ ca samānam
translated: The rising, setting, etc. of the gods, Rudra and others, and of the wise one are the same.

analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣadi tṛtīya adhyāyasya aṣṭama navama daśama khaṇḍāḥ
translated: Thus are the eighth, ninth and tenth sections of the third chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha tata ūrdhva udetya naivodetā nāstam etaikala eva madhye sthātā /
analyzed: atha tatas ūrdhvaḥ udetya na eva udetā na astam etā ekalaḥ eva madhye sthātā
translated: Then, rising above that, it neither rises nor sets, but remains alone in the middle.

analyzed: tat eṣa ślokaḥ  kṛtvā evam udaya astamanena prāṇinām sva karma phala bhoga nimittam anugraham
translated: This is the verse about it.🔽Having thus shown favor for the enjoyment of the fruits of their own actions by beings through rising and setting,

analyzed: tad karma phala upabhoga kṣaye tāni prāṇi jātāni ātmani saṃhṛtya atha tatas tasmāt anantaram
translated: when the enjoyment of the fruits of those actions is exhausted, those beings are withdrawn into the Self. Then, after that,

analyzed: prāṇi anugraha kālāt ūrdhvaḥ san ātmani udetya udgamya yān pratyudeti teṣām prāṇinām abhāvāt svātma sthaḥ
translated: After the time of favouring living beings, existing in the Self, rising up, having risen, for whom it rises, due to the absence of those living beings, remaining in the Self,

analyzed: na eva udetā na astametā ekalaḥ dvitīyaḥ na vayavaḥ madhye sva ātmani eva sthātā
translated: it should not rise, it should not set, being alone, without a second, without parts, it should remain in the middle, in the Self itself.

original: tatra kaścidvidvānvasvādisamānacaraṇo rohitādyamṛtabhogabhāgī yathoktakrameṇa svātmānaṃ savitāramātmatvenopetya samāhitaḥ sannetaṃ mantraṃ
analyzed: tatra kaścid vidvān vasu ādi samāna caraṇaḥ rohita ādi amṛta bhoga bhāgī yathā ukta krameṇa sva ātmānam savitāram ātmatvena upetya samāhitaḥ san etam mantram
translated: There, some wise one, having the same conduct as Vāsudeva and others, entitled to enjoy nectar like Rohita and others, having identified his own Self with the Sun in the manner described, having risen after seeing this mantra,

analyzed: dṛṣṭvā utthitaḥ nyasmai pṛṣṭavate jagāda
translated: having risen, he said this to another who asked,

original: yatastvamāgato brahmalokātkiṃ tatrāpyahorātrābhyāṃ parivartamānaḥ savitā prāṇināmāyuḥ kṣapayati yathehāsmākamityevaṃ pṛṣṭaḥ pratyāha /
analyzed: yatas tvam āgataḥ brahma lokāt kim tatra api ahar rātrābhyām parivartamānaḥ savitā prāṇinām āyuḥ kṣapayati yathā iha asmākam iti evam pṛṣṭaḥ pratyāha
translated: Since you have come from the world of Brahman, does the Sun, revolving there by day and night, diminish the life of living beings as it does here for us? Being asked thus, he replied,

original: tattatra yathā pṛṣṭe yathokte cārtha eṣa śloko bhavati tanokto yogineti śrutervacanamidam //🔽na vai tatra na nimloca /
analyzed: tat tatra yathā pṛṣṭe yathā ukte ca arthe eṣa ślokaḥ bhavati tanā uktaḥ yoginā iti śruteḥ vacanam idam  na vai tatra na nimloca
translated: There, in that place, this verse is for the purpose of what was asked and what was said. This statement is made by the sage, as it is heard in the scriptures.🔽Verily, it did not set there,

analyzed: na udiyāya kadācana
translated: nor did it rise at any time.

analyzed: devāḥ tena aham satyena
translated: By that truth, O gods,

analyzed: mā virādhiṣi brahmaṇā iti
translated: may I not be injured by Brahman.

original: na vai tatra yato 'haṃ brahmalokādāgatastasminna vai tatraitadasti yatpṛcchasi /
analyzed: na vai tatra yatas ham brahma lokāt āgataḥ tasmin na vai tatra etat asti yat pṛcchasi
translated: 'There is not that from which I have come here from the world of Brahman, and there is not that which you ask about.

original: na hi tatra nimloco 'stamagamatsavitā na codiyāyodgataḥ kutaścitkadācana kasmiṃścidapi kāla iti /
analyzed: na hi tatra nimlocaḥ stam agamat savitā na ca udiyāya udgataḥ kutaścid kadācana kasmiṃścid api kāle iti
translated: For there the sun does not set, does not go to rest, nor does it rise, does not rise from anywhere at any time.'

analyzed: udaya astamaya varjitaḥ brahma lokaḥ iti anupapannam iti uktaḥ śutham iva pratipede
translated: The world of Brahman, being free from rising and setting, is not possible. Thus spoken to, he agreed as if to a well-known fact.

original: he devāḥ sākṣiṇo yūyaṃ śṛṇuta yathā mayoktaṃ satyaṃ vacastena steyanāhaṃ brahmaṇā brahmasvarūpeṇa mā virādhiṣi mā virudhyeyamaprāptirbrahmaṇā
analyzed: he devāḥ sākṣiṇaḥ yūyam śṛṇuta yathā mayā uktam satyam vacaḥ tena steyana aham brahmaṇā brahma svarūpeṇa mā virādhiṣi mā virudhyeyam aprāptiḥ brahmaṇā
translated: 'O gods, you are the witnesses. Listen to my words. By the truth of what I have said, may I not be in conflict with Brahman, with the form of Brahman. May I not be in conflict with Brahman.

analyzed: mama mā bhūt iti arthaḥ
translated: May there be no non-attainment for me. This is the meaning.

original: na ha vā asmā udeti na nimlocati /
analyzed: na ha vai asmai udeti na nimlocati
translated: For him, the sun does not rise nor does it set.

analyzed: sakṛt divā ha eva asmai bhavati
translated: For him, it is always day.

original: ya etām evaṃ brahmopaniṣadaṃ veda //🔽satyaṃ tenoktamityāha śrutiḥna ha vā asmai yathoktabrahmavide nodeti
analyzed: yaḥ etām evam brahma upaniṣadam veda  satyam tena uktam iti āha śrutiḥ na ha vai asmai yathā ukta brahma vide na udeti
translated: For one who knows this Brahma Upanishad in this way.

original: na nimlocati nāstameti kiṃ tu brahmavide 'smai sakṛddivā haiva sadaivāharbhavati
analyzed: na nimlocati na astam eti kim tu brahma vide smai sakṛt divā ha eva sadā eva ahar bhavati
translated: The scripture says that what he has said is true. For one who knows Brahman as described, the sun does not rise nor does it set nor does it go to rest. But for him who knows Brahman, it is always day.

original: svayañjyotiṣṭvādya etāṃ yathoktāṃ brahmopaniṣadaṃ vedaguhyaṃ veda /
analyzed: svayañjyotiḥ tvā adya etām yathā uktām brahma upaniṣadam veda guhyam veda
translated: He who knows this secret of the Upanishad of Brahman, as stated, by himself being the light,

original: evaṃ tantreṇa vaṃśāditrayaṃ pratyamṛtasambandhaṃ ca yaccānyadavocāmaivaṃ jānātītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: evam tantreṇa vaṃśa ādi trayam prati amṛta sambandham ca yat ca anyat avocāma evam jānāti iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, by implication, the three generations beginning with the race, and the connection with immortality, and whatever else we have said, he knows thus - this is the meaning.

original: vidvānudayāstamayakālāparicchedyaṃ nityamajaṃ brahma bhavatītyarthaḥ //🔽tad dhaitad brahmā prajāpataya uvāca /
analyzed: vidvān udaya astamaya kāla aparicchedyam nityam ajam brahma bhavati iti arthaḥ  tat ha etat brahmā prajāpataye uvāca
translated: The learned one becomes Brahman, which is eternal and unborn, not limited by the time of rising and setting - this is the meaning.

analyzed: prajāpatiḥ manave
translated: That, indeed, this Brahman, Hiraṇyagarbha, the knower of Brahman, said to Prajāpatis.🔽Prajāpati to Manu.

analyzed: manuḥ prajābhyaḥ
translated: Manu to the people.

original: tad dhaitad uddālakāyāruṇaye jyeṣṭhāya putrāya pitā brahma provāca //
analyzed: tat ha etat uddālakāya aruṇaye jyeṣṭhāya putrāya pitā brahma provāca
translated: That, indeed, this knowledge of Brahman, Uddālaka Āruṇi's father, said to his eldest son.

original: taddhaitanmadhujñānaṃ brahmā hiraṇyagarbho virāje prajāpataya uvāca /
analyzed: tat ha etat madhu jñānam brahmā hiraṇyagarbhaḥ virāje prajāpataye uvāca
translated: That, indeed, this knowledge of honey, Brahman Hiraṇyagarbha said to the Prajāpatis in the Virāṭ world.

analyzed: saḥ pi manave
translated: He also to Manu.

original: manurikṣvākvādyābhyaḥ prajābhyaḥ provāceti vidyāṃ stauti brahmādiviśiṣṭakramāgateti /
analyzed: manuḥ ikṣvāku ādyābhyaḥ prajābhyaḥ provāca iti vidyām stauti brahma ādi viśiṣṭa krama āgata iti
translated: Manu said to the people beginning with Ikṣvāku. Thus he praises the knowledge as coming through the distinguished succession beginning with Brahman.

analyzed: kim ca tat ha etat madhu jñānam uddālakāya aruṇaye pitā
translated: And what is more, that knowledge of honey, Uddālaka Āruṇi's father

original: idaṃ vāva taj jyeṣṭhāya putrāya pitā brahma prabrūyāt praṇāyyāya vāntevāsine //
analyzed: idam vāva tat jyeṣṭhāya putrāya pitā brahma prabrūyāt praṇāyyāya vā antevāsine
translated: This, indeed, a father should declare to his eldest son, or to a grandson, or to a pupil.

original: idaṃ vāva tadyathoktamanyo 'pi jyeṣṭhāya putrāya sarvapriyārhāya brahma prabrūyāt /
analyzed: idam vāva tat yathā uktam anyaḥ pi jyeṣṭhāya putrāya sarva priya arhāya brahma prabrūyāt
translated: This, indeed, is that which one may expound to a son, the eldest, who is dear to him and deserves to have everything.

analyzed: praṇāyyāya vā yogyāya ai antevāsine śiṣyāya
translated: This, indeed, is that (Veda) which has been described, which one may impart to an eldest son, to a dear son, to a son who is fit for every duty, to a grandson, to a pupil, to a disciple.

analyzed: na anyasmai kasmaicana
translated: To none else, to no one whatever.

original: yady apy asmā imām adbhiḥ parigṛhītāṃ dhanasya pūrṇāṃ dadyād etad eva tato bhūya iti //
analyzed: yadi api asmai imām adbhiḥ parigṛhītām dhanasya pūrṇām dadyāt etat eva tatas bhūyaḥ iti
translated: Even if one were to give him this (earth) filled with water and wealth up to its boundaries, it would be as nothing compared with that.

analyzed: na anyasmai kasmaicana prabrūyāt tīrtha dvayam anujñātam anekeṣām prāptānām tīrthānām ācārya ādīnām
translated: To none else, to no one whatever. The two sources are permitted, of the many sources that are available, of the teachers and others.

original: kasmātpunastīrthasaṅkocanaṃ vidyāyā niṣkrayārthamācāryāya dhanasya pūrṇāṃ sampannāṃ
analyzed: kasmāt punar tīrtha saṅkocanam vidyāyāḥ niṣkraya artham ācāryāya dhanasya pūrṇām sampannām
translated: Why then is the source of knowledge restricted? For the purpose of paying the teacher's fee, one should give the teacher this (earth) filled with wealth up to its boundaries.

analyzed: bhoga upararaṇaiḥ na asau asya niṣkrayaḥ yasmāt dānāt etat eva yat madhu vidyā dānam
translated: That is not the fee for him, since it is a mere obstruction to enjoyment. Therefore, this giving of the knowledge of honey is far greater than that giving.

analyzed: bhūyaḥ bahutara phalam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it has a much greater fruit.

analyzed: dvis abhyāsaḥ ādara arthaḥ
translated: The repetition is for the purpose of respect.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi tṛtīya adhyāyasya ekādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eleventh section in the third chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: gāyatrī vā idaṃ sarvaṃ bhūtaṃ yad idam kiñca /
analyzed: gāyatrī vai idam sarvam bhūtam yat idam kiñca
translated: This entire world, whatever there is, is indeed Gāyatrī.

analyzed: vāc vai gāyatrī
translated: Speech indeed is Gāyatrī.

original: vāg vā idaṃ sarvaṃ bhūtaṃ gāyati ca trāyate ca //
analyzed: vāc vai idam sarvam bhūtam gāyati ca trāyate ca
translated: Speech indeed sings this whole world and protects it.

original: yata evamatiśayaphalaiṣā brahmavidyātaḥ sā prakārāntareṇāpi vaktavyeti gāyatrī vā ityādyārabhyate /
analyzed: yatas evam atiśaya phalā eṣā brahma vidyātaḥ sā prakāra antareṇa api vaktavyā iti gāyatrī vā ityādi ārabhyate
translated: Since this knowledge of Brahman has such a superior fruit, it should be stated in another way also. Therefore, beginning with Gāyatrī indeed, etc. is started.

analyzed: gāyatrī dvāreṇa ca ucyate
translated: And it is stated through the Gāyatrī.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ sarva viśeṣa rahitasya na iti na iti ityādi śiṣa pratiṣedha gamyasya durbodha tvāt
translated: Because Brahman, which is devoid of all distinctions and is to be understood through the prohibitions stated in the Upaniṣads beginning with Not this, not this, etc., is difficult to understand.

original: satsvanekeṣu cchandaḥsu gāyatryā eva brahmajñānadvāratayopādānaṃ prādhānyāt /
analyzed: satsu anekeṣu chandaḥsu gāyatryāḥ eva brahma jñāna dvāra tayā upādānam prādhānyāt
translated: And among the many meters, the Gāyatrī is chosen as the door to the knowledge of Brahman because it is primary.

original: somāharaṇāt itaracchandokṣarāharaṇenetaracchandovyāptyā ca sarvasavanavyāpakatvācca yajñe prādhānyaṃ gāyatryāḥ /
analyzed: soma āharaṇāt itara chandaḥ kṣara āharaṇena itara chandaḥ vyāptyā ca sarva savana vyāpaka tvāt ca yajñe prādhānyam gāyatryāḥ
translated: The Gāyatrī is primary in the sacrifice because it pervades all the Soma-extractions, because it pervades the other meters by extracting the syllables of the other meters, and because it pervades all the Soma-extractions.

original: gāyatrīsāratvācca brāhmaṇasya mātaramiva hitvā gurutarāṃ gāyatrīṃ tato 'nyadgurutaraṃ na pratipadyate yathoktaṃ brahmāpīti /
analyzed: gāyatrī sāra tvāt ca brāhmaṇasya mātaram iva hitvā gurutarām gāyatrīm tatas nyat gurutaram na pratipadyate yathā uktam brahmā api iti
translated: And because the Brāhmaṇa is the essence of the Gāyatrī, one does not take up anything heavier than the Gāyatrī, which is like a mother, as stated in even Brahmā.

analyzed: tasyām atyanta gauravasya prasiddha tvāt
translated: Because the extreme heaviness of that [Gāyatrī] is well-known.

analyzed: atas gāyatrī mukhena eva brahma ucyate
translated: Therefore, Brahman is stated through the Gāyatrī itself.

analyzed: gāyatrī vai iti avadhāraṇa arthaḥ vaiśabdaḥ
translated: The word vai has the meaning of restriction in Gāyatrī indeed.

original: idaṃ sarvaṃ bhūtaṃ prāmijātaṃ yatkiñca sthāvaraṃ jaṅgamaṃ vā tatsarvaṃ gāyatryeva /
analyzed: idam sarvam bhūtam prāmijātam yat kiñca sthāvaram jaṅgamam vā tat sarvam gāyatrī eva
translated: This entire universe, all that is born, whatever is stationary or moving, all that is indeed Gāyatrī.

analyzed: tasyāḥ chandomātrāyāḥ sarva bhūta tvam anupapannam iti gāyatrī kāraṇam vācam śabdayati asau
translated: The origin of Gāyatrī is declared, since it is not proper that mere meter should be all beings.

original: gaurasāvaśva iti ca trāyate ca rakṣatyamuṣmānmā bhaiṣīḥ kiṃ te bhayamutthitamityādinā
analyzed: gauḥ asau aśvaḥ iti ca trāyate ca rakṣati amuṣmān mā bhaiṣīḥ kim te bhayam utthitam ityādinā
translated: It protects one from this by saying Do not be afraid, what fear has arisen for you? etc.

original: sarvato bhayānnivartyamāno vācā trātaḥ syāt /🔽yadvāgbhūtaṃ gāyati ca trāyate ca gāyatryeva tadgāyati ca trāyate ca vāco 'nanyatvādgāyatryāḥ /
analyzed: sarvatas bhayāt nivartyamānaḥ vācā trātaḥ syāt  yat vāc bhūtam gāyati ca trāyate ca gāyatrī eva tat gāyati ca trāyate ca vācaḥ na anya tvāt gāyatryāḥ
translated: One would be protected by speech from all fear by being turned back.🔽Whatever is sung and protected by speech, that is indeed Gāyatrī, because Gāyatrī is not different from speech.

analyzed: gānāt trāṇāt ca gāyatryāḥ gāyatrī tvam
translated: Gāyatrī is so called because of singing and protecting.

original: yā vai sā gāyatrīyaṃ vāva sā yeyaṃ pṛthivī /
analyzed: yā vai sā gāyatrī iyam vāva sā yā iyam pṛthivī
translated: That which is Gāyatrī, which has such a nature and the form of all beings, is indeed this earth.

analyzed: asyām hi idam sarvam bhūtam pratiṣṭhitam
translated: For on this earth all beings are established.

original: etām eva nātiśīyate //🔽yā vai saivaṃlakṣaṇā sarvabhūtarūpā gāyatrī /
analyzed: etām eva na atiśīyate  yā vai sā evaṃlakṣaṇā sarva bhūta rūpā gāyatrī
translated: One does not go beyond this.

analyzed: iyam vāva sā yā iyam pṛthivī
translated: That which is Gāyatrī, which has such a nature and the form of all beings, is indeed this earth.

analyzed: katham punar iyam pṛthivī gāyatrī iti
translated: How again is this earth Gāyatrī?

analyzed: ucyate sarva bhūta sambandhāt
translated: It is said: because of the connection with all beings.

analyzed: katham sarva bhūta sambandhaḥ
translated: How is there connection with all beings?

original: asyāṃ pṛthivyāṃ hi yasmātsarvaṃ sthāvaraṃ jaṅgamaṃ ca bhūtaṃ pratiṣṭhitametāmeva pṛthivīṃ nātiśīyate nātivartata ityetat /
analyzed: asyām pṛthivyām hi yasmāt sarvam sthāvaram jaṅgamam ca bhūtam pratiṣṭhitam etām eva pṛthivīm na atiśīyate na ativartate iti etat
translated: Because all beings, both stationary and moving, are established on this earth; they do not go beyond or transcend this earth.

original: yathā gānatrāṇābhyāṃ bhūtasambandho gāyatryā evaṃ bhūtapratiṣṭhānādubhūtasambaddhā pṛthivyato gāyatrī pṛthivī //
analyzed: yathā gāna trāṇābhyām bhūta sambandhaḥ gāyatryāḥ evam bhūta pratiṣṭhānāt u bhūta sambaddhā pṛthivī atas gāyatrī pṛthivī
translated: Just as the Gayatri is connected with beings through singing and protection, in the same way, the earth is connected with beings through being the abode of beings, so the Gayatri is the earth.

original: yā vai sā pṛthivīyaṃ vāva sā yad idam asmin puruṣe śarīram /
analyzed: yā vai sā pṛthivī iyam vāva sā yat idam asmin puruṣe śarīram
translated: That which is the earth is indeed this, namely this body in this person.

analyzed: asmin hi ime prāṇāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: For in this, these vital breaths are established.

analyzed: etat eva na atiśīyante
translated: They do not go beyond this alone.

original: yā vai sā pṛthivī gāyatrīyaṃ vāva sedameva /
analyzed: yā vai sā pṛthivī gāyatrī iyam vāva sā idam eva
translated: That which is the earth, the Gayatri, is indeed this.

original: tatkiṃ / yadidamasminpuruṣe kāryakāraṇasaṅghāte jīvati śarīraṃ pārthivatvāccharīrasya /
analyzed: tat kim yat idam asmin puruṣe kārya kāraṇa saṅghāte jīvati śarīram pārthiva tvāt śarīrasya
translated: What is that? If this body, a collection of causes and effects, lives in this person, it is earthly because of the body.

analyzed: katham śarīrasya gāyatrī tvam iti
translated: How is the body the Gayatri?

analyzed: ucyate asmin hi ime prāṇāḥ bhūta śabda vācyāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: It is said: For in this, these vital breaths, denoted by the word beings, are established.

analyzed: atas pṛthivī vat bhūta śabda vācya prāṇa pratiṣṭhānāt śarīram gāyatrī
translated: Therefore, like the earth, the body is the Gayatri because it is the abode of the vital breaths denoted by the word beings.

analyzed: etat eva yasmāt śarīram na atiśīyante prāṇāḥ
translated: For the vital airs do not go beyond this body.

original: yad vai tat puruṣe śarīram idaṃ vāva tad yad idam asminn antaḥ puruṣe hṛdayam /
analyzed: yat vai tat puruṣe śarīram idam vāva tat yat idam asmin antar puruṣe hṛdayam
translated: That which is the body in man, verily, it is this which is here in the middle of man, the heart.

analyzed: asmin hi ime prāṇāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: For in this are the vital airs established.

original: etad eva nātiśīyante //🔽yadva tatpuruṣe śarīraṃ gāyatrīdaṃ vāva tat /
analyzed: etat eva na atiśīyante  yat vai tat puruṣe śarīram gāyatrī idam vāva tat
translated: They do not go beyond this.

analyzed: yat idam asmin antar madhye puruṣe hṛdayam puṇḍarīka ākhyam etat gāyatrī
translated: That which is the body in man, verily, it is this which is here in the middle of man, the heart.

original: kathamityāhaasminhīme prāṇāḥ pratiṣṭhitā ataḥ śarīravadgāyatrī hṛdayam /
analyzed: katham iti āha asmin hi ime prāṇāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ atas śarīravat gāyatrī hṛdayam
translated: For in this are the vital airs established. Therefore, like the body, the heart is Gāyatrī.

original: etadeva ca nātiśīyante prāṇāḥ /🔽prāṇo ha pitā /
analyzed: etat eva ca na atiśīyante prāṇāḥ  prāṇaḥ ha pitā
translated: And they do not go beyond this.🔽The vital airs are the father.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ mātā
translated: The vital airs are the mother.

analyzed: iti a hiṃsan sarva bhūtāni iti ca śruteḥ bhūta śabda vācyāḥ prāṇāḥ
translated: And because of the Vedic text Not injuring any beings, the vital airs are denoted by the word beings.

analyzed: sā eṣā catuṣpadā ṣaḍvidhā gāyatrī
translated: This is the four-footed, six-formed Gāyatrī.

analyzed: tat etat ṛcā abhyanūktam
translated: This has been stated in the Ṛg Veda:

original: saiṣā catuṣpadā ṣaḍakṣarapadā chandorūpā satī bhavati gāyatrī ṣaḍvidhā vāgbhūtapṛthivīśarīrahṛdayaprāṇarūpā satī ṣaḍvidhā bhavati
analyzed: sā eṣā catuṣpadā ṣaṣ akṣara padā chandaḥ rūpā satī bhavati gāyatrī ṣaḍvidhā vāc bhūta pṛthivī śarīra hṛdaya prāṇa rūpā satī ṣaḍvidhā bhavati
translated: This, having the form of a meter with four feet and six syllables per foot, becomes Gāyatrī of six kinds, having the form of speech, earth, body, heart, and vital airs, it becomes of six kinds.

analyzed: vāc prāṇayoḥ anya artha nirdiṣṭayoḥ api gāyatrī prakāra tvam
translated: The speech and life-breath, though indicated for another purpose, are also of the nature of the Gayatri.

analyzed: anyathā ṣaḍvidha saṃkhyā pūraṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, it would be impossible to complete the enumeration of six.

original: tadetasminnartha etadgīyatryākhyaṃ brahma gāyatryanugataṃ gāyatrīmukhenoktamṛcāpi mantreṇābhyanūktaṃ prakāśitam //
analyzed: tat etasmin arthe etat gīyatrī ākhyam brahma gāyatrī anugatam gāyatrī mukhena uktam ṛcā api mantreṇa abhyanūktam prakāśitam
translated: This Brahman, named Gayatri, which has this meaning, is sung, is followed by the Gayatri, is declared, is revealed, by the Gayatri, by the verse.

original: tāvān asya mahimā tato jyāyāṃś ca puruṣaḥ /
analyzed: tāvān asya mahimā tatas jyāyān ca puruṣaḥ
translated: So great is His greatness, and greater than that is the Person.

original: pādo 'sya sarvā bhūtāni tripād asyāmṛtaṃ divīti //
analyzed: pādaḥ u sya sarvā bhūtāni tri pād asya amṛtam divi iti
translated: One-fourth of Him are all beings, and three-fourths of Him is immortal in heaven.

original: tāvānasya gāyatryākhyasya brahmaṇaḥ samastasya mahimā vibhūtivistāraḥ /
analyzed: tāvān asya gāyatrī ākhyasya brahmaṇaḥ samastasya mahimā vibhūti vistāraḥ
translated: So great is the greatness, the glory, the extent, of this Brahman named Gayatri, in its entirety.

original: yāvāṃścatuṣpātṣaḍvidhaśca brahmaṇo vikāraḥ pādo gāyatrīti vyākhyātaḥ /
analyzed: yāvān catuṣpād ṣaḍvidhaḥ ca brahmaṇaḥ vikāraḥ pādaḥ gāyatrī iti vyākhyātaḥ
translated: And as much as the four-footed and six-fold modification of Brahman has been explained as the foot, named Gayatri,

analyzed: atas tasmāt vikāra lakṣaṇāt gāyatrī ākhyāt vācā ārambhaṇa mātrāt tatas jyāyān mahattaraḥ ca paramārtha satya rūpaḥ vikāraḥ pūruṣaḥ puruṣaḥ sarva pūraṇāt puri  śayanāt ca
translated: greater than that, more exalted, is the changeless Person, the truth in the highest sense, than that modification characterized by change, than that mere verbal expression named Gayatri. The Person is so called because He fills everything and because He lies within.

original: tasyāsya pādaḥ sarvā sarvāṇi bhūtāni tejobannādīni sasthāvarajaṅgamāni /
analyzed: tasya asya pādaḥ sarvā sarvāṇi bhūtāni tejaḥ banna ādīni sa sthāvara jaṅgamāni
translated: One-fourth of Him are all beings, all elements beginning with fire and food, with the immobile and the mobile.

analyzed: tripād trayaḥ pādāḥ asya saḥ yam tripād
translated: It has three feet, and three are its feet; thus it is three-footed.

original: tripādamṛtaṃ puruṣākhyaṃ samastasya gāyatryātmano divi dyotanavati svātmanyavasthitamityartha iti //
analyzed: tri pād amṛtam puruṣa ākhyam samastasya gāyatrī ātmanaḥ divi dyotanavati sva ātmani avasthitam iti arthaḥ iti
translated: The three-footed immortal Purusha, consisting of the entire Gāyatrī, is situated in the heaven, in its own Self, which is full of light; this is the meaning.

original: yad vai tad brahmetīdaṃ vāva tad yo 'yaṃ bahirdhā puruṣād ākāśaḥ /
analyzed: yat vai tat brahma iti idam vāva tat yaḥ yam bahirdhā puruṣāt ākāśaḥ
translated: That which is indeed Brahman - this, verily, is that which is outside the person, the space.

original: yo vai sa bahirdhā puruṣād ākāśaḥ //
analyzed: yaḥ vai sa bahirdhā puruṣāt ākāśaḥ
translated: That which is indeed the space outside the person - that which is indeed the space outside the person.

original: yadvai tat tripādamṛtaṃ gāyatrīmukhenoktaṃ brahmetīdaṃ vāva tadidameva /
analyzed: yat vai tat tri pād amṛtam gāyatrī mukhena uktam brahma iti idam vāva tat idam eva
translated: That which is indeed the three-footed immortal Brahman, spoken of through the face of Gāyatrī - this, verily, is that. This very (space).

original: tadyo 'yaṃ prasiddho bahirdhā bahiḥ puruṣādākāśo bhautiko yo vai sa bahirdhā puruṣādākāśa uktaḥ //
analyzed: tat yaḥ yam prasiddhaḥ bahirdhā bahis puruṣāt ākāśaḥ bhautikaḥ yaḥ vai sa bahirdhā puruṣāt ākāśaḥ uktaḥ
translated: That which is well-known as the space outside the person, the elemental space - that which is indeed the space outside the person, that has been spoken of.

original: ayaṃ vāva sa yo 'yam antaḥ puruṣa ākāśaḥ /🔽yo vai so 'ntaḥ puruṣa ākāśaḥ //
analyzed: ayam vāva sa yaḥ yam antar puruṣaḥ ākāśaḥ  yaḥ vai saḥ ntar puruṣaḥ ākāśaḥ
translated: This, verily, is that which is the space within the person.🔽That which is indeed the space within the person - that which is indeed the space within the person.

original: ayaṃ vāva sa yo 'yamantaḥ puruṣe śarīra ākāśo yo vai so 'ntaḥ puruṣa ākāśaḥ //
analyzed: ayam vāva sa yaḥ yam antar puruṣe śarīre ākāśaḥ yaḥ vai saḥ ntar puruṣaḥ ākāśaḥ
translated: This, verily, is that which is the space within the body of the person. That which is indeed the space within the person - that which is indeed the space within the person.

original: ayaṃ vāva sa yo 'yam antarhṛdaya ākāśaḥ /
analyzed: ayam vāva sa yaḥ yam antar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ
translated: This, verily, is that which is the space within the heart.

analyzed: tat etat pūrṇam a pravarti
translated: That is full and unmoving.

original: pūrṇam apravartinīṃ śriyaṃ labhate ya evaṃ veda //
analyzed: pūrṇam a pravartinīm śriyam labhate yaḥ evam veda
translated: One who knows thus obtains full and unmoving prosperity.

original: ayaṃ vāva sa yo 'yamantarhṛdaye hṛdayapuṇḍarīka ākāśaḥ /
analyzed: ayam vāva sa yaḥ yam antar hṛdaye hṛdaya puṇḍarīke ākāśaḥ
translated: This very one is that which is the space in the lotus of the heart within.

original: kathamekasya sata ākāśasya tridhā bheda iti /
analyzed: katham ekasya sataḥ ākāśasya tridhā bhedaḥ iti
translated: How is there a threefold division of the one existing space?

analyzed: ucyate bāhya indriya viṣaye jāgarita sthāne nabhasi duḥkha bāhulyam dṛśyate
translated: It is said: In the external space, which is the place of waking, a multitude of sorrows is seen.

original: tato 'ntaḥśarīre svapnasthānabhūte mandataraṃ duḥkhaṃ bhavati svapnānpaśyataḥ /
analyzed: tatas ntar śarīre svapna sthāna bhūte mandataram duḥkham bhavati svapnān paśyataḥ
translated: From that, in the internal body, which is the place of dreaming, sorrow becomes less.

original: hṛdayasthe punarnabhasi na kañcana kāmaṃ kāmayate na kañcana svapnaṃ paśyati /
analyzed: hṛdaya sthe punar nabhasi na kañcana kāmam kāmayate na kañcana svapnam paśyati
translated: But in the space located in the heart, one does not desire any object, one does not see any dream.

analyzed: atas sarva duḥkha nivṛtti rūpam ākāśam suṣupta sthānam
translated: Therefore, the space, which is the form of the cessation of all sorrow, is the place of deep sleep.

analyzed: atas yuktam ekasya api tridhā bheda anvākhyānam
translated: Therefore, it is proper to explain the threefold division of the one also.

analyzed: bahirdhā puruṣāt ārabhya ākāśasya hṛdaye saṅkoca karaṇam cetaḥ samādhāna sthāna stutaye
translated: The contraction of space from outside to the heart is for the praise of the place of mental concentration.

analyzed: yathā trayāṇām api lokānām kurukṣetram viśiṣyate
translated: Just as Kurukshetra is superior to all three worlds,

analyzed: ardhataḥ tu kurukṣetram ardhataḥ tu pṛthūdakam iti tadvat
translated: and half of it is Kurukshetra, and half is Prithudaka, so is it.

original: tadetaddhārdākāśākhyaṃ brahma pūrṇaṃ sarvagataṃ na hṛdayamātraparicchinnamiti mantavyam /
analyzed: tat etat hārda ākāśa ākhyam brahma pūrṇam sarva gatam na hṛdaya mātra paricchinnam iti mantavyam
translated: This Brahman, which is called the space in the heart, is full and all-pervading, and should not be thought of as limited to the heart alone.

original: yadyapi hṛdayākāśe cetaḥ samādhīyate 'pravarti na kutaścitkvacitpravartituṃ śīlamasyetyapravarti tadanucchittidharmakam /
analyzed: yadi api hṛdaya ākāśe cetaḥ samādhīyate pravarti na kutaścid kvacid pravartitum śīlam asya iti apravarti tad anucchitti dharmakam
translated: Although the mind is concentrated in the space of the heart, it is not inclined to move from anywhere to anywhere, hence it is not inclined. It has the nature of non-destruction.

original: yathānyāni bhūtāni paricchinnānyucchittidharmakāṇi na tathā hārdaṃ nabhaḥ /
analyzed: yathā anyāni bhūtāni paricchinnāni ucchitti dharmakāṇi na tathā hārdam nabhaḥ
translated: Just as other limited elements have the nature of destruction, the heart-space is not like that.

original: pūrṇāmapravartinīmanucchedātmikāṃ śriyaṃ vibhūtiṃ guṇaphalaṃ labhate dṛṣṭaṃ ya evaṃ
analyzed: pūrṇām apravartinīm anuccheda ātmikām śriyam vibhūtim guṇa phalam labhate dṛṣṭam yaḥ evam
translated: One who knows this obtains the seen prosperity, the complete, unmoving, indestructible nature, the fruit of the quality.

original: yathoktaṃ pūrṇāpravartiguṇaṃ brahma veda jānātīhaiva jīvaṃstadbhāvaṃ pratipadyata ityarthaḥ //
analyzed: yathā uktam pūrṇa a pravarti guṇam brahma veda jānāti iha eva jīvan tad bhāvam pratipadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: One who knows Brahman, which has the qualities of completeness and immovability as described, becomes like that even while living here. This is the meaning.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi tṛtīya adhyāyasya dvādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twelfth section in the third chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: tasya ha vā etasya hṛdayasya pañca devasuṣayaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ha vai etasya hṛdayasya pañca deva suṣayaḥ
translated: Now, this heart has five divine openings.

original: sa yo 'sya prāṅ suṣiḥ sa prāṇaḥ /
analyzed: sa yaḥ sya prāṅ suṣiḥ sa prāṇaḥ
translated: The one that is the eastern opening is the out-breath.

analyzed: tat cakṣuḥ
translated: That is the eye.

original: sa ādityaḥ /🔽tad etat tejo 'nnādyam ity upāsīta /
analyzed: saḥ ādityaḥ  tat etat tejaḥ nnādyam iti upāsīta
translated: That is the sun.🔽One should worship that as light and food.

original: tejasvy annādo bhavati ya evaṃ veda //
analyzed: tejasvī anna ādaḥ bhavati yaḥ evam veda
translated: One becomes luminous and an eater of food, one who knows this.

original: tasya ha vā ityādinā gāyatryākhyasya brahmaṇa upāsanāṅgatvena dvārapālādiguṇavidhānārthamārabhyate /
analyzed: tasya ha vā ityādinā gāyatrī ākhyasya brahmaṇaḥ upāsana aṅga tvena dvārapāla ādi guṇa vidhāna artham ārabhyate
translated: With His, etc., it is begun to prescribe the qualities of the doorkeeper, etc. as the means of meditation on Brahman called Gāyatrī.

original: yathā loke dvārapālā rājña upāsanena vaśīkṛtā rājaprāptyarthā bhavanti tathehāpīti /
analyzed: yathā loke dvārapālāḥ rājñaḥ upāsanena vaśīkṛtāḥ rāja prāpti arthāḥ bhavanti tathā iha api iti
translated: Just as in the world, doorkeepers, having been brought under control by serving the king, become the means of attaining the king, so it is here also.

analyzed: tasya iti prakṛtasya hṛdayasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The word his means the mentioned heart.

original: etasyānantaranirdiṣṭasya pañca pañcasaṃkhyākā devānāṃ suṣayo devasuṣayaḥ svargalokaprāptidvāracchidrāṇi
analyzed: etasya anantara nirdiṣṭasya pañca pañca saṃkhyākāḥ devānām suṣayaḥ deva suṣayaḥ svarga loka prāpti dvāra chidrāṇi
translated: The five devasuṣis, which are the holes in the door to attaining the heavenly world, are the five of the gods.

original: deveḥ prāṇādityādibhī rakṣyamāṇānītyato devasuṣayastasya svargalokabhavanasya hṛdayasyāsya🔽yaḥ prāṅsuṣiḥ pūrvābhimukhasya prāggataṃ yacchidraṃ dvāraṃ sa prāṇastatsthastena
analyzed: prāṇa āditya ādibhiḥ rakṣyamāṇāni iti atas deva suṣayaḥ tasya svarga loka bhavanasya hṛdayasya asya  yaḥ prāc suṣiḥ pūrva abhimukhasya prāk gatam yat chidram dvāram sa prāṇaḥ tad sthaḥ tena
translated: They are guarded by the gods Prāṇa, Āditya, etc. Therefore, they are devasuṣis. Of this, his heavenly abode, the heart,

original: dvāreṇa yaḥ sañcarati vāyuviśeṣaḥ sa prāganitīti prāṇaḥ /
analyzed: dvāreṇa yaḥ sañcarati vāyu viśeṣaḥ sa prāk aniti iti prāṇaḥ
translated: the eastern susis, the hole or door of one facing east, is Prāṇa. The special wind that moves through that door is called Prāṇa because it moves east.

original: tenaiva sambaddhamavyatiriktaṃ taccakṣustathaiva sa ādityaḥādityo ha vai bāhyaḥ prāṇaḥiti śruteścakṣūrūpapratiṣṭhākrameṇa hṛdi sthitaḥ /
analyzed: tena eva sambaddham avyatiriktam tat cakṣuḥ tathā eva saḥ ādityaḥ ādityaḥ ha vai bāhyaḥ prāṇaḥ iti śruteḥ cakṣuḥ rūpa pratiṣṭhā krameṇa hṛdi sthitaḥ
translated: The eye, which is not separate from it, is connected with it alone. The sun is like that. And because of the Vedic text, The external Prāṇa is indeed the sun, the eye is located in the heart in the order of the foundation of form.

original: sa ādityaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita iti cakṣuṣiityādi hi vājasaneyake /
analyzed: saḥ ādityaḥ kasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti cakṣuṣi ityādi hi vājasaneyake
translated: In the Vājasaneyaka, it is said: In what is the sun established? In the eye, and so on.

original: prāṇavāyudevataiva hyekā cakṣurādityaśca sahā'śrayeṇa /🔽vakṣyati caprāṇāya svāheti hatuṃ haviḥ sarvametattarpayatīti /
analyzed: prāṇa vāyu devatā eva hi ekā cakṣuḥ ādityaḥ ca saha āśrayeṇa  vakṣyati ca prāṇāya svāhā iti hatum haviḥ sarvam etat tarpayati iti
translated: For the eye and the sun are indeed the deity of the vital air, together with its abode.🔽And it will be said: To the vital air svāhā! By this oblation, all this is satisfied.

analyzed: tadā id prāṇa ākhyam svarga loka dvārapāla tvāt brahma
translated: That which is called the vital air is Brahman, because it is the doorkeeper of the heavenly world.

analyzed: svarga lokam pratipitsuḥ tejaḥ ca etat cakṣuḥ āditya sva rūpeṇa
translated: And he who desires to go to the heavenly world, and that light in the form of the eye and the sun,

analyzed: annādya tvāt ca savituḥ tejaḥ nnādyam iti ābhyām guṇābhyām upāsīta
translated: and because the sun is food, one should worship with these two qualities, light and food.

original: tatastejasvyannādaścā'mayāvitvarahito bhavati ya evaṃ veda tasyaitadguṇaphalam /
analyzed: tatas tejasvī anna ādaḥ ca āmayāvi tva rahitaḥ bhavati yaḥ evam veda tasya etat guṇa phalam
translated: Then, he who knows this becomes free from the state of being subject to death, and has the qualities of being brilliant and having food. This is the fruit of the qualities of that knowledge.

original: upāsanena vaśīkṛto dvārapaḥ svargalokaprāpti heturbhavatīti mukhyaṃ ca phalam //
analyzed: upāsanena vaśīkṛtaḥ dvārapaḥ svarga loka prāpti hetuḥ bhavati iti mukhyam ca phalam
translated: The doorkeeper, who is brought under control by worship, becomes the cause of attaining the heavenly world. This is the principal fruit.

original: atha yo 'sya dakṣiṇaḥ suṣiḥ sa vyānaḥ /
analyzed: atha yaḥ sya dakṣiṇaḥ suṣiḥ sa vyānaḥ
translated: Now, that which is his right nostril is vyāna.

analyzed: tat śrotram
translated: That is the ear.

original: sa candramāḥ /🔽tad etac chrīś ca yaśaś cety upāsīta /
analyzed: sa candramāḥ  tat etat śrīḥ ca yaśaḥ ca iti upāsīta
translated: And that is the moon.🔽One should worship that as glory and fame.

original: śrīmān yaśasvī bhavati ya evaṃ veda //
analyzed: śrīmān yaśasvī bhavati yaḥ evam veda
translated: He becomes glorious and famous who knows this.

original: atha yo 'sya dakṣiṇaḥ suṣistatstho vāyuviśeṣaḥ sa vīryavatkarma kurvanvigṛhya vā prāṇāpānau /
analyzed: atha yaḥ sya dakṣiṇaḥ suṣiḥ tad sthaḥ vāyu viśeṣaḥ sa vīryavat karma kurvan vigṛhya vā prāṇa apānau
translated: Now, that which is his southern hole, the wind located there, that wind, performing vigorous action, either separating the exhalation and inhalation,

original: nānā vānitīti vyānastatsambaddhameva ca tacchrotramindriyaṃ tathā sa candramāḥ /
analyzed: nānā vāniti iti vyānaḥ tat sambaddham eva ca tat śrotram indriyam tathā sa candramāḥ
translated: or various, thus it is vyāna. And that ear sense organ is connected with that, and that moon.

analyzed: śrotreṇa sṛṣṭāḥ diśaḥ ca candramāḥ ca iti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic text that the directions and the moon are created by the ear.

analyzed: saha āśrayau pūrvavat tat etat śrīḥ ca vibhūtiḥ śrotra candramasoḥ jñāna anna hetu tvam atas tābhyām śrī tvam
translated: Along with the support, as before. That is glory and prosperity. The ear and the moon are the cause of knowledge and food. Therefore, they are glorious by those two.

original: jñānānnavataśca yaśaḥ khyātirbhavatīti yaśohetutvādyaśastvamatastābhyāṃ guṇābhyāmupāsītetyādi samānam //
analyzed: jñāna annavataḥ ca yaśaḥ khyātiḥ bhavati iti yaśaḥ hetu tvāt yaśaḥ tvam atas tābhyām guṇābhyām upāsīta ityādi samānam
translated: And because fame arises from knowledge and food, it is fame. Because it is the cause of fame, it is fame. Therefore, it is glorious by those two qualities. The rest is the same as before.

analyzed: atha yaḥ sya pratyaṅ suṣiḥ saḥ pānaḥ
translated: Now, that which is his western hole, that is apāna.

analyzed: sā vāc
translated: That is speech.

analyzed: saḥ gniḥ
translated: That is fire.

original: tad etad brahmavarcasam annādyam ity upāsīta /
analyzed: tat etat brahmavarcasam annādyam iti upāsīta
translated: One should meditate upon that as Brahman-splendor and food.

original: brahmavarcasy annādo bhavati ya evaṃ veda //
analyzed: brahmavarcasī anna ādaḥ bhavati yaḥ evam veda
translated: One becomes resplendent and an eater of food who knows this thus.

original: atha yo 'sya pratyaṅsuṣiḥ paścimastatstho vāyuviśeṣaḥ sa mūtrapurīṣādyapanayannadho 'nitītyapānaḥ sā tathā vāk /
analyzed: atha yaḥ sya pratyaṅ suṣiḥ paścimaḥ tad sthaḥ vāyu viśeṣaḥ sa mūtra purīṣa ādi apanayan adhas sā tathā vāc
translated: Now, that which is his western hole, the wind located there, that wind, carrying away urine, feces, etc., going downwards, thus it is apāna. That is speech.

analyzed: tad sambandhāt tathā agniḥ tat etat brahmavarcasam  vṛtta svādhyāya nimittam tejaḥ brahmavarcasam
translated: And from its connection with that, the fire is that. This is the Brahmic glory.🔽The radiance that is the cause of the study of the Vedas is Brahmic glory.

analyzed: agni sambandhāt vṛtta svādhyāyasya
translated: From the connection with fire, of the study of the Vedas.

analyzed: anna ghrasana hetu tvāt apānasya annādya tvam
translated: The downward breath has food as its object because it is the cause of eating food.

analyzed: samānam anyat
translated: The rest is the same.

analyzed: atha yaḥ sya udaṅ suṣiḥ sa samānaḥ
translated: Now, that which is his northern aperture is the equalizing breath.

analyzed: tat manaḥ
translated: That is the mind.

analyzed: sa parjanyaḥ
translated: That is Parjanya.

original: tad etat kīrtiś ca vyuṣṭiś cetyupāsīta /
analyzed: tat etat kīrtiḥ ca vyuṣṭiḥ ca iti upāsīta
translated: One should meditate on that as fame and prosperity.

original: kīrtimān vyuṣṭimān bhavati ya evaṃ veda //
analyzed: kīrtimān vyuṣṭimān bhavati yaḥ evam veda
translated: One becomes famous and prosperous who knows this thus.

original: atha yo 'syodaṅsuṣirudaggataḥ suṣistatsyo vāyuviśeṣaḥ so 'śitapīte samaṃ nayatīti samānaḥ /
analyzed: atha yaḥ sya udaṅ suṣiḥ udak gataḥ suṣiḥ tad syaḥ vāyu viśeṣaḥ saḥ śita pīte samam nayati iti samānaḥ
translated: Now, that which is his northern aperture, the aperture facing north, that is a particular kind of air. It is called the equalizing breath because it carries the eaten and drunk food equally.

original: tatsambaddhaṃ mano 'ntaḥkaraṇaṃ sa parjanyo vṛṣṭyātmako devaḥ parjanyanimittāścā'pa iti /
analyzed: tat sambaddham manaḥ ntaḥkaraṇam sa parjanyaḥ vṛṣṭi ātmakaḥ devaḥ parjanya nimittāḥ ca āpaḥ iti
translated: The internal organ, the mind, connected with that, is Parjanya, the god consisting of rain. And the waters are caused by Parjanya.

analyzed: manasā sṛṣṭāḥ āpaḥ ca varuṇaḥ ca iti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic text, The waters and Varuna were created by the mind.

analyzed: tadā id kīrtiḥ ca
translated: That is this fame and prosperity.

analyzed: manasaḥ jñānasya kīrti hetu tvāt  ātma parokṣam vuśruta tvam kīrtiḥ
translated: Because the knowledge of the mind is the cause of fame.🔽Fame is the state of being known by oneself and others.

analyzed: yaśaḥ svakaraṇa saṃvedyam viśruta tvam
translated: Glory is the state of being known by one's own senses.

analyzed: vyuṣṭiḥ kāntiḥ deha gatam lāvaṇyam
translated: Prosperity is the beauty residing in the body.

analyzed: tatas ca kīrti sambhavāt kīrtiḥ ca iti
translated: And from the production of fame, it is also fame.

analyzed: samānam anyat
translated: The rest is the same.

analyzed: atha yaḥ sya ūrdhvaḥ suṣiḥ saḥ udānaḥ
translated: Now, that upper hole of his is the upward-moving breath.

analyzed: sa vāyuḥ
translated: That is air.

analyzed: saḥ ākāśaḥ
translated: That is space.

original: tad etad ojaś ca mahaś cety upāsīta /
analyzed: tat etat ojaḥ ca mahaḥ ca iti upāsīta
translated: One should meditate upon that as energy and greatness.

original: ojasvī mahasvān bhavati ya evaṃ veda //🔽atha yo 'syordhvaḥ suṣiḥ sa udāna ā pādalādārabhyordhvamutkramaṇādutkarṣārthaṃ
analyzed: ojasvī mahasvān bhavati yaḥ evam veda  atha yaḥ sya ūrdhvaḥ suṣiḥ saḥ udānaḥ ā pādalāt ārabhya ūrdhvam utkramaṇāt utkarṣa artham
translated: One who knows this becomes energetic and great.🔽Now, that upper hole of his is the upward-moving breath, because it moves upwards starting from the toes, and because it performs the function of uplifting.

analyzed: ca karma kurvan aniti iti udānaḥ sa vāyuḥ tad ādhāraḥ ca ākāśaḥ tat etat vāyu ākāśayoḥ ojaḥ hetu tvāt ojaḥ
translated: It is air and the space that supports it. That is energy because it is the cause of energy in air and space,

analyzed: balam mahat tvāt ca mahaḥ iti
translated: and it is great because of its vastness.

original: samānamanyat //🔽te vā ete pañca brahmapuruṣāḥ svargasya lokasya dvārapāḥ /🔽sa ya etān evaṃ pañca brahmapuruṣān svargasya lokasya dvārapān vedāsya kule vīro jāyate /
analyzed: samānam anyat  te vai ete pañca brahma puruṣāḥ svargasya lokasya dvārapāḥ  sa yaḥ etān evam pañca brahma puruṣān svargasya lokasya dvārapān veda asya kule vīraḥ jāyate
translated: The rest is the same.🔽Those five Brahmic persons are the doorkeepers of the heavenly world.🔽One who knows these five Brahmic persons as the doorkeepers of the heavenly world, a hero is born in his family.

original: pratipadyate svargaṃ lokaṃ ya etān evaṃ pañca brahmapuruṣān svargasya lokasya dvārapān veda //
analyzed: pratipadyate svargam lokam yaḥ etān evam pañca brahma puruṣān svargasya lokasya dvārapān veda
translated: He attains the heavenly world who knows these five Brahmic persons as the doorkeepers of the heavenly world.

original: te vā ete yathoktāḥ pañcasuṣisambandhātpañca brahmaṇo hārdasya puraṣā rājapuruṣā iva dvārasthāḥ svargasya hārdasya lokasya dvārapā
analyzed: te vai ete yathā uktāḥ pañca suṣi sambandhāt pañca brahmaṇaḥ hārdasya puraṣāḥ rāja puruṣāḥ iva dvāra sthāḥ svargasya hārdasya lokasya dvāra pā
translated: Those five men of Brahman, the heart, are like the five gate-keepers of a king, connected with the five susumnas as mentioned. They are the door-keepers of the heaven, the heart-world.

analyzed: dvārapālāḥ
translated: They are the door-keepers.

analyzed: etaiḥ hi cakṣuḥ śrotra vāc manaḥ prāṇaiḥ bahis mukha pravṛttaiḥ brahmaṇaḥ hārdasya prāpti dvārāṇi niruddhani
translated: For these - the eye, ear, speech, mind and life-force - when turned outward, block the doors to attaining Brahman, the heart.

original: pratyakṣaṃ hyetadajitakaraṇatayā bāhyaviṣayāsaṅgānṛtaprarūḍhatvānna hārde brahmaṇi manastiṣṭhati /
analyzed: pratyakṣam hi etat ajita karaṇa tayā bāhya viṣaya āsaṅga anṛta prarūḍha tvāt na hārde brahmaṇi manaḥ tiṣṭhati
translated: For it is a fact that the mind, due to the senses being unconquered, and being deeply rooted in untruth through attachment to external objects, does not rest in the heart-Brahman.

original: tasmātsatyamuktamete pañca brahmapuruṣāḥ svargasya dvārapā iti /
analyzed: tasmāt satyam uktam ete pañca brahma puruṣāḥ svargasya dvārapāḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is rightly said that these five men of Brahman are the door-keepers of heaven.

original: ataḥ sa ya etānevaṃ yathoktaguṇaviśiṣṭānsvargasya lokasya dvārapānvedopāsta upāsanayā
analyzed: atas sa yaḥ etān evam yathā ukta guṇa viśiṣṭān svargasya lokasya dvārapān veda upāste upāsanayā
translated: Therefore, he who knows them thus, as endowed with the mentioned qualities, as the door-keepers of the world of heaven, worships them through meditation.

original: vaśīkaroti sa rājadvārapālānivopāsanena vaśīkṛtya tairanivāritaḥ pratipadyate svargaṃ
analyzed: vaśīkaroti sa rāja dvārapālān iva upāsanena vaśīkṛtya taiḥ a nivāritaḥ pratipadyate svargam
translated: Having made them subservient through worship, like a king's gate-keepers, he, unobstructed by them, attains the heart-Brahman,

analyzed: rājānam iva hārdam brahma
translated: like a king's palace.

original: kiñcāsya viduṣaḥ kule vīraḥ putro jāyate vīrapuruṣasevanāt /
analyzed: kiñca asya viduṣaḥ kule vīraḥ putraḥ jāyate vīra puruṣa sevanāt
translated: Moreover, a heroic son is born in the family of the knower, through serving the heroic men.

analyzed: tasya ca ṛṇa apākaraṇena brahma upāsana pravṛtti hetu tvam
translated: And by the removal of that, there is the cause for engaging in the meditation on Brahman.

original: tataśca svargalokapratipattaye pāramparyeṇa bhavatīti svargalokapratipattirevaikaṃ phalama //
analyzed: tatas ca svarga loka pratipattaye pāramparyeṇa bhavati iti svarga loka pratipattiḥ eva ekam phalam
translated: And from that, it happens indirectly for the attainment of the heavenly world. Thus, the attainment of the heavenly world is the only fruit.

original: atha yad ataḥ paro divo jyotir dīpyate viśvataḥpṛṣṭheṣu sarvataḥpṛṣṭheṣv anuttameṣūttameṣu lokeṣv idaṃ vāva tad yad idam asminn antaḥ puruṣe🔽jyotiḥ /
analyzed: atha yat atas paras divaḥ jyotiḥ dīpyate viśvatas pṛṣṭheṣu sarvatas pṛṣṭheṣu anuttameṣu uttameṣu lokeṣu idam vāva tat yat idam asmin antar puruṣe  jyotiḥ
translated: Now, that light which shines above this heaven, on all sides, on the highest and best worlds, verily, that is this which is the light in this person here.

original: tasyaiṣā dṛṣṭir yatraitad asmiñ charīre saṃsparśenoṣṇimānaṃ vijānāti /
analyzed: tasya eṣā dṛṣṭiḥ yatra etat asmin śarīre saṃsparśena uṣṇimānam vijānāti
translated: This is its sight, where one perceives warmth by touch in this body.

original: tasyaiṣā śrutir yatraitat karṇāv apigṛhya ninadam iva nadathur ivāgner iva jvalata upaśṛnoti /
analyzed: tasya eṣā śrutiḥ yatra etat karṇau apigṛhya ninadam iva nadathuḥ iva agneḥ iva jvalataḥ upaśṛnoti
translated: This is its hearing, where, having grasped the ears, one hears as it were a roaring, as it were a rumbling, as it were a burning of fire.

original: tad etad dṛṣṭaṃ ca śrutaṃ cety upāsīta /
analyzed: tat etat dṛṣṭam ca śrutam ca iti upāsīta
translated: One should meditate on that as seen and heard.

original: cakṣuṣyaḥ śruto bhavati ya evaṃ veda ya evaṃ veda //
analyzed: cakṣuṣyaḥ śrutaḥ bhavati yaḥ evam veda yaḥ evam veda
translated: One becomes possessed of sight and hearing, who knows this, who knows this.

analyzed: atha yat asau vidvān svargam lokam vīra puruṣa sevanāt pratipadyate
translated: Now, when that learned one attains the heavenly world by serving the heroic men,

analyzed: yat ca uktam tripādasya amṛtam divi iti tat idam liṅgena cakṣuḥ śrotra indriya gocaram āpādayitavyam
translated: And what was said - The immortal with three feet in the heaven - that is to be brought within the range of the eye and ear sense organs by this indication.

analyzed: yathā agni ādi dhūma ādi liṅgena
translated: Just as fire etc. by the indication of smoke etc.

original: tathā hyevamevedamiti yathokte 'tha dṛḍha pratītiḥ syāt /
analyzed: tathā hi evam eva idam iti yathā ukte dṛḍha pratītiḥ syāt
translated: For thus there would be firm belief in this is just as it was said.

analyzed: ananya tvena ca niścayaḥ iti
translated: And there would be certainty of non-difference.

analyzed: atas āha yat atas muṣmāt divaḥ dyu lokāt paras param iti liṅga vyatyayena
translated: Therefore it is said - The light shines from that, from this heaven, the highest of the highest, by the reversal of the indication.

analyzed: jyotiḥ dīpyate  svayaṃprabham sadā prakāśa tvāt dīpyate iva dīpyate iti ucyate
translated: The light shines.

analyzed: agni ādi vāt jvalana lakṣaṇāyāḥ dīpteḥ asambhavāt
translated: Being self-luminous, it is said to shine as if it were shining, because of the impossibility of the shining characterized by burning like fire etc.🔽The explanation of on all sides is on every side.

analyzed: viśvatas pṛṣṭheṣu iti etasya vyākhyāna sarvatas pṛṣṭheṣu iti  saṃsārāt upari iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is above the world.

analyzed: saṃsāraḥ eva hi sarvaḥ
translated: For the world itself is all.

analyzed: asaṃsāriṇaḥ eka tvāt nirbheda tvāt ca
translated: Because the non-worldly is one and undifferentiated.

original: anuttameṣu tatpuruṣasamāsāśaṅkānivṛttaya āhottameṣu lokeṣviti satyalokādiṣu hiraṇyagarbhādikāryasthaparasyeśvarasyā'sannatvāducyata uttameṣu
analyzed: anuttameṣu tatpuruṣa samāsa āśaṅkā nivṛttaye āha uttameṣu lokeṣu iti satya loka ādiṣu hiraṇyagarbha ādi kārya stha parasya īśvarasya āsanna tvāt ucyate uttameṣu
translated: In order to remove the doubt of a Tatpurusa compound in the highest, it is said in the highest worlds, in the Satyaloka and so on, because the Supreme Lord residing in the effects of Hiranyagarbha etc. is near.

analyzed: lokeṣu iti
translated: It is said in the highest worlds.

original: idaṃ vāvedameva tadyadidamasminpuruṣe 'ntarmadhye jyotiścakṣuḥ śrotragrāhyeṇa liṅgenoṣṇimnā śabdena cāvagamyate /
analyzed: idam vāva idam eva tat yat idam asmin puruṣe ntar madhye jyotiḥ cakṣuḥ śrotra grāhyeṇa liṅgena uṣṇimnā śabdena ca avagamyate
translated: This indeed is that which is in the middle of this person, the light which is perceived by the eye, by the mark of heat perceptible to the ear, and by the word.

analyzed: yat tvacā sparśa rūpeṇa gṛhyate tat cakṣuṣā eva
translated: And what is grasped by the skin as touch is also by the eye itself.

analyzed: dṛḍha pratīti kara tvāt tvacaḥ
translated: Because the skin produces firm perception.

analyzed: a vinābhūta tvāt ca rūpa sparśayoḥ
translated: And because form and touch are inseparable.

original: kathaṃ punastasya jyotiṣo liṅgaṃ tvagdṛṣṭigocaratvamāpadyata iti /
analyzed: katham punar tasya jyotiṣaḥ liṅgam tvac dṛṣṭi gocara tvam āpadyate iti
translated: But how does the mark of that light come within the range of vision of the skin?

analyzed: āha yatra yasmin kāle
translated: He says: Where, at what time.

analyzed: etat iti kriyā viśeṣaṇam
translated: This is a qualification of the action.

analyzed: asmin śarīre hastena ālabhya saṃsparśena uṣṇimānam rūpa sahabhāvinam uṣṇa sparśa bhāvam vijānāti
translated: In this body, by touching with the hand, one perceives heat, which is of the nature of touch and is concomitant with form.

original: sa hyūṣṇimā nāmarūpavyākaraṇāya dehamanupraviṣṭasya caitanyātmajyotiṣo liṅgamavyabhicārāt /
analyzed: sa hi ūṣṇimā nāma rūpa vyākaraṇāya deham anupraviṣṭasya caitanya ātma jyotiṣaḥ liṅgam avyabhicārāt
translated: For heat is the invariable mark of the light of consciousness, the self, which has entered the body for the purpose of manifesting name and form.

original: na hi jīvantamātmānamūṣṇimā vyabhicaratiuṣṇa eva jīviṣyañśīto mariṣyann iti hi vijñāyate /
analyzed: na hi jīvantam ātmānam ūṣṇimā vyabhicarati uṣṇaḥ eva jīviṣyan śītaḥ mariṣyan iti hi vijñāyate
translated: For heat never deviates from the living self. It is known that one who is hot will live, one who is cold will die.

original: maraṇakāle ca tejaḥ parasyāṃ devatāyāmiti pareṇāvibhāgatvopagamāt /
analyzed: maraṇa kāle ca tejaḥ parasyām devatāyām iti pareṇa a vibhāga tva upagamāt
translated: And at the time of death, the heat merges into the supreme deity, because it is accepted that it becomes undifferentiated from the supreme.

analyzed: sādhāramam liṅgam auṣṇyam agneḥ iva dhūmaḥ
translated: Therefore, this mark is unique, like heat is for fire.

original: atastasya parasyaiṣā dṛṣṭiḥ sākṣādiva darśanaṃ darśanopāya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas tasya parasya eṣā dṛṣṭiḥ sākṣāt iva darśanam darśana upāyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is the vision of that Supreme Self, as if directly seen. The meaning is that vision is the means of seeing.

original: tathā tasya jyotiṣa eṣā śrutiḥ śravaṇaṃśravaṇopāyo 'pyucyamānaḥ /
analyzed: tathā tasya jyotiṣaḥ eṣā śrutiḥ śravaṇam śravaṇa upāyaḥ upi ucyamānaḥ
translated: Similarly, this hearing of that light is said to be the means of hearing.

original: yatra yadā puruṣo jyotiṣo liṅgaṃ śuśrūṣati śrotamicchati tadaitatkarṇāvapigṛhyaitacchabdaḥ kriyāviśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: yatra yadā puruṣaḥ jyotiṣaḥ liṅgam śuśrūṣati śrotam icchati tadā etat karṇau apigṛhya etad śabdaḥ kriyā viśeṣaṇam
translated: When a person desires to hear the mark of light, when he wishes to hear, then having covered the ears with the fingers, the word having covered is an adverb modifying the action.

original: apigṛhyāpidhāyetyartho 'ṅgulibhyāṃ prorṇutya ninadamiva rathasyeva ghoṣo ninadastamiva🔽śṛṇoti nadathuriva ṛṣabhakūjitamiva śabdo yathā cāgnerbahirjvalata evaṃ śabdamantaḥ🔽śarīra upaśṛṇoti tadetajjyotirdṛṣṭaśrutaliṅgatvāddṛṣṭaṃ ca śrutaṃ cetyupāsīta /
analyzed: apigṛhya apidhāya iti arthaḥ ṅgulibhyām prorṇutya ninadam iva rathasya iva ghoṣaḥ ninadaḥ tam iva  śṛṇoti nadathuḥ iva ṛṣabha kūjitam iva śabdaḥ yathā ca agneḥ bahis jvalataḥ evam śabdam antar  śarīre upaśṛṇoti tat etat jyotiḥ dṛṣṭa śruta liṅga tvāt dṛṣṭam ca śrutam ca iti upāsīta
translated: Having covered, meaning having closed, with the fingers, he hears a sound like the rumbling of a chariot.🔽Like the sound of a bull, and like the sound of a fire burning outside, he hears a sound inside the body. That light, because of having seen and heard marks, should be meditated upon as seen and heard.

analyzed: tathā upāsanāt cakṣuṣyaḥ darśanīyaḥ śrutaḥ viśrutaḥ ca
translated: And by meditating in that way, he becomes one whose eyes are pleasing to look at and whose fame is well-known.

original: yatsparśaguṇopāsananimittaṃ phalaṃ tadrūpe sampādayati cakṣuṣya iti /
analyzed: yat sparśa guṇa upāsana nimittam phalam tat rūpe sampādayati cakṣuṣyaḥ iti
translated: The result that is the cause of meditating on the quality of touch, he accomplishes in form, saying pleasing to the eyes.

analyzed: rūpa sparśayoḥ sahabhāvi tvāt
translated: Because form and touch exist together.

analyzed: iṣṭa tvāt ca darśanīya tāyāḥ
translated: And because beauty is desirable.

original: evaṃ ca vidyāyāḥ phalamupapannaṃ syānna tu mṛdutvādisparśavattve /
analyzed: evam ca vidyāyāḥ phalam upapannam syāt na tu mṛdu tva ādi sparśavattve
translated: And thus the fruit of knowledge would be reasonable, not if it had the quality of being touchable as soft, etc.

analyzed: yaḥ evam yathā uktau guṇau veda
translated: One who knows these two qualities as stated.

analyzed: svarga loka pratipattiḥ tu uktam adṛṣṭam phalam
translated: The attainment of the heavenly world is the unseen fruit mentioned.

analyzed: dvis abhyāsaḥ ādara arthaḥ
translated: The repetition twice is for the purpose of respect.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi tṛtīya adhyāyasya trayodaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the thirteenth section of the third chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: sarvaṃ khalv idaṃ brahma tajjalān iti śānta upāsīta /
analyzed: sarvam khalu idam brahma tat jalān iti śāntaḥ upāsīta
translated: One should worship as tranquil, All this is indeed Brahman, that which is born of water.

original: atha khalu kratumayaḥ puruṣo yathākratur asmiṃl loke puruṣo bhavati tathetaḥ pretya bhavati /
analyzed: atha khalu kratu mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yathā kratuḥ asmin loke puruṣaḥ bhavati tathā itas pretya bhavati
translated: Now, indeed, a person consisting of thought becomes in this world a person according to his thought, even so he becomes after death.

analyzed: sa kratum kurvīta
translated: He should form a thought.

original: punastasyaiva tripādamṛtasya brahmaṇo 'nantaguṇavato 'nantaśakteranekabhedopāsyasya viśiṣṭaguṇaśaktimatvenopāsanaṃ vidhitsannāhasarvaṃ🔽khalviti vākyālaṅkārārtho nipātaḥ /
analyzed: punar tasya eva tripād amṛtasya brahmaṇaḥ nanta guṇavataḥ nanta śakteḥ aneka bheda upāsyasya viśiṣṭa guṇa śaktimat tvena upāsanam vidhitsan āha sarvam  khalu iti vākya alaṅkāra arthaḥ nipātaḥ
translated: Again, desiring to enjoin the worship of Brahman, which is the triple-footed immortal, which has infinite qualities, infinite powers, and is to be worshipped in many ways, as having distinguished qualities and powers, he says: All this... The particle kha is used for the purpose of ornamenting the sentence.

analyzed: idam jagat nāma rūpa vikṛtam pratyakṣa ādi viṣayam brahma kāraṇam vṛddhatama tvāt brahma
translated: This world, modified by name and form, which is the object of perception etc., is Brahman, the cause, because it is the oldest, and is Brahman.

analyzed: katham sarvasya brahmatvam iti atas āha tad jalān iti
translated: How is it that all is Brahman? In answer to this he says: ‘From that are born, etc.’

analyzed: tasmāt brahmaṇaḥ jātam tejaḥ banna ādi krameṇa sarvam
translated: All this, beginning with fire and food, is born from Brahman.

analyzed: atas tad jam
translated: Hence it is born of that.

original: tathā tenaiva jananakrameṇa pratilomatayā tasminneva brahmaṇi līyate tadātmatayā śliṣyata iti tallam /
analyzed: tathā tena eva janana krameṇa pratiloma tayā tasmin eva brahmaṇi līyate tad ātma tayā śliṣyate iti tallam
translated: In the same manner, by the same process of creation in the reverse order, it merges into that same Brahman, it becomes identified with that Self, hence it is absorbed in that.

original: tathā tasminneva sthitikāle 'niti prāṇiti ceṣṭata iti /
analyzed: tathā tasmin eva sthiti kāle prāṇiti ceṣṭate iti
translated: In the same manner, while existing in that, it moves, it breathes, it acts.

analyzed: evam brahma ātma tayā triṣu kāleṣu aviśiṣṭam tad vyatirekeṇa agrahaṇāt
translated: Thus, being Brahman, it is not different in the three times, because nothing else is perceived except that.

analyzed: atas tat eva idam jagat
translated: Hence, this same universe is that.

original: yathā cedaṃ tadevaikamadvitīyaṃ tathā ṣaṣṭhe vistareṇa vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca idam tat eva ekam advitīyam tathā ṣaṣṭhe vistareṇa vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And how this is that same one, without a second, we shall explain in detail in the sixth chapter.

analyzed: yasmāt ca sarvam idam brahma
translated: And since all this is Brahman,

original: ataḥ śānto rāgadveṣādidoṣarahitaḥ saṃyataḥ sanyattatsarvaṃ brahma tadvakṣyamāṇairguṇairupāsīta /
analyzed: atas śāntaḥ rāga dveṣa ādi doṣa rahitaḥ saṃyataḥ san yat tat sarvam brahma tat vakṣyamāṇaiḥ guṇaiḥ upāsīta
translated: therefore, being tranquil, free from the faults of passion, hatred, etc., being restrained, one should meditate upon that, upon all this, as Brahman, with the attributes to be described.

analyzed: katham upāsīta
translated: How should one meditate upon it?

original: kratuṃ kurvīta kraturniścayo 'dhyavasāya evameva nānyathetyavicalaḥ pratyayastaṃ kratuṃ kurvītopāsītetyanena vyavahitena sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: kratum kurvīta kratuḥ niścayaḥ dhī avasāyaḥ evam eva na anyathā iti avicalaḥ pratyayaḥ tam kratum kurvīta upāsīta iti anena vyavahitena sambandhaḥ
translated: One should form the idea, the firm conviction, the determination, that ‘it is thus, not otherwise’; one should form this idea, one should meditate upon it; this is connected with the word ‘upāsīta’ (should meditate) through the intervening word ‘kuryāt’ (should form).

analyzed: kim punar kratu karaṇena kartavyam prayojanam
translated: What is the purpose of performing a sacrifice?

original: kathaṃ vā kratuḥ kartavyaḥ kratukaraṇaṃ cābhipretārthasiddhisādhanaṃ kathamityasyārthasya pratipādanārthamathetyādigranthaḥ /
analyzed: katham vā kratuḥ kartavyaḥ kratu karaṇam ca abhipreta artha siddhi sādhanam katham iti asya arthasya pratipādana artham atha ityādi granthaḥ
translated: Or how should a sacrifice be performed? And how is the performance of a sacrifice a means to accomplishing the desired goal? The text beginning with atha is for the purpose of teaching this meaning.

analyzed: atha khalu iti hetvarthaḥ
translated: Atha khalu has the sense of cause.

analyzed: yasmāt kratu mayaḥ kratu prāyaḥ dhī avasāya ātmakaḥ puruṣaḥ jīvaḥ
translated: Because a person, a living being, is made of thought, consisting mostly of thought, having the nature of determination.

original: yathākraturyādṛśaḥ kraturasya so 'yaṃ yathākraturyathādhyavasāyo yādṛṅniścayo 'smiṃlloke jīvanniha puruṣo bhavati tatheto 'smāddehātpretya
analyzed: yathākratuḥ yādṛśaḥ kratuḥ asya saḥ yam yathākratuḥ yathā adhyavasāyaḥ yādṛś niścayaḥ smin loke jīvan iha puruṣaḥ bhavati tathā itas smāt dehāt pretya
translated: As his thought is, so is he. As his determination is, as his resolve is, as his ascertainment is in this world while living here, so does he become after leaving this body.

analyzed: mṛtvā bhavati
translated: After dying, he becomes.

analyzed: kratu anurūpa phala ātmakaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he becomes of the nature of the fruit corresponding to his thought.

analyzed: evam hi etat śāsrataḥ dṛṣṭam
translated: For this is seen in the scriptures in this way.

original: yaṃ yaṃ vāpi smaranbhāvaṃ tyajatyante kalevaramityādi /
analyzed: yam yam vā api smaran bhāvam tyajati ante kalevaram ityādi
translated: Whatever state one remembers at the end when leaving the body, that he becomes, and so on.

original: yata evaṃ vyavasthā śāsradṛṣṭātaḥ sa evaṃ jānankatuṃ kurvīta yādṛśaṃ kratuṃ vakṣyāmastam /
analyzed: yatas evam vyavasthā śāsra dṛṣṭā atas saḥ evam jānan katum kurvīta yādṛśam kratum vakṣyāmaḥ tam
translated: Since this is the established rule seen in the scriptures, one who knows this should perform a sacrifice of the kind we will describe.

original: yata evaṃ śāsraprāmāṇyādupapadyate kratvanurūpaṃ phalamataḥ sa kartavyaḥ kratuḥ //
analyzed: yatas evam śāsra prāmāṇyāt upapadyate kratu anurūpam phalam atas sa kartavyaḥ kratuḥ
translated: Since thus it is possible that the result is in accordance with the sacrifice, on the ground of the authority of the scriptures, therefore that sacrifice should be performed.

original: manomayaḥ prāṇaśarīro bhārūpaḥ satyasaṃkalpa ākāśātmā sarvakarmā sarvakāmaḥ sarvagandhaḥ sarvarasaḥ sarvam idam abhyatto 'vāky anādaraḥ //
analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ bhā rūpaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ ākāśa ātmā sarva karmā sarva kāmaḥ sarva gandhaḥ sarva rasaḥ sarvam idam abhyattaḥ vākī anādaraḥ
translated: He is made of mind, his body is breath, his form is light, his resolve is truth, his self is space, he is all action, all desire, all smell, all taste, he has entered into all this, he is without speech, without heedlessness.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ manaḥ prāyaḥ
translated: He is made of mind, he is mostly mind.

original: manute 'neneti manastatsvavṛttyā viṣayeṣu pravṛttaṃ bhavati tena manasā tanmayaḥ /
analyzed: manute nena iti manaḥ tad svavṛttyā viṣayeṣu pravṛttam bhavati tena manasā tad mayaḥ
translated: It is thought by this, therefore it is mind. It functions in the objects through its own function. He is made of that mind.

original: tathā pravṛtta iva tatprāyo nivṛtta iva ca /
analyzed: tathā pravṛttaḥ iva tad prāyaḥ nivṛttaḥ iva ca
translated: Similarly, he is mostly like that when functioning, and he is mostly like that when withdrawn.

original: ata eva prāṇaśarīraḥ prāṇo liṅgātmā vijñānakriyāśaktidvayasaṃmīrchitaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva prāṇa śarīraḥ prāṇaḥ liṅga ātmā vijñāna kriyā śakti dvaya saṃmīrchitaḥ
translated: For this very reason, his body is breath. The breath is the embodied form of the sign, consisting of the union of the two powers of knowledge and action.

original: yo vai prāṇaḥ sā prajñā yā vā prajñā sa prāṇaḥiti śruteḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ vai prāṇaḥ sā prajñā yā vā prajñā sa prāṇaḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: As it is said in the Upanishad: That which is breath is wisdom, and that which is wisdom is breath.

analyzed: sa śarīram yasya sa prāṇa śarīraḥ
translated: He whose body is that is one whose body is breath.

analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ āṇa śarīra netā iti ca śruti antarāt
translated: And in another Upanishad: He is made of mind, his body is breath.

analyzed: bhā rūpaḥ
translated: His form is light.

original: bhā dīptiścaitanyalakṣaṇaṃ rūpaṃ yasya sa bhārūpaḥ /
analyzed: bhā dīptiḥ caitanya lakṣaṇam rūpam yasya sa bhā rūpaḥ
translated: He whose form is light, whose characteristic is consciousness, is one whose form is light.

analyzed: satya saṅkalpaḥ
translated: His resolve is truth.

original: satyā avitathāḥ saṅkalpā yasya so 'yaṃ satyasaṅkalpaḥ /
analyzed: satyāḥ avitathāḥ saṅkalpāḥ yasya saḥ yam satya saṅkalpaḥ
translated: He whose intentions are true and not false is this one with true intentions.

original: na yathā saṃsāriṇa ivānaikāntikaphalaḥ saṅkalpa īśvarasyetyarthaḥ /🔽anṛtena mithyāphalatvahetunā pratyūḍhatvātsaṅkalpasya mithyāphalatvam /
analyzed: na yathā saṃsāriṇaḥ iva anaikāntika phalaḥ saṅkalpaḥ īśvarasya iti arthaḥ  anṛtena mithyā phala tva hetunā pratyūḍha tvāt saṅkalpasya mithyā phala tvam
translated: The meaning is that God's intention is not like that of worldly people, whose intentions are not always fruitful.🔽The intention is fruitless because it is obstructed by untruth, the cause of false results.

analyzed: vakṣyati anṛtena hi pratyūḍhāḥ iti  ākāśa ātmā
translated: He will say, Indeed, they are obstructed by untruth.🔽He has the soul of space.

original: ākāśa ivā'tmā svarūpaṃ yasya sa ākāśātmā /
analyzed: ākāśaḥ iva ātmā svarūpam yasya saḥ ākāśa ātmā
translated: He who has a nature like space is one who has the soul of space.

analyzed: sarva gata tvam sūkṣma tvam ca ākāśa tulya tā īśvarasya
translated: God's similarity to space is in being all-pervading, subtle, and devoid of form, etc.

analyzed: sarva karmā
translated: He is the doer of all.

original: sarvaṃ viśvaṃ teneśvareṇa kriyata iti jagatsarvaṃ karmāsya sa sarvakarmā /
analyzed: sarvam viśvam tena īśvareṇa kriyate iti jagat sarvam karma asya sa sarva karmā
translated: The entire universe is created by that God, therefore the entire world is His action. He is the doer of all.

analyzed: sa hi sarvasya kartā iti śruteḥ  sarva kāmaḥ
translated: For the scripture says, He is the maker of all.🔽He has all desires.

analyzed: sarve kāmāḥ doṣa rahitāḥ asya iti sarva kāmaḥ
translated: He who has all desires free from faults is one who has all desires.

analyzed: dharma viruddhaḥ bhūteṣu smṛteḥ
translated: For the smrti says, I am desire in beings, contrary to dharma.

original: nanu kāmo 'smīti vacanādiha bahuvrīhistathā kāmo 'smītismṛtyartho vācyaḥ /🔽sarvagandhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu kāmaḥ smi iti vacanāt iha bahuvrīhiḥ tathā smi iti smṛti arthaḥ vācyaḥ  sarva gandhaḥ
translated: But since it is said I am desire, here the bahuvrihi compound should be explained as meaning I have desire, according to the smrti.🔽He has all smells.

original: sarve gandhāḥ sukhakarā asya so 'yaṃ sarvagandhaḥ /
analyzed: sarve gandhāḥ sukha karāḥ asya saḥ yam sarva gandhaḥ
translated: He who has all smells that bring happiness is one who has all smells.

analyzed: puṇyaḥ gandhaḥ pṛthivyām iti smṛteḥ
translated: Because it is said in the Smriti: The fragrant smell is on the earth.

original: tathā rasā api vijñeyāḥ apuṇyagandharasagrahaṇasya pāpmasambandhanimittatvaśravaṇāt /
analyzed: tathā rasāḥ api vijñeyāḥ apuṇya gandha rasa grahaṇasya pāpma sambandha nimitta tva śravaṇāt
translated: Similarly, the tastes should be known. Because it is heard that the grasping of non-fragrant smells and tastes is due to the connection with sin.

original: tasmāttenobhayaṃ jighrati surabhi ca durgandhi ca /
analyzed: tasmāt tena ubhayam jighrati surabhi ca durgandhi ca
translated: Therefore, he smells both, the fragrant and the foul-smelling.

analyzed: pāpmanā hi eṣu viddhaḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: Because it is said in the Shruti: For he is pierced by sin.

analyzed: na ca pāpma saṃsarge īśvarasya
translated: And there is no contact with sin for God.

analyzed: avidyā ādi doṣasya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the faults of ignorance etc. are not possible for Him.

analyzed: sarvam idam jagat abhyāttaḥ abhivyāptaḥ
translated: This entire world is pervaded, completely covered.

analyzed: atateḥ vyāpti arthasya kartari niṣṭhā
translated: The suffix kṛt is used in the sense of pervasion from the root atata.

analyzed: tathāvākī ucyate naya iti vāc vāc eva vākaḥ
translated: Similarly, it is said: That by which one speaks, that is speech. Speech itself is vāka.

analyzed: dvā vaceḥ ghañ antasya karaṇe vāc
translated: Vāka is the instrumental case of the verbal noun vāc, which ends in ghañ.

original: sa yasya vidyate sa vākī na vākyavākī /
analyzed: sa yasya vidyate sa vākī na vākya vākī
translated: He who has that is vāki, not vākyavāki.

analyzed: vāc pratiṣedhaḥ ca atra upalakṣaṇa arthaḥ
translated: And the negation of speech here is for the purpose of illustration.

analyzed: gandha rasa ādi śravaṇāt īśvarasya prāptā nighrāṇa ādīni karaṇāni gandha ādi grahaṇāya
translated: The sense organs such as the nose of God are obtained for grasping smells etc.

analyzed: atas vāc pratiṣedhena pratiṣidhyante tāni
translated: Therefore, they are prohibited by the prohibition of speech.

original: apāṇipādo javano grahītā paśyatyacakṣuḥ sa śṛṇotyakarṇaḥityādimantravarṇāt /
analyzed: a pāṇi pādaḥ javanaḥ grahītā paśyati a cakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoti a karṇaḥ ityādi mantra varṇāt
translated: He who has no hands or feet, who is swift, who grasps, who sees without eyes, who hears without ears, etc. - from the words of this mantra.

analyzed: anādaraḥ saṃbhramaḥ
translated: A disregard is non-confusion.

analyzed: a prāpta prāptau hi saṃbhramaḥ syāt an āpta kāmasya
translated: For there would be confusion in the attainment of what has not been attained, for one whose desires are unfulfilled.

analyzed: na tu āpta kāma tvāt nitya tṛptasya īśvarasya saṃbhramaḥ sti kvacid
translated: But for the Lord, who is ever-content because His desires are fulfilled, there is no confusion anywhere.

original: eṣa ma ātmā antarhṛdaye 'ṇīyān vrīher vā yavād vā sarṣapād vā śyāmākād vā śyāmākataṇḍulād vā /
analyzed: eṣa me ātmā antar hṛdaye ṇīyān vrīheḥ vā yavāt vā sarṣapāt vā śyāmākāt vā śyāmāka taṇḍulāt vā
translated: This Self of mine is within the heart, smaller than a rice grain, smaller than a barley grain, smaller than a mustard seed, smaller than a grain of millet, smaller than a grain of rice.

original: eṣa ma ātmā antarhṛdaye jyāyān pṛthivyā jyāyān antarikṣāj jyāyān divo jyāyān ebhyo lokebhyaḥ //
analyzed: eṣa me ātmā antar hṛdaye jyāyān pṛthivyāḥ jyāyān antarikṣāt jyāyān divaḥ jyāyān ebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ
translated: This Self of mine is within the heart, greater than the earth, greater than the atmosphere, greater than the sky, greater than these worlds.

original: eṣa yathoktaguṇo me mamā'tmāntarhṛdaye hṛdayapuṇḍarīkasyāntarmadhye 'ṇīyānaṇutaro vrīhervā yavādvetyādyatyantasūkṣmatvapradarśanārtham
analyzed: eṣa yathā ukta guṇaḥ me mama ātmā antar hṛdaye hṛdaya puṇḍarīkasya antar madhye ṇīyān aṇutaraḥ vrīheḥ vā yavāt vā ityādi atyanta sūkṣmatva pradarśana artham
translated: This Self of mine, which has been described as having such qualities, is within the heart, in the middle of the lotus of the heart, smaller than a rice grain, smaller than a barley grain, etc., in order to show that it is extremely subtle.

original: śyāmākādvā śyāmākataṇḍulādveti paricchinnaparimāṇādaṇīyānityukte 'ṇuparimāṇatvaṃ prāptamāśaṅkyātastatpratiṣedhāyā'rabhate eṣa ma ātmāntarhṛdaye🔽jyāyānpṛthivyā ityādinā /
analyzed: śyāmākāt vā śyāmāka taṇḍulāt vā iti paricchinna parimāṇāt aṇīyān iti ukte ṇu parimāṇa tvam prāptam āśaṅkya atas tad pratiṣedhāya ārabhate eṣa me ātmā antar hṛdaye  jyāyān pṛthivyāḥ ityādinā
translated: Smaller than a grain of millet, smaller than a grain of rice, it is said to be smaller than something with limited dimensions. Fearing that it might be thought that it has atomic dimensions, in order to refute that, he begins This Self of mine is within the heart.

analyzed: jyāyaḥ parimāṇāt ca jyāyaḥ tvam darśayan ananta parimāṇa tvam darśayati
translated: With greater than the earth, etc., he shows that it is greater than something with greater dimensions, thus showing that it has infinite dimensions.

original: sarvakarmā sarvakāmaḥ sarvagandhaḥ sarvarasaḥ sarvam idam abhyatto 'vākyanādaraḥ /🔽eṣa ma ātmā antarhṛdaye /
analyzed: sarva karmā sarva kāmaḥ sarva gandhaḥ sarva rasaḥ sarvam idam abhyattaḥ vākya anādaraḥ  eṣa me ātmā antar hṛdaye
translated: He is all action, all desire, all smell, all taste, he has entered into all this, he is the unmanifest, the imperishable.

analyzed: etat brahma
translated: This is my Self within the heart, which is Brahman.

original: etam itaḥ pretyābhisaṃbhavitā asmīti yasya syād addhā na vicikitsā asti /
analyzed: etam itas pretya abhisaṃbhavitā asmi iti yasya syāt addhā na vicikitsā asti
translated: After departing from here, I shall become this, for him who has this, there is no doubt.

analyzed: iti ha sma āha śāṇḍilyaḥ śāṇḍilyaḥ
translated: Thus indeed did Śāṇḍilya Śāṇḍilya say.

original: manomaya ityādinā jyāyānebhyo lokebhya ityantena yathoktaguṇalakṣaṇa
analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ ityādinā jyāyānebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ iti antena yathā ukta guṇa lakṣaṇa
translated: By the words consisting of mind and so on up to greater than the great, the God who has the qualities and characteristics described

original: īśvaro dhyeyo na tu tadguṇaviśiṣṭa eva yathā rājapuruṣamānaya citraguṃ vetyukte na
analyzed: īśvaraḥ dhyeyaḥ na tu tad guṇa viśiṣṭaḥ eva yathā rāja puruṣam ānaya citragum vā iti ukte na
translated: is to be meditated upon, but not just as possessing those qualities, just as when it is said Bring the king's man with the variegated horse,

original: viśeṣaṇaśyāpyānayane vyāpriyate tadvadihāpīti prāptamatastannivṛttyartha sarvakarmetyādi punarvacanam /
analyzed: viśeṣaṇa śyāpya ānayane vyāpriyate tadvat iha api iti prāptam atas tad nivṛtti artha sarva karma ityādi punarvacanam
translated: the bringing is not done with reference to the qualities. It is the same here also. This being the prima facie view, the repetition of all action and so on is for the purpose of refuting that.

analyzed: tasmāt manaḥ maya tva ādi guṇa viśiṣṭaḥ eva īśvaraḥ dhyeyaḥ
translated: Therefore, God, who is distinguished by the qualities of consisting of mind and so on, is to be meditated upon.

original: ata eva ṣaṣṭhasaptamayoriva tattvamasyātmaivedaṃ sarvamiti neha svārājye 'bhiṣiñcati /
analyzed: atas eva ṣaṣṭha saptamayoḥ iva tattvam asi ātmā eva idam sarvam iti na iha svārājye bhiṣiñcati
translated: For this very reason, as in the sixth and seventh (chapters), That art thou, All this is verily Brahman, he does not anoint (the disciple) in the sovereignty of self here.

original: eṣa ma ātmaitadbrahmaitamitaḥ pratyābhisambhavitāsmīti liṅgānna tvātmaśabdena pratyagātmaivocyate /
analyzed: eṣa me ātmā etat brahma etam itas liṅgāt na tu ātma śabdena pratyagātmā eva ucyate
translated: This is my Self, this is Brahman, I shall be united with this after death - from the indication of this, the Self is not spoken of by the word Self as the inner Self.

analyzed: mama iti ṣaṣṭhyāḥ sambandha artha pratyāyaka tvāt etam abhisambhavitāsmi iti ca karma kartṛ tva nirdeśāt
translated: Because the genitive case expresses the meaning of relation, and because the statement I shall be united with this indicates the relation of action and agent.

original: nanu ṣaṣṭhe 'pyatha sampatsya iti satsampatteḥ kālāntaritatvaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: nanu ṣaṣṭhe sampatsye iti sat sampatteḥ kāla antarita tvam darśayati
translated: But in the sixth chapter also, in the statement I shall be united with the existent, it shows that the attainment of the existent is at a later time.

analyzed: na ārabdha saṃskāra śeṣa sthiti artha para tvāt na kāla antarita artha tā
translated: No. Because it is meant to refer to the duration of the remaining impressions of what has begun, it does not refer to a later time.

original: anyathā tattvamasītyetasyārthasya bādhaprasaṅgāt /🔽yadyapyātmaśabdasya pratyagarthatvaṃ sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahmeti ca prakṛtameṣa ma
analyzed: anyathā tat tvam asi iti etasya arthasya bādha prasaṅgāt  yadi api ātma śabdasya pratyagartha tvam sarvam khalu idam brahma iti ca prakṛtam eṣa ma
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of negating the meaning of the statement That thou art.

analyzed: ātmā antar hṛdaye etat brahma iti ucyate tathā api antardhānam īṣat a parityajya eva etam ātmānam itas
translated: Even though the word Self refers to the inner object, and even though it is said that all this is Brahman, and that this is the Self, this is Brahman within the heart, still, without completely abandoning concealment, it is said I shall be united with this Self after death.

analyzed: smāt śarīrāt pretya abhisambhavitāsmi iti uktam
translated: From this body, after death, I shall be united with this Self.

analyzed: yathā kratu rūpasya ātmanaḥ pratipattāsmi iti yasya evaṃvidaḥ syāt bhavet addhā satyam evam
translated: He for whom there is such a knower of the Self, who thinks I shall attain the Self in the form of the will, for him, indeed, this is true.

original: syāmahaṃ pretya evaṃ na syāmiti na ca vicikitsāstītyetasminnarthe kratuphalasambandhe
analyzed: syām aham pretya evam na syām iti na ca vicikitsā asti iti etasmin arthe kratu phala sambandhe
translated: I shall be after death, I shall not be' - there is no doubt about this matter, about the connection between the sacrifice and its result.

original: sa tathaiveśvarabhāvaṃ pratipadyate vidvānityetadāha smoktavānkila śāṇḍalyo nāmarṣiḥ /
analyzed: sa tathā eva īśvara bhāvam pratipadyate vidvān iti etat āha sma uktavān kila śāṇḍalyaḥ nāma ṛṣiḥ
translated: The learned one attains that very state of being God. This is what the sage named Śāṇḍilya said.

analyzed: dvis abhyāsaḥ ādara arthaḥ
translated: The repetition is for emphasis.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi tṛtīya adhyāyasya caturdaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourteenth section in the third chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: antarikṣodaraḥ kośo bhūmibudhno na jīryati /🔽diśo hy asya sraktayo dyaur asyottaraṃ bilam /
analyzed: antarikṣa udaraḥ kośaḥ bhūmi budhnaḥ na jīryati  diśaḥ hi asya sraktayaḥ dyauḥ asya uttaram bilam
