translated: He eats food, he sees what is dear, and in his family there is spiritual glory, for one who worships this Self as Vaiśvānara in this way.

original: prāṇas tv eṣa ātmana iti hovāca /
analyzed: prāṇaḥ tu eṣaḥ ātmanaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: He said, But this is the breath of your Self.

original: prāṇas ta udakramiṣyad yan māṃ nāgamiṣya iti //
analyzed: prāṇaḥ te udakramiṣyat yat mām na agamiṣyaḥ iti
translated: If you had not come to me, my breath would have departed from you.

analyzed: atsi annam ityādi samānam
translated: The same as before, He eats food, etc.

original: praṇastveṣa ātmana iti hovāca prāṇaste tavodakramiṣyadutkrānto 'bhaviṣyadyanmāṃ nā'gamiṣya iti //
analyzed: praṇaḥ tu eṣaḥ ātmanaḥ iti ha uvāca prāṇaḥ te tava udakramiṣyat utkrāntaḥ bhaviṣyat yat mām na agamiṣyaḥ iti
translated: He said, But this is the breath of your Self. If you had not come to me, my breath would have departed, would have left you.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya caturdaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Fourteenth Section in the Fifth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: atha ha uvāca janam śārkarākṣyam
translated: Then he said to Jana Śārkara-ākṣya:

original: śārkarākṣya kaṃ tvam ātmānam upāssa iti /
analyzed: śārkarākṣya kam tvam ātmānam upāsse iti
translated: Jana Śārkara-ākṣya, which Self do you worship?

original: ākāśam eva bhagavo rājann iti hovāca /
analyzed: ākāśam eva bhagavaḥ rājan iti ha uvāca
translated: He said, The space, O revered king.

original: eṣa vai bahula ātmā vaiśvānaro yaṃ tvam ātmānam upasse /
analyzed: eṣa vai bahulaḥ ātmā vaiśvānaraḥ yam tvam ātmānam upasse
translated: This is the extensive Self, Vaiśvānara, whom you worship as your Self.

original: tasmāt tvaṃ bahulo 'si prajayā ca dhanena ca //
analyzed: tasmāt tvam bahulaḥ si prajayā ca dhanena ca
translated: Therefore, you are extensive in offspring and wealth.

analyzed: atha ha uvāca janam ityādi samānam
translated: Then he said to Jana, etc., the same as before.

analyzed: eṣa vai bahulaḥ ātmā vaiśvānaraḥ
translated: This is the extensive Self, Vaiśvānara.

analyzed: bahula tvam ākāśasya sarva gata tvāt
translated: The extensiveness of space is due to its all-pervasiveness.

original: bahulaguṇopāsanācca tvaṃ bahulo 'si prajayā ca putrapautrādilakṣaṇayā dhanena ca hiraṇyādinā //
analyzed: bahula guṇa upāsanāt ca tvam bahulaḥ si prajayā ca putra pautra ādi lakṣaṇayā dhanena ca hiraṇya ādinā
translated: And because you meditate on the Vaiśvānara Self as possessed of many qualities, you are many. And you are many in offspring characterized by sons, grandsons, etc., and in wealth consisting of gold, etc.

analyzed: atsi annam paśyasi priyam
translated: You eat food and see what is dear.

original: atty annaṃ paśyati priyaṃ bhavaty asya brahmavarcasaṃ kule ya etam evam ātmānaṃ vaiśvānaram upāste /
analyzed: atti annam paśyati priyam bhavati asya brahmavarcasam kule yaḥ etam evam ātmānam vaiśvānaram upāste
translated: One who thus meditates on this Self as Vaiśvānara eats food, sees what is dear, and his family attains Brahmic glory.

original: saṃdehas tv eṣa ātmana iti hovāca /
analyzed: saṃdehaḥ tu eṣaḥ ātmanaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: But this is a doubt about the Self, he said.

original: saṃdehas te vyaśīryad yan māṃ nāgamiṣya iti //
analyzed: saṃdehaḥ te vyaśīryat yat mām na agamiṣyaḥ iti
translated: Your doubt would have been shattered if you had not come to me.

analyzed: sandehaḥ tu eṣa sandehaḥ madhyamam śarīram vaiśvānarasya
translated: This doubt is the middle body of Vaiśvānara.

original: diherupacayārthatvānmāṃsarudhirāsthyādibhiśca bahulaṃ śarīraṃ tatsandehaste tava śarīraṃ vyaśīryacchīrṇamabhaviṣyadyanmāṃ nā'gamiṣya iti //
analyzed: diheḥ upacaya artha tvāt māṃsa rudhira asthi ādibhiḥ ca bahulam śarīram tat sandehaḥ te tava śarīram vyaśīryat śīrṇam abhaviṣyat yat mām na agamiṣyaḥ iti
translated: The body is many due to the meaning of the root dih (to increase) and due to flesh, blood, bones, etc. That doubt, your body, would have been shattered, broken, if you had not come to me.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya pañcadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifteenth section in the fifth chapter of Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: atha ha uvāca buḍilam āśvatarāśvim
translated: Then he said to Buḍila Āśvatarāśvi,

original: vaiyāghrapadya kaṃ tvam ātmānam upāssa iti /
analyzed: vaiyāghrapadya kam tvam ātmānam upāsse iti
translated: Vāyāghrapadya, on what Self do you meditate?

original: apa eva bhagavo rājann iti hovāca /
analyzed: apaḥ eva bhagavaḥ rājan iti ha uvāca
translated: Water, O revered king, he said.

original: eṣa vai rayir ātmā vaiśvānaro yaṃ tvam ātmānam upāsse /
analyzed: eṣa vai rayiḥ ātmā vaiśvānaraḥ yam tvam ātmānam upāsse
translated: This very wealth, the Self, is Vaiśvānara, whom you worship as the Self.

analyzed: tasmāt tvam rayimān puṣṭimān asi
translated: Therefore you are wealthy, prosperous.

analyzed: atha ha uvāca buḍilam āśvatarāśvim ityādi samānam
translated: Then he said to Buḍila Āśvatarāśvi... and so on, the same as before.

analyzed: eṣa vai rayiḥ ātmā vaiśvānaraḥ dhana rūpaḥ
translated: This very wealth, the Self, is Vaiśvānara, in the form of wealth.

analyzed: adbhyaḥ nnam tatas dhanam iti
translated: From water comes food, from that wealth.

analyzed: tasmāt rayimān dhanavān tvam puṣṭimān ca śarīreṇa
translated: Therefore you are wealthy, prosperous, and well-nourished in your body.

analyzed: puṣṭeḥ ca anna nimitta tvāt
translated: And because nourishment is caused by food.

analyzed: atsi annam paśyasi priyam
translated: You will eat food, you will see what is dear.

original: atty annaṃ paśyati priyaṃ bhavaty asya brahmavarcasaṃ kule ya etam evam ātmānaṃ vaiśvānaram upāste /
analyzed: atti annam paśyati priyam bhavati asya brahmavarcasam kule yaḥ etam evam ātmānam vaiśvānaram upāste
translated: One who thus worships this Self as Vaiśvānara eats food, sees what is dear, and in his family there is spiritual glory.

original: bastis tv eṣa ātmana iti hovāca /
analyzed: bastiḥ tu eṣaḥ ātmanaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: The bladder is indeed this Self, he said.

original: bastis te vyabhetsyad yan māṃ nāgamiṣya iti //
analyzed: bastiḥ te vyabhetsyat yat mām na agamiṣyaḥ iti
translated: Your bladder would have burst if you had not come to me.

original: bastistveṣa ātmano vaiśvānarasya bastirmūtrasaṃgrahasthānaṃ bastirmūtrasaṃgrahasthānaṃ bastiste vyabhetsyadbhinno 'bhaviṣyadyanmāṃ
analyzed: vastiḥ tu eṣaḥ ātmanaḥ vaiśvānarasya bastiḥ mūtra saṃgraha sthānam bastiḥ mūtra saṃgraha sthānam vastiḥ te vyabhetsyat bhinnaḥ bhaviṣyat yat mām
translated: The bladder is indeed this Self of Vaiśvānara. The bladder is the place for collecting urine. Your bladder would have burst, would have broken, if you had not come to me.

analyzed: na āgamiṣye iti
translated: If you had not come to me.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya ṣoḍaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Sixteenth Section in the Fifth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: atha ha uvāca uddālakam āruṇim
translated: Then he said to Uddalaka Aruni:

original: gautama kaṃ tvam ātmānam upassa iti /
analyzed: gautama kam tvam ātmānam upasse iti
translated: Gautama, which Self do you worship?

original: pṛthivīm eva bhagavo rājann iti hovāca /
analyzed: pṛthivīm eva bhagavaḥ rājan iti ha uvāca
translated: The earth, indeed, O Lord, O King, he replied.

original: eṣa vai pratiṣṭhātmā vaiśvānaro yaṃ tvam ātmānam upāsse /
analyzed: eṣa vai pratiṣṭhā ātmā vaiśvānaraḥ yam tvam ātmānam upāsse
translated: This, indeed, is the Self that is the support, Vaiśvānara, which you worship as your Self.

original: tasmāt tvaṃ pratiṣṭhito 'si prajayā ca paśubhiś ca //
analyzed: tasmāt tvam pratiṣṭhitaḥ si prajayā ca paśubhiḥ ca
translated: Therefore you are supported by offspring and by cattle.

analyzed: atsi annam paśyasi priyam
translated: You eat food and see what is dear.

original: atty annaṃ paśyati priyaṃ bhavaty asya brahmavarcasaṃ kule ya etam evam ātmānaṃ vaiśvānaram upāste /
analyzed: atti annam paśyati priyam bhavati asya brahmavarcasam kule yaḥ etam evam ātmānam vaiśvānaram upāste
translated: One who worships this very Self as Vaiśvānara eats food, sees what is dear, and has spiritual radiance in his family.

original: pādau tv etāv ātmana iti hovāca /
analyzed: pādau tu etau ātmanaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: These are the feet of the Self, he said.

original: pādau te vyamlāsyetāṃ yan māṃ nāgamiṣya iti //
analyzed: pādau te vyamlāsyetām yat mām na agamiṣyaḥ iti
translated: Your feet would have withered if you had not come to me.

analyzed: atha ha uvāca uddālakam ityādi samānam
translated: Then he said to Uddalaka and so on, the same as before.

analyzed: pṛthivīm eva bhagavaḥ rājan iti ha uvāca
translated: The earth, indeed, O Lord, O King, he replied.

analyzed: eṣa vai pratiṣṭhā pādau vaiśvānarasya
translated: This, indeed, is the support, the feet of Vaiśvānara.

original: pādau te vyamlāsyetāṃ vimlānāvabhaviṣyatāṃ ślathībhūtau yanmāṃ nā'gamiṣya iti //
analyzed: pādau te vyamlāsyetām vimlānau abhaviṣyatām ślathībhūtau yat mām na agamiṣyaḥ iti
translated: Your feet would have withered, would have become withered and loose, if you had not come to me.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya saptadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the seventeenth section in the fifth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: tān ha uvāca
translated: He said to them:

original: ete vai khalu yūyaṃ pṛthag ivemam ātmānaṃ vaiśvānaraṃ vidvāṃso 'nnam attha /
analyzed: ete vai khalu yūyam pṛthak iva imam ātmānam vaiśvānaram vidvāṃsaḥ nnam attha
translated: You, indeed, knowing this Vaiśvānara Self as if separate, eat food.

original: yas tv etam evaṃ prādeśamātram abhivimānam ātmānaṃ vaiśvānaram upāste /
analyzed: yaḥ tu etam evam prādeśa mātram abhivimānam ātmānam vaiśvānaram upāste
translated: But he who worships this Vaiśvānara Self as of the size of a span,

original: sa sarveṣu lokeṣu sarveṣu bhūteṣu sarveṣv ātmasv annam atti //🔽tānyathoktavaiśvānaradarśanavato hovāca /
analyzed: sa sarveṣu lokeṣu sarveṣu bhūteṣu sarveṣu ātmasu annam atti  tāni atha ukta vaiśvānara darśanavataḥ ha uvāca
translated: he eats food in all worlds, in all beings, in all selves.🔽To them, who had the vision of Vaiśvānara as described, he said:

original: ete yūyaṃ vai khalvityanarthakau /🔽yūyaṃ pṛthagivāpṛthaksantamimamekaṃ vaiśvānaramātmānaṃ vidvāṃso 'nnamattha paricchinnātmabuddhyetyetaddhastidarśana iva jātyandhāḥ /🔽yastvetamevaṃ yathoktāvayavairdyumūrdhādibhiḥ pṛthivīpādāntairviśiṣṭamekaṃ prādeśamātraṃ prādeśairdyumūrdhādibhiḥ pṛthivīpādāntairadhyātmaṃ
analyzed: ete yūyam vai khalu iti anarthakau  yūyam pṛthak iva apṛthak santam imam ekam vaiśvānaram ātmānam vidvāṃsaḥ nnamattha paricchinna ātma buddhyā iti etat hasti darśane iva jāti andhāḥ  yaḥ tu etam evam yathā ukta avayavaiḥ dyu mūrdha ādibhiḥ pṛthivī pāda antaiḥ viśiṣṭam ekam prādeśa mātram prādeśaiḥ dyu mūrdha ādibhiḥ pṛthivī pāda antaiḥ adhyātmam
translated: You, indeed, (ho),🔽you, knowing this one Vaiśvānara Self as if separate, as distinct, eat food, with the notion of a limited Self, like those born blind in the case of the elephant.🔽But he who knows this one Vaiśvānara Self as distinguished by the parts described, beginning with the head of heaven and ending with the feet of earth, as of the size of a span,

analyzed: mīyate jñāyate iti prādeśa mātrām
translated: is measured, is known, by the parts beginning with the head of heaven and ending with the feet of earth, as of the size of a span.

original: mukhādiṣu vā karaṇeṣvattṛtvena mīyata iti prādeśamātraḥ /
analyzed: mukha ādiṣu vā karaṇeṣu attṛ tvena mīyate iti prādeśa mātraḥ
translated: Or he is measured, known, as the enjoyer in the organs such as the mouth etc., as of the size of a span.

analyzed: dyu loka ādi pṛthivī anta pradeśa parimāṇaḥ vā prādeśa mātraḥ
translated: Or, it is of the size of the space from heaven to earth.

original: prakarṣeṇa śāsreṇā'diśyanta iti prādeśā dyulokādaya etāvatparimāṇaḥ /
analyzed: prakarṣeṇa śāsreṇa ādiśyante iti prādeśāḥ dyu loka ādayaḥ etāvat parimāṇaḥ
translated: The Pradeshas are heaven etc., which are indicated by the scriptures as having such and such a size.

original: śākhāntare tu mūrdhādiḥ cibukapratiṣṭha iti prādeśamātraṃ kalpayanti /
analyzed: śākhā antare tu mūrdha ādiḥ cibuka pratiṣṭhaḥ iti prādeśa mātram kalpayanti
translated: But in another branch, they conceive the Pradesha to be from the head to the chin.

original: iha tu na tathābhipretaḥ /🔽tasya ha vā etasyā'tmana ityādyupasaṃhārāt /
analyzed: iha tu na tathā abhipretaḥ  tasya ha vai etasya ātmanaḥ ityādi upasaṃhārāt
translated: But here it is not intended to be so.🔽Because of the conclusion beginning with That is this Self.

analyzed: pratyagātma tayā abhivimīyate ham iti jñāyate iti abhivimānaḥ tam etam ātmānam vaiśvānaram
translated: The Self is known as I by being measured inwardly. That Self, the Vaiśvānara,

original: viśvānnarānnayati puṇyapāpānurūpāṃ gatiṃ sarvātmaiṣa īśvaro vaiśvānaro viśvo nara
analyzed: viśvān narān nayati puṇya pāpa anurūpām gatim sarva ātmā eṣaḥ īśvaraḥ vaiśvānaraḥ viśvaḥ nara
translated: leads the all-men to the state befitting their merit and demerit. This all-Self is God, the Vaiśvānara, all and men,

analyzed: eva vā sarva ātma tvāt
translated: or it is so because of being the all-Self.

original: viśvairvā naraiḥ pratyagātmatayā pravibhajya nīyata iti vaiśvānarastamevamupāste
analyzed: viśvaiḥ vā naraiḥ pratyak ātma tayā pravibhajya nīyate iti vaiśvānaraḥ tam evam upāste
translated: Or it is led by all men as the inner Self. He who worships that Vaiśvānara thus,

original: yaḥ so 'dannannādī sarveṣu lokeṣu dyulokādiṣu sarveṣu bhūteṣu carācareṣu sarveṣvātmasu
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ dan anna ādī sarveṣu lokeṣu dyu loka ādiṣu sarveṣu bhūteṣu carācareṣu sarveṣu ātmasu
translated: he eats, he is the eater of food, in all the worlds beginning with the heavenly world, in all beings moving and unmoving, in all the Selfs,

original: śarīrendriyamanobuddhiṣu teṣu hyātmakalpanāvyapadeśaḥ prāṇināmannamatti vaiśvānaravitsarvātmā sannannamatti /
analyzed: śarīra indriya manaḥ buddhiṣu teṣu hi ātma kalpanā vyapadeśaḥ prāṇinām annam atti vaiśvānara vid sarva ātmā san annam atti
translated: For in those bodies, senses, mind, and intellect, there is the designation of the conception of the self of living beings. He eats food, being the all-pervading self, like Vaiśvānara. He eats food.

analyzed: na yathājñaḥ piṇḍa mātra abhimānaḥ san iti arthaḥ
translated: Not like one who is ignorant and conceives himself to be merely a gross body, is the meaning.

original: tasya ha vā etasyātmano vaiśvānarasya mūrdhaiva sutejāś cakṣur viśvarūpaḥ prāṇaḥ
analyzed: tasya ha vai etasya ātmanaḥ vaiśvānarasya mūrdhā eva su tejāḥ cakṣuḥ viśva rūpaḥ prāṇaḥ
translated: Now, of this Vaiśvānara-ātman, the head itself is the bright light, the eye is the all-form, the breath

original: pṛthagvartmātmā saṃdeho bahulo bastir eva rayiḥ pṛthivy eva pādāv ura eva vedir lomāṇi
analyzed: pṛthak vartmā ātmā saṃdehaḥ bahulaḥ vastiḥ eva rayiḥ pṛthivī eva pādau uraḥ eva vediḥ lomāṇi
translated: is the separate path, the body is the doubt, the belly is the abundance, the bladder itself is the wealth, the feet are the earth, the chest itself is the altar, the hairs

original: barhir hṛdayaṃ gārhapatyo mano 'nvāhāryapacana āsyam āhavanīyaḥ //
analyzed: barhiḥ hṛdayam gārhapatyaḥ manaḥ nvāhāryapacanaḥ āsyam āhavanīyaḥ
translated: are the sacrificial grass, the heart is the Gārhapatya fire, the mind is the Anvāhāryapacana fire, the mouth is the Āhavanīya fire.

analyzed: kasmāt evam
translated: Why is it so?

original: yasmāttasya ha vai prakṛtasyaivaitasyā'tmano vaiśvānarasya mūrdhaiva sutejāścakṣurviśvarūpaḥ prāṇaḥ pṛthagvartmā'tmā sandeho bahulo bastireva
analyzed: yasmāt tasya ha vai prakṛtasya eva etasya ātmanaḥ vaiśvānarasya mūrdhā eva su tejāḥ cakṣuḥ viśva rūpaḥ prāṇaḥ pṛthak vartmā ātmā sandehaḥ bahulaḥ vastiḥ eva
translated: Because the head itself of that very primordial Vaiśvānara-ātman is the bright light, the eye is the all-form, the breath is the separate path, the body is the doubt, the belly is the abundance, the bladder itself is

analyzed: rayiḥ pṛthivī eva pādau
translated: the wealth, the feet are the earth.

analyzed: athavā vidhi artham etat vacanam evam upāsyaḥ iti
translated: Or this statement is for the purpose of injunction: One should meditate thus.

original: athedānīṃ vaiśvānaravido bhojane 'gnihotraṃ saṃpipādayiṣannāhaetasya vaiśvānarasya bhokturura eva vedirākārasāmāvanyāt /
analyzed: atha idānīm vaiśvānara vidaḥ bhojane gnihotram saṃpipādayiṣan āha etasya vaiśvānarasya bhoktuḥ uraḥ eva vediḥ ākāra sāmau anyāt
translated: Now, wishing to establish the Agnihotra in eating for one who knows the Vaiśvānara, he says: The chest itself of this Vaiśvānara, the eater, is the altar, because of the similarity of shape.

analyzed: lomāni barhiḥ vedyām iva urasi lomāni āstīrṇāni na dṛśyante
translated: The hairs are the sacrificial grass. The hairs on the chest are spread out like the altar, but are not seen.

original: hṛdayaṃ gārhapatyo hṛdayāddhi manaḥ praṇītamivānantarī bhavatyato 'nvāhāryapacano 'gnirmanaḥ /
analyzed: hṛdayam gārhapatyaḥ hṛdayāt hi manaḥ praṇītam iva anantarī bhavati atas nvāhāryapacanaḥ gniḥ manaḥ
translated: The heart is the Gārhapatya fire, because the mind is as if led out from the heart. Therefore, the Anvāhāryapacana fire is the mind.

analyzed: āsyam mukham āhavanīyaḥ iva āhavanīyaḥ hūyate smin annam iti
translated: The mouth is the Āhavanīya fire, because food is offered into it like the Āhavanīya fire.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya aṣṭādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eighteenth section of the fifth chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: tad yad bhaktaṃ prathamam āgacchet tad dhomīyam /
analyzed: tat yat bhaktam prathamam āgacchet tat homīyam
translated: Whatever food comes first, that is to be offered in the fire.

original: sa yāṃ prathamām āhutiṃ juhuyāt tāṃ juhuyāt prāṇāya svāheti /
analyzed: sa yām prathamām āhutim juhuyāt tām juhuyāt prāṇāya svāhā iti
translated: One should offer the first oblation with the formula, Svāhā to Prāṇa.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ tṛpyati
translated: Prāṇa is satisfied.

original: tattatraivaṃ sati yadbhaktaṃ bhojanakāla āgacchedbhojanārthaṃ taddhotavyam /
analyzed: tat tatra evam sati yat bhaktam bhojana kāle āgacchet bhojana artham tat hotavyam
translated: When this is so, whatever food comes at the time of eating for the purpose of eating, that should be offered in the fire.

analyzed: agnihotra sampad mātrasya vivakṣita tvāt na agnihotra aṅga itikartavya tā prāptiḥ iha
translated: Since only the completion of the Agnihotra is intended here, the procedure for the Agnihotra is not obtained here.

original: sa bhoktā yāṃ prathamāmāhutiṃ juhuyāttāṃ kathaṃ juhutādityāhaprāṇāya svāhetyanena mantreṇā'hutiśabdādavadānapramāṇamannaṃ prakṣipedityarthaḥ
analyzed: sa bhoktā yām prathamām āhutim juhuyāt tām katham juhutāt iti āha prāṇāya svāhā iti anena mantreṇa āhuti śabdāt avadāna pramāṇam annam prakṣipet iti arthaḥ
translated: How should he offer that first oblation which he is to offer? He should offer it with this formula, 'To the breath Svâhâ!' The meaning is that he should throw into the fire a portion of food equal to the oblation, by the word 'oblation.'

analyzed: tena prāṇaḥ tṛpyati  prāṇe tṛpyati cakṣuḥ tṛpyati
translated: By that the breath is satisfied.🔽When the breath is satisfied, the eye is satisfied.

original: cakṣuṣi tṛpyaty ādityas tṛpyati /🔽āditye tṛpyati dyaus tṛpyati /
analyzed: cakṣuṣi tṛpyati ādityaḥ tṛpyati  āditye tṛpyati dyauḥ tṛpyati
translated: When the eye is satisfied, the sun is satisfied.🔽When the sun is satisfied, the sky is satisfied.

original: divi tṛpyantyāṃ yat kiṃca dyauś cādityaś cādhitiṣṭhatas tat tṛpyati /
analyzed: divi tṛpyantyām yat kiṃca dyauḥ ca ādityaḥ ca adhitiṣṭhataḥ tat tṛpyati
translated: When the sky is satisfied, whatever the sky and the sun rule over is satisfied.

original: tasyānu tṛptiṃ tṛpyati prajayā paśubhir annādyena tejasā brahmavarcaseneti //
analyzed: tasya anu tṛptim tṛpyati prajayā paśubhiḥ annādyena tejasā brahmavarcasena iti
translated: In the satisfaction of that he himself is satisfied with offspring, cattle, food, splendour, and holy lustre.

original: prāṇe tṛpyati cakṣurādityo dyauścetyādi tṛpyati yaccānyaddyauścā'dityaśca svāmitvenādhitiṣṭhatastacca tṛpyati tasya tṛptimanu
analyzed: prāṇe tṛpyati cakṣuḥ ādityaḥ dyauḥ ca ityādi tṛpyati yat ca anyat dyauḥ ca ādityaḥ ca svāmi tvena adhitiṣṭhataḥ tat ca tṛpyati tasya tṛptim anu
translated: When the breath is satisfied, the eye, the sun, and the sky are satisfied, and whatever else the sun and the sky rule over as lords, that is satisfied. In the satisfaction of that

analyzed: svayam bhuñjānaḥ tṛpyati evam pratyakṣam
translated: he himself, while eating, is satisfied. This is directly perceived.

original: kiṃ ca prajādibhiśca /🔽tejaḥ śarīrasthā dīptirujjvalatvaṃ prāgalbhyaṃ vā /
analyzed: kim ca prajā ādibhiḥ ca  tejaḥ śarīra sthā dīptiḥ ujjvala tvam prāgalbhyam vā
translated: And also by offspring, etc.🔽Splendour is the radiance in the body, or the state of being bright and shining, or the state of being bold and confident.

analyzed: brahmavarcasam vṛtta svādhyāya nimittam tejaḥ
translated: Holy lustre is the splendour that results from good conduct and the study of the Veda.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya ekonaviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Nineteenth Section in the Fifth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha yāṃ dvitīyāṃ juhuyāt tāṃ juhuyād vyānāya svāheti /
analyzed: atha yām dvitīyām juhuyāt tām juhuyāt vyānāya svāhā iti
translated: Then the second oblation he should offer with 'To Vyāna Svâhâ!'

analyzed: vyānaḥ tṛpyati
translated: Vyâna is satisfied.

analyzed: vyāne tṛpyati śrotram tṛpyati
translated: When Vyâna is satisfied, the ear is satisfied.

original: śrotre tṛpyati candramās tṛpyati /🔽candramasi tṛpyati diśas tṛpyanti /
analyzed: śrotre tṛpyati candramāḥ tṛpyati  candramasi tṛpyati diśaḥ tṛpyanti
translated: When the ear is satisfied, the moon is satisfied.🔽When the moon is satisfied, the quarters are satisfied.

original: dikṣu tṛpyantīṣu yat kiṃca diśaś candramāś cādhitiṣṭhanti tat tṛpyati /
analyzed: dikṣu tṛpyantīṣu yat kiṃca diśaḥ candramāḥ ca adhitiṣṭhanti tat tṛpyati
translated: When the quarters are satisfied, whatever the quarters and the moon rule is satisfied.

original: tasyānu tṛptiṃ tṛpyati prajayā paśubhir annādyena tejasā brahmavarcaseneti //
analyzed: tasya anu tṛptim tṛpyati prajayā paśubhiḥ annādyena tejasā brahmavarcasena iti
translated: By its satisfaction he is satisfied with offspring, with cattle, with food, with lustre, with holy lustre.

original: atha yāṃ dvitīyāṃ caturthīṃ pañcamīmiti samānam //
analyzed: atha yām dvitīyām caturthīm pañcamīm iti samānam
translated: Then the second, the fourth, the fifth oblation he should offer in the same way.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya viṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Twentieth Section in the Fifth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha yāṃ tṛtīyāṃ juhuyāt tāṃ juhuyād apānāya svāheti /
analyzed: atha yām tṛtīyām juhuyāt tām juhuyāt apānāya svāhā iti
translated: Then the third oblation he should offer with 'To Apâna Svâhâ!'

analyzed: apānaḥ tṛpyati  apāne tṛpyati vāc tṛpyati
translated: Apâna is satisfied.🔽When Apâna is satisfied, speech is satisfied.

analyzed: vāci tṛpyantyām agniḥ tṛpyati
translated: When speech is satisfied, fire is satisfied.

analyzed: agnau tṛpyati pṛthivī tṛpyati
translated: When fire is satisfied, the earth is satisfied.

original: pṛthivyāṃ tṛpyantyāṃ yat kiṃ ca pṛthivī cāgniś cādhitiṣṭhatas tat tṛpyati /
analyzed: pṛthivyām tṛpyantyām yat kim ca pṛthivī ca agniḥ ca adhitiṣṭhataḥ tat tṛpyati
translated: When the earth is satisfied, whatever is supported by the earth and fire is satisfied.

original: tasyānutṛptiṃ tṛpyati prajayā paśubhir annādyena tejasā brahmavarcaseneti //
analyzed: tasya anu tṛptim tṛpyati prajayā paśubhiḥ annādyena tejasā brahmavarcasena iti
translated: By its satisfaction, one is satisfied with offspring, cattle, food, radiance, and spiritual glory.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya ekaviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Twenty-first Section of the Fifth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha yāṃ caturthīṃ juhuyāt tāṃ juhuyāt samānāya svāheti /
analyzed: atha yām caturthīm juhuyāt tām juhuyāt samānāya svāhā iti
translated: Then one should offer the fourth oblation with Svāhā to Samāna.

analyzed: samānaḥ tṛpyati  samāne tṛpyati manaḥ tṛpyati
translated: Samāna is satisfied.🔽When Samāna is satisfied, the mind is satisfied.

original: manasi tṛpyati parjanyas tṛpyati /🔽parjanye tṛpyati vidyut tṛpyati /
analyzed: manasi tṛpyati parjanyaḥ tṛpyati  parjanye tṛpyati vidyut tṛpyati
translated: When the mind is satisfied, Parjanya is satisfied.🔽When Parjanya is satisfied, lightning is satisfied.

original: vidyuti tṛpyantyāṃ yat kiṃ ca vidyuc ca parjanyaś cādhitiṣṭhatas tat tṛpyati /
analyzed: vidyuti tṛpyantyām yat kim ca vidyut ca parjanyaḥ ca adhitiṣṭhataḥ tat tṛpyati
translated: When lightning is satisfied, whatever is supported by lightning and Parjanya is satisfied.

original: tasyānu tṛptiṃ tṛpyati prajayā paśubhir annādyena tejasā brahmavarcaseneti //
analyzed: tasya anu tṛptim tṛpyati prajayā paśubhiḥ annādyena tejasā brahmavarcasena iti
translated: By its satisfaction, one is satisfied with offspring, cattle, food, radiance, and spiritual glory.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya dvāviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Twenty-second Section of the Fifth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha yām pañcamīṃ juhuyāt tāṃ juhuyāt udānāya svāheti /
analyzed: atha yām pañcamīm juhuyāt tām juhuyāt udānāya svāhā iti
translated: Then one should offer the fifth oblation with Svāhā to Udāna.

analyzed: udānaḥ tṛpyati
translated: Udāna is satisfied.

original: udāne tṛpyati tvak tṛpyati tvaci tṛpyantyāṃ vāyus tṛpyati /🔽vāyau tṛpyaty ākāśas tṛpyati /
analyzed: udāne tṛpyati tvac tṛpyati tvaci tṛpyantyām vāyuḥ tṛpyati  vāyau tṛpyati ākāśaḥ tṛpyati
translated: When the upward-moving breath is satisfied, the skin is satisfied. When the skin is satisfied, the air is satisfied.🔽When the air is satisfied, space is satisfied.

original: ākāśe tṛpyati yat kiṃca vāyuś cākāśaś cādhitiṣṭhatas tat tṛpyati /
analyzed: ākāśe tṛpyati yat kiṃca vāyuḥ ca ākāśaḥ ca adhitiṣṭhataḥ tat tṛpyati
translated: When space is satisfied, whatever is supported by air and space is satisfied.

original: tasyānu tṛptiṃ tṛpyati prajayā paśubhir annādyena tejasā brahmavarcaseneti //
analyzed: tasya anu tṛptim tṛpyati prajayā paśubhiḥ annādyena tejasā brahmavarcasena iti
translated: After that, he is satisfied with offspring, cattle, food, splendor, and brahminical glory.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya trayoviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-third section of the fifth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: sa ya idam avidvān agnihotraṃ juhoti yathāṅgārān apohya bhasmani juhuyāt tādṛk tat syāt //
analyzed: sa yaḥ idam a vidvān agnihotram juhoti yathā aṅgārān apohya bhasmani juhuyāt tādṛś tat syāt
translated: One who offers the Agnihotra without knowing this, it would be as if one were to offer on ashes after removing the coals.

analyzed: sa yaḥ kaścid idam vaiśvānara darśanam yathā uktam avidvān san agnihotram
translated: One who, not knowing this teaching on Vaiśvānara,

original: prasiddhaṃ juhoti yathāṅgārānāhutiyogyānapohyānāhutisthāne bhasmani juhuyāttādṛktattulyaṃ🔽tasya tadagnihotrahavanaṃ syādvaiśvānaravido 'gnihotramapekṣyeti prasiddhāgnihotranindayā
analyzed: prasiddham juhoti yathā aṅgārān āhuti yogyān apohya an āhuti sthāne bhasmani juhuyāt tādṛś tat tulyam  tasya tat agnihotra havanam syāt vaiśvānara vidaḥ gnihotram apekṣya iti prasiddha agnihotra nindayā
translated: offers the well-known Agnihotra, it would be as if one were to offer on ashes, the place of non-offering, after removing the coals suitable for the offering. That would be similar to that.🔽That offering of his Agnihotra would be, in comparison to the Agnihotra of one who knows Vaiśvānara,

analyzed: vaiśvānara vidaḥ gnihotram stūyate
translated: by the criticism of the well-known Agnihotra, the Agnihotra of one who knows Vaiśvānara is praised.

original: atha ya etad evaṃ vidvān agnihotraṃ juhoti tasya sarveṣu lokeṣu sarveṣu bhūteṣu sarveṣv ātmasu hutaṃ bhavati //
analyzed: atha yaḥ etat evam vidvān agnihotram juhoti tasya sarveṣu lokeṣu sarveṣu bhūteṣu sarveṣu ātmasu hutam bhavati
translated: Now, he who, knowing this, offers the Agnihotra, for him the offering is made in all the worlds, in all beings, in all the Selfs.

analyzed: atas ca etat viśiṣṭam agnihotram
translated: And for this reason this Agnihotra is superior.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: atha ya etadevaṃ vidvānagnihotraṃ juhoti tasya yathoktavaiśvānaravijñānavataḥ sarveṣu lokeṣvityādyuktārtham /
analyzed: atha yaḥ etat evam vidvān agnihotram juhoti tasya yathā ukta vaiśvānara vijñānavataḥ sarveṣu lokeṣu ityādi ukta artham
translated: Now, he who, knowing this, offers the Agnihotra, for him, who has the knowledge of Vaiśvānara as described, in all the worlds, etc., the meaning of which has been already explained.

analyzed: hutam annam atti iti anayoḥ ekārtha tvāt
translated: Because the meaning of 'he eats the offered food' and this is the same.

original: tad yatheṣīkātūlam agnau protaṃ pradūyetaivaṃ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante ya etad evaṃ vidvān agnihotraṃ juhoti //
analyzed: tat yathā iṣīkā tūlam agnau protam pradūyeta evam ha asya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante yaḥ etat evam vidvān agnihotram juhoti
translated: Just as a cotton ball thrown into a fire would be consumed, so are all his sins consumed, he who, knowing this, offers the Agnihotra.

original: kiñca tadyatheṣīkāyāstūlamagramagnau protaṃ prakṣiptaṃ pradūyeta pradahyeta
analyzed: kiñca tat yathā iṣīkāyāḥ tūlam agram agnau protam prakṣiptam pradūyeta pradahyeta
translated: And just as the topmost part of a cotton plant thrown into a fire would be consumed, would be quickly burnt,

original: kṣipramevaṃ hāsya viduṣaḥ sarvātmabhūtasya sarvānnānāmattuḥ sarve niravaśiṣṭāḥ pāpmāno
analyzed: kṣipram evam ha asya viduṣaḥ sarva ātma bhūtasya sarva annānām attuḥ sarve niravaśiṣṭāḥ pāpmānaḥ
translated: so are all the sins of this wise man, who has become all-Self, who eats all food,

original: dharmādharmākhyā anekajanmasañcitā iha ca prāgjñānotpatterjñānasahabhāvinaśca pradūyante
analyzed: dharma adharma ākhyāḥ aneka janma sañcitāḥ iha ca prāk jñāna utpatteḥ jñāna sahabhāvinaḥ ca pradūyante
translated: the dharmas and adharmas accumulated in many births, here and before the origin of knowledge, and those associated with knowledge, consumed without remainder.

analyzed: pradahyeran vartamāna śarīra ārambhaka pāpma varjam
translated: would be burnt, except for the sin that produces the present body.

analyzed: lakṣyam prati mukta iṣu vat pravṛtta phala tvāt tasya na dāhaḥ
translated: The result of that (sin) has already commenced, like an arrow shot towards a target, so it is not burnt.

analyzed: yaḥ etat evam vidvān agnihotram juhoti bhuṅkte
translated: One who, knowing this thus, offers the Agnihotra, eats.

original: tasmād u haivaṃvid yady api caṇḍālāya ucchiṣṭaṃ prayacchet /
analyzed: tasmāt u ha evaṃvid yadi api caṇḍālāya ucchiṣṭam prayacchet
translated: Therefore, even if one who knows this thus would give the leavings to an outcaste,

original: ātmani haivāsya tad vaiśvānare hutaṃ syād iti /
analyzed: ātmani ha eva asya tat vaiśvānare hutam syāt iti
translated: it would be as if it were offered in his own self, in the Vaiśvānara Agni.

analyzed: tat eṣa ślokaḥ
translated: This is the verse:

analyzed: sa yadi api caṇḍālāya ucchiṣṭa anarhāya ucchiṣṭam prayacchet ucchiṣṭam dadyāt pratiṣiddham ucchiṣṭa dānam
translated: Even if one were to give the leavings, which are unfit to be given as leavings, to an outcaste, one would give the leavings, which is prohibited.

original: yadyapi kuryādātmani haivāsya caṇḍālahehasthe vaiśvānare taddhutaṃ syānnādharmanimittamiti vidyāmeva stauti /
analyzed: yadi api kuryāt ātmani ha eva asya caṇḍāla heha sthe vaiśvānare tat hutam syāt na adharma nimittam iti vidyām eva stauti
translated: Even if one were to do it, it would be as if it were offered in one's own self, in the Vaiśvānara Agni residing in the outcaste's body, not as a result of sin. Thus it praises the knowledge itself.

analyzed: tat etasmin stuti arthe ślokaḥ mantraḥ pi eṣa bhavati
translated: This verse, this mantra, is for the purpose of praising that.

analyzed: yathā iha kṣudhitāḥ bālāḥ mātaram paryupāsate
translated: Just as hungry children here serve their mother,

analyzed: evam sarvāṇi bhūtāni agnihotram upāsata
translated: in the same way all beings serve the Agnihotra.

original: yatheha loke kṣudhitā bubhukṣitā bālā mātaraṃ paryupāsate kadā no mātānnaṃ
analyzed: yathā iha loke kṣudhitāḥ bubhukṣitāḥ bālāḥ mātaram paryupāsate kadā naḥ mātā annam
translated: Just as hungry, famished children in this world serve their mother, thinking When will our mother give us food?

analyzed: prayacchati iti evam sarvāṇi bhūtāni anna ādāni evaṃvidaḥ gnihotram bhojanam upāsate kadā
translated: In this way, all beings, which are food, offer the Agnihotra of eating to one who knows thus. When

analyzed: tu asau bhokṣyate iti
translated: does he eat?

analyzed: jagat sarvam vidvas bhojanena tṛptam bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the entire world becomes satisfied by the eating of the knower.

analyzed: dviruktiḥ adhyāya parisamāpti arthā
translated: The repetition is for the purpose of concluding the chapter.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya caturviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-fourth section in the fifth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣad brāhmaṇe pañcamaḥ adhyāyaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad-Brāhmaṇa.

analyzed: atha ṣaṣṭhaḥ udhyāyaḥ
translated: Now, the sixth chapter.

analyzed: śvetaketuḥ ha āruṇeyaḥ āsa
translated: Śvetaketu Āruṇeya was there.

original: taṃ ha pitovāca śvetaketo vasa brahmacaryam /
analyzed: tam ha pitā uvāca śvetaketo vasa brahmacaryam
translated: His father said to him, Śvetaketu, live the life of a celibate student.

original: na vai somyāsmat kulīno 'nanūcya brahmabandhur iva bhavatīti //
analyzed: na vai somya asmat kulīnaḥ nanūcya brahmabandhuḥ iva bhavati iti
translated: For, dear one, one of our family should not become a Brahmanical bondsman without having studied.

analyzed: śvetaketuḥ ha āruṇeyaḥ āsa ityādi adhyāya sambandhaḥ
translated: Śvetaketu Āruṇeya was there, etc. is connected with the first chapter.

original: sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma tajjalānityuktaṃ kathaṃ tasmājjagadidaṃ jāyate tasminneva ca līyate 'niti ca tenaivetyetadvaktavyam /
analyzed: sarvam khalu idam brahma tat jalān iti uktam katham tasmāt jagat idam jāyate tasmin eva ca līyate ca tena eva iti etat vaktavyam
translated: All this is indeed Brahman, that is born from water, etc. has been said. How is it that this world is born from that, and dissolves into that very same thing? That by which it is to be stated.

original: anantaraṃ caikasminbhukte viduṣi sarvaṃ jagattṛptaṃ bhavatītyuktaṃ tadekatve satyātmanaḥ sarvabhūtasthasyopapadyate nā'tmabhede /
analyzed: anantaram ca ekasmin bhukte viduṣi sarvam jagat tṛptam bhavati iti uktam tat ekatve sati ātmanaḥ sarva bhūta sthasya upapadyate na ātma bhede
translated: And it has been said that when one wise man eats, the whole world becomes satisfied; and this is possible only if the Self is one, existing in all beings, and not if there is diversity of Self.

original: kathaṃ ca tadekatvamiti tadartho 'yaṃ ṣaṣṭho 'dhyāya ārabhyate /
analyzed: katham ca tad ekatvam iti tad arthaḥ yam ṣaṣṭhaḥ dhyāyaḥ ārabhyate
translated: And how is that oneness? For the sake of that, this sixth chapter begins.

analyzed: pitāputra ākhyāyikā vidyāyāḥ sāriṣṭha tva pradarśana arthā
translated: The story of the father and son is for the purpose of showing the excellence of knowledge.

original: śvetaketuriti nāmato hetyaitihyārthaḥ āruṇeyo 'ruṇasya pautra āsa babhūva /
analyzed: śvetaketuḥ iti nāmataḥ ha iti aitihya arthaḥ āruṇeyaḥ ruṇasya pautraḥ āsa babhūva
translated: He whose name was Śvetaketu, the word ha has the sense of tradition, was the grandson of Aruneya, i.e., of Aruna.

original: taṃ putraṃ hā'ruṇiḥ pitā yogyaṃ vidyābhājanaṃ manvānastasyopanayanakālātyayaṃ ca paśyannuvāca he śvetaketo 'nurūpaṃ guruṃ kulasya no gatvā
analyzed: tam putram ha āruṇiḥ pitā yogyam vidyā bhājanam manvānaḥ tasya upanayana kāla atyayam ca paśyan uvāca he śvetaketo nurūpam gurum kulasya naḥ gatvā
translated: That son, the father Āruṇi, considering him fit to be a vessel of knowledge, and seeing the delay in his initiation, said: O Śvetaketu, go to a suitable teacher for our family

analyzed: vasa brahmacaryam
translated: and live the life of celibacy.

original: na caitadyuktaṃ yadasmatkulīno he somyānanūcyānadhītya brahmabandhuriva bhavatīti brāhmaṇānbandhūnvyapadiśati na svayaṃ brāhmaṇavṛtta iti //
analyzed: na ca etat yuktam yat asmad kulīnaḥ he somyān anūcya an adhītya brahmabandhuḥ iva bhavati iti brāhmaṇān bandhūn vyapadiśati na svayam brāhmaṇa vṛttaḥ iti
translated: And this is not proper: That one of our family, O Soma, having not studied after learning, becomes like a Brahman-fettered one, he refers to the Brahmanas as relatives, not himself as one who follows the conduct of a Brahmin.

original: sa ha dvādaśavarṣa upetya caturviṃśativarṣaḥ sarvān vedān adhītya mahāmanā anūcānamānī stabdha eyāya /
analyzed: sa ha dvādaśa varṣaḥ upetya caturviṃśati varṣaḥ sarvān vedān adhītya mahāmanāḥ anūcāna mānī stabdhaḥ eyāya
translated: He, having gone to study at the age of twelve, and having studied all the Vedas and become twenty-four years old, haughty and proud of his learning, came back home.

analyzed: tam ha pitā uvāca
translated: His father said to him:

analyzed: tasya atas pravāsaḥ numīyate pituḥ
translated: From this it is inferred that the father had to go away,

analyzed: yena svayam guṇavān san putram na upaneṣyati
translated: because he would not initiate his own son, though he himself was qualified.

original: sa pitroktaḥ śvetaketurha dvādaśavarṣaḥ sannupetyā'cāryaṃ yāvaccatuviṃśativarṣo babhūva
analyzed: sa pitrā uktaḥ śvetaketuḥ ha dvādaśa varṣaḥ san upetya ācāryam yāvat catuviṃśati varṣaḥ babhūva
translated: That Śvetaketu, thus addressed by his father, having gone to the teacher at the age of twelve, remained there till he became twenty-four years old.

original: tāvatsarvānvedāṃścaturo 'pyadhītya tadarthaṃ ca buddhvā mahāmanā mahadgambhīraṃ mano🔽yasyāsamamātmānamanyairmanyamānaṃ mano yasya so 'yaṃ mahāmanāḥ anūcānamānyanūcānamātmānaṃ
analyzed: tāvat sarvān vedān caturaḥ pi adhītya tad artham ca buddhvā mahāmanāḥ mahat gambhīram manaḥ  yasya asamam ātmānam anyaiḥ manyamānam manaḥ yasya saḥ yam mahāmanāḥ anūcānam āni anūcānam ātmānam
translated: During that time, he studied all the four Vedas and understood their meaning. He became haughty, with a great and deep mind.

original: manyata ityevaṃśīlo yaḥ so 'nūcānamānī stabdho 'praṇatasvabhāva eyāya gṛham /
analyzed: manyate iti evaṃśīlaḥ yaḥ saḥ nūcāna mānī stabdhaḥ praṇata svabhāvaḥ eyāya gṛham
translated: He who considers his own self to be unequalled by others, he whose mind is thus, he is called 'mahāmana'. He was proud of his learning, thinking himself to be a great scholar.

original: tamevaṃbhūtaṃ hā'tmano 'nanurūpaśīlaṃ stabdhaṃ māninaṃ putraṃ dṛṣṭvā pitovāca saddharmāvatāracikīrṣayā /
analyzed: tam evaṃbhūtam ha ātmanaḥ nanurūpa śīlam stabdham māninam putram dṛṣṭvā pitā uvāca saddharma avatāra cikīrṣayā
translated: He who was of such a nature, haughty and conceited, having seen his son of such a character, not befitting himself, the father said to him, with a desire to make him enter the true dharma.

original: śvetaketo yannivadaṃ mahāmanā anūcānamānī stabdhaścāsi kaste 'tiśayaḥ prāpta upādhyāyāt /
analyzed: śvetaketo yat nivadam mahāmanāḥ anūcāna mānī stabdhaḥ ca asi kaḥ te tiśayaḥ prāptaḥ upādhyāyāt
translated: O Śvetaketu, since you are so conceited, proud of your learning, and arrogant, what special knowledge have you gained from your teacher?

original: utāpi tamādeśamādiśyata ityādeśaḥ kevalaśāsrācāryopadeśagamyamityetadyena vā paraṃ brahmā'diśyate sa ādeśastamaprākṣyaḥ pṛṣṭavānasyācāryam
analyzed: uta api tam ādeśam ādiśyate iti ādeśaḥ kevala śāsra ācārya upadeśa gamyam iti etat yena vā param brahma ādiśyate saḥ ādeśaḥ tam aprākṣyaḥ pṛṣṭavān asya ācāryam
translated: And even if you have been taught that instruction which is to be learned by the teacher's instruction alone, you have asked your teacher about it.

original: śvetaketo yan nu somyedaṃ mahāmanā anūcānamānī stabdho 'si /
analyzed: śvetaketo yat nu somya idam mahāmanāḥ anūcāna mānī stabdhaḥ si
translated: O Śvetaketu, since you are so conceited, proud of your learning, and arrogant,

original: uta tam ādeśam aprākṣyaḥ yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavaty amataṃ matam avijñātaṃ vijñātam iti /
analyzed: uta tam ādeśam aprākṣyaḥ yena a śrutam śrutam bhavati a matam matam a vijñātam vijñātam iti
translated: have you asked about that instruction by which the unheard becomes heard, the unthought becomes thought, the unknown becomes known?

original: kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bhavatīti //🔽tamādeśaṃ viśinaṣṭiyenā'deśena śrutenāśrutamapyanyacchataṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamatarkitaṃ tarkitaṃ bhavatyavijñānaṃ vijñātamaniścitaṃ
analyzed: katham nu bhagavaḥ saḥ ādeśaḥ bhavati iti  tam ādeśam viśinaṣṭi yena ādeśena śrutena aśrutam api anyat śatam bhavati amatam matam atarkitam tarkitam bhavati avijñānam vijñātam aniścitam
translated: How is that instruction, O revered one?

analyzed: niścitam bhavati iti
translated: He specifies that instruction by which, when heard, the unheard becomes heard, the unthought becomes thought, the unknown becomes known, the uncertain becomes certain.

original: sarvānapi vedānadhātya sarvaṃ cānyadvedyamadhigamyāpyakṛtārtha eva bhavati yāvadātmatattvaṃ na jānātītyākhyāyikāto 'vagamyate /
analyzed: sarvān api vedān adhātya sarvam ca anyat vedyam adhigamya api akṛtārthaḥ eva bhavati yāvat ātma tattvam na jānāti iti ākhyāyikātaḥ vagamyate
translated: Having mastered all the Vedas and understood all other knowable things, one is still not accomplished until one knows the truth of the Self, as is understood from the narrative.

original: tadetadadbhutaṃ śrutvā'hakathaṃ nvetadaprasiddhamanyavijñānenānyadvijñātaṃ bhavatītyevaṃ manvānaḥ pṛcchati kathaṃ nu kena prakāreṇa he bhagavaḥ
analyzed: tat etat adbhutam śrutvā āha katham nu etat aprasiddham anya vijñānena anyat vijñātam bhavati iti evam manvānaḥ pṛcchati katham nu kena prakāreṇa he bhagavaḥ
translated: Having heard this wonderful statement, he thinks, How is it that something unknown is known through the knowledge of something else? Thinking thus, he asks: How, O revered one,

analyzed: saḥ ādeśaḥ bhavati iti
translated: does that instruction come about?

original: yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ vijñātaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yathā somya ekena mṛd piṇḍena sarvam mṛd mayam vijñātam syāt
translated: Just as, my dear, by one lump of clay, everything made of clay would be known,

original: vācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttikety eva satyam //
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam
translated: speech is the beginning, modification is a name, clay is indeed the truth.

original: yathā sa ādeśo bhavati tacchṛṇu he somya /
analyzed: yathā saḥ ādeśaḥ bhavati tat śṛṇu he somya
translated: Listen, my dear, how that instruction comes about.

original: yathā loka ekena mṛtpiṇḍena ghaṭaśarāvādikāraṇabhūtena vijñātena sarvamanyadvikārajātaṃ mṛnmayaṃ mṛdvikārajātaṃ vijñātaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yathā loke ekena mṛd piṇḍena ghaṭa śarāva ādi kāraṇa bhūtena vijñātena sarvam anyat vikāra jātam mṛd mayam mṛd vikāra jātam vijñātam syāt
translated: Just as in the world, by one lump of clay, which is the cause of pots, water jars, etc., if everything else made of clay, the class of modifications of clay, were to be known.

original: kathaṃ mṛtpiṇḍe kāraṇe vijñāte kāryamanyadvijñātaṃ syāt /
analyzed: katham mṛd piṇḍe kāraṇe vijñāte kāryam anyat vijñātam syāt
translated: How, when the cause, the lump of clay, is known, could the effect, something else, be known?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: kāraṇena ananya tvāt kāryasya
translated: Because the effect is not different from the cause.

analyzed: yat manyase nyasmin vijñāte nyat na jñāyate iti
translated: You think that when one thing is known, another is not known.

analyzed: satyam evam syāt
translated: This is true, it would be so.

analyzed: yadi anyat kāraṇāt kāryam syāt na tu evam anyat kāraṇāt kāryam
translated: If the effect were different from the cause, but the effect is not different from the cause at all.

original: kathaṃ tarhidaṃ loka idaṃ kāraṇamayasya vikāra iti /
analyzed: katham tarhi idam loke idam kāraṇa mayasya vikāraḥ iti
translated: How then is this world the modification of that cause?

analyzed: śṛṇu
translated: Listen.

original: vācā'rambhaṇaṃ vāgārambhaṇaṃ vāgālambanamityetat /🔽ko 'sau vikāro nāmadheyaṃ nāmaiva nāmadheyaṃ svārthe dheyapratyayaḥ /
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vāc ārambhaṇam vāc ālambanam iti etat  kaḥ sau vikāraḥ nāmadheyam nāma eva nāmadheyam svārthe dheya pratyayaḥ
translated: It is a mere verbal designation, a mere verbal reference.🔽What is called modification is merely a name. The suffix 'dheyapratyaya' is used in its own sense.

original: vāgālambanamātraṃ nāmaiva kevalaṃ na vikāro nāma vastvasti paramārthato mṛttiketyeva tu mṛttiketyeva tu mṛttikaiva satyaṃ vastvasti //
analyzed: vāc ālambana mātram nāma eva kevalam na vikāraḥ nāma vastu asti paramārthataḥ mṛttikā iti eva tu mṛttikā iti eva tu mṛttikā eva satyam vastu asti
translated: It is mere verbal reference, merely a name. There is no real entity called modification. Only earth is the real entity.

original: yathā somyaikena lohamaṇinā sarvaṃ lohamayaṃ vijñātaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yathā somya ekena loha maṇinā sarvam loha mayam vijñātam syāt
translated: Just as, dear one, by a single piece of iron, all that is made of iron would be known.

original: vācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ loham ity eva satyam //
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam loham iti eva satyam
translated: Modification is a mere verbal designation, iron alone is the truth.

original: yathā saumyaikena lohamaṇinā suvarṇapiṇḍena sarvamanyadvikārajātaṃ kaṭakamukuṭakeyūrādi vijñātaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yathā saumya ekena loha maṇinā suvarṇa piṇḍena sarvam anyat vikāra jātam kaṭaka mukuṭa keyūra ādi vijñātam syāt
translated: Just as, dear one, by a single piece of gold, a lump of gold, all the other modifications like bracelet, crown, earring, etc. would be known.

analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam ityādi samānam
translated: The rest is the same as before.

original: yathā somyaikena nakhanikṛntanena sarvaṃ kārṣṇāyasaṃ vijñātaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yathā somya ekena nakha nikṛntanena sarvam kārṣṇāyasam vijñātam syāt
translated: Just as, dear one, by a single nail-cutter, all that is made of iron would be known.

original: vācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ kṛṣṇāyasam ity eva satyam /
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam kṛṣṇāyasam iti eva satyam
translated: Modification is a mere verbal designation, iron alone is the truth.

analyzed: evam somya saḥ ādeśaḥ bhavati iti
translated: Thus, my dear, is that instruction.

original: na vai nūnaṃ bhagavantas ta etad avediṣuḥ /
analyzed: na vai nūnam bhagavantaḥ te etat avediṣuḥ
translated: Verily, revered sir, they did not know that.

original: yad dhy etad avediṣyan kathaṃ me nāvakṣyan /🔽iti bhagavāṃs tv eva me bravītv iti /
analyzed: yat hi etat avediṣyan katham me na avakṣyan  iti bhagavān tu eva me bravītu iti
translated: For if they had known it, how could they have failed to tell me?🔽Therefore, revered sir, do you tell me.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: To him who said this, he said: 'So it is, my dear.'

analyzed: yathā saumya ekena nakha nikṛntanena upalakṣitena kṛṣṇāyasa piṇḍena iti arthaḥ
translated: As, my dear, by one finger-ring, which is the distinguishing mark of a lump of black iron,

analyzed: sarvam kārṣṇāyasam kṛṣṇāyasa vikāra jātam vijñātam syāt
translated: all that is made of black iron, the whole class of products of black iron, would be known;

analyzed: samānam anyat
translated: the rest is the same.

analyzed: aneka dṛṣṭānta upādānam dārṣṭāntika āreka bheda anugama artham dṛḍha pratīti artham ca
translated: The citing of many similes is for the purpose of following the various aspects of the illustrated matter and for the purpose of firm understanding.

original: evaṃ somya sa ādeśo yo mayokto bhavatītyuktavati pitaryāhetaro na vai nūnaṃ bhagavantaḥ pūjāvanto guravo mama ye ta etadyadbhavaduktaṃ vastu
analyzed: evam somya saḥ ādeśaḥ yaḥ mayā uktaḥ bhavati iti uktavati pitari āha itaraḥ na vai nūnam bhagavantaḥ pūjāvantaḥ guravaḥ mama ye te etat yat bhavat uktam vastu
translated: Thus, my dear, is that instruction which has been imparted by me. When the father said this, the other said: Verily, revered sir, they did not know that, the revered teachers of mine who were worshipped.

analyzed: na avediṣuḥ na vijñātavantaḥ nūnam
translated: For if they had known it, how could they have failed to tell me?

original: yadyadi hyavediṣyan viditavanta etadvastu kathaṃ me guṇavate bhaktāyānugatāya nāvakṣyannoktavantastenāhaṃ manye na viditavanta iti /
analyzed: yat yadi hi avediṣyan viditavantaḥ etat vastu katham me guṇavate bhaktāya anugatāya na avakṣyan na uktavantaḥ tena aham manye na viditavantaḥ iti
translated: For, if they had known this thing, how is it that they did not tell me, who am devoted to them, who follow them, and who am endowed with good qualities? Therefore, I think they did not know it.

analyzed: a vācyam api guroḥ nyagbhāvam avādīt punar guru kulam prati preṣaṇa bhayāt
translated: Out of fear of being sent back to his teacher's house, he again spoke of his teacher's contempt, which should not have been spoken of.🔽Therefore, O Lord, tell me that thing by knowing which I shall become omniscient.

original: ato bhagavāṃstveva me mahyaṃ tadvastu yena sarvajñatvaṃ jñātena me syāttadbravītu kathayatvityuktaḥ pitovāca tathāstu saumyeti //
analyzed: atas bhagavān tu eva me mahyam tat vastu yena sarvajña tvam jñātena me syāt tat bravītu kathayatu iti uktaḥ pitā uvāca tathā astu saumya iti
translated: Thus addressed, the Lord said, Let it be so, O gentle one.

original: iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭhādhyāyasya prathamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ🔽sad eva somyedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam /
analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya prathamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ  sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam
translated: Thus ends the first section of the sixth chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.🔽O Somya, this was indeed Being in the beginning, one only, without a second.

original: tad dhaika āhur asad evedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam /
analyzed: tat ha eke āhuḥ asat eva idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam
translated: Some say that in the beginning this was indeed Non-being, one only, without a second.

analyzed: tasmāt asataḥ sat jāyata
translated: From that Non-being Being was born.

original: sadeva sadityastitāmātraṃ vastu sūkṣmaṃ nirviśeṣaṃ sarvagatamekaṃ nirañjanaṃ niravayavaṃ vijñānaṃ yadavagamyate sarvavedāntebhyaḥ
analyzed: sat eva sat iti astitā mātram vastu sūkṣmam nirviśeṣam sarva gatam ekam nirañjanam niravayavam vijñānam yat avagamyate sarva vedāntebhyaḥ
translated: The Being is indeed the subtle, undifferentiated, all-pervading, one, unstained, partless knowledge which is understood from all the Vedāntas.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ vadhāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: The word eva (indeed) is for the purpose of restriction.

analyzed: kim tat avadhriyate iti āha
translated: What is that which is restricted? It is said:

analyzed: idam jagat nāma rūpa kriyāvat vikṛtam upalabhyate yat tat sat eva āsīt iti āsīt śabdena sambadhyate
translated: This universe, which is perceived as having names, forms, and actions, existed as mere Being. This is connected with the word was.

analyzed: kadā sat eva idam āsīt iti ucte
translated: When it is said In the beginning this was mere Being,

analyzed: agre jagataḥ prāk utpatteḥ
translated: it means before the creation of the universe.

analyzed: kim na idānīm idam yat yena agre āsīt iti viśeṣyate
translated: If it is qualified as what was before, why is it not so now?

analyzed: na katham tarhi viśeṣaṇam
translated: No. Then how is it qualified?

original: idānīmapīdaṃ sadeva kintu nāmarūpaviśeṣaṇavadidaṃśabdabuddhiviṣayaṃ cetīdaṃ ca bhavati /
analyzed: idānīm api idam sat eva kintu nāma rūpa viśeṣaṇavat idam śabda buddhi viṣayam ca iti idam ca bhavati
translated: Now also this is mere Being, but it has names and forms, and is the object of the word this and the intellect. This is how it is.

analyzed: prāk utpatteḥ tu agre kevala sat śabda buddhi mātra gamyam eva iti sat eva idam agre āsīt iti avadhāryate
translated: But before creation, in the beginning, it was known only by the word Being and the intellect. Thus it is determined that in the beginning this was mere Being.

original: na hi prāgutpatternāmavadrūpavadvedamiti grahītuṃ śakyaṃ vastu suṣuptakāla iva /
analyzed: na hi prāk utpatteḥ nāmavat rūpavat vā idam iti grahītum śakyam vastu suṣupta kāle iva
translated: For before creation, it is not possible to apprehend an entity as having a name or form, like at the time of deep sleep.

original: yathā suṣuptādutthitaḥ sattvamātramavagacchati suṣupte sanmātrameva kevalaṃ vastviti tathā prāgutpatterityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā suṣuptāt utthitaḥ sattva mātram avagacchati suṣupte sat mātram eva kevalam vastu iti tathā prāk utpatteḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that just as one, on waking from deep sleep, understands mere existence, that in deep sleep there was only mere Being as the entity, so it was before creation.

original: yathedamucyate loke pūrvāhne ghaṭādi sisṛkṣuṇā kulālena mṛtpiṇḍaṃ prasāritamupalabhya
analyzed: yathā idam ucyate loke pūrvāhne ghaṭa ādi sisṛkṣuṇā kulālena mṛd piṇḍam prasāritam upalabhya
translated: As is said in the world, a potter desiring to create a pot etc. in the forenoon perceives a lump of clay stretched out,

original: grāmāntaraṃ gatvā pratyāgato 'parāhne tatraiva ghaṭaśarāvādyanekabhedabhinnaṃ kāryamupalabhya
analyzed: grāma antaram gatvā pratyāgataḥ parāhne tatra eva ghaṭa śarāva ādi aneka bheda bhinnam kāryam upalabhya
translated: Having gone to another village and returned in the afternoon, he observes there the same effect, divided into many kinds such as pots, bowls, etc.,

original: mṛdevedaṃ ghaṭaśarāvādi kevalaṃ pūrvāhne āsīditi tathehāpyucyate sadevedamagra āsīditi /
analyzed: mṛdā iva idam ghaṭa śarāva ādi kevalam pūrvāhne āsīt iti tathā iha api ucyate sat eva idam agre āsīt iti
translated: and says This was only clay in the form of pots, bowls, etc., in the morning. Similarly, it is said here This existed as Being in the beginning.

analyzed: ekam eva iti
translated: One only.

analyzed: sva kārya patitam anyat na asti iti ekam eva iti ucyate
translated: It is said to be one only because there is nothing else fallen into its own effect.

analyzed: advitīyam iti
translated: Without a second.

analyzed: mṛd vyatirekeṇa mṛdaḥ yathā anyat ghaṭa ādi ākāreṇa pariṇamayitṛ kulāla ādi nimitta kāraṇam dṛṣṭam
translated: Just as a potter, the instrumental cause that transforms clay into the form of pots, etc., is seen as a cause different from clay,

original: tathā sadvyatirekeṇa sataḥ sahakārikāraṇaṃ dvitīyaṃ vastvantaraṃ prāptaṃ pratiṣidhyate 'dvitīyamiti /
analyzed: tathā sat vyatirekeṇa sataḥ sahakāri kāraṇam dvitīyam vastu antaram prāptam pratiṣidhyate dvitīyam iti
translated: in the same way, a second entity, a cooperating cause, of Being, apart from Being, is denied, saying without a second.

analyzed: na asya dvitīyam vastu antaram vidyate iti advitīyam
translated: It is without a second because there is no other entity as its second.

analyzed: nanu veśeṣika pakṣe sat sāmānādhikaramyam sarvasya upapadyate  dravya guṇa ādiṣu sat śabda buddhi anuvṛtteḥ
translated: But even in the Vaiśeṣika view, the identity of locus of Being is possible for everything.🔽Because the word and the concept of Being continue in substances, qualities, etc.

analyzed: sat dravyam sat guṇaḥ sat karma ityādi darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen that Being is a substance, Being is a quality, Being is an action, and so on.

original: satyamevaṃ syādidānīṃ prāgutpattestu naivedaṃ kāryaṃ sadevā'sīdityabhyupagamyate vaiśeṣikaiḥ prāgutpatteḥ kāryasyāsattvābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: satyam evam syāt idānīm prāk utpatteḥ tu na eva idam kāryam sat eva āsīt iti abhyupagamyate vaiśeṣikaiḥ prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya asattva abhyupagamāt
translated: This would be true, but the Vaiśeṣikas admit that before creation this world was not existent, because they admit that before creation the effect did not exist.

analyzed: na ca ekam eva sat advitīyam prak utpatteḥ icchanti
translated: And they do not hold that the one existent, without a second, existed before creation.

analyzed: tasmāt vaiśeṣika parikalpitāt sataḥ nyat kāraṇam idam sat ucyate mṛd ādi dṛṣṭāntebhyaḥ
translated: Therefore, this cause is said to be existent, different from the existent imagined by the Vaiśeṣikas, due to the examples of clay and so on.

original: tattatra haitasminprāgutpattervastunirūpaṇa eke vaināśikā āhurvastu nirūpayanto 'satsadabhāvamātraṃ prāgutpatteridaṃ jagadekamevāgre 'dvitīyamāsīditi
analyzed: tat tatra ha etasmin prāgutpatteḥ vastu nirūpaṇe eke vaināśikāḥ āhuḥ vastu sat sat abhāva mātram prāk utpatteḥ idam jagat ekam eva agre dvitīyam āsīt iti
translated: There, in this description of the entity before creation, some nihilists, describing the entity, say that before creation this world was non-existent, mere absence of existence, and was originally one without a second.

analyzed: sat abhāva mātram hi prāk utpatteḥ tattvam kalpayanti bauddhāḥ
translated: For the Buddhists imagine that before creation its reality is mere absence of existence.

analyzed: na tu sat pratidvandvi vastu antaram icchanti
translated: But they do not accept a real entity as its opposite.

original: yathā saccāsaditi gṛhyamāmaṃ yathābhūtaṃ tadviparītaṃ tattvaṃ bhavatīti naiyāyikāḥ /
analyzed: yathā sat ca asat iti gṛhyamāmam yathābhūtam tad viparītam tattvam bhavati iti naiyāyikāḥ
translated: As the Naiyāyikas say, What is grasped as existent and non-existent becomes reality in a way contrary to that.

original: nanu sadabhāvamātraṃ prāgutpatteścedabhipretaṃ vaināśikaiḥ kathaṃ prāgutpatteridamāsīdasadekamevādvitīyaṃ ceti kālasambandhaḥ saṃkhyāsambandho
analyzed: nanu sat abhāva mātram prāk utpatteḥ ced abhipretam vaināśikaiḥ katham prāk utpatteḥ idam āsīt asat ekam eva advitīyam ca iti kāla sambandhaḥ
translated: If the Vāiśeṣikas mean to assert that mere non-existence of an existent thing is the state of things prior to their production, how is it that they speak of the relation of time, the relation of number,

analyzed: dvitīya tvam ca ucyate taiḥ
translated: and non-duality, saying, ‘Prior to production this was non-existent, one without a second’?

analyzed: bāḍham na yuktam teṣām bhāva abhāva mātram abhyupagacchatām
translated: It is true that it is not proper for them who admit mere existence and non-existence.

analyzed: asattava mātra abhyupagamaḥ pi ayuktaḥ eva abhyupagantuḥ anabhyupagama anupapatteḥ
translated: The admission of mere non-existence is also improper, because it is impossible for the admitter not to admit.

analyzed: idānīm abhyupagantā abhyupagamyate na prāk utpatteḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the admitter is admitted now, not prior to production, it is not so.

original: prāgutpatteḥ sadabhāvasya pramāṇābhāvāt prāgutpatterasadevetikalpanānupapattiḥ /🔽nanu kathaṃ vastvākṛteḥ śabdārthatve 'sadekamevādvitīyamitipadārthavākyārthopapatt iḥ /
analyzed: prāk utpatteḥ sat abhāvasya pramāṇa abhāvāt prāk utpatteḥ asat eva iti kalpanā anupapattiḥ  nanu katham vastu ākṛteḥ śabda artha tve sat ekam eva advitīyam iti padārtha vākyārtha upapatt iḥ
translated: Because there is no proof of the non-existence of an existent thing prior to production, the assumption that it was non-existent prior to production is impossible.🔽If it be said that how, in the case of the denotation of the form of a thing by a word, is the meaning of the words ‘asat’, ‘ekam’, ‘advitīyam’ possible?

analyzed: tad anupapattau ca idam vākyam apramāṇam prasajyeta iti ca iti
translated: And if that is impossible, this sentence becomes a non-means of knowledge, it is not so.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ  sat grahaṇa nivṛtti paratvāt vākyasya
translated: This is not a fault.🔽Because the sentence is meant to negate the grasping of existence.

analyzed: sat iti ayam tāvat śabdaḥ sat ākṛti vācakaḥ
translated: This word ‘sat’ is a denoter of the form of existence always.

analyzed: ekam eva advitīyam iti etau ca sat śabdena samāna adhikaraṇau
translated: The two statements One without a second and That existed have the same subject as the word Sat.

original: tathedamāsīditi ca /🔽tatra nañ sadvākye prayuktaḥ sadvākyamevāvalambya sadvākyārthaviṣayāṃ buddhiṃ sadekamevādvitīyamidamāsīdityevaṃlakṣaṇāṃ
analyzed: tathā idam āsīt iti ca  tatra sat vākye prayuktaḥ sat vākyam eva avalambya sat vākya artha viṣayām buddhim sat ekam eva advitīyam idam āsīt iti evaṃlakṣaṇām
translated: Similarly, This existed.🔽There, the negative particle used in the sentence Sat relies on the sentence Sat itself and turns the mind towards the meaning of the sentence Sat, which has the characteristic of Sat, One without a second, This existed.

analyzed: tatas sat vākya arthān nivartayati aśva ārūḍhaḥ śvam tad abhimukha viṣayān nivartayati tadvat
translated: Then it turns away from the meaning of the sentence Sat, just as a rider on a horse, relying on the horse, turns the horse away from its objective.

analyzed: na tu punar sat abhāvam eva abhidhatteḥ
translated: But it does not again express the non-existence of Sat.

analyzed: atas puruṣasya viparīta grahaṇa nivṛtti artha param idam asat eva ityādi vākyam prayujyate
translated: Therefore, this sentence Asat etc. is used with the purpose of turning away the person's contrary grasping.

original: darśayitvā hi viparītagrahaṇaṃ tato nivartayituṃ śakyata ityarthavattvādasadādivākyasya śrautatvaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ ca siddhamityadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: darśayitvā hi viparīta grahaṇam tatas nivartayitum śakyate iti arthavat tvāt asat ādi vākyasya śrauta tvam prāmāṇyam ca siddham iti adoṣaḥ
translated: For, having shown the contrary grasping, it can be turned away. Thus, because the sentence Asat etc. has meaning, its audibility and authoritativeness are established. This is not a fault.

analyzed: tasmāt asataḥ sarva abhāva rūpāt sat vidyamānam ajāyata samutpannam
translated: Therefore, from Asat, which is of the form of the non-existence of all, Sat, which exists, was born, was produced.

original: aḍabhāvaśchāndasaḥ //🔽kutas tu khalu somyaivaṃ syād iti hovāca /
analyzed: aṭ abhāvaḥ chāndasaḥ  kutas tu khalu somya evam syāt iti ha uvāca
translated: The absence of a is Vedic.🔽But, my dear, how could this be? he said.

analyzed: katham asataḥ sat jāyeta
translated: How could the existent be born from the non-existent?

original: sat tv eva somyedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam //🔽tadetadviparītagrahaṇaṃ mahāvaināśikapakṣaṃ darśayitvā pratiṣedhatikutastu
analyzed: sat tu eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam  tat etat viparīta grahaṇam mahā vaināśika pakṣam darśayitvā pratiṣedhati kutas tu
translated: But, verily, this, my dear, was in the beginning, being only one, without a second.

original: pramāṇātkhalu he somyaivaṃ syādasataḥ sajjāyatetyevaṃ kuto bhavenna kutaścitpramāṇādevaṃ🔽sambhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: pramāṇāt khalu he somya evam syāt asataḥ sat jāyata iti evam kutas bhavet na kutaścid pramāṇāt evam  sambhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Having thus shown the view of the great nihilists, which is the opposite of this, he refutes it. From what evidence, indeed, my dear, could this be so, that the existent is born from the non-existent? How could this be so? From no evidence whatsoever. This is the meaning.

original: yadapi bījopamarde 'ṅkuro jāyamāno dṛṣṭo 'bhāvadeveti tadapyabhyupagamaviruddhaṃ teṣām /
analyzed: yat api bīja upamarde ṅkuraḥ jāyamānaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ bhāva deva iti tat api abhyupagama viruddham teṣām
translated: Even what is seen, that a sprout is born when the seed is destroyed, that is also contrary to their acceptance.

original: katham /🔽ye tāvadbījāvayavā bījasaṃsthānaviśiṣṭāste 'ṅkure 'pyanuvartanta eva na teṣāmupamarde 'ṅkurajanmani /
analyzed: katham  ye tāvat bīja avayavāḥ bīja saṃsthāna viśiṣṭāḥ te ṅkure pi anuvartante eva na teṣām upamarde ṅkura janmani
translated: How?🔽Those parts of the seed that are distinguished by the shape of the seed continue in the sprout as well. There is no destruction of them in the birth of the sprout.

original: yatpunarbījākārasaṃsthānaṃ tadbījāvayavavyatirekeṇa vastubhūtaṃ na vaināśikairabhyupagamyate yadaṅkurajanmanyupamṛdyeta /
analyzed: yat punar bīja ākāra saṃsthānam tat bīja avayava vyatirekeṇa vastu bhūtam na vaināśikaiḥ abhyupagamyate yat aṅkura janmani upamṛdyeta
translated: But the shape of the seed, which is a real entity separate from the parts of the seed, is not accepted by the nihilists as something that could be destroyed in the birth of the sprout.

original: atha tadastyavayavavyatiriktaṃ vastubhūtaṃ tathā ca satyabhyupagamavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: atha tat asti avayava vyatiriktam vastu bhūtam tathā ca satī abhyupagama virodhaḥ
translated: If it exists as a real entity separate from the parts, then there is a contradiction with their acceptance.

analyzed: atha saṃvṛtya abhyupagatam bīja saṃsthāna rūpam upamṛdyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the form of the shape of the seed, which is accepted conventionally, is destroyed,

analyzed: kā iyam saṃvṛtiḥ nāma kim asau abhāvaḥ uta
translated: What is this so-called conventional? Is it non-existence or existence?
If it is non-existence, there is no example.

analyzed: atha bhāvaḥ tathā api na abhāvāt aṅkura utpattiḥ bīja avayavebhyaḥ hi aṅkura utpattiḥ
translated: Even if it is existence, the sprout does not arise from non-existence, but from the parts of the seed.

analyzed: avayavāḥ api upamṛdyante iti ced na
translated: If you say the parts are also destroyed, no.

analyzed: tad avayaveṣu tulya tvāt
translated: Because it is the same for the parts of that.

original: yathā vaināśikānāṃ bījasaṃsthānarūpo 'vayavī nāsti tathāvayavā apīti teṣāmapyupamardānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: yathā vaināśikānām bīja saṃsthāna rūpaḥ vayavī na asti tathā avayavāḥ api iti teṣām api upamarda anupapattiḥ
translated: Just as for the annihilationists there is no whole in the form of the shape of the seed, so the parts also do not exist. Therefore, for them also destruction is not possible.

original: bījāvayavānāmapi sūkṣmāvayavāstadavayavānāmapyanye sūkṣmatarāvayavā ityevaṃ prasaṅgasyānivṛtteḥ sarvatropamardānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: bīja avayavānām api sūkṣma avayavāḥ tad avayavānām api anye sūkṣmatara avayavāḥ iti evam prasaṅgasya anivṛtteḥ sarvatra upamarda anupapattiḥ
translated: The parts of the seed also have subtler parts, and those parts also have even subtler parts. Thus, since the consequence is not averted, destruction is not possible everywhere.

original: sadbuddhyanuvṛtteḥ sattvānivṛttiśceti sadvādināṃ sata eva sadutpattiḥ setsyati /
analyzed: sat buddhi anuvṛtteḥ sattva anivṛttiḥ ca iti sat vādinām sataḥ eva sat utpattiḥ setsyati
translated: And because the notion of existence continues, existence is not averted. Thus, for the proponents of existence, the arising of existence from existence will be established.

analyzed: na tu asat vādinām dṛṣṭāntaḥ asti asataḥ sat utpatteḥ
translated: But for the proponents of non-existence, there is no example of the arising of existence from non-existence.

analyzed: mṛd piṇḍāt ghaṭa utpattiḥ dṛśyate sat vādinām tad bhāve bhāvāt tad abhāve ca abhāvāt
translated: For the proponents of existence, the arising of the pot from the lump of clay is seen, because it exists when that exists and does not exist when that does not exist.

original: yadyabhāvādeva ghaṭa utpadyeta ghaṭārthinā mṛtpiṇḍo nopādīyeta /
analyzed: yadi abhāvāt eva ghaṭaḥ utpadyeta ghaṭa arthinā mṛd piṇḍaḥ na upādīyeta
translated: If the pot were to arise from non-existence alone, one seeking a pot would not take up a lump of clay.

analyzed: abhāva śabda buddhi anuvṛttiḥ ca ghaṭa ādau prasajyeta
translated: And the application of the words and ideas of non-existence would follow in the case of a pot, etc.

analyzed: na tu etat asti atas na asataḥ sat utpattiḥ
translated: But this is not so. Therefore, there is no origination of the existent from the non-existent.

analyzed: yat api āhuḥ mṛd buddhiḥ ghaṭa buddheḥ nimittam iti mṛd buddhiḥ ghaṭa buddheḥ kāraṇam ucyate
translated: As for what they say - The idea of clay is the cause of the idea of the pot - the idea of clay is said to be the cause of the idea of the pot,

original: na tu paramārthata eva mṛdghaṭo vāstīti tadapi mṛdbuddhirvidyamānā vidyamānāyā eva
analyzed: na tu paramārthataḥ eva mṛd ghaṭaḥ vā asti iti tat api mṛd buddhiḥ vidyamānā vidyamānāyāḥ eva
translated: but it is not that the clay and the pot really exist. Even that - the existing idea of clay

analyzed: ghaṭa buddheḥ kāraṇam iti na asataḥ sat utpattiḥ
translated: is the cause of the existing idea of the pot. Therefore, there is no origination of the existent from the non-existent.

analyzed: mṛd ghaṭa buddhyoḥ nimitta naimittika tayā ānantarya mātram na tu kārya kāraṇatvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the idea of clay and the idea of the pot are merely sequential due to being cause and effect, but not actually cause and effect, that is not so.

analyzed: buddhīnām nairantarye gamyamāne vaināśikānām bahis dṛṣṭānta abhāvāt
translated: When the sequence of ideas is understood, the nihilists have no external examples.

original: ataḥ kutastu khalu somyaivaṃ syāditi hovāca kathaṃ kena prakāreṇāsataḥ sajjāyeteti /
analyzed: atas kutas tu khalu somya evam syāt iti ha uvāca katham kena prakāreṇa asataḥ sat jāyeta iti
translated: Therefore, From what, verily, could this be so? he said. How, in what manner, could the existent be born from the non-existent?

analyzed: asataḥ sat utpattau na kaścid api dṛṣṭānta prakāraḥ sti iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no example whatsoever for the origination of the existent from the non-existent.

analyzed: evam asat vādi pakṣam unmadhya upasaṃharati sattvā iva somya idam agre āsīt iti sva pakṣa siddhim
translated: Thus, having refuted the view of the non-existence proponents, he concludes by establishing his own view, Verily, my dear, this existed in the beginning as Being alone.

original: nanu sadvādino 'pi sataḥ sadutpadyata iti naiva dṛṣṭānto 'sti /
analyzed: nanu sat vādinaḥ sataḥ sat utpadyate iti na eva dṛṣṭāntaḥ sti
translated: But even for the proponents of existence, there is no example of existence arising from existence.

analyzed: ghaṭāt ghaṭa antara utpatti adarśanāt
translated: Because the arising of another pot from a pot is not seen.

original: satyamevaṃ na sataḥ sadantaramutpadyate kiṃ tarhi sadeva saṃsthānāntareṇāvatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: satyam evam na sataḥ sat antaram utpadyate kim tarhi sat eva saṃsthāna antareṇa avatiṣṭhate
translated: It is true that another existence does not arise from existence. But rather, existence itself remains in a different form.

analyzed: yathā sarpaḥ kuṇḍalī bhavati
translated: Just as a snake becomes coiled.

analyzed: yathā ca mṛd cūrṇa piṇḍa ghaṭa kapāla ādi prabhedaiḥ
translated: And just as clay remains in the forms of powder, lump, pot, potsherd, etc.

analyzed: yadi evam sat eva sarva prakāra avastham prāk utpatteḥ idam āsīt iti
translated: If that is so, how can it be said that this existed before creation, when existence itself remains in all forms?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: nanu na śrutaṃ tvayā sadevetyava dhāraṇamidaṃśabdavācyasya kāryasya /
analyzed: nanu na śrutam tvayā dhāraṇam idam śabda vācyasya kāryasya
translated: Has it not been heard by you that this is a restriction of the word this denoting the effect, that it is existence itself?

analyzed: prāptam tarhi prāk utpatteḥ asat eva āsīt na idam śabda vācyam idānīm idam jātam iti  na
translated: Then it follows that before creation, it was indeed non-existence, not denoted by the word this. Now this is born. No.

analyzed: sataḥ eva idam śabda buddhi viṣaya tayā avasthānāt yathā mṛdā iva piṇḍa ghaṭa ādi śabda buddhi viṣaya tvena avatiṣṭhate tadvat
translated: Because existence itself remains as the object of the word this and the cognition, just as clay remains as the object of the words and cognitions of lump, pot, etc.

original: nanu yathā mṛdvastvevaṃ piṇḍaghaṭādyapi tadvatsadbuddheranyabuddhiviṣayatvātkāryasya sato 'nyadvastvantaraṃ syātkāryajātaṃ yathāśvādgauḥ /🔽piṇḍaghaṭādīnāmitaretaravyabhicāre 'pi mṛttvāvyabhicārāt /
analyzed: nanu yathā mṛd vastu evam piṇḍa ghaṭa ādi api tadvat sat buddheḥ anya buddhi viṣaya tvāt kāryasya sataḥ nyat vastu antaram syāt kārya jātam yathā aśvāt gauḥ  piṇḍa ghaṭa ādīnām itaretara vyabhicāre pi mṛd tva avyabhicārāt
translated: But just as the substance clay is so also the pot, lump, etc. are. Because the effect is the object of a different cognition than the cognition of existence, the aggregate of effects would be a different substance, like a cow from a horse.🔽Even though the pot, lump, etc. differ from each other, they do not differ from clay.

original: yadyapi ghaṭaḥ piṇḍaṃ vyabhicarati piṇḍaśca ghaṭaṃ tathāpi mṛttavaṃ na vyabhicaratastasmānmṛnmātraṃ piṇḍaghaṭau /
analyzed: yadi api ghaṭaḥ piṇḍam vyabhicarati piṇḍaḥ ca ghaṭam tathā api mṛd tavam na vyabhicarataḥ tasmāt mṛd mātram piṇḍa ghaṭau
translated: Although the pot differs from the lump and the lump from the pot, they do not differ from the nature of clay. Therefore, the pot and lump are mere clay.

analyzed: vyabhicarati tu aśvam gauḥ aśvaḥ vā gām
translated: But a horse differs from a cow and a cow from a horse.

analyzed: tasmāt mṛd ādi saṃsthāna mātram ghaṭa ādayaḥ
translated: Therefore, the pot, etc. are merely the arrangement of clay, etc.

analyzed: evam sat saṃsthāna mātram idam sarvam iti yuktam prāk utpatteḥ  sadā eva iti
translated: Thus, it is proper to say that this entire universe is merely the arrangement of existence prior to creation.

original: vācārambhaṇamātratvādvikārasaṃsthānamātrasya /🔽nanu niravayavaṃ satniṣkalaṃ niṣkriyaṃ śāntaṃ niravadyaṃ nirañjanaṃdivyo hyamūrtaḥ
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇa mātra tvāt vikāra saṃsthāna mātrasya  nanu niravayavam sat niṣkalam niṣkriyam śāntam niravadyam nirañjanam divyaḥ hi amūrtaḥ
translated: Only existence means that the pot, etc. are merely the arrangement of the effect, because they are mere verbal expressions.🔽But how can the arrangement of effects be logically possible for existence, which is partless, without parts, without action, tranquil, faultless, and free from passion, and is indeed divine and incorporeal,

original: puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaityādiśrutibhyo niravayavasya sataḥ kathaṃ vikārasaṃsthānamupapadyate /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ sa bāhya abhyantaraḥ hi aja etyādi śrutibhyaḥ niravayavasya sataḥ katham vikāra saṃsthānam upapadyate
translated: and is unborn, both internal and external, according to the Upanishadic texts? How can the arrangement of effects be logically possible for partless existence?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: rajju ādi avayavebhyaḥ sarpa ādi saṃsthāna vat buddhi pārikalpitebhyaḥ sat avayavebyaḥ vikāra saṃsthāna upapatteḥ
translated: Just as the form of a snake, etc. is imagined by the intellect from the parts of a rope, etc., so the form of modification is possible from the real parts.

original: vācā'rambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyamevaṃ sadeva satyamiti śruteḥ /
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam evam sat eva satyam iti śruteḥ
translated: The modification is a mere verbal designation, the name clay is real, existence is real in the same way, according to the Vedic text Existence alone is Truth.

analyzed: ekam eva advitīyam paramārthataḥ idam buddhi kāle pi
translated: One without a second is ultimately real, even at the time of the cognition of this.

analyzed: tat aikṣata
translated: That [existence] desired [to create the world].

analyzed: bahu syām prajāyeya iti  tat tejaḥ sṛjata
translated: It thought, Let me become many, let me be born.🔽It created fire.

analyzed: tat tejaḥ aikṣata
translated: That fire desired [to create the world].

analyzed: bahu syām prajāyeya iti
translated: It thought, Let me become many, let me be born.

analyzed: tat apaḥ sṛjata
translated: It created water.

original: tasmād yatra kva ca śocati svedate vā puruṣas tejasa eva tad adhy āpo jāyante //🔽tatsadaikṣatekṣāṃ darśanaṃ kṛtavat /
analyzed: tasmāt yatra kva ca śocati svedate vā puruṣaḥ tejasaḥ eva tat adhi āpaḥ jāyante  tat sat aikṣata īkṣām darśanam kṛta vat
translated: Therefore, wherever a person grieves or sweats, water is born from fire alone.🔽It [existence] desired [to create the world]. Desire is the act of desiring.

analyzed: atas ca na pradhānam sāṃkhya parikalpitam jagat kāraṇam
translated: And therefore, the pradhāna postulated by the Sāṃkhyas is not the cause of the world.

analyzed: pradhānasya acetana tva abhyupadamāt
translated: Because the pradhāna is accepted as being non-intelligent.

analyzed: idam tu sat cetanam īkṣitṛ tvāt
translated: But this [existence] is intelligent, because it is the seer.

original: tatkathamaikṣatetyāhabahu prabhūtaṃ syāṃ bhaveyaṃ prajāyeta prakarṣeṇotpadyeya /
analyzed: tat katham aikṣata iti āha bahu prabhūtam syām bhaveyam prajāyeta prakarṣeṇa utpadyeya
translated: How did it desire? It said, I would be many, abundant, be born, be born with excellence.

original: yathā mṛdghaṭādyākareṇa yathā vā rajjavādi sarpādyākāreṇa buddhiparikalpitena /🔽asadeva tarhi sarvaṃ yadgṛhyate rajjuriva sarpādyākāreṇa buddhiparikalpitena /
analyzed: yathā mṛd ghaṭa ādi ākareṇa yathā vā rajjavādi sarpa ādi ākāreṇa buddhi parikalpitena  asat eva tarhi sarvam yat gṛhyate rajjuḥ iva sarpa ādi ākāreṇa buddhi parikalpitena
translated: Just as a clay pot is imagined by the intellect to have the form of a pot, or just as a rope, etc. is imagined by the intellect to have the form of a snake, etc.🔽Then everything that is grasped is unreal, like a rope imagined by the intellect to have the form of a snake, etc.

original: asadeva tarhi sarvaṃ yadgṛhyate rajjuriva sarpādyākareṇa / na /
analyzed: asat eva tarhi sarvam yat gṛhyate rajjuḥ iva sarpa ādi ākareṇa na
translated: Then everything that is grasped is unreal, like a rope imagined by the intellect to have the form of a snake, etc. No.

analyzed: sataḥ eva dvaita bhedena anyathā gṛhyamāṇa tvāt na asattvam kasyacid kvacid iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say that nothing is non-existent anywhere, because it is grasped differently as having the form of duality.

original: yathā sato 'nyadvastvantaraṃ parikalpya punastasyaiva prāgutpatteḥ pradhvaṃsāccordhvamasattvaṃ
