analyzed: tat etat ha asya pituḥ uktam manaḥ ādīnām anna ādi maya tvam vijajñau vijñātavān śvetaketuḥ
translated: Śvetaketu, the son, understood, i.e., knew, this which was said by his father, that the mind, etc., are made of food, etc.

analyzed: dvis abhyāsaḥ trivṛt karaṇa prakaraṇa samāpti arthaḥ
translated: The repetition twice is for the purpose of concluding the section on the creation of the three.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya saptamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the seventh section of the sixth chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: uddālako hāruṇiḥ śvetaketuṃ putram uvāca svapnāntaṃ me somya vijānīhīti /
analyzed: uddālakaḥ ha āruṇiḥ śvetaketum putram uvāca svapna antam me somya vijānīhi iti
translated: Uddālaka Āruṇi said to his son Śvetaketu, My dear, know the end of sleep.

original: yatraitat puruṣaḥ svapiti nāma satā somya tadā saṃpanno bhavati /
analyzed: yatra etat puruṣaḥ svapiti nāma satā somya tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati
translated: When a person sleeps, then, my dear, he becomes united with Being.

analyzed: svam api itas bhavati
translated: He goes into his own.

analyzed: tasmāt enam svapiti iti ācakṣate
translated: Therefore they call him sleeping,

analyzed: svam hi api itas bhavati
translated: for he goes into his own.

original: yasminmanasi jīvenā'tmanānupraviṣṭā parā devatā'darśa iva puruṣaḥ pratibimbena jalādiviṣviva ca sūryādayaḥ pratibimbaiḥ /
analyzed: yasmin manasi jīvena ātmanā anupraviṣṭā parā devatā ādarśaḥ iva puruṣaḥ pratibimbena jalāt iva ca sūrya ādayaḥ pratibimbaiḥ
translated: In that mind, into which the individual soul has entered as the supreme deity, just as a man in a mirror or the sun, etc., in water and other reflecting surfaces, with their reflections.

analyzed: tat manaḥ nna mayam tejaḥ ṃ mayābhyām vāc prāṇābhyām saṃgatam adhigatam
translated: That mind, consisting of food, united with speech and breath, both consisting of light, has been obtained.

original: yanmayo yatsthaśca jīvo mananadarśanaśravaṇādivyāvahārāya kalpate taduparame ca svaṃ devatārūpameva pratipadyate /
analyzed: yad mayaḥ yad sthaḥ ca jīvaḥ manana darśana śravaṇa ādi vyāvahārāya kalpate tad uparame ca svam devatā rūpam eva pratipadyate
translated: The individual soul, which is of the nature of that (Brahman), and which is situated in that (Brahman), is fit for the purposes of thought, sight, hearing, and so on; and when that (Brahman) ceases, it attains its own nature, which is of the form of the deity.

original: taduktaṃ śrutyantaredhyāyatīva lelāyatīva sadhīḥ svapno bhūtvemaṃ lokamatikrāmatisa vā āyamātmā brahma vijñānamayo manomayaityādi /
analyzed: tat uktam śruti antare dhyāyati iva lelāyati iva sa dhīḥ svapnaḥ bhūtvā imam lokam atikrāmati sa vai ā ayam ātmā brahma vijñāna mayaḥ manaḥ maya etyādi
translated: It is said in another scripture: As if meditating, as if moving, the wise one, becoming dream, passes beyond this world. This very self is Brahman, consisting of knowledge, consisting of mind, etc.

analyzed: svapnena śārīram ityādi
translated: By dream, the embodied one etc.

analyzed: prāṇan eva prāṇaḥ nāma bhavati ityādi ca
translated: By breathing, he becomes what is called 'breath' etc.

original: tasyāsya manaḥsthasya mana ākhyāṃ gatasya manaupaśamadvāreṇendriyaviṣayebhyo nivṛttasya
analyzed: tasya asya manaḥ sthasya manaḥ ākhyām gatasya manaḥ upaśama dvāreṇa indriya viṣayebhyaḥ nivṛttasya
translated: When this one, the individual soul, situated in the mind, having attained the name of mind, has turned away from the objects of the senses by the means of the cessation of the mind,

original: yasyāṃ parasyāṃ devatāyāṃ svātmabhātāyāṃ yadavasthānaṃ tatputrāyā'cikhyāsuruddālako
analyzed: yasyām parasyām devatāyām sva ātma bhātāyām yat avasthānam tat putrāya ācikhyāsuḥ uddālakaḥ
translated: in that supreme deity, which has become one's own self, that state - Uddālaka, desiring to teach his son,

analyzed: ha kila aruṇiḥ śvetaketum putram uvāca uktavān
translated: indeed said, spoke to his son Śvetaketu.

original: svapnāntaṃ svapnamadhyaṃ svapna iti darśanavṛtteḥ svapnasyā'khyā tasya madhyaṃ svapnāntaṃ suṣuptamityetat /
analyzed: svapnāntam svapnamadhyam svapnaḥ iti darśana vṛtteḥ svapnasya ākhyā tasya madhyam svapnāntam suṣuptam iti etat
translated: The end of sleep, the middle of dream - this is called dream because of the occurrence of seeing. The middle of that is the end of sleep, which is deep sleep.

analyzed: athavā svapna antam svapna sa tattvam iti arthaḥ tatra api arthāt suṣuptam eva bhavati
translated: Or, the meaning is that the end of sleep is the true nature of sleep; and even there, sleep is only deep sleep,

analyzed: svam api itas bhavati iti vacanāt
translated: because of the statement that he goes to his own.

analyzed: na hi anyatra suṣuptāt svam apītim jīvasya icchanti brahma vidaḥ
translated: For the knowers of Brahman do not desire the individual soul to go to its own except in deep sleep.

original: tatra hyādarśāpanayane puruṣapratibimbi ādarśagato yathā svameva puruṣamapīto bhavatyevaṃ🔽mana ādyuparame caitanyapratibimbarūpeṇa jīvenā'tmanā manasi praviṣṭā nāmarūpavyākaraṇāya
analyzed: tatra hi ādarśa apanayane puruṣa pratibimbi ādarśa gataḥ yathā svam eva puruṣam api itas bhavati evam  manaḥ ādi uparame caitanya pratibimba rūpeṇa jīvena ātmanā manasi praviṣṭāḥ nāma rūpa vyākaraṇāya
translated: For just as, when the mirror is removed, the reflection of the person in the mirror goes to its own person,🔽so, when the mind and other sense organs cease to function, the Supreme Deity, which has entered the mind in the form of a reflection of consciousness as the individual soul for the purpose of creating names and forms,

original: parā devatā sā svamevā'tmānaṃ pratipadyate jīvarūpatāṃ mana ākhyāṃ hitvā /
analyzed: parā devatā sā svam eva ātmānam pratipadyate jīva rūpa tām manaḥ ākhyām hitvā
translated: attains its own Self, abandoning the state of being the individual soul called mind.

analyzed: atas suṣuptaḥ eva svapna anta śabda vācyaḥ iti avagamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that deep sleep alone is denoted by the term 'end of sleep'.

original: yatra tu suptaḥ svapnānpaśyati tatsvāpnaṃ darśanaṃ sukhaduḥkhasaṃyuktamiti puṇyāpuṇyayorhi sukhaduḥkhārambhakatvaṃ prasiddham /
analyzed: yatra tu suptaḥ svapnān paśyati tat svāpnam darśanam sukha duḥkha saṃyuktam iti puṇya apuṇyayoḥ hi sukha duḥkha ārambhaka tvam prasiddham
translated: But when one sees dreams while asleep, that dream-seeing is accompanied by pleasure and pain. For it is well-known that merit and demerit are the causes of pleasure and pain.

analyzed: puṇya apuṇyayoḥ ca avidyā kāma upaṣṭambhena eva sukha duḥkha tad darśana kārya ārambhaka tvam upapadyate na anyathā iti avidyā kāma karmabhiḥ saṃsāra hetubhiḥ saṃyukta
translated: And the production of the effects of the experience of pleasure and pain, which are due to the experience of merit and demerit, is possible only when they are supported by Nescience and desire; not otherwise. Thus, the soul is connected with Nescience, desire, and works, which are the causes of the world.

original: eva svapna iti na svamapītā bhavati /
analyzed: eva svapnaḥ iti na svam apītā bhavati
translated: Therefore, it is not in its own nature.

original: ananvāgataṃ puṇyenānanvāgataṃ pāpena tīrṇo hi tadā sarvāñchokānhṛdayasya bhavatitadvā asyaitadaticchandāeṣa parama ānandaityādiśrutibhyaḥ
analyzed: an anvāgatam puṇyena an anvāgatam pāpena tīrṇaḥ hi tadā sarvān śokān hṛdayasya bhavati tat vai asya etat aticchandāḥ eṣa paramaḥ ānanda ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: It is not connected with merit, not connected with demerit. For then all sorrows of the heart are indeed crossed over. This is because of such Vedic texts as This is his supreme bliss.

original: suṣupta eva svaṃ devatārūpaṃ jīvatvavinirmuktaṃ darśayiṣyāmītyāha /
analyzed: suṣupte eva svam devatā rūpam jīva tva vinirmuktam darśayiṣyāmi iti āha
translated: He says, I will show that in deep sleep itself, the soul's own form as a deity, free from the state of being a living being.

original: svapnāntaṃ me mama nigadato he somya vijānīhi vispaṣṭamavadhārayetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: svapna antam me mama nigadataḥ he somya vijānīhi vispaṣṭam avadhāraya iti arthaḥ
translated: O dear one, understand clearly from me who am speaking, the end of sleep. This is the meaning.

analyzed: kadā svapna antaḥ bhavati iti ucyate
translated: When does the end of sleep occur? This is said:

original: yatra yasminkāla etannāma bhavati puruṣasya svapsyataḥ /
analyzed: yatra yasmin kāle etat nāma bhavati puruṣasya svapsyataḥ
translated: When this name occurs for a person who is about to sleep.

analyzed: prasiddham hi loke svapiti iti
translated: For sleeping is well-known in the world.

analyzed: gauṇam ca idam nāma iti āha
translated: And this name is figurative, he says.

original: yadā svapitītyucyate puruṣastadā tasminkāle satā sacchabdavācyayā prakṛtayā devatayā saṃpanno bhavati saṃgata ekībhūto bhavati /
analyzed: yadā svapiti iti ucyate puruṣaḥ tadā tasmin kāle satā sat śabda vācyayā prakṛtayā devatayā saṃpannaḥ bhavati saṃgataḥ ekībhūtaḥ bhavati
translated: When a man is said to be sleeping, then at that time he becomes united, becomes one, with the true, the deity denoted by the word 'sat'.

original: manasi praviṣṭaṃ mana ādisaṃsargakṛtaṃ jīvarūpaṃ parityajya svaṃ sadrūpaṃ yatparamārthasatyamapīto 'pigato bhavati /
analyzed: manasi praviṣṭam manaḥ ādi saṃsarga kṛtam jīva rūpam parityajya svam sat rūpam yat paramārtha satyam api itas pigataḥ bhavati
translated: Having abandoned the form of the individual soul which has entered the mind, created by the contact with the mind and other sense organs, he becomes united with his own true form, which is the ultimate reality.

analyzed: atas tasmāt svapiti iti enam ācakṣate lokikāḥ
translated: Therefore, worldly people call him 'sleeping'.

analyzed: svam ātmānam hi yasmāt apītaḥ bhavati
translated: Because he becomes united with his own self.

original: tataścā'yastānāṃ karaṇānāmanekavyāpāranimittaglānānāṃ svavyāpārebhya uparamo bhavati /🔽śruteścaśrāmyatyeva vākśrāmyati cakṣur ityevamādi /
analyzed: tatas ca a yastānām karaṇānām aneka vyāpāra nimitta glānānām sva vyāpārebhyaḥ uparamaḥ bhavati  śruteḥ ca śrāmyati eva vāc śrāmyati cakṣuḥ iti evamādi
translated: And then there is cessation of the functions of the sense organs, which are fatigued due to the many activities,🔽And the scriptures say that speech becomes fatigued, the eye becomes fatigued, and so on.

original: tathā cagṛhītā vāggṛhītaṃ śrotraṃ gṛhītaṃ manaityevamādīni karaṇāni prāṇagrastāni /
analyzed: tathā ca gṛhītā vāc gṛhītam śrotram gṛhītam manaḥ eti evamādīni karaṇāni prāṇa grastāni
translated: And thus the sense organs, such as speech, hearing, and mind, are grasped,

original: prāṇa eko 'śrānto dehe kulāye yo jāgarti tadā jīvaḥ śramāpanuttaye svaṃ devatārūpamātmānaṃ pratipadyate /
analyzed: prāṇaḥ ekaḥ śrāntaḥ dehe kulāye yaḥ jāgarti tadā jīvaḥ śrama apanuttaye svam devatā rūpam ātmānam pratipadyate
translated: When the one tireless breath, which is awake in the body like a bird, then the individual soul attains its own divine nature in order to remove fatigue.

original: nānyatra svarūpāvasthānācchramāpanodaḥ syāditi yuktā prasiddhirlaukikānāṃ svaṃ hyapīto bhavatīti /
analyzed: na anyatra sva rūpa avasthānāt śrama apanodaḥ syāt iti yuktā prasiddhiḥ laukikānām svam hi api itas bhavati iti
translated: It is proper for people to have the well-known notion that one goes to one's own, since there can be no relief from fatigue except by resting in one's own nature.

original: dṛśyate hi loke jvarādirogagrastānāṃ tadvinirnoke svātmasthānāṃ viśramaṇaṃ tadvadihāpi syāditi yuktam /
analyzed: dṛśyate hi loke jvara ādi roga grastānām sva ātma sthānām viśramaṇam tadvat iha api syāt iti yuktam
translated: For in the world, those afflicted by diseases like fever, when cured, rest in their own selves. Similarly, it is proper to think that it would be so here also.

original: tadyathā śyeno vā suparṇo vā viparipatya śrāntaityādiśruteṣca //
analyzed: tat yathā śyenaḥ vā suparṇaḥ vā viparipatya śrāntaḥ etyādi śruteṣu ca
translated: And because of the Vedic text: Just as a hawk or a bird, flying and tired...

original: sa yathā śakuniḥ sūtreṇa prabaddho diśaṃ diśaṃ patitvānyatrāyatanam alabdhvā bandhanam evopaśrayate /
analyzed: sa yathā śakuniḥ sūtreṇa prabaddhaḥ diśam diśam patitvā anyatra āyatanam a labdhvā bandhanam eva upaśrayate
translated: Just as a bird, tied with a string, flying in all directions, not finding a place elsewhere, resorts to its very bondage.

original: evam eva khalu somya tan mano diśaṃ diśaṃ patitvānyatrāyatanam alabdhvā prāṇam evopaśrayate /
analyzed: evam eva khalu somya tat manaḥ diśam diśam patitvā anyatra āyatanam a labdhvā prāṇam eva upaśrayate
translated: In the same way, my dear, that mind, flying in all directions, not finding a place elsewhere, resorts to the very life-breath.

analyzed: prāṇa bandhanam hi somya manaḥ iti
translated: For the mind, my dear, is indeed bound by the life-breath.

original: tatrāyaṃ dṛṣṭānto yathokter'thesa yathā śakuniḥ pakṣī śakunighātakasya
analyzed: tatra ayam dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā ukta irthā isa yathā śakuniḥ pakṣī śakuni ghātakasya
translated: Here is the illustration for the meaning stated: Just as a bird, caught by a bird-catcher

original: hastagatena sūtreṇa prabaddhaḥ pāśito diśaṃ diśaṃ bandhanamokṣārthī sanpratiśidiśaṃ
analyzed: hasta gatena sūtreṇa prabaddhaḥ pāśitaḥ diśam diśam bandhana mokṣa arthī san pratiśidiśam
translated: bound with a string in his hand, flying in all directions, desiring to be free from bondage, in every direction

analyzed: patitvā anyatra bandhanāt āyatanam āśrayam viśramaṇāya a labdhvā a prāpya bandhanam eva upaśrayate
translated: Having fallen elsewhere, not having obtained, not having reached, a resting place, a support, a place of rest, he resorts to bondage itself.

original: evameva yathāyaṃ dṛṣṭāntaḥ khalu he sobhya tanmanastatprakṛtaṃ poḍaśakalamannopacitaṃ
analyzed: evam eva yathā ayam dṛṣṭāntaḥ khalu he sobhya tat manaḥ tat prakṛtam poḍaśa kalamanna upacitam
translated: Just as this example, O So-and-so, that mind, in its original state, nourished by food consisting of sixteen parts,

original: mano nirdhāritaṃ tatepraviṣṭastatsthastadupalakṣito jīvastanmana iti nirdiśyate mañcākrośanavat /
analyzed: manaḥ nirdhāritam tate praviṣṭaḥ tad sthaḥ tad upalakṣitaḥ jīvaḥ tat manaḥ iti nirdiśyate mañca ākrośana vat
translated: the mind is determined. He who has entered that, who abides in that, who is characterized by that, that individual soul is indicated as the mind, like shouting on a couch.

original: sa mana ākhyopādhirjīvo 'vidyākāmakarmopadiṣṭāṃ diśaṃ diśaṃ sukhaduḥkhādilakṣaṇāṃ jāgratsvapnayoḥ patitvā gatvānubhūyetyarthaḥ /🔽anyatra sadākhyātsvātmana āyatanaṃ viśramaṇasthānamalabdhvā prāṇameva prāṇena sarvakāryakaraṇāśrayeṇopalakṣitā prāṇa ityucyate sadākhyā parā
analyzed: sa manaḥ ākhyā upādhiḥ jīvaḥ vidyā kāma karma upadiṣṭām diśam diśam sukha duḥkha ādi lakṣaṇām jāgrat svapnayoḥ patitvā gatvā anubhūya iti arthaḥ  anyatra sat ākhyāt sva ātmanaḥ āyatanam viśramaṇa sthānam a labdhvā prāṇam eva prāṇena sarva kārya karaṇa āśrayeṇa upalakṣitā prāṇaḥ iti ucyate sat ākhyā parā
translated: That individual soul, the mind as the limiting adjunct, having fallen, having gone, having experienced, the state characterized by happiness, sorrow, etc., in the various directions indicated by ignorance, desire and action, in the waking and dream states,

analyzed: devatā
translated: not having obtained a resting place, a place of rest, other than the Self called Sadā, he resorts to the very life-breath. The life-breath is indicated by the life-breath which is the support of all actions and sense organs. It is called the life-breath. The Supreme Deity called Sadā,

analyzed: prāṇasya prāṇam prāṇa śarīraḥ bhā rūpaḥ etyādi śruteḥ
translated: the life-breath of the life-breath, having the form of light, etc., as stated in the scriptures.

analyzed: atas tām devatām prāṇam prāṇa ākhyām eva upaśrayate
translated: Therefore, he resorts to that Deity, the life-breath, called the life-breath itself.

original: prāṇo bandhanaṃ yasya manasastatprāṇabandhanaṃ hi yasmātsomya manaḥ prāṇopalakṣitadevatāśrayaṃ mana iti tadupalakṣito jīva iti //
analyzed: prāṇaḥ bandhanam yasya manasaḥ tat prāṇa bandhanam hi yasmāt somya manaḥ prāṇa upalakṣita devatā āśrayam manaḥ iti tad upalakṣitaḥ jīvaḥ iti
translated: That mind which has the vital air for its bond, because the mind, my dear, has the vital air for its bond; the mind is what is indicated by the vital air; the individual soul is what is indicated by that.

analyzed: aśanā pipāse me somya vijānīhi iti
translated: Know hunger and thirst, my dear, to be the truth.

original: yatraitat puruṣo 'śiśiṣati nāmāpa eva tad aśitaṃ nayante /
analyzed: yatra etat puruṣaḥ śiśiṣati nāma apaḥ eva tat aśitam nayante
translated: When a person desires to eat, the water carries that food.

original: tad yathā gonāyo 'śvanāyaḥ puruṣanāya ity evaṃ tad apa ācakṣate 'śanāyeti /
analyzed: tat yathā gonāyo śvanāyaḥ puruṣanāyaḥ iti evam tat apaḥ ācakṣate śanāya iti
translated: Just as they call a cow-pen, a horse-pen, a human pen, so they call water the food-pen.

analyzed: tatra etat śuṅgam utpatitam somya vijānīhi
translated: Know that shoot which has sprung up there, my dear.

analyzed: na idam amūlam bhaviṣyati iti
translated: It cannot be without a root.

original: evaṃ svapitināmaprasiddhidvāreṇa yajjīvasya satyasvarūpaṃ jagato mūlaṃ tatputrasya darśayitvā'hānnādikāryakāraṇaparamparayāpi
analyzed: evam yat jīvasya satya svarūpam jagataḥ mūlam tat putrasya darśayitvā āha anna ādi kārya kāraṇa paramparayā api
translated: Thus, by the door of the well-known name of sleep, having shown the son the true nature of the individual soul, which is the root of the world, he (the father) says that he will show the root of the world by the series of causes and effects beginning with food.

analyzed: jagataḥ mūlam sat didarśayiṣuḥ
translated: The truth of hunger and thirst is to be known.

analyzed: aśanā pipāse aśitum icchā aśanā yā lopena
translated: Hunger is the desire to eat, with the elision of the verbal root.

original: pātumicchā pipāsā te aśanāpipāse aśanāpipāsayoḥ satatvaṃ vijānīhītyetat /
analyzed: pātum icchā pipāsā te aśanā pipāse aśanā pipāsayoḥ satatvam vijānīhi iti etat
translated: Thirst is the desire to drink. Hunger and thirst are hunger and thirst. The truth of hunger and thirst is to be known. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yatra yasmin kāle etad nāma puruṣaḥ bhavati
translated: When, at what time, a person has this name.

analyzed: kim
translated: What is that? It desires to eat, wishing to eat.

original: tadā tasya puruṣasya kinimittaṃ nāma bhavatītyāha /
analyzed: tadā tasya puruṣasya kinimittam nāma bhavati iti āha
translated: Then, for what reason does that person have that name? It is said:

original: yattatpuruṣeṇāśitamannaṃ kaṭhinaṃ potā āpo nayante dravīkṛtya rasādibhāvena vipariṇamayante tadā bhuktamannaṃ jīryati /
analyzed: yat tat puruṣeṇa aśitam annam kaṭhinam potāḥ āpaḥ nayante dravīkṛtya rasa ādi bhāvena vipariṇamayante tadā bhuktam annam jīryati
translated: When that food eaten by the person is carried by the waters, making it liquid and transforming it into juice and so on, then the eaten food is digested.

analyzed: atha ca bhavati asya nāma aśiśiṣati iti gauṇam
translated: And then, his name becomes Ashishirshati, which is secondary.

analyzed: jīrṇe hi anne śitum icchati sarvaḥ hi jantuḥ
translated: For when the food is digested, everyone desires to eat.

original: tat tatra apāmaśitanetṛtvādaśanāyā iti nāma prasiddhamityetasminnarthe /🔽yathā gonāyo gāṃ nayatīti gonāya ityucyate gopālaḥ /
analyzed: tat tatra apām aśita netṛ tvāt aśanāyāḥ iti nāma prasiddham iti etasmin arthe  yathā gonāyaḥ gām nayati iti gonāyaḥ iti ucyate gopālaḥ
translated: There, the name Ashana is well-known in this sense, because water carries the food.🔽Just as one who leads cows is called a cow-leader, a cowherd.

analyzed: tathā aśvān nayati iti aśvanāyo śvapālaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Similarly, one who leads horses is called a horse-leader, a horsekeeper.

analyzed: puruṣa nāyaḥ puruṣān nayati iti rājā senāpatiḥ vā
translated: A leader of men, who leads men, is called a king or a general.

original: evaṃ tattadāpa ācakṣate laukikā aśanāyeti visarjanīyalopena /
analyzed: evam tat tat āpaḥ ācakṣate laukikāḥ aśanāya iti visarjanīya lopena
translated: Thus, worldly people call those waters Ashana, with the elision of the visarga.

original: tatraivaṃ satyadbhī rasādibhāvena nītenāśitenānnena niṣpāditamidaṃ śarīraṃ vaṭakaṇikāyāmiva
analyzed: tatra evam satī adbhī rasa ādi bhāvena nītena aśitena annena niṣpāditam idam śarīram vaṭa kaṇikāyām iva
translated: When that is so, this body is produced by that eaten food, carried by water in the form of juice and so on, like a small ball of dough.

original: śuṅgo 'ṅkura utpatita udgatastamimaṃ śuṅgaṃ kāryaṃ śarīrākhyaṃ vaṭādiśuṅgavadutpatitaṃ
analyzed: śuṅgaḥ ṅkuraḥ utpatitaḥ udgataḥ tam imam śuṅgam kāryam śarīra ākhyam vaṭa ādi śuṅga vat utpatitam
translated: The sprout has sprung up, has come forth. Know, O Sobhya, that this sprout, the body, has sprung up, has come forth, like the sprout of a banyan tree, etc.

analyzed: he sobhya vijānīhi
translated: O Sobhya, know this.

analyzed: kim tatra vijñeyam iti ucyate
translated: What is to be known there? It is said:

original: śuṇvidaṃ śuṅgavatkāryatvāccharīraṃ nāmūlaṃ mūlarahitaṃ bhaviṣyatītyukta āha śvetaketuḥ //
analyzed: śuṇu idam śuṅga vat kārya tvāt śarīram na amūlam mūla rahitam bhaviṣyati iti uktaḥ āha śvetaketuḥ
translated: Listen. This body, like a sprout, will be rootless, devoid of a root, because it is an effect. Thus it has been said. Śvetaketu said:

analyzed: tasya kva mūlam syāt anyatra annāt
translated: Where can its root be, other than food?

original: evam eva khalu somyānnena śuṅgenāpo mūlam anviccha /🔽adbhiḥ somya śuṅgena tejo mūlam anviccha /
analyzed: evam eva khalu somya annena śuṅgena apaḥ mūlam anviccha  adbhiḥ somya śuṅgena tejaḥ mūlam anviccha
translated: In the same way, O gentle one, seek the root of water with the sprout of food.🔽With water as the sprout, O gentle one, seek the root of fire.

analyzed: tejasā somya śuṅgena sat mūlam anviccha
translated: With fire as the sprout, O gentle one, seek the root of Being.

original: sanmūlāḥ somyemāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sadāyatanāḥ satpratiṣṭhāḥ //
analyzed: sat mūlāḥ somya imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sat āyatanāḥ sat pratiṣṭhāḥ
translated: O gentle one, all these beings have Being as their root, Being as their abode, and Being as their support.

original: yadyevaṃ samūlamidaṃ śarīraṃ vaṭādiśuṅgavattasyāsya kva mūlaṃ syādbhavedityevaṃ pṛṣṭa āha pitā /
analyzed: yadi evam sa mūlam idam śarīram vaṭa ādi śuṅga vat tasya asya kva mūlam syāt bhavet iti evam pṛṣṭaḥ āha pitā
translated: If this is so, then this body has a root like the sprout of a banyan tree, etc. Where can its root be? Thus asked, the father said:

analyzed: tasya kva mūlam syāt anyatra annāt annam mūlam iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Where can its root be, other than food? The intention is that food is the root.

analyzed: katham
translated: How is it so?

original: aśitaṃ hyannamadbhirdravīkṛtaṃ jāṭhareṇāgninā pacyamānaṃ rasabhāvena pariṇamate /
analyzed: aśitam hi annam adbhiḥ dravīkṛtam jāṭhareṇa agninā pacyamānam rasa bhāvena pariṇamate
translated: For food that is eaten is liquefied by water, cooked by the stomach fire, and transformed into the essence of rasa.

original: rasocchoṇitaṃ śoṇitānmāṃsaṃ māṃsānmedo medaso 'sthīnyasthibhyo majjā majjāyāḥ śukram /
analyzed: rasāt ucchoṇitam śoṇitāt māṃsam māṃsāt medaḥ medasaḥ sthīni asthibhyaḥ majjā majjāyāḥ śukram
translated: From the juice, blood; from blood, flesh; from flesh, fat; from fat, bones; from bones, marrow; from marrow, semen.

original: tathā yoṣidbhuktaṃ cānnaṃ rasādikrameṇaivaṃ pariṇataṃ lohitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tathā yoṣit bhuktam ca annam rasa ādi krameṇa evam pariṇatam lohitam bhavati
translated: Similarly, the food eaten by a woman is transformed into blood in the same sequence of juice, etc.

analyzed: tābhyām śukra śoṇitābhyām anna kāryābhyām saṃyuktābhyām annena eva pratyaham bhujyamānena āpūryamāṇābhyām
translated: The body-sprout, which is rooted in food, is fully accomplished, like a wall being built up with lumps of clay, by those two, the semen and blood, which are the effects of food, being joined together and constantly replenished by the food being eaten every day.

original: kuḍyamiva mṛtpiṇḍaiḥ pratyuhamupacīyamāno 'nnamūlo dehaśuṅgaḥ pariniṣpanna ityarthaḥ /🔽yattu dehaśuṅgo 'nnamūla evameva khalu somyānnena śuhgena kāryabhūtenāpo mūlamannasya śuṅgasyānviccha pratipadyasva /🔽apāmapi vināśotpattimattavācchuṅgatvameveti adbhiḥ sīmya śuṅgena kāryeṇa kāraṇaṃ tejo mūlamanviccha /
analyzed: kuḍyam iva mṛd piṇḍaiḥ pratyuham upacīyamānaḥ nna mūlaḥ deha śuṅgaḥ pariniṣpannaḥ iti arthaḥ  yat tu deha śuṅgaḥ nna mūlaḥ evam eva khalu somya annena śuhgena kārya bhūtena apaḥ mūlam annasya śuṅgasya anviccha pratipadyasva  apām api vināśa utpattimat tavāt śuṅga tvam eva iti adbhiḥ sīmya śuṅgena kāryeṇa kāraṇam tejaḥ mūlam anviccha
translated: The meaning is that the body-sprout, which is rooted in food, is fully accomplished.🔽But, O dear one, just as the body-sprout is rooted in food, in the same way, seek, understand, the water as the root of the food, which is the effect of the food-sprout.🔽Since water also has origination and destruction, it is also a sprout. Therefore, O dear one, with the water-sprout, which is the effect, seek the fire as the cause.

original: tejaso 'pi vināśotpattimattavācchuṅgatvamiti tejasā somya śuṅgena sanmūlamekamevādvitīyaṃ paramārthasatyam /
analyzed: vināśa utpattimat tavāt śuṅga tvam iti tejasā somya śuṅgena sat mūlam ekam eva advitīyam paramārtha satyam
translated: Since fire also has origination and destruction, it is also a sprout. Therefore, O dear one, with the fire-sprout, seek the Being as the root, which is one without a second, the ultimate truth.

original: yasminsarvamidaṃ vācā'rambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyamanṛtaṃ rajjvāmiva sarpādivikalpajātamadhyastamavidyayā
analyzed: yasmin sarvam idam vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam anṛtam rajjvām iva sarpa ādi vikalpa jātam adhyastam avidyayā
translated: In which all this is mere verbal expression, modification, name, and untruth, like the various notions of a snake, etc., superimposed on a rope by Nescience.

original: tadasya jagato mūlamataḥ sanmūlāḥ satkāraṇā he somyemāḥ sthāvarajaṅgamalakṣaṇāḥ sarvāḥ
analyzed: tat asya jagataḥ mūlam atas sat mūlāḥ sat kāraṇāḥ he somya imāḥ sthāvara jaṅgama lakṣaṇāḥ sarvāḥ
translated: That is the root of this world. Therefore, O dear one, all these creatures characterized by the immobile and the moving have their root in Being, their cause is Being.

original: prajā na kevalaṃ sanmūlā evedānīmapi sthitikāle sadāyatanāḥ sadāśrayā eva /
analyzed: prajāḥ na kevalam sat mūlāḥ eva idānīm api sthiti kāle sat āyatanāḥ sat āśrayāḥ eva
translated: Not only do they have their root in Being now at the time of origination, but even at the time of persistence they have Being as their abode, they have Being as their support.

analyzed: nahi mṛdam an āśritya ghaṭa ādeḥ sattvam sthitiḥ vā asti
translated: For, without depending on clay, there is neither existence nor persistence of a pot, etc.

original: ato mṛdvatsanmūtvātprajānāṃ sadāyatanaṃ yāsāṃ tāḥ sadāyatanāḥ prajāḥ /
analyzed: atas mṛdvat sat mūtvāt prajānām sat āyatanam yāsām tāḥ sat āyatanāḥ prajāḥ
translated: Therefore, because of having Being as their root like clay, those creatures which have Being as their abode are the creatures which have Being as their abode.

original: ante ca satpratiṣṭhāḥ sadeva pratiṣṭā layaḥ samāptipavasānaṃ pariśeṣo yāsāṃ tāḥ satpratiṣṭhāḥ //
analyzed: ante ca sat pratiṣṭhāḥ sat eva pratiṣṭhā layaḥ samāpti pavasānam pariśeṣaḥ yāsām tāḥ sat pratiṣṭhāḥ
translated: And in the end they have Being as their support. That which is the support, the resting place, the end, the remainder, of them is Being. Those which have that are the creatures which have Being as their support.

original: atha yatraitat puruṣaḥ pipāsati nāma teja eva tat pītaṃ nayate /
analyzed: atha yatra etat puruṣaḥ pipāsati nāma tejaḥ eva tat pītam nayate
translated: Now, when a person is said to be thirsty, then that very fire carries the water drunk.

original: tad yathā gonāyo 'śvanāyaḥ puruṣanāya ity evaṃ tat teja ācaṣṭa udanyeti /
analyzed: tat yathā gonāyo śvanāyaḥ puruṣanāyaḥ iti evam tat tejaḥ ācaṣṭe udanyā iti
translated: Just as one speaks of a cow-vehicle, a horse-vehicle, a man-vehicle, so it is said that the fire carries the water upwards.

original: tatraitad eva śuṅgam utpatitaṃ somya vijānīhi /
analyzed: tatra etat eva śuṅgam utpatitam somya vijānīhi
translated: There, O dear one, know that very shoot to have sprung up.

analyzed: na idam amūlam bhaviṣyati iti
translated: It will not be without a root.

analyzed: atha idānīm apśuṅga dvāreṇa sataḥ mūlasya anugamaḥ kāryaḥ iti āha
translated: Now, the author proceeds to show the connection of the Root of Being with the sprout in the form of water.

original: yatra yasminkāla etannāma pipāsati pātumicchatīti puruṣo bhavati /
analyzed: yatra yasmin kāle etat nāma pipāsati pātum icchati iti puruṣaḥ bhavati
translated: When, at what time, the person becomes ‘pipāsati’, desirous of drinking.

analyzed: aśiśiṣati iti vat idam api gauṇam eva nāma bhavati
translated: This name also is figurative, like the term ‘aśiṣiṣati’.

original: dravīkṛtasyāśitasyānnasya netrya āpo 'nnaśuṅgaṃ dehaṃ kledayantyaḥ śithilī kuryurabbāhulyādyadi tejasā na śoṣyante /🔽nitarāṃ ca tejasā śoṣyamāṇā svapsu dehabhāvena pariṇamamānāsu pātumicchā puruṣasya jāyate tadā puruṣaḥ pipāsati nāma tadetadāha /🔽teja eva tattadā pītamabādi śoṣayaddehagatalohitaprāṇabhāvena nayate pariṇamayati /
analyzed: dravīkṛtasya aśitasya annasya netryaḥ āpaḥ nna śuṅgam deham kledayantyaḥ śithilī kuryuḥ ap bāhulyāt yadi tejasā na śoṣyante  nitarām ca tejasā śoṣyamāṇā svapsu deha bhāvena pariṇamamānāsu pātum icchā puruṣasya jāyate tadā puruṣaḥ pipāsati nāma tat etat āha  tejaḥ eva tat tadā pītam ap ādi śoṣayat deha gata lohita prāṇa bhāvena nayate pariṇamayati
translated: The water, which is the sprout of food, would moisten the body which is the sprout of food, and make it loose, if it were not dried up by fire.🔽And when the water, being dried up by fire, is being transformed into the form of blood and life in the body, the desire to drink arises in the person. Then the person is said to be ‘pipāsati’. This is what is meant here.🔽That fire, having drunk the water etc., carries them, transforms them into the form of blood and life in the body.

original: tadyathā gonāya ityādi samānamevaṃ tatteja ācaṣṭe loka udanyetyudakaṃ nayatītyudanyam /
analyzed: tat yathā gonāyaḥ ityādi samānam evam tat tejaḥ ācaṣṭe lokaḥ udanyā iti udakam nayati iti udanyam
translated: The people call that fire ‘udan’, which carries the water upwards.

analyzed: udanyā iti iti chāndasam tatra api pūrvavat
translated: The Vedic form is ‘udan’, which is similar to the previous one.

analyzed: apām api etat eva śarīra ākhyam śuṅgam na anyat iti evamādi samānam anyat
translated: The water also has the same sprout in the form of the body, not anything else. The rest is similar.

original: tasya kva mūlaṃ syād anyatrādbhyaḥ /🔽adbhiḥ somya śuṅgena tejo mūlam anviccha /
analyzed: tasya kva mūlam syāt anyatra adbhyaḥ  adbhiḥ somya śuṅgena tejaḥ mūlam anviccha
translated: Where can its root be, other than in water?🔽O Somya, with the sprout of water, seek the root of fire.

analyzed: tejasā somya śuṅgena sat mūlam anviccha
translated: O Somya, with the sprout of fire, seek the root of Being.

original: sanmūlāḥ somyemāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sad āyatanāḥ satpratiṣṭhāḥ /
analyzed: sat mūlāḥ somya imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sat āyatanāḥ sat pratiṣṭhāḥ
translated: O Somya, all these beings have Being as their root, Being as their abode, and Being as their support.

original: yathā nu khalu somyemās tisro devatāḥ puruṣaṃ prāpya trivṛt trivṛd ekaikā bhavati tad uktaṃ purastād eva bhavati /
analyzed: yathā nu khalu somya imāḥ tisraḥ devatāḥ puruṣam prāpya trivṛt trivṛt ekaikā bhavati tat uktam purastāt eva bhavati
translated: O Somya, how is it that these three deities, having reached a person, become threefold each? This has been stated before.

original: asya somya puruṣasya prayato vāṅ manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇas tejasi tejaḥ parasyāṃ devatāyām //
analyzed: asya somya puruṣasya prayataḥ vāc manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇaḥ tejasi tejaḥ parasyām devatāyām
translated: O Somya, when this person is about to die, speech merges into mind, mind into life-breath, life-breath into fire, and fire into the supreme deity.

analyzed: sāmarthyāt tejasaḥ u pi etat eva śarīra ākhyam śuṅgam
translated: By implication, this same body is the sprout of fire.

original: ato 'pśuṅgena dehenā'po mūlaṃ gamyate /🔽adbhiḥ śuṅgena tejo mūlaṃ gamyate /
analyzed: atas pūuṅgena dehena apaḥ mūlam gamyate  adbhiḥ śuṅgena tejaḥ mūlam gamyate
translated: Therefore, with the sprout of water, the body, water is understood to be the root.🔽With the sprout of water, fire is understood to be the root.

analyzed: tejasā śuṅgena sat mūlam gamyate pūrvavat
translated: With the sprout of fire, the root of Being is understood, as before.

original: evaṃ hi tejobannamayasya dehaśuṅgasya vācārambhaṇamātrasyānnādiparamparayā paramārthasatyaṃ
analyzed: evam hi tejaḥ banna mayasya deha śuṅgasya vācā ārambhaṇa mātrasya anna ādi paramparayā paramārtha satyam
translated: Thus, for the body which is a sprout of fire and food, and is mere verbal expression, the ultimate truth is understood by the sequence of food etc., as

original: sanmūlamabhayasaṃtrāsaṃ nirāyāsaṃ sanmūlamanviccheti putraṃ gamayitvāśiśiṣati pipāsatīti🔽nāmaprasiddhidvāreṇa yadanyadihāsminprakaraṇe tejobannānāṃ puruṣeṇopabhujyamānānāṃ
analyzed: sat mūlam abhaya saṃtrāsam nirāyāsam sat mūlam anviccha iti putram gamayitvā aśiśiṣati pipāsati iti  nāma prasiddhi dvāreṇa yat anyat iha asmin prakaraṇe tejaḥ bannānām puruṣeṇa upabhujyamānānām
translated: Having instructed his son to seek a good root, which is free from fear and anxiety, and which is free from trouble, he desires to teach and to make known.🔽By the way of the well-known names, what is to be stated here in this section is the fact that the combination of the effects and organs, the body-sprout, of the fire, water and food, which are being enjoyed by the Purusha,

analyzed: kārya karaṇa saṃghātasya deha śuṅgasya sva jāti asāṃkaryeṇa upacaya kara tvam vaktavyam prāptam
translated: is conducive to nourishment by not mixing with its own kind.

analyzed: tat iha uktam eva draṣṭavyam iti pūrva uktam vyapadiśati
translated: That which is stated here should be seen as already stated. Thus he refers to what was stated earlier.

original: yathā nu khalu yena prakāreṇemāstejobannākhyāstisro devatāḥ puruṣaṃ prāpya trivṛttrivṛdekaikā bhavati taduktaṃ purastādeva bhavatyannamaśitaṃ
analyzed: yathā nu khalu yena prakāreṇa imāḥ tejaḥ banna ākhyāḥ tisraḥ devatāḥ puruṣam prāpya trivṛt trivṛt ekaikā bhavati tat uktam purastāt eva bhavati annam aśitam
translated: Now, indeed, in what manner these three deities called fire, water and food, having reached the Purusha, become threefold each, that has been stated earlier itself, that the food eaten

analyzed: tredhā vidhīyate ityādi
translated: is divided into three parts, and so on.

original: tatraivoktamannādīnāmasitānāṃ ye mavyamā dhātavaste sāptadhātukaṃ śarīramupacinvantītyuktam /
analyzed: tatra eva uktam anna ādīnām asitānām ye mavyamāḥ dhātavaḥ te sāptadhātukam śarīram upacinvanti iti uktam
translated: There itself it is stated that the middlemost essences of the eaten food and so on nourish the body consisting of seven essences.

original: māṃsaṃ bhavati lohitaṃ bhavati majjā bhavatyasthi bhavati ye tvaṇiṣṭhā dhātavo manaḥ
analyzed: māṃsam bhavati lohitam bhavati majjā bhavati asthi bhavati ye tu aṇiṣṭhāḥ dhātavaḥ manaḥ
translated: It becomes flesh, it becomes blood, it becomes marrow, it becomes bone. But the subtlest essences, the mind,

original: prāṇaṃ vācaṃ dehasyāntaḥkaraṇasaṃghātamupacinvantīti coktaṃtanmano bhavati sa prāṇo
analyzed: prāṇam vācam dehasya antaḥkaraṇa saṃghātam upacinvanti iti ca uktam tat manaḥ bhavati sa prāṇaḥ
translated: and the life-breath, speech, and the aggregate of internal organs of the body are accumulated, that becomes the mind, that is the life-breath.

analyzed: bhavati sā vāc bhavati iti
translated: And it has been said that the life-breath, speech, and the aggregate of internal organs of the body are accumulated, that becomes the mind, that becomes the life-breath, that becomes speech.

original: so 'yaṃ prāṇakaraṇasaṃghāto dehe viśīrṇe dehāntaraṃ jīvādhiṣṭhito yena krameṇa pūrvadehātpracyuto
analyzed: saḥ yam prāṇa karaṇa saṃghātaḥ dehe viśīrṇe deha antaram jīva dhiṣṭhitaḥ yena krameṇa pūrva dehāt pracyutaḥ
translated: That aggregate of life-breath organs, when the body is destroyed, goes to another body under the control of the individual soul, in the same order in which it has departed from the previous body.

original: gacchati tadāhāsya he somya puruṣasya prayato mriyamāṇasya vāṅmanasi saṃpadyate manasyupasaṃhriyate /
analyzed: gacchati tat āha asya he somya puruṣasya prayataḥ mriyamāṇasya vāc manasi saṃpadyate manasi upasaṃhriyate
translated: Then he says: My dear, when this person is about to die, speech is merged in mind, it is withdrawn into mind.

analyzed: atha tat āhuḥ jñātayaḥ na vadati iti
translated: Then at that time the relatives say: He is not speaking.

analyzed: manaḥ pūrvakaḥ hi vāc vyāpāraḥ
translated: For the activity of speech is preceded by the mind.

original: yadvai manasā dhyāyati tadvācā vadatiiti śruteḥ /
analyzed: yat vai manasā dhyāyati tat vācā vadati iti śruteḥ
translated: As it is said in the scripture: Whatever one thinks with the mind, that one speaks with the voice.

original: vācyupasaṃhṛtāyāṃ manasi mano mananavyāpāreṇa kevalena vartate /
analyzed: vāci upasaṃhṛtāyām manasi manaḥ manana vyāpāreṇa kevalena vartate
translated: When speech is withdrawn into the mind, the mind functions solely with the activity of thinking.

original: mano 'pi yadopasaṃhriyate tadā manaḥ prāṇe saṃpannaṃ bhavati suṣuptakāla iva tadā pārśvasthā jñātayo na vijānātītyāhuḥ /
analyzed: manaḥ pi yadā upasaṃhriyate tadā manaḥ prāṇe saṃpannam bhavati suṣupta kāle iva tadā pārśva sthāḥ jñātayaḥ na vijānāti iti āhuḥ
translated: When the mind is also withdrawn, then the mind is merged in the life-breath, as in the state of deep sleep. Then the relatives by the side say: He does not know.

original: prāṇaśca tadordhvocchvāsī svātmanyupasaṃhṛtabāhyakaraṇaḥ saṃvargavidyāyāṃ darśanāddhastapādādīnvikṣipanmarmasthānāni nikṛntannana ivotsṛjan
analyzed: prāṇaḥ ca tadā ūrdhva ucchvāsī sva ātmani upasaṃhṛta bāhya karaṇaḥ saṃvarga vidyāyām darśanāt hasta pāda ādīn vikṣipan marma sthānāni nikṛntan anaḥ iva utsṛjan
translated: And then the life-breath rises upwards, the external organs being withdrawn into the self, as is seen in the saṃvarga-vidyā. Throwing off the hands, feet, etc., as if cutting off the vital parts,

analyzed: krameṇa upasaṃhṛtaḥ tejasi sampadyate
translated: it is gradually withdrawn and merges into fire.

original: tadā'hurjñātayo na calatīti mṛto neti vā vicikitsanto dehamālabhamānā uṣṇaṃ copalabhamānā
analyzed: tat āhuḥ jñātayaḥ na calati iti mṛtaḥ na iti vā vicikitsantaḥ deham ālabhamānāḥ uṣṇam ca upalabhamānā
translated: Then the relatives say, He does not move, or doubt whether he is dead or not, touching the body and feeling the heat.

original: deha uṣṇo jīvatīti yadā tadapyauṣṇyaliṅgaṃ teja upasaṃhriyate tadā tattejaḥ parasyāṃ
analyzed: dehaḥ uṣṇaḥ jīvati iti yadā tat api auṣṇya liṅgam tejaḥ upasaṃhriyate tadā tat tejaḥ parasyām
translated: When even that heat-sign is withdrawn and the fire merges into the supreme

analyzed: devatāyām praśāmyati
translated: deity, then that fire is pacified in the supreme deity.

original: tadevaṅkrameṇopasaṃhṛte svamūlaṃ prāpte ca manasi tatstho jīvo 'pi suṣuptakālavannimittopasaṃhārādupasaṃhriyamāṇaḥ
analyzed: tat evaṅkrameṇa upasaṃhṛte sva mūlam prāpte ca manasi tad sthaḥ jīvaḥ pi suṣupta kāla vat nimitta upasaṃhārāt upasaṃhriyamāṇaḥ
translated: Thus, when the mind has been withdrawn in this way and has reached its own root, the individual soul residing in it is also being withdrawn due to the withdrawal of the cause, as in the state of deep sleep.

original: sansatyābhisaṃdhipūrvakaṃ cedupasaṃhriyate sadeva saṃpadyate na punardehāntarāya
analyzed: san satya abhisaṃdhi pūrvakam ced upasaṃhriyate sat eva saṃpadyate na punar deha antarāya
translated: If it is withdrawn with the prior intention of merging, it merges into Being itself, and does not rise again like from deep sleep

analyzed: suṣuptāt iva uttiṣṭhati
translated: to another body.

original: yathā loke sabhaye deśe vartamānaḥ kathañcidivābhayaṃ deśaṃ prāptastadvat /
analyzed: yathā loke sa bhaye deśe vartamānaḥ kathañcid iva abhayam deśam prāptaḥ tadvat
translated: Just as one living in a fearful country somehow reaches a safe country, so is it.

analyzed: itaraḥ tu anātma jñaḥ tasmāt eva mūlāt suṣuptāt iva utthāya mṛtvā punar deha jālam āviśati
translated: The other, however, who is ignorant of the Self, rises from that very root, as it were, from sleep, after death, and again enters the net of bodies.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: He who is this subtle essence, the Self, of all this,

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: that is Truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the Self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, O Revered One.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, my son, he said.

original: yasmānmūlādutthāya dehamāviśati jīvaḥ sa yaḥ sadākhya eṣa ukto 'ṇimāṇubhāvo jagato mūlamaitadātmyametatsadātmā yasya sarvasya
analyzed: yasmāt mūlāt utthāya deham āviśati jīvaḥ sa yaḥ sat ākhyaḥ eṣaḥ uktaḥ ṇima aṇu bhāvaḥ jagataḥ mūlam aitadātmyam etat sat ātmā yasya sarvasya
translated: From which root the individual soul rises and enters the body, that which is called Sat, the subtle essence, is the root of the universe. This is the essence of the Self of all this.

analyzed: tat etat ātma tasya bhāvaḥ aitadātmyam
translated: That is the Self. The essence of that is this essence of the Self.

analyzed: etena sat ākhyena ātmanā ātma vat sarvam idam jagat
translated: By this Self called Sat, this entire universe is pervaded, as if by the Self.

analyzed: na anyaḥ asti asya ātmā saṃsārī
translated: There is no other Self of this transmigrating being.

original: nānyadato 'ti śrotṛityādiśrutyantarāt /🔽yena cā'tmanā'tmavatsarvamidaṃ jagattadeva sadākhyaṃ kāraṇaṃ satyaṃ paramārthasat /
analyzed: na anyat atas ti śrotṛ ityādi śruti antarāt  yena ca ātmanā ātma vat sarvam idam jagat tat eva sat ākhyam kāraṇam satyam paramārtha sat
translated: There is nothing else but that, according to other scriptures.🔽And by that Self, this entire universe is pervaded, as if by the Self. That alone is the true cause, called Sat, which is the ultimate reality.

original: ataḥ sa evā'tmā jagataḥ pratyaksvarūpaṃ satattvaṃ yāthātmyam /
analyzed: atas saḥ eva ātmā jagataḥ pratyak svarūpam sa tattvam yāthātmyam
translated: Therefore, that alone is the true nature, the essence, the Self of the universe.

analyzed: ātma śabdasya nirupapadasya pratyagātmani go ādi śabda vat nirūḍha tvāt
translated: Because the word 'ātman' without any prefix is well-established in the individual self, like the word 'cow'.

original: atastatsattvamasīti he śvetaketo ityevaṃ pratyāyitaḥ putra āhabhūya eva mā bhagavānvijñāpayatu
analyzed: atas tat sattvam asi iti he śvetaketo iti evam pratyāyitaḥ putraḥ āha bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu
translated: Therefore, when he was thus addressed, 'That is your Self, that is your Self', the son said, 'Sir, please explain it to me again.'

original: yadbhavaduktaṃ tatsandigdhaṃ mamāhanyahani sarvāḥ prajāḥ suṣupte satsaṃpadyanta ityetadyena
analyzed: yat bhavat uktam tat sandigdham mama ahani ahani sarvāḥ prajāḥ suṣupte sat saṃpadyante iti etat yena
translated: What you have said, that all beings in deep sleep merge into Being day after day, that is doubtful to me.

analyzed: tat saṃpadya na viduḥ sat sampannāḥ vayam iti
translated: By merging into that, they do not know, 'We have merged into Being.'

analyzed: atas mām pratyāyayatu iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, please explain it to me again by an example that is seen.

analyzed: evam uktaḥ tathā astu somya iti ha uvāca pitā
translated: Thus addressed, the father said, 'So be it, my son.'

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya aṣṭamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eighth section in the sixth chapter of Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: yathā somya madhu madhukṛto nistiṣṭhanti nānātyayānāṃ vṛkṣāṇāṃ rasān samavahāram ekatāṃ rasaṃ gamayanti //
analyzed: yathā somya madhu madhukṛtaḥ nistiṣṭhanti nānātyayānām vṛkṣāṇām rasān samavahāram ekatām rasam gamayanti
translated: Just as, my dear, the honey-makers place the honey, having collected the juices of various trees in different ways, and make them into one juice,

original: yatpṛcchasyahanyahani satsaṃpadya na viduḥ satsaṃpannāḥ sma iti tatkasmādityatra śṛṇu dṛṣṭāntam /
analyzed: yat pṛcchasi ahani ahani sat saṃpadya na viduḥ sat saṃpannāḥ smaḥ iti tat kasmāt iti atra śṛṇu dṛṣṭāntam
translated: as to what you ask, 'Why do they not know, We have merged into Being, when they merge into Being day after day?' listen to the example for that.

original: yathā loke he somya madhukṛto madhu kurvantīti madhukṛto madhukaramakṣikā madhu nistiṣṭhanti madhu niṣpādayanti tatparāḥ santaḥ /
analyzed: yathā loke he somya madhukṛtaḥ madhu kurvanti iti madhukṛtaḥ madhukara makṣikāḥ madhu nistiṣṭhanti madhu niṣpādayanti tad parāḥ santaḥ
translated: As in the world, my dear, the honey-makers make honey. The honey-makers, the honey-bees, make honey, they complete honey, they are intent on that.

original: katham /nānātyayānāṃ nānāgatīnāṃ nānādikkānāṃ vṛkṣāṇāṃ rasānsamavahāraṃ samāhṛtyaikatāmekabhāvaṃ madhutvena rasāngamayanti madhutvamāpādayanti
analyzed: katham nānā atyayānām nānā gatīnām nānā dikkānām vṛkṣāṇām rasān samavahāram samāhṛtya ekatām eka bhāvam madhu tvena rasān gamayanti madhu tvam āpādayanti
translated: How? Having collected the juices of trees of various kinds, of various destinations, of various directions, they bring them to unity, to oneness, they make the juices attain the state of honey, they bring them to the state of honey.

original: te yathā tatra na vivekaṃ labhante 'muṣyāhaṃ vṛkṣasya raso 'smy amuṣyāhaṃ vṛkṣasya raso 'smīti /
analyzed: te yathā tatra na vivekam labhante muṣya aham vṛkṣasya rasaḥ smi amuṣya aham vṛkṣasya rasaḥ smi iti
translated: As they do not attain discrimination there, 'I am the juice of this tree, I am the juice of that tree.'

original: evam eva khalu somyemāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sati saṃpadya na viduḥ sati saṃpadyāmaha iti //
analyzed: evam eva khalu somya imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sati saṃpadya na viduḥ sati saṃpadyāmahe iti
translated: Even so, my dear, all these creatures, becoming united in Being, do not know, 'We are united in Being.'

original: te rasā yathā madhutvenaikatāṃ gatāstatra madhuni vivekaṃ na labhante /
analyzed: te rasāḥ yathā madhu tvena eka tām gatāḥ tatra madhuni vivekam na labhante
translated: Those juices, having become one as honey, do not attain discrimination in that honey.

original: katham / amuṣyāhamāmrasya panasasya vā vṛkṣasya raso 'smīti /
analyzed: katham amuṣya aham āmrasya panasasya vā vṛkṣasya rasaḥ smi iti
translated: How? 'I am the juice of this mango tree, I am the juice of that jackfruit tree.'

original: yathā hi loke bahūnāṃ cetanāvatāṃ sametānāṃ prāṇināṃ vivekalābho bhavatyamuṣyāhaṃ putro 'muṣyāhaṃ naptāsmīti /
analyzed: yathā hi loke bahūnām cetanāvatām sametānām prāṇinām viveka lābhaḥ bhavati amuṣya aham putraḥ muṣya aham naptā asmi iti
translated: For just as in the world, there is attainment of discrimination among many conscious beings who have come together, 'I am the son of this one, I am the grandson of that one.'

original: te ca labdhavivekāḥ santo na saṃkīryante na tathehānekaprakāravṛkṣarasānāmapi madhurāmlatiktakaṭukādīnāṃ madhutvenaikatāṃ gatānāṃ madhurādibhāvena
analyzed: te ca labdha vivekāḥ santaḥ na saṃkīryante na tathā iha aneka prakāra vṛkṣa rasānām api madhura amla tikta kaṭuka ādīnām madhu tvena ekatām gatānām madhura ādi bhāvena
translated: And those, having obtained discrimination, are not confused. But it is not so here. Even of the many kinds of tree juices, sweet, sour, bitter, pungent, etc., which have become one as honey, the discrimination is grasped as sweet, etc.

analyzed: vivekaḥ gṛhyate iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that.

original: yathāyaṃ dṛṣṭānta ityevameva khalu somyemāḥ sarvāḥ prajā ahanyahani sati saṃpadya suṣuptakāle maraṇapralayayośca na vidurna vijānīyuḥ sati
analyzed: yathā ayam dṛṣṭāntaḥ iti evam eva khalu somya imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ ahani ahani sati saṃpadya suṣupta kāle maraṇa pralayayoḥ ca na viduḥ na vijānīyuḥ sati
translated: Just as this is an example, so indeed, O dear one, all these creatures, becoming united with Being day after day, at the time of deep sleep and at the time of death and dissolution, do not know, do not understand, that they are becoming united with Being

analyzed: saṃpadyāmahe iti saṃpannāḥ iti vā
translated: or that they are united.

original: ta iha vyaghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yad yad bhavanti tad ābhavanti //
analyzed: te iha vyaghraḥ vā siṃhaḥ vā vṛkaḥ vā varāhaḥ vā kīṭaḥ vā pataṅgaḥ vā daṃśaḥ vā maśakaḥ vā yat yat bhavanti tat ābhavanti
translated: Here, they become whatever they are born as due to their actions - a tiger, a lion, a wolf, a boar, a worm, a moth, a gadfly, or a mosquito. They become that.

analyzed: yasmāt ca evam ātmanaḥ sat rūpa tām a jñātvā eva sat saṃpadyante
translated: And because in this way they become united with Being without knowing the true nature of the Self,

original: atasta iha loke yatkarmanimittāṃ yāṃ yāṃ jātiṃ pratipannā āsurvyāghrādīnāṃ vyāghro
analyzed: atas te iha loke yad karma nimittām yām yām jātim pratipannāḥ āsuḥ vyāghra ādīnām
translated: therefore they, having assumed whatever birth here in this world due to their actions - a tiger among tigers,

original: 'haṃ siṃho 'hamityevaṃ te tatkarmajñānavāsanāṅkitāḥ santaḥ satpraviṣṭā api tadbhāvenaiva
analyzed: haṃ siṃhaḥ ham iti evam te tad karma jñāna vāsanā aṅkitāḥ santaḥ sat praviṣṭāḥ api tad bhāvena eva
translated: a lion among lions - thus marked by the impressions of the knowledge and actions of that [birth], even though they have entered Being, they become that very [animal].

original: punarābhavanti punaḥ sata āgatya vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo
analyzed: punar ābhavanti punar sataḥ āgatya vyāghraḥ vā siṃhaḥ vā vṛkaḥ vā varāhaḥ vā kīṭaḥ vā pataṅgo
translated: Again they become, again coming back to life, a tiger, a lion, a wolf, a boar, a worm, a fly,

original: vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yadyatpūrvamiha loke bhavanti vabhūvurityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vā daṃśaḥ vā maśakaḥ vā yat yat pūrvam iha loke bhavanti vabhūvuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: a gadfly, or a mosquito. Whatever they were in this world before, that is the meaning.

original: tadeva punarāgatya bhavanti yugasahasrakoṭyantaritāpi saṃsāriṇo jantoryā purā bhāvitā vāsanā sā na naśyatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat eva punar āgatya bhavanti yuga sahasra koṭi antaritā api saṃsāriṇaḥ jantoḥ yā purā bhāvitā vāsanā sā na naśyati iti arthaḥ
translated: They become that very thing again, coming back to it. Even after an interval of thousands of crores of yugas, the latent impressions of beings in saṃsāra do not perish, that is the meaning.

analyzed: yathāprajñam hi saṃbhavāḥ iti śrutti antarāt
translated: For it is said in another Upaniṣad: The possibilities are according to one's wisdom.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: That which is this subtle self, all this is that.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is the truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, O revered one.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, my child, he said.

analyzed: tāḥ prajāḥ yasmin praviśya punar āvirbhavanti
translated: Those beings who enter into that and again manifest.

original: ye tvito 'nye satsatyātmābhisaṃdhā yamaṇubhāvaṃ sadātmānaṃ praviśya nā'vartante sa ya eṣo 'ṇimetyādi vyākhyātam /
analyzed: ye tu itas nye sat satya ātma abhisaṃdhāḥ yam aṇu bhāvam sat ātmānam praviśya na āvartante sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā ityādi vyākhyātam
translated: But those others who, having a different intention, who enter into that subtle self which is real, and do not return, that which is this subtle self, etc. has been explained.

original: yathā loke svakīye gṛhe supta utthāya grāmāntaraṃ gato jānāti svagṛhādāgato 'smītyevaṃ
analyzed: yathā loke svakīye gṛhe suptaḥ utthāya grāma antaram gataḥ jānāti sva gṛhāt āgataḥ smi iti evam
translated: Just as in the world, a man, having slept in his own house, rises and goes to another village, and knows that he has come from his own house,

original: sata āgato 'smīti ca jantūnāṃ kasmādvijñānaṃ na bhavatīti bhūya eva mā bhagavānvijñāpayatvityuktastathā
analyzed: satas āgataḥ smi iti ca jantūnām kasmāt vijñānam na bhavati iti bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti uktaḥ tathā
translated: in the same way, why do not creatures know that they have come from the Self? May the Blessed One explain this again, indeed, to me.' Thus asked, he said:

analyzed: sobhya iti ha uvāca pitā
translated: 'He comes back, indeed, O son.'

analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya navamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Ninth Section in the Sixth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: imāḥ somya nadyaḥ purastāt prācyaḥ syandante paścāt pratīcyaḥ /
analyzed: imāḥ somya nadyaḥ purastāt prācyaḥ syandante paścāt pratīcyaḥ
translated: O Somya, these rivers flow eastwards in the front and westwards in the back.

analyzed: tāḥ samudrāt samudram eva apiyanti
translated: They go from ocean to ocean.

analyzed: sa samudraḥ eva bhavati
translated: They become the ocean itself.

original: tā yathā tatra na vidur iyam aham asmīyam aham asmīti //🔽śṛṇu tatra dṛṣṭāntaṃ yathā somyemā nadyo gaṅgādyāḥ purastātpūrvāṃ diśaṃ prati prācyaḥ prāgañcanāḥ syandante sravanti /
analyzed: tāḥ yathā tatra na viduḥ iyam aham asmi iyam aham asmi iti  śṛṇu tatra dṛṣṭāntam yathā somya imāḥ nadyaḥ gaṅgā ādyāḥ purastāt pūrvām diśam prati prācyaḥ prāc añcanāḥ syandante sravanti
translated: As they do not know there, 'I am this one, I am that one.'🔽Listen to the illustration there, O Somya, as these rivers Ganga and others flow eastwards in the front towards the east, and those flowing westwards in the back towards the west,

original: paścātpratīcīṃ diśaṃ prati sindhvādyāḥ pratīcīmañcanti gacchantīti pratīcyastāḥ samudrādambhonidherjaladharairākṣiptāḥ
analyzed: paścāt pratīcīm diśam prati sindhu ādyāḥ pratīcīm añcanti gacchanti iti pratīcyaḥ tāḥ samudrāt ambhonidheḥ jaladharaiḥ ākṣiptāḥ
translated: they are carried by the clouds from the ocean, the reservoir of water, the ocean,

original: punarvṛṣṭirūpeṇa patitā gaṅgādinadīrūpiṇyaḥ punaḥ samudramambhonidhimevāpiyanti sa
analyzed: punar vṛṣṭi rūpeṇa patitāḥ gaṅgā ādi nadī rūpiṇyaḥ punar samudram ambhonidhim eva apiyanti sa
translated: The rivers, having fallen again in the form of rain, again flow into the ocean, the storehouse of water.

original: samudra eva bhavati tā nadyo yathā tatra samudre samudrātmanaikatāṃ gatā na vidurna
analyzed: samudraḥ eva bhavati tāḥ nadyaḥ yathā tatra samudre samudra ātmanā ekatām gatāḥ na viduḥ na
translated: The rivers become the ocean itself. Just as there, in the ocean, having become one with the ocean, they do not know,

analyzed: jānanti iyam gaṅgā aham asmi iyam yamunā aham asmi iti iyam mahī aham asmi iti ca
translated: do not understand, This is the Ganges, I am this, this is the Yamuna, I am this, this is the Mahanadi, I am this.

original: evam eva khalu somyemāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sata āgamya na viduḥ sata āgacchāmaha iti /
analyzed: evam eva khalu somya imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sataḥ āgamya na viduḥ sataḥ āgacchāmahe iti
translated: In the same way, my dear, all these beings, having come from Being, do not know, 'We have come from Being.'

original: ta iha vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yad yad bhavanti tad ābhavanti //
analyzed: te iha vyāghraḥ vā siṃhaḥ vā vṛkaḥ vā varāhaḥ vā kīṭaḥ vā pataṅgaḥ vā daṃśaḥ vā maśakaḥ vā yat yat bhavanti tat ābhavanti
translated: Here, they become whatever they are - a tiger, a lion, a wolf, a boar, a worm, a moth, a gadfly, or a mosquito - that they become.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: That which is the smallest here, that is the self, that is to be known, that is all this.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, revered sir.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, my dear, he said.

original: evameva khalu somyemāḥ sarvāḥ prajā yasmātsati sampadya na vidustasmātsata āgamya na viduḥ sata āgacchāmaha āgatā iti vā /
analyzed: evam eva khalu somya imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ yasmāt sati sampadya na viduḥ tasmāt sataḥ āgamya na viduḥ sataḥ āgacchāmahe āgatāḥ iti vā
translated: In the same way, my dear, all these creatures, when they become united with Being, do not know it. Therefore, having come from Being, they do not know it, thinking, 'We have come from Being, we have arrived.'

analyzed: te iha vyāghraḥ ityādi samānam anyat
translated: The rest is the same as before, beginning with 'Here, a tiger...'.

original: dṛṣṭaṃ loke jale vīcītaraṅgaphenabudādaya utthitāḥ punastadbhāvaṃ gatā vinaṣṭā iti /
analyzed: dṛṣṭam loke jale vīcī taraṅga phena buda ādayaḥ utthitāḥ punar tad bhāvam gatāḥ vinaṣṭāḥ iti
translated: It is seen in the world that waves, foam, bubbles, etc. in water rise up and then return to that state and disappear.

original: jīvāstu tatkāraṇamaṇubhāvaṃ pratyahaṃ gacchanto 'pi suṣupte maraṇapralayayośca na vinaśyantītyetat bhūya eva mā bhagavānvijñāpayatu dṛṣṭāntena
analyzed: jīvāḥ tu tad kāraṇam aṇu bhāvam pratyaham gacchantaḥ suṣupte maraṇa pralayayoḥ ca na vinaśyanti iti etat bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu dṛṣṭāntena
translated: But the individual souls, even though they return to the state of the cause, which is atomic, every day, do not perish in deep sleep, at death, or at the time of cosmic dissolution. May the Blessed One please explain this again with an example.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca pitā
translated: Thus said the father, So it is, my dear.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya daśamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the tenth section in the sixth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: asya somya mahato vṛkṣasya yo mūle 'bhyāhanyāj jīvan sraved yo madhye 'bhyāhanyāj jīvan sraved yo 'gre 'bhyāhanyāj jīvan sravet /
analyzed: asya somya mahataḥ vṛkṣasya yaḥ mūle bhyāhanyāt jīvan sravet yaḥ madhye bhyāhanyāt jīvan sravet yaḥ gre bhyāhanyāt jīvan sravet
translated: O Somya, of this great tree, if one were to strike at the root, it would ooze with life. If one were to strike in the middle, it would ooze with life. If one were to strike at the top, it would ooze with life.

original: sa eṣa jīvenātmanānuprabhūtaḥ pepīyamāno modamānas tiṣṭhati //
analyzed: saḥ eṣa jīvena ātmanā anuprabhūtaḥ pepīyamānaḥ modamānaḥ tiṣṭhati
translated: It stands, filled with the living Self, being drunk and delighted.

original: śṛṇu dṛṣṭāntamasya he somya mahato 'nekaśākhādiyuktasya vṛkṣasyāsyetyagrataḥ sthitaṃ vṛkṣaṃ darśayannāha /
analyzed: śṛṇu dṛṣṭāntam asya he somya mahataḥ neka śākhā ādi yuktasya vṛkṣasya asya iti agratas sthitam vṛkṣam darśayan āha
translated: Listen to an illustration of this, O son. Pointing to the tree standing in front, he says, 'Of this great tree with many branches and so on.'

original: yadi yaḥ kaścidasya mūle 'bhyāhanyātparaśvādinā sakṛdghātamātreṇa na śuṣyatīti jīvanneva bhavati tadā tasya rasaḥ sravet /
analyzed: yadi yaḥ kaścid asya mūle bhyāhanyāt paraśu ādinā sakṛt ghāta mātreṇa na śuṣyati iti jīvan eva bhavati tadā tasya rasaḥ sravet
translated: If someone were to strike its root with an axe or something else, and it does not wither with just one blow, but remains alive, then its sap would flow out.

analyzed: tathā yaḥ madhye bhyāhanyāt jīvan sravet tathā yaḥ gre bhyāhanyāt jīvan sravet saḥ eṣa
translated: Similarly, if someone were to strike it in the middle, the living sap would flow out. Similarly, if someone were to strike its top, the living sap would flow out. This tree

analyzed: vṛkṣaḥ idānīm jīvena ātmanā anuprabhūtaḥ nu vyāptaḥ pepīyamānaḥ tyartham piban udakam
translated: now stands filled and pervaded by the living self, drinking excessively,

analyzed: bhaumān ca rasān mūlaiḥ gṛhṇan modamānaḥ harṣam prāpnuvan tiṣṭhati
translated: drinking the water and grasping the earthly juices with its roots, rejoicing, attaining delight.

original: asya yad ekāṃ śākhāṃ jīvo jahāty atha sā śuṣyati /
analyzed: asya yat ekām śākhām jīvaḥ jahāti atha sā śuṣyati
translated: When the life-breath leaves one branch of it, that branch withers.

analyzed: dvitīyām jahāti atha sā śuṣyati
translated: When it leaves the second, that withers.

analyzed: tṛtīyām jahāti atha sā śuṣyati
translated: When it leaves the third, that withers.

analyzed: sarvam jahāti sarvaḥ śuṣyati
translated: When it leaves all, all withers.

original: tasyāsya yadekāṃ śākhāṃ rogagrastāmāhatāṃ vā jīvo jahātyupasaṃharati śākhāyāṃ viprasṛtamātmāṃśam /
analyzed: tasya asya yat ekām śākhām roga grastām āhatām vā jīvaḥ jahāti upasaṃharati śākhāyām viprasṛtam ātma aṃśam
translated: When the life-force abandons or withdraws the part of the Self that had spread out into a branch of that tree which is afflicted with disease or struck down,

analyzed: atha sā śuṣyati
translated: then that branch dries up.

original: vāṅmanaḥprāṇakaraṇagrāmānupraviṣṭo hi jīva iti tadupasaṃhāra upasaṃhriyate /
analyzed: vāc manaḥ prāṇa karaṇa grāma anupraviṣṭaḥ hi jīvaḥ iti tad upasaṃhāraḥ upasaṃhriyate
translated: For the life-force is present in the group of faculties such as speech, mind, and life-force, so when it withdraws, it is withdrawn.

original: jīvena ca prāṇayuktenāśitaṃ potaṃ ca rasatāṃ gataṃ jīvaccharīraṃ vṛkṣaṃ vardhayadrasarūpeṇa jīvasya sadbhāve liṅgaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: jīvena ca prāṇa yuktena aśitam potam ca rasa tām gatam jīvat śarīram vṛkṣam vardhayat rasa rūpeṇa jīvasya sadbhāve liṅgam bhavati
translated: And when the life-force along with the vital breaths consumes what is eaten and drunk and it becomes rasa, it nourishes the living body, the tree, and the sign of the presence of the life-force is in the form of rasa.

original: aśitapītābhyāṃ hi dehe jīvastiṣṭhati te cāśitapīte jīvakarmānusāriṇī iti /
analyzed: aśita pītābhyām hi dehe jīvaḥ tiṣṭhati te ca aśita pīte jīva karma anusāriṇī iti
translated: For the life-force resides in the body through what is eaten and drunk, and those eaten and drunk things follow the action of the life-force.

original: tasyaikāṅgavaikalyanimittaṃ karma yadopasthitaṃ bhavati tadā jīva ekāṃ śākhāṃ jahāti śākhāyā ātmānamupasaṃharati /
analyzed: tasya eka aṅga vaikalya nimittam karma yadā upasthitam bhavati tadā jīvaḥ ekām śākhām jahāti śākhāyāḥ ātmānam upasaṃharati
translated: When the karma that is the cause of the deficiency of one of its limbs becomes present, then the life-force abandons one branch, withdraws the Self from the branch.

analyzed: atha tadā sā śākhā śuṣyati
translated: Then at that time that branch dries up.

original: jīvasthitinimitto raso jīvakarmākṣipto jīvopasaṃhāre na tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: jīva sthiti nimittaḥ rasaḥ jīva karma ākṣiptaḥ jīva upasaṃhāre na tiṣṭhati
translated: The rasa that is the cause of the life-force remaining, projected by the karma of the life-force, does not remain when the life-force is withdrawn.

analyzed: rasa apagame ca śākhā śoṣam upaiti
translated: And when the rasa departs, the branch dries up.

original: tathā sarvaṃ vṛkṣameva yadāyaṃ jahāti tadā sarvo 'pi vṛkṣaḥ śuṣyati /
analyzed: tathā sarvam vṛkṣam eva yadā ayam jahāti tadā sarvaḥ api vṛkṣaḥ śuṣyati
translated: Similarly, when this [soul] leaves the entire tree, the entire tree withers.

original: vṛkṣasya rasasravaṇaśoṣaṇādiliṅgājjīvavattvaṃ dṛṣṭāntaśruteśca cetanāvantaḥ sthāvarā iti bauddhakāṇādamatamacetanāḥ sthāvarā ityetadasāramiti
analyzed: vṛkṣasya rasa sravaṇa śoṣaṇa ādi liṅgāt jīvavat tvam dṛṣṭānta śruteḥ ca cetanāvantaḥ sthāvarāḥ iti bauddha kāṇāda matam acetanāḥ sthāvarāḥ iti etat asāram iti
translated: From the signs such as the flow of sap and withering of the tree, and from the scriptural statement about the example, it is seen that the insentient things are living beings. Therefore, the Buddhist and Kāṇāda doctrines that insentient things are living beings are shown to be false.

analyzed: darśitam bhavati
translated: It is shown that the doctrine that insentient things are living beings is false.

original: evam eva khalu somya viddhīti ha uvāca /
analyzed: evam eva khalu somya viddhi iti ha uvāca
translated: Thus, O Somya, understand. He said.

original: jīvāpetaṃ vāva kiledaṃ mriyate na jīvo mriyata iti /
analyzed: jīva apetam vāva kila idam mriyate na jīvaḥ mriyate iti
translated: Indeed, this which is separated from the living being dies, not the living being dies.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: That which is this subtle, that is the self of all this.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is the truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, O Revered One.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, O Somya, he said.

original: yathāsminvṛkṣadṛṣṭānte darśitaṃ jīvena yukto vṛkṣo 'śuṣko rasapānādiyukto jāvatītyucyate tadapetaśca mriyata ityucyate /
analyzed: yathā asmin vṛkṣa dṛṣṭānte darśitam jīvena yuktaḥ vṛkṣaḥ śuṣkaḥ rasa pāna ādi yuktaḥ tad apetaḥ ca mriyate iti ucyate
translated: Just as in this example of the tree, it is said that a tree connected with a living being is not dry, is connected with drinking sap, and so on, and when separated from that, it is said to die.

original: evameva khalu somya viddhīti hovācajīvāpetaṃ jīvaviyuktaṃ vāva kiledaṃ śarīraṃ mriyate
analyzed: evam eva khalu somya viddhi iti ha uvāca jīva apetam jīva viyuktam vāva kila idam śarīram mriyate
translated: In the same way, O Somya, understand. He said: Indeed, this body which is separated from the living being, which is devoid of life, dies.

original: na jīvo mriyata iti kāryaśeṣe ca suptotthitasya mamedaṃ kāryaśeṣamaparisamāptamiti
analyzed: na jīvaḥ mriyate iti kārya śeṣe ca supta utthitasya mama idam kārya śeṣam aparisamāptam iti
translated: And in the case of the remainder of an action, one who has risen from sleep thinks, This remainder of my action was not completed.

analyzed: smṛtvā samāpana darśanāt  jāta mātrāṇām ca jantūnām stanya abhilāṣayā ādi darśanāt ca atīta janmāntara anubhūta stana
translated: And in the case of one who has resumed his work after sleep, it is seen that he remembers that this part of his work was unfinished and completes it.

analyzed: pāna duḥkha anubhava smṛtiḥ gamyate
translated: And from the fact that newborn creatures are seen to have a desire for milk, it is inferred that they remember the experience of drinking milk in their previous lives.

original: agnihotrādīnāṃ ca vaidikānāṃ karmaṇāmarthavattvānna jīvo mriyata iti /
analyzed: agnihotra ādīnām ca vaidikānām karmaṇām arthavat tvāt na jīvaḥ mriyate iti
translated: And because Vedic rites such as the Agnihotra have a purpose, the individual soul does not die.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimetyādi samānam /🔽kathaṃ punaridamatyantasthīlaṃ pṛthivyādi nāmarūpavajjagadatyantasūkṣmātsadrūpānnāmarūparah itātsato jāyata ityetaddṛṣṭāntena bhūya eva mā
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā ityādi samānam  katham punar idam atyanta sthīlam pṛthivī ādi nāma rūpavat jagat atyanta sūkṣmāt sat rūpāt nāma rūpa rah itāt sataḥ jāyate iti etad dṛṣṭāntena bhūyas eva mā
translated: The same as before, beginning with That which is the smallest...

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca pitā
translated: How then is this world, which is extremely gross, consisting of earth etc. with name and form, born from Being which is extremely subtle, devoid of name and form? This is to be understood by another example. Therefore, he said: So, my dear...

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya ekādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus, in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad, the eleventh section of the sixth chapter.

analyzed: nyagrodha phalam atas āhara iti
translated: Bring that fig fruit.

analyzed: idam bhagavaḥ iti
translated: This, O revered one.

analyzed: bhinddhi iti
translated: Break it.

analyzed: bhinnam bhagavaḥ iti
translated: It is broken, O revered one.

analyzed: kim atra paśyasi iti
translated: What do you see there?

analyzed: aṇvyaḥ iva imāḥ dhānāḥ bhagavaḥ iti
translated: Tiny seeds, O revered one.

analyzed: āsām aṅga ekām bhinddhi iti
translated: Break one of these grains.

analyzed: bhinnā bhagavaḥ iti
translated: Broken, O Lord.

analyzed: kim atra paśyasi iti
translated: What do you see here?

analyzed: na kiṃcana bhagavaḥ iti
translated: Nothing, O Lord.

analyzed: yadi etat pratyakṣīkartum icchasi
translated: If you wish to see this directly,

analyzed: atas smāt mahataḥ nyagrodhāt phalam ekam āhara iti uktaḥ tathā cakāra
translated: then pick a fruit from this great banyan tree. When told to do so, he did as instructed.

original: sa idaṃ bhagava upahṛtaṃ phalamiti darśitavantaṃ pratyāha phalaṃ bhindhīti /
analyzed: saḥ idam bhagavaḥ upahṛtam phalam iti darśitavantam pratyāha phalam bhindhi iti
translated: When he showed the fruit, saying O Lord, this is the fruit I have offered, the father said, Break the fruit.

original: bhinnamityāhetaraḥ /🔽tamāha pitā kimatra paśyasītyukta āhāṇvyo 'ṇutarā ivemā dhānā bījāni paśyāmi bhagava iti /
analyzed: bhinnam iti āha itaraḥ  tam āha pitā kim atra paśyasi iti uktaḥ āha aṇvyaḥ ṇutarāḥ iva imāḥ dhānāḥ bījāni paśyāmi bhagavaḥ iti
translated: The other said it was broken.🔽The father asked him, What do you see here? When told to speak, he said, O Lord, I see these grains, smaller than the smallest.

original: āsāṃ dhānānāmekāṃ dhānāmaṅga he vatsa bhindhītyukta āha bhinnā bhagava iti /
analyzed: āsām dhānānām ekām dhānām aṅga he vatsa bhindhi iti uktaḥ āha bhinnā bhagavaḥ iti
translated: The father said, O child, break one of these grains. When told to do so, he said, Broken, O Lord.

original: yadi bhinnā dhānā tasyāṃ bhinnāyāṃ kiṃ paśyasītyukta āha na kiñcana paśyāmi bhagava iti //
analyzed: yadi bhinnā dhānā tasyām bhinnāyām kim paśyasi iti uktaḥ āha na kiñcana paśyāmi bhagavaḥ iti
translated: If the grain is broken, what do you see in that broken grain? When told to speak, he said, I see nothing, O Lord.

original: taṃ hovāca yaṃ vai somyaitam aṇimānaṃ na nibhālayasa etasya vai somyaiṣo 'ṇimna evaṃ mahānyagrodhas tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: tam ha uvāca yam vai somya etam aṇimānam na nibhālayase etasya vai somya eṣaḥ ṇimnaḥ evam mahā nyagrodhaḥ tiṣṭhati
translated: He said to him, O Somya, that which you could not see as the smallest, from that smallest indeed, O Somya, this great banyan tree stands.

analyzed: śraddhatsva somya iti
translated: Have faith, O Somya.

original: taṃ putraṃ hovāca vaṭadhānāyāṃ bhinnāyāṃ yaṃ vaṭabījāṇimānaṃ he saumyaitaṃ na nibhālayase na paśyasi /
analyzed: tam putram ha uvāca vaṭa dhānāyām bhinnāyām yam vaṭa bīja aṇimānam he saumya etam na nibhālayase na paśyasi
translated: He said to his son, 'In a split of a jujube fruit, O dear one, you do not see, you do not perceive, that much of the jujube seed.

original: tathāpyetasya vai kila somyaiṣa mahānnyagrodho bījasyāṇimnaḥ sūkṣmasyādṛśyamānasya
analyzed: tathā api etasya vai kila somya eṣa mahān nyagrodhaḥ bījasya aṇimnaḥ sūkṣmasya a dṛśyamānasya
translated: Nevertheless, O dear one, this great banyan tree, which is the effect of that subtle, invisible seed,

analyzed: kārya bhūtaḥ sthūla śākhā skandha phala palāśavān tiṣṭhati utpannaḥ san uttiṣṭhati iti
translated: stands, having arisen, having been born. The word 'uttisthati' (stands)

original: 'dhyāhāryo 'taḥ śraddhatsva somya sata evāṇimnaḥ sthūlaṃ nāmarūpādimatkāryaṃ jagadutpannamiti /
analyzed: dhyāhārya u tas śraddhatsva somya sataḥ eva aṇimnaḥ sthūlam nāma rūpa ādimat kāryam jagat utpannam iti
translated: should be supplied. Therefore, O dear one, have faith that the gross world with name and form, etc., is born from the subtle seed alone.

analyzed: yadi api nyāya āgamābhyām nirdhārita ūrthaḥ tathā evā iti avagamyate tathā api atyanta sūkṣmeṣu artheṣu
translated: Even though the meaning determined by reasoning and scripture is understood to be just so, still in the case of extremely subtle matters,

analyzed: bāhya viṣaya āsakta manasaḥ svabhāva pravṛttasya asatyām gurutarāyām śraddhāyām duravagama tvam
translated: for one whose mind is attached to external objects and who proceeds naturally, if there is no strong faith,

analyzed: syāt iti āha śraddhatsva iti
translated: it would be difficult to understand. Therefore he says 'have faith'.

original: śraddhāyāṃ tu satyāṃ manasaḥ samādhānaṃ bubhutsiter'the bhavettataśca tadarthāvagatiḥ /
analyzed: śraddhāyām tu satyām manasaḥ samādhānam bubhutsita irthe bhavet tatas ca tad artha avagatiḥ
translated: But when there is faith, the mind becomes concentrated on the desired object, and then there is understanding of that object.

analyzed: anyatramanāḥ abhūvam ityādi śruteḥ
translated: As stated in the Upanishad: 'I was elsewhere, etc.'

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: That which is the subtle, that is the Self, all this (universe) has that as its Self.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is Truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the Self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, O Revered One.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, my son, said he.

analyzed: sa yaḥ ityādi ukta artham
translated: The words he who etc. are of well-known meaning.

original: yadi tatsajjagato mūlaṃ kasmānnopalabhyata ityetaddṛṣṭāntena mā bhagavānbhūya eva vijñāpayatviti /
analyzed: yadi tat sat jagataḥ mūlam kasmāt na upalabhyate iti etad dṛṣṭāntena mā bhagavān bhūyas eva vijñāpayatu iti
translated: If that is the root of the existent universe, why is it not perceived? Please explain this to me again, O Revered One, by means of an illustration.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca pitā
translated: So be it, my son, said he.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya dvādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twelfth section in the sixth chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: lavaṇam etad udake 'vadhāyātha mā prātar upasīdathā iti /
analyzed: lavaṇam etat udake vadhāya atha mā prātar upasīdathāḥ iti
translated: Place this salt in the water and come to me in the morning.

analyzed: sa ha tathā cakāra
translated: He did as he was told.

original: taṃ hovāca /🔽yad doṣā lavaṇam udake 'vādhā aṅga tad āhareti /
analyzed: tam ha uvāca  yat doṣā lavaṇam udake vā adhāḥ aṅga tat āhara iti
translated: He said to him:🔽Bring me the salt that you put in the water yesterday.

analyzed: tat ha avamṛśya na viveda
translated: He took some of the water in his hand and tasted it, but could not detect any salt in it.

original: vidyamānamapi vastu nopalabhyate prakārāntareṇa tūpalabhyata iti śṛṇvatra
analyzed: vidyamānam api vastu na upalabhyate prakāra antareṇa tu upalabhyate iti śṛṇu atra
translated: Even an existent object is not perceived, but is perceived in another way. Listen to the illustration here.

original: dṛṣṭāntam yadi cemamarthaṃ pratyakṣo sa ha pitroktamarthaṃ pratyakṣīkartumicchaṃstathā cakāra /
analyzed: dṛṣṭāntam yadi ca imam artham sa ha pitrā uktam artham pratyakṣīkartum icchan tathā cakāra
translated: If this meaning is directly perceived, he, desiring to directly perceive the meaning stated by his father, did as he was told.

original: taṃ hovāca paredyuḥ prātarūpasīdathā upagacchethā iti /
analyzed: tam ha uvāca paredyus prātar upasīdathāḥ upagacchethāḥ iti
translated: The next day, in the morning, he said to him, 'Sit down, my dear, and eat.'

analyzed: sa ha pitrā uktam artham pratyakṣīkartum icchan tathā cakāra
translated: Desiring to make manifest the matter spoken of by his father, he did as he was told.

original: taṃ hovāca paredyuḥ prātaryallavaṃ doṣā rātrāvudake 'vādhā nikṣiptavānasyaṅga he vatsa tadāharetyuktastallavaṇamājihīrṣurha kilāvamṛśyodake
analyzed: tam ha uvāca paredyus prātar yat lavam doṣā rātrau udake vā adhāḥ nikṣiptavānasi aṅga he vatsa tat āhara iti uktaḥ tat lavaṇam ājihīrṣuḥ ha kila avamṛśya udake

analyzed: yathā vilīnam eva

analyzed: katham iti

analyzed: tat śaśvat saṃvartate
