translated: He said to him, 'Verily, my dear, you do not perceive it there. Verily, it is there alone.'

original: yathā vilīnaṃ lavaṇaṃ na vettha tathāpi taccakṣuṣā sparśanena ca piṇḍarūpaṃ🔽lavaṇamagṛhyamāṇaṃ vidyata evāpsūpalabhyate copāyāntareṇetyetatputraṃ pratyāyayitumicchannāhaaṅgāsyodakasyāntādupari
analyzed: yathā vilīnam lavaṇam na vettha tathā api tad cakṣuṣā sparśanena ca piṇḍa rūpam  lavaṇam agṛhyamāṇam vidyate eva apsu upalabhyate ca upāya antareṇa iti etat putram pratyāyayitum icchan āha aṅga asya udakasya antāt upari
translated: Just as you do not know the dissolved salt, yet that salt exists in the water, though not perceived by the eye or touch as a lump,🔽and is perceived by another means, desiring to convince his son of this, he said: Take water from the end of this water.

original: gṛhītvā'cāmetyuktvā putraṃ tathākṛtavantamuvāca kathamitītara āha lavaṇaṃ svādutaḥ iti /🔽tathā madhyādudakasya gṛhītvā'cāmeti kathamiti lavaṇamiti /
analyzed: gṛhītvā ācāma iti uktvā putram tathā kṛtavantam uvāca katham iti itaraḥ āha lavaṇam svādutaḥ iti  tathā madhyāt udakasya gṛhītvā ācāma iti katham iti lavaṇam iti
translated: Having said this, and the son having done as told, he said: How? The other said: Taste it.🔽Similarly, having taken water from the middle, he said: Taste it. How? Salt.

analyzed: tathā antāt adhas deśāt gṛhītvā ācāma iti katham iti lavaṇam iti
translated: Similarly, having taken from the end, from the lower part, he said: Taste it. How? Salt.

original: yadyevamabhiprāsya parityajyaitadudakamācamyātha mopasīdathā iti taddha tathā cakāra lavaṇaṃ parityajya pitṛsamīpamājagāmetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yadi evam abhiprāsya parityajya etat udakam ācamya atha mā upasīdathāḥ iti tat ha tathā cakāra lavaṇam parityajya pitṛ samīpam ājagāma iti arthaḥ
translated: If it is so, then having drunk water after discarding it, then come to me. He did as told, discarded the salt, and came near his father. This is the meaning.

original: idaṃ vacanaṃ bravaṃstallavamaṃ tasminnevodake yanmayā rātrau kṣiptaṃ śāśvannityaṃ saṃvartate vidyamānameva satsamyagvartate /
analyzed: idam vacanam bravan tat lavamam tasmin eva udake yat mayā rātrau kṣiptam śāśvat nityam saṃvartate vidyamānam eva sat samyak vartate
translated: Saying this, he said: That salt which I dropped into the water last night, that which exists, always, eternally, that which is present, that which is rightly present.

analyzed: iti evam uktavantam tam ha uvāca pitā
translated: Having spoken thus, his father said to him:

original: yathedaṃ lavaṇaṃ darśanasparśanābhyāṃ pūrvaṃ gṛhītaṃ punarudake vilīnaṃ tābhyāmagṛhyamāṇamapi vidyata evopāyāntareṇa jihvayopalabhyamānatvāt
analyzed: yathā idam lavaṇam darśana sparśanābhyām pūrvam gṛhītam punar udake vilīnam tābhyām agṛhyamāṇam api vidyate eva upāya antareṇa jihvayā upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: Just as this salt, which was previously perceived by sight and touch, when dissolved in water, is not perceived by those two [senses], yet it exists, because it is perceived by the tongue through another means.

analyzed: evam eva atra eva asmin eva tejaḥ banna ādi kārye śuṅgedehe
translated: In the same way, in this very body, which is the sprout of the effects like fire, food, etc.

analyzed: vāva kila iti ācārya upadeśa smaraṇa pradarśana arthau  sat tejaḥ banna ādi śuṅga kāramam vaṭa bīja aṇima vat vidyamānam eva indriyaiḥ na upalabhase na nibhālayase
translated: Vāva, indeed, is used to show the remembrance of the teacher's instruction.🔽You do not perceive, do not see, that which is the cause of the sprout of fire, food, etc., which exists like the subtle seed of the banyan tree, by the senses.

analyzed: yathā atra eva udake darśana sparśanābhyām anupalabhyamānam lavaṇam vidyamānam eva jihvayā upalabdhavān asi
translated: Just as you have perceived by the tongue the salt that exists here itself in the water, but is not perceived by sight and touch.

original: evamevātraiva kila vidyamānaṃ sajjaganmūlamupāyāntareṇa lavaṇāṇimavadupalapsyasa iti vākyaśeṣaḥ //
analyzed: evam eva atrā eva kila vidyamānam sat jagat mūlam upāya antareṇa lavaṇa aṇima vat upalapsyase iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: In the same way, you will perceive by another means the existence of this very world, the root of the universe, like the subtle salt. This is the remainder of the sentence.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: That which is this subtle [Self], that is the essence of all this.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the Self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, O Revered One.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, my son, he said.

analyzed: sa yaḥ ityādi samānam
translated: The passage beginning with That which is... is the same as before.

original: yadyevaṃ lavaṇāṇimavadindriyairanupalabhyamānamapi jaganmūlaṃ sadupāyāntareṇopalabdhuṃ🔽śakyate yadupalambhātkṛtārthaḥ syāmanupalambhāccākṛtārthaḥ syāmahaṃ tasyaivopalabdhau
analyzed: yadi evam lavaṇa aṇima vat indriyaiḥ anupalabhyamānam api jagat mūlam sat upāya antareṇa upalabdhum  śakyate yat upalambhāt kṛtārthaḥ syām anupalambhāt ca akṛtārthaḥ syām aham tasya eva upalabdhau
translated: If so, the root of the world, which is not perceived by the senses like a salt atom, can be perceived by some other means.🔽By the perception of which I would be satisfied, and by the non-perception of which I would not be satisfied, what is the means for the perception of that?

original: ka upāya ityetadbhūya eva mā bhagavānvijñāpayatu dṛṣṭāntena tathā somyeti hovāca //
analyzed: kaḥ upāyaḥ iti etat bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu dṛṣṭāntena tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: Please explain this again, O Venerable One, with an example. So be it, my dear, he said.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya trayodaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the thirteenth section in the sixth chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: yathā somya puruṣaṃ gandhārebhyo 'bhinaddhākṣam ānīya taṃ tato 'tijane visṛjet /
analyzed: yathā somya puruṣam gandhārebhyaḥ bhinaddha akṣam ānīya tam tatas ti jane visṛjet
translated: Just as, my dear, one might bring a man from the Gandhāras with his eyes bound, and let him go there among a crowd of people.

original: sa yathā tatra prāṅ vodaṅ vā adharāṅ vā pratyaṅ vā pradhmāyītābhinaddhākṣa ānīto 'bhinaddhākṣo visṛṣṭaḥ //
analyzed: sa yathā tatra prāṅ vā udaṅ vā adharāṅ vā pratyaṅ vā ānītaḥ bhinaddha akṣaḥ visṛṣṭaḥ

analyzed: deśe visṛjet sa tatra diś bhrama upetaḥ yathā

analyzed: vā iti arthaḥ

analyzed: sa grāmāt grāmam pṛcchan paṇḍitaḥ medhāvī gandhārān eva upasaṃpadyeta

analyzed: evam eva iha ācāryavān puruṣaḥ veda
translated: In the same way, here, a person with a teacher knows.

analyzed: tasya tāvat eva ciram yāvat na vimokṣye saṃpatsye iti

analyzed: evam vikrośataḥ tasya yathā abhinahanam yathā bandhanam pramucya muktvā
translated: Thus, for him who is crying out, having untied, having released, his binding, as it was bound,

analyzed: kāruṇikaḥ kaścid etām diśam uttaratas gandhārāḥ etām diśam vraja iti prabrūyāt saḥ evam kāruṇikena
translated: some compassionate one would say, This way are the Gandhāras, this way go. He, by a compassionate one

translated: A learned man, who has been released from bondage, who is asking about villages, who is wise, who is instructed, who is capable of determining the path to enter a village taught by others,

analyzed: san gandhārān eva upasampadyeta na itaraḥ mūḍha matiḥ deśa antara darśana tṛṣ vā
translated: would reach Gandhara itself, not the other, who is of deluded understanding or thirsty for seeing other countries.

original: yathāyaṃ dṛṣṭānto varṇitaḥ svaviṣayebhyo gandhārebhyaḥ puruṣastaskarairabhinaddhākṣo
analyzed: yathā ayam dṛṣṭāntaḥ varṇitaḥ sva viṣayebhyaḥ gandhārebhyaḥ puruṣaḥ taskaraiḥ abhinaddha akṣaḥ
translated: As this example is described, a man from Gandhara, his own country, whose eyes are bound by thieves,

original: 'viveko diṅmūḍho 'śanāyāpipāsādimānvyāghrataskarādyanekabhayānatharvrātayutamaraṇyaṃ🔽praveśito duḥkhārto vikrośanbandhanebhyo mumukṣustiṣṭhati sa kathañcideva kāruṇikena
analyzed: vivekaḥ śanāyā pipāsā ādimān vyāghra taskara ādi aneka bhayānathaḥ vrāta yutam araṇyam  praveśitaḥ duḥkha ārtaḥ vikrośan bandhanebhyaḥ mumukṣuḥ tiṣṭhati sa kathañcid eva kāruṇikena
translated: is devoid of discrimination, confused about directions, suffering from hunger, thirst, etc., and is made to enter a forest full of many dangers such as tigers, thieves, etc.,

translated: distressed by suffering, crying out, desiring to be released from bondage, he somehow stands. He is released by someone compassionate. Having reached his own country, Gandhara itself, he is content and becomes happy.

analyzed: evam eva sataḥ jagadātmanaḥ svarūpāt tejaḥ vat ādi mayam deha araṇyam vāta pitta kapha rudhira medaḥ māṃsa asthi majjā śukra kṛmi mūtra purīṣavat śīta uṣṇa ādi aneka dvandva sukha duḥkhavat ca idam
translated: In the same way, this world, consisting of light, food, etc., is the forest of the body of the Self of the universe, which is full of many pairs of opposites such as cold and hot, and has happiness and sorrow, like wind, bile, phlegm, blood, fat, flesh, bones, marrow, semen, worms, urine and feces,

analyzed: moha paṭa abhinaddha akṣaḥ bhāryā putra mitra paśubandhu ādi dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa aneka viṣaya tṛṣṇā pāśitaḥ
translated: His eyes covered with the veil of delusion, he is bound by the noose of thirst for many objects, seen and unseen, such as wife, sons, friends, cattle, relatives, etc.

original: puṇyāpuṇyāditaskaraiḥ praveśito'hamamuṣya putro mamaite bāndhavāḥ sukhyahaṃ duḥkhī
analyzed: puṇya apuṇya ādi taskaraiḥ praveśitaḥ aham amuṣya putraḥ mama ete bāndhavāḥ sukhī aham duḥkhī
translated: He is entered by thieves in the form of merit, demerit, etc., thinking I am the son of so-and-so, these are my relatives, I am happy, I am miserable,

original: mūḍhaḥ paṇḍito dhārmiko bandhumāñjāto mṛto jīrṇaḥ pāpī putro me mṛto dhanaṃ me naṣṭaṃ
analyzed: mūḍhaḥ paṇḍitaḥ dhārmikaḥ bandhumān jātaḥ mṛtaḥ jīrṇaḥ pāpī putraḥ me mṛtaḥ dhanam me naṣṭam
translated: I am foolish, learned, righteous, fortunate, born, dead, old, sinful, my son is dead, my wealth is lost,

original: hā hato 'smi kathaṃ jāviṣyāmi kā me gatiḥ kiṃ me trāṇam ityevamanekaśatasahasrānarthajālavānvikrośankathañcideva
analyzed: hā hataḥ smi katham kā me gatiḥ kim me trāṇam iti evam aneka śata sahasra anartha jālavān vikrośan kathañcid eva
translated: Alas! I am ruined, how shall I live? What is my refuge? What is my protection? Thus, with a net of many hundreds of thousands of misfortunes, he cries out and somehow

analyzed: puṇya atiśayāt parama kāruṇikam kañcid sat brahma ātma vidam vimukta bandhanam brahmiṣṭham
translated: by the excess of his merit, he finds a certain supremely compassionate knower of Brahman, whose bonds are loosened, who is most devoted to Brahman,

analyzed: yat āsādayati tena ca brahma vidā kāruṇyāt darśita saṃsāra viṣaya doṣa darśana mārgaḥ viraktaḥ
translated: and by that knower of Brahman, out of compassion, he is shown the path of seeing the faults of the objects of worldly life, and being detached,

original: saṃsāraviṣayebhyo nāsi tvaṃ saṃsāryamuṣya putratvādidharmavānkiṃ tarhi sadyattattvamasītyavidyāmohapaṭābhinahanānmokṣito
analyzed: saṃsāra viṣayebhyaḥ na asi tvam saṃsārī amuṣya putra tva ādi dharmavān kim tarhi sat yat tat tvam asi iti avidyā moha paṭa abhinahanāt mokṣitaḥ
translated: he is freed from the objects of worldly life, and is released from the bonds of the notion You are not an experiencer of worldly life, having the quality of being the son of so-and-so, but rather you are That, the Truth, you are That. Thus, he is freed from the veil of delusion caused by ignorance,

original: gandhārapuruṣavacca svaṃ sadātmānamupasampadya sukhī nirvṛtaḥ syādityetamevārthamāhā'cāryavānpuruṣo
analyzed: gandhāra puruṣa vat ca svam sat ātmānam upasampadya sukhī nirvṛtaḥ syāt iti etam eva artham āha ācāryavān puruṣaḥ
translated: And like the Gandhara man, he would attain his own Self always and be happy and contented. This very meaning the teacher has stated by saying, 'The person who has a teacher'

original: vedeti tasyāsyaivamācāryavato muktāvidyābhinahanasya tāvadeva tāvāneva kālaściraṃ
analyzed: veda iti tasya asya evam ācāryavataḥ muktāvidyā abhinahanasya tāvat eva tāvān eva kālaḥ ciram
translated: 'knows Brahman.' The rest of the sentence is that for such a person who has a teacher and is released from the bondage of ignorance, that much, that much time only is long

analyzed: kṣepaḥ sat ātma sva rūpa sampatteḥ iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: for the attainment of the nature of the Self always.

original: kiyānkālaściramityucyate yāvanna vimokṣye na vimokṣyata ityetatpuruṣavyatyanena /
analyzed: kiyān kālaḥ ciram iti ucyate yāvat na vimokṣye na vimokṣyate iti etat puruṣa vyatyanena
translated: How much time is long? It is said, 'as long as he will not be released,' 'he will not be released' - this is stated by changing the person.

analyzed: sāmarthyāt
translated: By implication.

original: yena karmaṇā śarīramārabdhaṃ tasyopabhogena yenāthaśabda ānantaryārthaḥ syāt /🔽nanu yathā sadvijñānāntarameva dehapātaḥ satsampattiśca na bhavati karmaśeṣavaśāttathāpravṛttaphalāni
analyzed: yena karmaṇā śarīram ārabdham tasya upabhogena yena atha śabdaḥ ānantarya arthaḥ syāt  nanu yathā sat vijñāna antaram eva dehapātaḥ sat sampattiḥ ca na bhavati karma śeṣa vaśāt tathā pravṛtta phalāni
translated: By that action by which the body is begun, by the experience of that, the word 'athā' would have the meaning of immediacy.🔽But just as the fall of the body and the attainment of Being do not happen immediately after the knowledge of Being, due to the remaining power of past actions, in the same way, there are also actions accumulated in other births before the arising of knowledge,

analyzed: prāk jñāna utpatteḥ janma antara sañcitāni api karmāṇi santi iti tad phala upabhoga artham patite 🔽smin śarīra antaram ārabdhavyam
translated: which have not yet produced their results. Therefore, when this body falls, another body must be begun for the experience of their results.

original: utpanne ca jñāne yāvajjīvaṃ vihitāni pratiṣiddhāni vā karmāṇi karotyeveti tatphalopabhogārthaṃ
analyzed: utpanne ca jñāne yāvajjīvam vihitāni pratiṣiddhāni vā karmāṇi karoti eva iti tad phala upabhoga artham
translated: And when knowledge has arisen, he continues to perform, throughout life, the enjoined and prohibited actions.

original: cāvaśyaṃ śarīrāntaramārabdhavyaṃ tataśca karmāṇi tataḥ śarīrāntaramiti jñānārthakyaṃ
analyzed: ca avaśyam śarīra antaram ārabdhavyam tatas ca karmāṇi tatas śarīra antaram iti jñāna ārthakyam
translated: And for the experience of the fruits of those actions, he must necessarily take up another body. Then, from those actions, there is another body. Thus, knowledge is useless.

analyzed: karmaṇām phalavat tvāt
translated: Because actions have results.

original: atha jñānavataḥ kṣīyante karmāṇi tadā jñānaprāptisamakālameva jñānasya satsampattihetutvānmokṣaḥ syāditi śarīrapātaḥ syāt /
analyzed: atha jñānavataḥ kṣīyante karmāṇi tadā jñāna prāpti sama kālam eva jñānasya sat sampatti hetu tvāt mokṣaḥ syāt iti śarīrapātaḥ syāt
translated: If, on the other hand, the actions of one who has knowledge are destroyed, then at the very time of attaining knowledge, there would be liberation due to knowledge being the cause of attaining the good, and there would be the falling of the body.

analyzed: tathā ca ācārya abhāva eti ācāryavān puruṣaḥ veda iti ācāryavat tva anupapattiḥ jñānāt mokṣa abhāva prasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: And thus, there would be the impossibility of having a teacher, as in the statement A person with a teacher knows the Veda. There would be the impossibility of having a teacher, the contingency of there being no liberation from knowledge,

analyzed: deśa antara prāpti upāya jñāna vat anaikāntika phala tvam vā jñānasya na
translated: Or, the result of knowledge is uncertain, like the knowledge of the means of attaining another place. No.

analyzed: karmaṇām pravṛtta apravṛtta phalavat tva viśeṣa upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible to distinguish between actions that have results that have begun and those that have not begun.

analyzed: yat uktam apravṛtta phalānām dhruva phalavat tvāt brahma vidaḥ śarīre patite śarīra antaram ārabdhavyam apravṛtta karma phala upabhogāt iti etat asat
translated: What was said - that because actions that have not begun to bear fruit have fixed results, when the body of one who knows Brahman falls, another body must be taken up in order to experience the fruits of those actions that have not begun - that is not so.

original: viduṣastasya tāvadeva ciram iti śruteḥ prāmāṇyāt /
analyzed: viduṣaḥ tasya tāvat eva ciram iti śruteḥ prāmāṇyāt
translated: Because the Vedic text, ‘For him who knows this, there is delay only so long’ is authoritative.

analyzed: nanu puṇyaḥ vai pumyena karmaṇā bhavati ityādi śruteḥ api prāmāṇyam eva
translated: But the Vedic text, ‘Verily, a man becomes good by good actions’ is also authoritative.

analyzed: tasya evam
translated: This is so.

analyzed: tathā api pravṛtta phalānām apravṛtta phalānām ca karmaṇām viśeṣaḥ sti
translated: But there is a difference between the actions whose fruits have begun to operate and those whose fruits have not begun to operate.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: yāni pravṛttaphalāni karmāṇi yairvidvaccharīramārabdhaṃ teṣāmupabhogenaiva kṣayaḥ /
analyzed: yāni pravṛtta phalāni karmāṇi yaiḥ vidvas śarīram ārabdham teṣām upabhogena eva kṣayaḥ
translated: Those actions whose fruits have begun to operate, by which the body of the knower of Brahman has been begun, they are destroyed only by being enjoyed.

original: yathā'rahdhavegasya lakṣyamukteṣvādervegakṣayādeva sthitirna tu lakṣyavedhasamakālameva prayojanaṃ nāstīti tadvat /
analyzed: yathā arahdha vegasya lakṣya mukteṣu ādeḥ vega kṣayāt eva sthitiḥ na tu lakṣya vedha sama kālam eva prayojanam na asti iti tadvat
translated: Just as an arrow shot with full force remains in the air only till the force is exhausted, not till the purpose of hitting the target is accomplished, so also those actions.

original: anyāni tvapravṛttaphalānīha prāgjñānotpatterūrdhvaṃ ca kṛtāni vā kriyamāṇāni vātītajanmāntarakṛtāni vāpravṛttaphalāni jñānena dahyante prāyaścitteneva
analyzed: anyāni tu apravṛtta phalāni iha prāk jñāna utpatteḥ ūrdhvam ca kṛtāni vā kriyamāṇāni vā atīta janmāntara kṛtāni vā apravṛtta phalāni jñānena dahyante prāyaścittena iva
translated: But the other actions, whose fruits have not begun to operate, those done before the rise of knowledge, those done afterwards, those being done, those done in other past lives, whose fruits have not begun to operate, are burnt by knowledge, as if by expiation.

analyzed: kṣīyante ca asya karmāṇi iti ca ātharvaṇe
translated: And in the Atharvaṇa it is said, ‘And his actions are destroyed.’

original: ato brahmavido jīvanādiprayojanābhāve 'pi pravṛttaphalānāṃ karmaṇāmavaśyameva phalopabhogaḥ
analyzed: atas brahma vidaḥ jīvana ādi prayojana abhāve pravṛtta phalānām karmaṇām avaśyam eva phala upabhogaḥ
translated: Therefore, even though there is no purpose for the knower of Brahman to live, etc., the fruits of the actions whose fruits have begun to operate must necessarily be experienced.

original: syāditi mukteṣuvattasya tāvadeva ciramiti yuktamevoktamiti yathoktadoṣacodanānupapattiḥ
analyzed: syāt iti mukta iṣu vat tasya tāvat eva ciram iti yuktam evā uktam iti yathā ukta doṣa codana anupapattiḥ
translated: It is proper to say, It is only for a long time as for one from whom arrows have been shot. Thus, the objection regarding the stated faults is not proper.

analyzed: jñāna utpatteḥ ūrdhvam ca brahma vidaḥ karma abhāvam avocāma brahma saṃsthaḥ mṛta tvam eti iti atra
translated: And after the arising of knowledge, we have stated the absence of action for one who knows Brahman, in the passage He who rests in Brahman attains immortality.

analyzed: tat ca smartum arhasi
translated: And you should remember that.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: He who is this subtle essence, He is all this.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is Truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: He is the Self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are That, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, O Revered One.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: To this, he said, So be it, my child.

analyzed: sa yaḥ ityādi ukta artham
translated: The meaning of He who is this etc. has been explained.

original: ācāryavānvidvānyena krameṇa satsampadyate taṃ kramaṃ dṛṣṭāntena bhūya eva mā bhagavānvijñāpayatviti /
analyzed: ācāryavān vidvān yena krameṇa sat sampadyate tam kramam dṛṣṭāntena bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: The learned one who has a teacher, in what sequence he becomes united with the True, that sequence, please explain to me again by an example, O Revered One.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: To this, he said, So be it, my child.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya caturdaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourteenth section in the sixth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: puruṣaṃ somyotopatāpinaṃ jñātayaḥ paryupāsate jānāsi māṃ jānāsi mām iti /
analyzed: puruṣam somya uta upatāpinam jñātayaḥ paryupāsate jānāsi mām jānāsi mām iti
translated: O Somya, the relatives sit around a dying man, saying, Do you know me? Do you know me?

original: tasya yāvan na vāṅ manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇas tejasi tejaḥ parasyāṃ devatāyāṃ tāvaj jānāti //
analyzed: tasya yāvat na vāc manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇaḥ tejasi tejaḥ parasyām devatāyām tāvat jānāti
translated: As long as his speech does not merge into the mind, the mind into the life-breath, the life-breath into the fire, and the fire into the Supreme Deity, he knows nothing.

original: puruṣaṃ he somyotopatāpinaṃ jvarādyupatāpavantaṃ jñātayo bāndhavāḥ
analyzed: puruṣam he somya uta upatāpinam jvara ādi upatāpavantam jñātayaḥ bāndhavāḥ
translated: His relatives, O dear one, attend upon the man who is afflicted with fever and other afflictions,

original: parivāryopāsate mumūrṣuṃ jānāsi māṃ tava pitaraṃ putraṃ bhrātaraṃ veti pṛcchantastasya🔽mumūrṣoryāvanna vāṅmanasi sampadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇastejasi tejaḥ parasyāṃ devatāyāmityetaduktartham //
analyzed: parivārya upāsate mumūrṣum jānāsi mām tava pitaram putram bhrātaram vā iti pṛcchantaḥ tasya  mumūrṣoḥ yāvat na vāc manasi sampadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇaḥ tejasi tejaḥ parasyām devatāyām iti etat ukta artham
translated: asking him, Do you know me as your father, son or brother?🔽As long as his speech does not merge into the mind, the mind into the life-breath, the life-breath into the fire, and the fire into the Supreme Deity, he knows nothing.

original: atha yadāsya vāṅ manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇas tejasi tejaḥ parasyāṃ devatāyām atha na jānāti //
analyzed: atha yadā asya vāc manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇaḥ tejasi tejaḥ parasyām devatāyām atha na jānāti
translated: Now, when his speech merges into the mind, the mind into the life-breath, the life-breath into the fire, and the fire into the Supreme Deity, then he knows nothing.

original: saṃsāriṇo yo maraṇakramaḥ sa evāyaṃ viduṣo 'pi satsampattikrama ityetadāha parasyāṃ devatāyāṃ tejasi sampanne 'tha na jānāti
analyzed: saṃsāriṇaḥ yaḥ maraṇa kramaḥ saḥ eva ayam sat sampatti kramaḥ iti etat āha parasyām devatāyām tejasi sampanne na jānāti
translated: The same process of death for the transmigrating soul is the same process of attaining the True for the knower. This is what is said. When the fire merges into the Supreme Deity, then he knows nothing.

original: avidvāṃstu sata utthāya prāgbhāvitaṃ vyāghrādibhāvaṃ devamanuṣyādibhāvaṃ vā viśati /
analyzed: a vidvān tu sataḥ utthāya prāc bhāvitam vyāghra ādi bhāvam deva manuṣya ādi bhāvam vā viśati
translated: But the ignorant one, having risen from the True, enters the state of a tiger or other animal, or the state of a god, human or other, as previously experienced.

original: vidvāṃstu śāsrācāryopadeśajanitajñānadīpaprakāśitaṃ sadbrahmātmānaṃ praviśya nā'vartata ityeṣa satsampattikramaḥ /
analyzed: vidvān tu śāsra ācārya upadeśa janita jñāna dīpa prakāśitam sat brahma ātmānam praviśya na āvartate iti eṣa sat sampatti kramaḥ
translated: But the man of knowledge, having entered into the true Brahman, whose light is illumined by the lamp of knowledge born of the teaching of the scriptures and the teacher, does not return. This is the way to attain the truth.

analyzed: anye tu mūrdhanyayā nāḍyā utkramya āditya ādi dvāreṇa sat gacchanti iti āhuḥ tat asat
translated: Others say that one goes to the truth through the sun etc. by departing through the cranial aperture. That is not so.

analyzed: deśa kāla nimitta phala abhisandhānena gamana darśanāt
translated: Because going is seen with reference to place, time, cause and result.

analyzed: na hi sat ātma ekatva darśinaḥ satya abhisandhasya deśa kāla nimitta phala ādi anṛta abhisandhiḥ upapadyate
translated: For one who sees the oneness of the Self with the true Brahman, who is intent on the truth, it is not possible to be intent on untruth in the form of place, time, cause, result etc.

analyzed: virodhāt
translated: Because of contradiction.

analyzed: avidyā kāma karmaṇām ca gamana nimittānām sat vijñāna hutāśana vipluṣṭa tvāt gamana anupapattiḥ eva
translated: And because of the burning away by the fire of the knowledge of the true Brahman of ignorance, desire and action, which are the causes of going, there can be no going at all.

analyzed: paryāpta kāmasya kṛtātmanaḥ tivahā eva sarve pravilīyanti kāmāḥ ityādi ātharvaṇe
translated: As it is said in the Atharva Veda: For one whose desires are fulfilled and whose Self is perfected, all desires are dissolved right here.

analyzed: nadī samudra dṛṣṭānta śruteḥ ca
translated: And because of the scriptural analogy of a river and the ocean.

original: sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitad ātmyam idaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: That which is the smallest of the small, that which is the subtlest of the subtle, that which is the innermost of all inner spaces, that which is the Self, that is all this.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the Self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: bhūya eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatv iti /
analyzed: bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: Please explain it to me again, O revered one.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, my son, he said.

analyzed: sa yaḥ ityādi samānam
translated: The rest is the same as before.

original: yadi mariṣyato mumukṣataśca tulyā satsampattistatra vidvānsatsampanno nā'vartata
analyzed: yadi mariṣyataḥ mumukṣataḥ ca tulyā sat sampattiḥ tatra vidvān sat sampannaḥ na āvartata
translated: If the attainment of Being is the same for one who is dying and for one who is seeking liberation, then the learned one, having attained Being, does not return.

original: āvartate tvavidvānityatra kāraṇaṃ dṛṣṭāntena bhūya eva mā bhagavānvijñāpayatviti
analyzed: āvartate tu avidvān iti atra kāraṇam dṛṣṭāntena bhūyas eva mā bhagavān vijñāpayatu iti
translated: But the ignorant one does return. Here, the reason for this is to be understood through an example. May the Blessed One please explain this again.

analyzed: tathā somya iti ha uvāca
translated: So be it, my boy, he said.

original: iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭhādhyāyasya pañcadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ🔽puruṣaṃ somyota hastagṛhītam ānayanti /
analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya pañcadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ  puruṣam somya uta hasta gṛhītam ānayanti
translated: Thus ends the Fifteenth Section in the Sixth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: apahārṣīt steyam akārṣīt paraśum asmai tapateti /
analyzed: apahārṣīt steyam akārṣīt paraśum asmai tapata iti
translated: O Somya, they bring a man, his hands bound behind him, saying, He has stolen! He has committed theft! The axe burns for him!

original: sa yadi tasya kartā bhavati tata evānṛtam ātmānaṃ kurute /
analyzed: sa yadi tasya kartā bhavati tatas eva anṛtam ātmānam kurute
translated: If he is the doer of that, then he makes himself a liar.

analyzed: saḥ nṛtā abhisaṃdhaḥ nṛtena ātmānam antardhāya paraśum taptam pratigṛhṇāti
translated: That one, whose resolve is false, having concealed himself with falsehood, takes up the burning axe.

analyzed: sa dahyate
translated: He is burned.

analyzed: atha hanyate
translated: Then he is killed.

original: śṛṇu yathā somya puruṣaṃ cauryakarmaṇi sandihyamānaṃ nigrahāya parīkṣaṇāya votāpi hastagṛhītaṃ baddhahastamānayanti rājapuruṣāḥ
analyzed: śṛṇu yathā somya puruṣam caurya karmaṇi sandihyamānam nigrahāya parīkṣaṇāya vā uta api hasta gṛhītam baddha hastam ānayanti rāja puruṣāḥ
translated: Listen, O Somya, as to how they bring a man suspected of theft for punishment and examination, his hands bound behind him, by the king's men.

analyzed: kim kṛtavān ayam iti pṛṣṭāḥ ca āhuḥ apahārśīt dhanam asya ayam
translated: And when asked what he has done, they say, He has stolen the wealth of this man.

analyzed: te ca āhuḥ kim apaharaṇa mātrā ima bandhanam arhati
translated: And they say, Should one be bound merely for stealing?

original: anyathā datte 'pi dhane bandhanaprasaṅgādityuktāḥ punarāhuḥ steyamakārṣīttauryeṇa dhanamapahārṣīditi /
analyzed: anyathā datte dhane bandhana prasaṅgāt iti uktāḥ punar āhuḥ steyam akārṣīt tauryeṇa dhanam apahārṣīt iti
translated: If not, then even if the money is given, there would be the problem of binding. Thus spoken to, they say again, You stole, you took away the money by force.

analyzed: teṣu evam vadatsu itaraḥ upahnate na aham tad kartā iti
translated: While they are speaking thus, the other denies, saying, I did not do that.

analyzed: te ca āhuḥ sandihyamānam steyam akārṣīḥ tvam asya dhanasya iti
translated: And they say, You are suspected of having stolen this money.

original: tasmiṃścāpahnavāne āhuḥ paraśumasmai tapateti śodhayatvātmānamiti /🔽sa yadi tasya stainyasya kartā bavati bahiścāpahnate sa evaṃbhūtastata evānṛtamanyathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: tasmin ca apahnavāne āhuḥ paraśum asmai tapata iti śodhayatu ātmānam iti  sa yadi tasya stainyasya kartā bavati bahis ca apahnate saḥ evaṃbhūtaḥ tatas eva anṛtam anyathābhūtam
translated: And when he denies, they say, We will heat an axe for him. Let him purify himself.🔽If he is the doer of that theft and denies externally, being such, he makes himself false, otherwise than he is.

analyzed: santam anyathā mānam kurute sa tathā anṛta abhisandhaḥ nṛtena ātmānam antardhāya vyavahitam
translated: That one, thus resolved on falsehood, having concealed himself with falsehood, having made himself hidden,

original: kṛtvā paraśuṃ taptaṃ mohātpratigṛhrāti sa dahyate 'tha hanyate rājapuruṣaiḥ svakṛtenānṛtābhisandhidoṣeṇa //
analyzed: kṛtvā paraśum taptam mohāt pratigṛhrāti sa dahyate hanyate rāja puruṣaiḥ sva kṛtena anṛta abhisandhi doṣeṇa
translated: out of delusion takes up the heated axe. He is burned, then killed by the king's men, by the fault of his own false resolve.

analyzed: atha yadi tasya akartā bhavati
translated: Now if he is not the doer of that,

analyzed: tatas eva satyam ātmānam kurute
translated: then he makes himself true.

original: sa satyābhisandhaḥ satyenātmānam antardhāya paraśuṃ taptaṃ pratigṛhṇāti /
analyzed: sa satya abhisandhaḥ satyena ātmānam antardhāya paraśum taptam pratigṛhṇāti
translated: He, being resolved on truth, having concealed himself by truth, takes up the heated axe.

analyzed: sa na dahyate
translated: He is not burned.

analyzed: atha mucyate
translated: Then he is released.

original: atha yadi tasya karmaṇo 'kartā bhavati tata eva satyamātmānaṃ kurute
analyzed: atha yadi tasya karmaṇaḥ kartā bhavati tatas eva satyam ātmānam kurute
translated: Now, if he becomes not the doer of that deed, then he makes himself true by that very (truth).

original: sa satyena tayā stainyākartṛtayā'tmānamantardhāya paraśuṃ taptaṃ pratigṛhṇāti sa
analyzed: sa satyena tayā stainya akartṛ tayā ātmānam antardhāya paraśum taptam pratigṛhṇāti sa
translated: He, being resolved on truth, having concealed himself by that truth of not being the doer of the theft, takes up the heated axe. He

original: satyābhisandhaḥ sanna dahyate satyavyavadhānādatha mucyate ca mṛṣābhiyoktṛbhyaḥ /
analyzed: satya abhisandhaḥ san na dahyate satya vyavadhānāt atha mucyate ca mṛṣā abhiyoktṛbhyaḥ
translated: being resolved on truth is not burned, because of the obstruction of truth, and then he is released from the accusers of falsehood.

original: taptaparaśuhastatalasaṃyogasya tulyatve 'pi steyakartrakartroranṛtābhisandho dahyate na tu satyābhisandhaḥ //
analyzed: tapta paraśu hasta tala saṃyogasya tulya tve pi steya kartṛ akartroḥ anṛta abhisandhaḥ dahyate na tu satya abhisandhaḥ
translated: Even though the contact of the hand with the heated axe is the same, the one who is resolved on falsehood is burned, but not the one who is resolved on truth.

analyzed: sa yathā tatra na ādāhyeta
translated: So that he may not be burned there,

analyzed: etat ātmyam idam sarvam
translated: this is the Self, all this.

analyzed: tat satyam
translated: That is truth.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: That is the Self.

analyzed: tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti
translated: You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: tad dhāsya vijajñāv iti vijajñāv iti //
analyzed: tat ha asya vijajñau iti vijajñau iti
translated: Then he understood it. He understood it thus.

analyzed: sa yathā satya abhisandhaḥ tapta paraśu grahaṇa karmaṇi satya vyavahita hasta tala tvāt na ādāhyeta
translated: As he, being resolved on truth, would not be burned in the act of taking up the heated axe, because of the obstruction of truth in the hand,

original: na dahyetetyetadevaṃ sadbrahmasatyābhisandhītarayoḥ śarīrapātakāle ca tulyāyāṃ satsampattau
analyzed: na dahyeta iti etat evam sat brahma satya abhisandhi itarayoḥ śarīrapāta kāle ca tulyāyām sat sampattau
translated: The two, the knower of the Self and the non-knower of the Self, who have the same attainment of the True at the time of the fall of the body,

analyzed: vidvān sat sampadya na punar vyāghra deva ādi deha grahaṇāya āvartate
translated: the knower of the Self, having attained the True, does not return to take up a body as a tiger, a god, etc.

original: avidvāṃstu vikārānṛtābhisandhaḥ punarvyāghrādibhāvaṃ devatādibhāvaṃ vā yathākarma yathāśrutaṃ pratipadyate /
analyzed: a vidvān tu vikāra anṛta abhisandhaḥ punar vyāghra ādi bhāvam devatā ādi bhāvam vā yathākarma yathāśrutam pratipadyate
translated: But the non-knower of the Self, who has the idea of the modifications as True, again takes up the state of a tiger, etc. or the state of a god, etc., according to his actions and as he has heard.

original: yadātmābhisandhyanabhisandhikṛte mokṣabandhane yacca mūlaṃ jagato yadāyatanā yatpratiṣṭhāśca
analyzed: yad ātma abhisandhi an abhisandhi kṛte mokṣa bandhane yat ca mūlam jagataḥ yad āyatanāḥ yad pratiṣṭhāḥ ca
translated: That by which there is the bondage of liberation and non-liberation due to the idea of the Self and not having the idea of the Self, which is the root of the world, which is the abode and the support

original: sarvāḥ prajā yadātmakaṃ ca sarvaṃ yaccājamamṛtamabhayaṃ śivamadvitīyaṃ tatsatyaṃ
analyzed: sarvāḥ prajāḥ yad ātmakam ca sarvam yat ca ajam amṛtam abhayam śivam advitīyam tat satyam
translated: of all beings, which is the Self of all, and which is unborn, immortal, fearless, auspicious, and without a second, that is the Truth,

original: sa ātmā tavātastattvamasi he śvetaketo ityuktārthamasakṛdvākyam /
analyzed: saḥ ātmā tava atas tat tvam asi he śvetaketo iti ukta artham asakṛt vākyam
translated: that is the Self, therefore you are That, O Śvetaketu. The sentence has been stated many times.

analyzed: kaḥ punar asau śvetaketuḥ tvam śabda arthaḥ
translated: But who is that Śvetaketu who is the meaning of the word 'you'?

original: yo 'haṃ śvetaketuruddālakasya putra iti vedā'tmānamādeśaṃ śrutvā matvā vijñāya cāśrutamamatamavijñātaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ ham śvetaketuḥ uddālakasya putraḥ iti veda ātmānam ādeśam śrutvā matvā vijñāya ca a śrutam amatam avijñātam
translated: He who, having heard, understood, and known the teaching that 'I am Śvetaketu, the son of Uddālaka', and having heard, understood, and known what has not been heard, understood, or known,

original: vijñātuṃ pitaraṃ papraccha kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bavatīti sa eṣo 'dhikṛtaḥ
analyzed: vijñātum pitaram papraccha katham nu bhagavaḥ saḥ ādeśaḥ bavati iti saḥ eṣaḥ dhikṛtaḥ
translated: In order to understand this, he asked his father: 'Sir, how does that instruction come about?' He, being qualified,

original: śrotā mantā vijñātā tejobannamayaṃ kāryakāraṇasaṅghātaṃ praviṣṭā paraiva devatā nāmasvarūpavyākaraṇāyā'darśa
analyzed: śrotā mantā vijñātā tejaḥ banna mayam kārya kāraṇa saṅghātam praviṣṭā parā eva devatā nāma svarūpa vyākaraṇāya adarśa
translated: the hearer, the thinker, the knower, having entered the aggregate of effects and causes consisting of fire and food, is the very same divine being, for the purpose of having his name and form explained,

analyzed: iva puruṣaḥ sūryāduḥ iva jala ādau pratibodhitaḥ tat tvam asi iti dṛṣṭāntaiḥ hetubhiḥ ca tad pituḥ asya
translated: like a man in a mirror, or like the sun in water, etc., having been awakened, by the examples and reasons such as 'That thou art', he, his father,

analyzed: ha kila uktam sat eva aham asmi iti vijajñau vijñātavān
translated: has indeed said this. He has understood, has known, 'I am indeed that very existent one.'

analyzed: dvirvacanam adhyāya parisamāpti artham
translated: The repetition is for the completion of the chapter.

original: kiṃ punaratra ṣaṣṭhe vākyapramāṇena janitaṃ phalam /
analyzed: kim punar atra ṣaṣṭhe vākya pramāṇena janitam phalam
translated: What, then, is the result produced here in the sixth by the means of valid knowledge of speech?

original: ātmani kartṛtvabhoktṛtvayoradhikṛtatvavijñānanivṛttistasya phalaṃ yaṃ vayamavocāma tvaṃśabdavācyamarthaṃ śrotuṃ mantuṃ cādhikṛtamavijñātavijñānaphalārtham
analyzed: ātmani kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tvayoḥ adhikṛta tva vijñāna nivṛttiḥ tasya phalam yam vayam avocāma tvad śabda vācyam artham śrotum mantum ca adhikṛtam avijñāta vijñāna phala artham
translated: The result of that is the cessation of the knowledge of being qualified for action and enjoyment in the self, which we have said is the object denoted by the word 'you', qualified to hear and think about the meaning for the purpose of the result of knowing the unknown,

analyzed: prāk ca etasmāt vijñānāt aham evam kariṣyāmi agnihotra ādīni karmāṇi aham atra adhikṛtaḥ
translated: and before this knowledge, 'I shall perform such actions as the Agnihotra, I am qualified for this.'

original: eṣāṃ ca karmaṇāṃ phalamihāmutra ca bhokṣye kṛteṣu vā karmasu kṛtakartavyaḥ syāmityevaṃ
analyzed: eṣām ca karmaṇām phalam iha amutra ca bhokṣye kṛteṣu vā karmasu kṛta kartavyaḥ syām iti evam
translated: And when the fruits of these acts are enjoyed here and hereafter, or when the acts are done, he would be one who has done his duty. Thus

analyzed: kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tvayoḥ smi iti ātmani yat vijñānam abhūt tat tasya yat sat jagataḥ mūlam ekam eva advitīyam
translated: the knowledge that he is entitled to the states of agent and enjoyer in the self, that is his. That which is the one, non-dual, root of this real world,

analyzed: tat tvam asi iti anena vākyena pratibuddhasya nivartate
translated: for one who is enlightened by the sentence That thou art, that [knowledge of the non-dual Self] ceases.

analyzed: virodhāt
translated: Because of contradiction.

original: na hyekasminnadvitīya ātmanyayamahamasmīti vijñāte mamedamanyadanena kartavyamidaṃ kṛtvāsya phalaṃ bhokṣya iti vā bhedavijñānamupapadyate /
analyzed: na hi ekasmin advitīye ātmani ayam aham asmi iti vijñāte mama idam anyat anena kartavyam idam kṛtvā asya phalam bhokṣye iti vā bheda vijñānam upapadyate
translated: For when it is known that I am He, the one, non-dual Self, the knowledge of difference, that This is different from me, this should be done by me, having done this, I will enjoy its fruit, is not possible.

analyzed: tasmāt sat satya advitīya ātma vijñāne vikāra anṛta jīva ātma vijñānam nivartate iti yuktam
translated: Therefore, it is right that the knowledge of the changing, unreal individual self ceases in the knowledge of the real, non-dual Self.

original: nanu tattvamasītyatra tvaṃśabdavācyer'the sadbuddhirādhitsyate yathā'dityamana ādiṣu brahmādibuddhiḥ /
analyzed: nanu tat tvam asi iti atra tvaṃśabda vācya ṛthe sat buddhiḥ ādhitsyate yathā āditya manaḥ ādiṣu brahma ādi buddhiḥ
translated: But in That thou art, the idea of reality is intended to be imposed on the object denoted by the word thou, just as the idea of Brahman, etc. is [imposed] on the sun, etc.,

original: yathā ca loke pratimādiṣu viṣṇvādibuddhistadvannatu sadeva tvamiti /
analyzed: yathā ca loke pratimā ādiṣu viṣṇu ādi buddhiḥ tadvat na tu sat eva tvam iti
translated: and just as the idea of Vishnu, etc. is [imposed] on images, etc. in the world. But it is not that thou is real.

original: yadi sadeva śvetaketuḥ syātkathamātmānaṃ na vijānīyādyena tasmai tattvamasītyupadiśyate / na /
analyzed: yadi sat eva śvetaketuḥ syāt katham ātmānam na vijānīyāt yena tasmai tat tvam asi iti upadiśyate na
translated: If Śvetaketu were really existent, how could he not know the Self, for whose sake it is taught to him that ‘That thou art’?—No;🔽

analyzed: āditya ādi vākya vailakṣaṇyāt
translated: because of the difference from the statements about Āditya and so on.

analyzed: ādityaḥ brahma ityādau itiśabda vyavadhānāt na sākṣāt brahmatvam gamyate
translated: In the statements ‘Āditya is Brahman’ and so on, the word ‘is’ is interposed, and so it is not directly understood that they are Brahman.

original: rūpādimattvāccā'dityādīnāmākāśamanasoścetiśabdavyavadhānādevābrahmatvamiha tu sata eveha praveśaṃ darśayitvā tattvamasīti niraṅkuśaṃ sadātmabhāvamupadiśati
analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvāt ca āditya ādīnām ākāśa manasoḥ ca iti śabda vyavadhānāt eva a brahmatvam iha tu sataḥ eva iha praveśam darśayitvā tat tvam asi iti niraṅkuśam sat ātma bhāvam upadiśati
translated: And because Āditya and so on have form and other qualities, and because Ākāśa and Manas are only indirectly Brahman because of the word ‘ca’ (in the text). But here, after showing the entry of the existent one into this (world), it is taught without restraint that the nature of the Self is the existent one, by saying ‘That thou art.’

original: nanu parākramādiguṇaḥ siṃho 'si tvamitivattattvamasīti syāt / na /
analyzed: nanu parākrama ādi guṇaḥ siṃhaḥ si tvam iti vat tat tvam asi iti syāt na
translated: But it may be argued that just as one says ‘You are a lion with the qualities of valour and so on,’ so it is said ‘That thou art.’ No;

analyzed: mṛd ādi vat sat ekam eva advitīyam satyam iti upadeśāt
translated: because of the teaching that the existent one alone is without a second, like clay and so on.

analyzed: na ca upacāra vijñānāt tasya tāvat eva ciram iti sat sampattiḥ ūpadiśyeta
translated: And the attainment of the existent one cannot be taught by the knowledge of figurative usage, that ‘For him it is a long time,’

analyzed: mṛṣātvāt upacāra vijñānasya
translated: because the knowledge of figurative usage is false.

analyzed: tvam indraḥ si yamaḥ itivat  nā api stutiḥ anupāsya tvāt śvetaketoḥ
translated: Like the statement ‘You are Indra, you are Yama.’🔽Nor is it praise, because Śvetaketu is not to be meditated upon.

analyzed: na api sat śvetaketu tva upadeśena stūyeta
translated: Nor would he be praised by the teaching that the existent one is Śvetaketu.

original: na hi rājā dāsastvamiti stutyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na hi rājā dāsaḥ tvam iti stutyaḥ syāt
translated: For one is not praised by saying ‘You are a king, you are a slave.’

original: nāpi sataḥ sarvātmana ekadeśanirodho yuktastattvamasīti deśādhipateriva grāmādhyakṣastvamiti /
analyzed: na api sataḥ sarvātmanaḥ eka deśa nirodhaḥ yuktaḥ tat tvam asi iti deśa adhipateḥ iva grāma adhyakṣaḥ tvam iti
translated: Nor is it proper that the whole of the existent should be obstructed in one part, as in the case of the lord of a country, the governor of a village is said to be the country.

analyzed: na ca anyā gatiḥ iha sat ātmatva upadeśāt artha antara bhūtā sambhavati
translated: And there is no other way here apart from the teaching of the identity with the existent.

original: nanu sadasmītibuddhimātramiha kartavyatayā codyate na tvajñātaṃ sadasīti jñāpyata iti cet /
analyzed: nanu sat asmi iti buddhi mātram iha kartavya tayā codyate na tu ajñātam sat asi iti jñāpyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that here only the idea I am existent is enjoined as something to be done, and not that I am the unknown existent is to be made known,

analyzed: nanu asmin pakṣe pi aśrutam śrutam bhavati ityādi anupapannam
translated: then even in this view, the statement what was not heard becomes heard and so on would be inappropriate.

analyzed: na sat asmi iti buddhi vidheḥ stuti artha tvāt
translated: No, because the injunction to have the idea I am existent is for the purpose of praise.

original: na / ācāryavānpuruṣo veda tasya tāvadeva ciramityupadeśāt /
analyzed: na ācāryavān puruṣaḥ veda tasya tāvat eva ciram iti upadeśāt
translated: No, because of the teaching A person who has a teacher knows, for him that alone is for a long time.

original: yadi hi sadasmīti buddhimātraṃ kartavyatayā vidhīyate na tu tvaṃśabdavācyasya sadrūpatvameva tadā nā'cāryavānvedeti jñānopāyopadeśo vācyaḥ
analyzed: yadi hi sat asmi iti buddhi mātram kartavyatayā vidhīyate na tu tvaṃśabda vācyasya sat rūpa tvam eva tadā na ācāryavān veda iti jñāna upāya upadeśaḥ vācyaḥ
translated: For if only the idea I am existent is enjoined as something to be done, and not the nature of the one denoted by the word you as existent, then the teaching of the means of knowledge should not be stated as one who has a teacher knows.

analyzed: yathā agnihotram juhuyāt iti evamādiṣu artha prāptam eva ācāryavat tvam iti tadvat
translated: Just as in statements like one should offer the agnihotra, the having a teacher is already implied, so it is here.

original: tasya tāvadeva ciramiti ca kṣepakaraṇaṃ na yuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tasya tāvat eva ciram iti ca kṣepa karaṇam na yuktam syāt
translated: And the dismissal that alone is for a long time would not be appropriate.

analyzed: sat ātma tattve vijñāte sakṛt buddhi mātra karaṇe mokṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: For, if the truth about the Self were not known, then liberation would follow from the mere production of the knowledge of the Self once.

original: na ca tattvamasītyukte nāhaṃ saditipramāṇavākyajanitā buddhīrnivartayituṃ śakyā notpanneti vā śakyaṃ vaktum /
analyzed: na ca tat tvam asi iti ukte na aham sat iti pramāṇa vākya janitāḥ buddhīḥ nivartayitum śakyā nā utpannā iti vā śakyam vaktum
translated: And when it is said, 'That thou art,' it is not possible to say that the knowledge produced by the authoritative statement, 'I am not real,' is not to be averted, or that it is not produced.

analyzed: sarva upaniṣad vākyānām tad para tayā eva upakṣayāt
translated: Because all the Upaniṣadic statements are subsumed under that alone.

analyzed: yathā agnihotra ādi vidhi janita agnihotra ādi kartavya tā buddhīnām atathārtha tvam anutpanna tvam vā na śakyate vaktum tadvat
translated: Just as it is not possible to say that the knowledge of the duty to perform the Agnihotra, etc., produced by the injunctions to perform the Agnihotra, etc., is not true or not produced, so it is in this case.

original: yattūktaṃ sadātmā sannātmānaṃ kathaṃ na jānīyāditi /
analyzed: yat tu uktam sat ātmā sanna ātmānam katham na jānīyāt iti
translated: But it has been said: 'How is it that the real Self does not know itself as real?'

analyzed: na asau doṣaḥ
translated: That is not a fault.

original: kāryakaraṇasaṅghātavyatirikto 'haṃ jīvaḥ kartā bhoktetyapi svabhāvataḥ prāṇināṃ vijñānādarśanātkisu tasya sadātmavijñānam /
analyzed: kārya karaṇa saṅghāta vyatiriktaḥ ham jīvaḥ kartā bhoktā iti api svabhāvataḥ prāṇinām vijñāna adarśanāt kisu tasya sat ātma vijñānam
translated: Because the knowledge of the individual soul, the agent and enjoyer separate from the aggregate of body and organs, is not seen in living beings by nature, how can there be the knowledge of the real Self for it?

original: kathamevaṃ vyatiriktavijñāne sati teṣāṃ kartṛtvādivijñānaṃ sambhavati dṛśyate ca /
analyzed: katham evam vyatirikta vijñāne sati teṣām kartṛ tva ādi vijñānam sambhavati dṛśyate ca
translated: And how is it possible for them to have the knowledge of being the agent, etc., when there is the knowledge of being separate? And it is seen.

analyzed: tadvat tasya api deha ādiṣu ātma buddhi tvāt na syāt sat ātma vijñānam
translated: In the same way, for it also, because of the knowledge of the Self in the body, etc., there would not be the knowledge of the real Self.

original: tasmādvikārānṛtādhikṛtajīvātmavijñānanivartakamevedaṃ vākyaṃ tattvamasīti siddhamiti //🔽iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭhādhyāyasya ṣoḍaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
analyzed: tasmāt vikāra anṛta adhikṛta jīvātma vijñāna nivartakam eva idam vākyam tat tvam asi iti siddham iti  iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya ṣoḍaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is established that this statement, 'That thou art', serves only to set aside the knowledge of the individual soul, which is based on the untruth of modification.🔽Thus ends the sixteenth section in the sixth chapter of Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣad brāhmaṇe ṣaṣṭhaḥ udhyāyaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus ends the sixth chapter of Chāndogya Upaniṣad-Brāhmaṇa.

analyzed: atha saptamaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Now begins the seventh chapter.

original: adhīhi bhagava iti hopasasāda sanatkumāraṃ nāradaḥ /
analyzed: adhīhi bhagavaḥ iti ha upasasāda sanatkumāram nāradaḥ
translated: Narada approached Sanatkumara, saying, Venerable Sir, teach me.

original: taṃ hovāca yad vettha tena mopasīda /
analyzed: tam ha uvāca yat vettha tena mā upasīda
translated: He said to him, Approach me with what you know.

analyzed: tatas te ūrdhvam vakṣyāmi iti
translated: Then I will tell you what is beyond that.

analyzed: sa ha uvāca
translated: He said:
The sixth chapter, which is mainly concerned with the teaching of the ultimate truth, is useful only in determining the oneness of the Self and Being.

original: na sator'vāgvikāralakṣaṇāni tattvāni nirdiṣṭānītyatastāni nāmādīni prāṇāntāni krameṇa🔽nirdiśya taddvāreṇāpi bhūmākhyaṃ niratiśayaṃ tattvaṃ nirdekṣyāmīti śākhācandradarśanavaditīnaṃ
analyzed: na satoḥ vāc vikāra lakṣaṇāni tattvāni nirdiṣṭāni iti atas tāni nāma ādīni prāṇa antāni krameṇa  nirdiśya tad dvāreṇa api bhūma ākhyam niratiśayam tattvam nirdekṣyāmi iti śākhā candra darśana vat itīnam
translated: The truths characterized by modifications below Being have not been indicated. Therefore, those truths beginning with name and ending with vital force, in order,🔽having indicated them, I will teach the truth called the Supreme Self through that door also. This is the seventh section,

analyzed: saptamam prapāṭhakam ārabhate
translated: like seeing the moon in a branch.🔽He begins.

original: anirdiṣṭeṣu hi sator'vāktattveṣu sanmātre ca nirdiṣṭe 'nyadapyavijñātaṃ syādityāśaṅkā kasyacitsyātsā mā bhūditi vā tāni nirdidikṣati /
analyzed: a nirdiṣṭeṣu hi satoḥ vāc tattveṣu sat mātre ca nirdiṣṭe syāt iti āśaṅkā kasyacid syāt sā mā bhūt iti vā tāni nirdidikṣati
translated: For, when the existent things below Brahman have not been pointed out, and only the mere existent Brahman has been pointed out, some one might entertain the doubt that there are other things also which are not known; in order to remove this doubt, he points out those things.

original: athavā sopānārohaṇavatsthūlādārabhya sūkṣmaṃ sūkṣamataṃ ca buddhiviṣayaṃ jñāpayitvā tadatirikte svārājye 'bhiṣekṣyāmīti nāmādīni nirdidikṣati
analyzed: athavā sopāna ārohaṇa vat sthūlāt ārabhya sūkṣmam ca buddhi viṣayam jñāpayitvā tad atirikte svārājye bhiṣekṣyāmi iti nāma ādīni nirdidikṣati
translated: Or, he points out the name, &c., thinking, As one who climbs a flight of steps begins with the broad steps and then gradually reaches the more and more slender ones, so I will teach him the objects of the buddhi, beginning with the gross ones and ending with the subtile ones, and then will consecrate him in the sovereignty over the Self which is beyond them.

original: athavā nāmādyuttarottaraviśiṣṭāni tattvānyatitarāṃ ca teṣāmutkṛṣṭatamaṃ bhūmākhyaṃ tattvamiti tatstutyarthaṃ nāmādīnāṃ krameṇopanyāsaḥ /
analyzed: athavā nāma ādi uttarottara viśiṣṭāni tattvāni atitarām ca teṣām utkṛṣṭatamam bhūma ākhyam tattvam iti tad stuti artham nāma ādīnām krameṇa upanyāsaḥ
translated: Or else, the names, &c., are mentioned in succession in order to glorify the highest truth, which is called the bhūman, the highest of all the truths, which are distinguished by their increasing subtility, and which begin with the name.

analyzed: ākhyāyikā tu para vidyā stuti arthā
translated: The story is meant to glorify the highest knowledge.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

original: nārado devarṣiḥ kṛtakartavyaḥ sarvavidyo 'pi sannanātmajñatvācchuśocaiva kimu vaktavyamanyo 'lpavijjanturakṛtapuṇyātiśayo 'kṛtārtha iti /
analyzed: nāradaḥ deva ṛṣiḥ kṛta kartavyaḥ sarva vidyaḥ sarva vidyaḥ san an ātma jña tvāt śuśoca eva kimu vaktavyam anyaḥ lpa vid jantuḥ akṛta puṇya atiśayaḥ kṛtārthaḥ iti
translated: The divine sage Nārada, although he had performed all that was to be performed, and was omniscient, still grieved because he did not know the Self; how much more then other men, who are of little knowledge, who have not performed meritorious actions, and who have not attained their end?

analyzed: athavā na anyat ātma jñānāt niratiśaya śreyaḥ sādhanam asti iti etad pradarśana artham sanatkumāra nārada ākhyāyikā ārabhyate
translated: Or, in order to show that there is no other means of attaining the highest good than the knowledge of the Self, the story of Sanatkumāra and Nārada is begun.

original: yena sarvavijñānasādhanaśaktisampannasyāpi nāradasya devarṣeḥ śreyo na babhūva yenottamābhijanavidyāvṛttasādhanaśaktisampattinimittābhi
analyzed: yena sarva vijñāna sādhana śakti sampannasya api nāradasya deva ṛṣeḥ śreyaḥ na babhūva yena uttama abhijana vidyā vṛtta sādhana śakti sampatti nimitta abhi
translated: By which, although Nārada, the celestial sage, was endowed with the power to know everything, he did not attain the highest good. Therefore,

analyzed: mānam hitvā prākṛta puruṣa vat sanatkumāram upasasāda śreyaḥ sādhana prāptaye prakhyāpitam
translated: having abandoned the pride caused by the possession of the best lineage, learning, conduct, and the power to attain the means, he approached Sanatkumāra like an ordinary person, in order to attain the means of attaining the highest good. Therefore,

original: bhavati niratiśayaprāptisādhanatvamātmavidyāyā iti /🔽adhīhyadhīṣva bhagavā bha vinniti kilopasasāda /
analyzed: bhavati niratiśaya prāpti sādhana tvam ātma vidyāyāḥ iti  adhīhi adhīṣva bhagavān bha vid iti kila upasasāda
translated: it is proclaimed that the knowledge of the Self is the means of attaining the highest good.🔽He approached, saying, Teach me, O revered one, it is said.

analyzed: adhīhi bhagavaḥ iti mantraḥ
translated: The mantra is Teach me, O revered one.

analyzed: sanatkumāram yogi īśvaram brahmiṣṭham nāradaḥ upasannavān
translated: Nārada approached Sanatkumāra, the lord of yogis, the most Brahmanic one.

original: taṃ nyāyata upasannaṃ hovāca yadātmaviṣaye kiñcidvettha tena tatprakhyāpanena māmupasīdedamahaṃ
analyzed: tam nyāyataḥ upasannam ha uvāca yat ātma viṣaye kiñcid vettha tena tad prakhyāpanena mām upasīda idam aham
translated: To him, who approached in the proper way, he said, Whatever you know about the Self, by proclaiming that, approach me. I will teach you the Self.

original: jāna iti tato 'haṃ bhavato vijñānātte tubyamūrdhvaṃ vakṣyāmītyuktavati sa hovāca nāradaḥ //
analyzed: jāne iti tatas ham bhavataḥ vijñānāt te tubyam ūrdhvam vakṣyāmi iti uktavati sa ha uvāca nāradaḥ
translated: Then, when I have understood this from you, I will tell you what is above that. When he said this, Narada said:

analyzed: ṛgvedam bhagavaḥ dhyemi yajurvedam sāmavedam ātharvaṇam caturtham itihāsa purāṇam

analyzed: brahma vidyām bhūta vidyām kṣatra vidyām nakṣatra vidyām sarpa deva jana vidyām etat bhagavaḥ

original: tathā yajurvedaṃ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthaṃ vedaṃ vedaśabdasya prakṛtatvāditihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedaṃ vedānāṃ bhāratapañcamānāṃ vedaṃ

translated: For the Rig Veda and others are known by grammar through the division of words and so on.

analyzed: pitryam śrāddha kalpam  kāśim gaṇitam

analyzed: daivam utpāta jñānam
translated: The science of astrology is the knowledge of portents.

analyzed: nidhim mahākāla ādi nidhi śāstram
translated: The science of treasure is the treatise on treasure such as Mahakalatantra.

analyzed: vākovākyam tarka śāsram
translated: The science of logic is the science of grammar.

analyzed: ekāyanam nīti śāsram
translated: The science of politics is the science of polity.

analyzed: deva vidyām niruktam
translated: The science of the gods is etymology.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ ṛk yajuḥ sāma ākhyasya vidyām brahma vidyām śikṣā kalpa chandaḥ vicitayaḥ
translated: The science of the Veda called Rig, Yajur, and Sama is the science of Brahman. The sciences of prosody, ritual, and grammar are the branches of the science of Brahman.

analyzed: bhūtavidyām bhūtatantram
translated: The science of beings is the science of natural philosophy.

analyzed: kṣattra vidyām dhanurvedam
translated: The science of the Kshatriyas is the science of archery.

analyzed: nakṣatra vidyām jyautiṣam
translated: The science of the stars is the science of astrology.

analyzed: sarpa deva jana vidyām sarpa vidyām gāruḍam deva jana vidyām gandha yukti nṛtya gīta vādyi śilpa ādi vijñānāni
translated: The science of the serpents and the gods is the science of the serpents and the science of the gods. The knowledge of perfumes, composition, dance, music, and the arts, etc. is the science of the gods.

analyzed: etat sarvam he bhagavaḥ dhyemi
translated: All this, O revered one, I study.

analyzed: saḥ ham bhagavaḥ mantra vid eva asmi na ātma vid
translated: I, O revered one, am indeed a knower of mantras, but not a knower of the self.

original: śrutaṃ hy eva me bhagavaddṛśebhyas tarati śokam ātmavid iti /
analyzed: śrutam hi eva me bhagavat dṛśebhyaḥ tarati śokam ātma vid iti
translated: For I have heard from the seers of the revered one that one who knows the self crosses over sorrow.

analyzed: saḥ ham bhagavaḥ śocāmi
translated: Therefore, O revered one, I grieve.

original: taṃ mā bhagavāñ chokasya pāraṃ tārayatv iti /
analyzed: tam mā bhagavān śokasya pāram tārayatu iti

analyzed: na ca vikāraḥ ātmā iṣyate

analyzed: nanu ātmā api ātma śabdena abhidhīyate

analyzed: nayataḥ vācaḥ nivartante

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ

translated: The word, when used in regard to the internal Self who possesses a body and is the object of the distinction, when the Selfhood of the body, etc. is denied, conveys the knowledge of that which remains, though inexpressible.

translated: Therefore, I am only one who knows mantras and knows rituals, and everything to be done by rituals is modification, so I am only a knower of modification, not a knower of the Self, not a knower of the nature of the Self. This is the meaning.

analyzed: brahma vidyām bhūta vidyām kṣatra vidyām nakṣatra vidyām sarpa deva jana vidyām divam ca
