original: yadyadi vāṅnābhaviṣyaddharmādi na vyajñāpayiṣyadvāgabhāve 'dhyayanābhāve tadarthaśravaṇābhāvastacchravaṇābhāve dharmādi na vyajñāpayiṣyanna
analyzed: yat yadi vāc na abhaviṣyat dharma ādi na vyajñāpayiṣyat vāc abhāve dhyayana abhāve tad artha śravaṇa abhāvaḥ tad śravaṇa abhāve dharma ādi na vyajñāpayiṣyat na
translated: If there were no speech, it would not make known Dharma, etc. In the absence of speech, there would be no study. In the absence of hearing its meaning, it would not make known Dharma, etc.

analyzed: vijñātam abhaviṣyat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it would not be known.

original: tasmādvāgevaitacchabdoccāraṇena sarvaṃ vijñāpayatyato bhūyasī vāṅnāmnastasmādvācaṃ brahmetyupāḥsva //
analyzed: tasmāt vāc eva etat śabda uccāraṇena sarvam vijñāpayati atas bhūyasī vāc nāmnaḥ tasmāt vācam brahma iti upāḥsva
translated: Therefore, speech alone makes known everything by uttering these sounds. Therefore, speech is greater than name. Therefore, meditate upon speech as Brahman.

analyzed: sa yaḥ vācam brahma iti upāste
translated: One who meditates upon speech as Brahman,

original: yāvad vāco gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati yo vācaṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: yāvat vācaḥ gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ vācam brahma iti upāste
translated: As far as speech goes, he has power over it, who worships speech as Brahman.

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ vācaḥ bhūyaḥ iti
translated: 'Is there anything greater than speech, Revered Sir?'

analyzed: vācaḥ vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: 'Certainly, speech is greater.'

analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti
translated: 'Revered sir, please tell me that.'

analyzed: samānam anyat
translated: The rest is the same as before.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Second Section of the Seventh Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: manaḥ vāva vācaḥ bhūyaḥ
translated: The mind, verily, is greater than speech.

original: yathā vai dve vāmalake dve vā kole dvau vākṣau muṣṭir anubhavaty evaṃ vācaṃ ca nāma ca mano 'nubhavati /
analyzed: yathā vai dve vā āmalake dve vā kole dvau vā akṣau muṣṭiḥ anubhavati evam vācam ca nāma ca manaḥ nubhavati
translated: Just as a fist experiences two myrobalans or two jujubes or two eyes, so the mind experiences speech and name.

original: sa yadā manasā manasyati mantrān adhīyīyety athādhīte /
analyzed: sa yadā manasā manasyati mantrān adhīyīya iti atha adhīte
translated: When he mentally resolves, 'I will study the mantras,' then he studies.

analyzed: karmāṇi kurvīya iti atha kurute
translated: 'I will perform rites,' then he performs.

analyzed: putrān ca paśūn ca iccheya iti atha icchate
translated: 'I will desire sons and cattle,' then he desires.

original: imaṃ ca lokam amuṃ ceccheyety athecchate /
analyzed: imam ca lokam amum ca iccheya iti atha icchate
translated: 'I will desire this world and the next,' then he desires.

analyzed: manaḥ hi ātmā
translated: For the mind is the self.

analyzed: manaḥ hi lokaḥ
translated: The mind is the world.

analyzed: manaḥ hi brahma
translated: The mind is Brahman.

analyzed: manaḥ upāssva iti  manaḥ manasyana viśiṣṭam antaḥkaraṇam vācaḥ bhūyaḥ
translated: Meditate upon the mind.'🔽The mind, the internal organ distinguished by the activity of mental resolve, is greater than speech.

analyzed: tat hi manasyana vyāpāravat vācam vaktavye prerayati
translated: For it, having the activity of mental resolve, impels speech to speak what is to be spoken.

analyzed: tena vāc manasi antarbhavati
translated: Therefore, speech is included in the mind.

original: yacca yasminnantarbhavati tattasya vyāpakatvāttato bhūyo bhavati /
analyzed: yat ca yasmin antarbhavati tat tasya vyāpaka tvāt tatas bhūyas bhavati
translated: And that which is included in something else is greater than that, because it pervades it.

original: yathā vai loke dve vā'malake phale dve vā kole badaraphale dvau vākṣau vibhītakaphale muṣṭiranubhavati muṣṭiste phale vyāpnoti muṣṭau hi te🔽antarbhavataḥ /
analyzed: yathā vai loke dve vā āmalake phale dve vā kole badara phale dvau vā akṣau vibhītaka phale muṣṭiḥ anubhavati muṣṭiḥ te phale vyāpnoti muṣṭau hi te  antarbhavataḥ
translated: Just as in the world, two āmalaka fruits or two kola fruits or two akṣa fruits are experienced by a fist, the fist experiences those fruits, for they are included in the fist.

analyzed: evam vācam ca nāma ca āmalaka ādi vat manaḥ nubhavati
translated: In the same way, the mind experiences speech and name, like the āmalaka fruit etc.

original: sa yadā puruṣe yasminkāle manasāntaḥkaraṇena manasyati manasyanaṃ vivakṣābuddhiḥ kathaṃ /🔽mantrānadhīyīyoccārayeyamityevaṃ vivakṣāṃ kṛtvāthādhīte tathā karmāṇi kurvīyeti cikīrṣābuddhiṃ
analyzed: sa yadā puruṣe yasmin kāle manasā antaḥkaraṇena manasyati manasyanam vivakṣā buddhiḥ katham  mantrān adhīyīya uccārayeyam iti evam vivakṣām kṛtvā atha adhīte tathā karmāṇi kurvīya iti cikīrṣā buddhim
translated: When in a person, at that time, when one thinks with the internal organ of the mind, thinking is the cognition of desire to speak. How?🔽Having formed the desire to speak thus: I will recite the mantras, I will utter them, then one recites. Having formed the intention thus: I will perform actions, then one performs.

original: kṛtvātha kurute putrāṃśca paśūṃśceccheyeti prāptīcchāṃ kṛtvā tatprāptyupāyānuṣṭhānenāthecchate
analyzed: kṛtvā atha kurute putrān ca paśūn ca iccheya iti prāpti icchām kṛtvā tad prāpti upāya anuṣṭhānena atha icchate
translated: Having formed the desire to obtain sons and animals, then one desires them by performing the means to obtain them.

analyzed: putra ādīn prāpnoti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that one obtains sons etc.

original: tathemaṃ ca lokamamuṃ copāyeneccheyeti tatpraptyupāyānuṣṭhānenāthecchace prāpnoti /
analyzed: tathā imam ca lokam amum ca upāyena iccheya iti tad prapti upāya anuṣṭhānena atha icchace prāpnoti
translated: In the same way, having formed the desire to obtain this world and the other world by some means, one desires them by performing the means to obtain them. One obtains them.

original: mano hyātmā'tmanaḥ kartṛtvaṃ bhoktṛtvaṃ ca sati manasi nānyatheti mano hyātmetyucyate /
analyzed: manaḥ hi ātmā ātmanaḥ kartṛ tvam bhoktṛ tvam ca sati manasi na anyathā iti manaḥ hi ātmā iti ucyate
translated: For the self is the mind. The self's agency and enjoyership are possible only when the mind exists, not otherwise. Therefore, the mind is said to be the self.

original: mano hi lokaḥ satyeva hi manasi loko bhavati tatprāptyupāyānuṣṭhānaṃ ceti mano hi loko yasmāttasmānmano hi brahma /
analyzed: manaḥ hi lokaḥ sati eva hi manasi lokaḥ bhavati tad prāpti upāya anuṣṭhānam ca iti manaḥ hi lokaḥ yasmāt tasmāt manaḥ hi brahma
translated: For the mind is the world. The world exists only when the mind exists, and the performance of the means to attain it. Therefore, the mind is the world. From that, the mind is Brahman.

analyzed: yatas evam tasmāt manaḥ upāḥsva iti
translated: Since it is so, therefore, meditate on the mind.

analyzed: sa yaḥ manaḥ brahma iti upāste
translated: He who meditates on the mind as Brahman,

original: yāvan manaso gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati yo mano brahmety upāste /🔽asti bhagavo manaso bhūya iti /
analyzed: yāvat manasaḥ gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ manaḥ brahma iti upāste  asti bhagavaḥ manasaḥ bhūyaḥ iti
translated: he has freedom to act as he wishes within the range of the mind, he who meditates on the mind as Brahman.🔽Is there anything greater than the mind, revered sir?

analyzed: manasaḥ vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: There is something greater than the mind, said he.

analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti
translated: Please tell me that, revered sir.

analyzed: sa yaḥ ityādi samānam
translated: The rest is the same as before.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya tṛtīyaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Third Section in the Seventh Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: saṃkalpaḥ vāva manasaḥ bhūyān
translated: Sanctified resolve, verily, is greater than the mind.

analyzed: yadā vai saṃkalpayate manasyati
translated: For when one resolves, then he thinks with the mind.

analyzed: atha vācam īrayati
translated: Then he utters speech.

analyzed: tām u nāmni īyūati
translated: He utters it in names.

analyzed: nāmni mantrāḥ ekam bhavanti
translated: In names the Mantras become one.

analyzed: mantreṣu karmāṇi
translated: In the Mantras the rites.

analyzed: saṃkalpaḥ vāva manasaḥ bhūyān
translated: Sanctified resolve, verily, is greater than the mind.

analyzed: saṃkalpaḥ pi manasyana vat antaḥkaraṇa vṛttiḥ kartavya akartavya viṣaya vibhāgena samarthanam
translated: Resolution also is a function of the internal organ, like reflection, which is the determination of the distinction between what should be done and what should not be done.

original: vibhāgena hi samarthite viṣaye cikīrṣābuddhirmanasyanānantaraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: vibhāgena hi samarthite viṣaye cikīrṣā buddhiḥ manasi anā anantaram bhavati
translated: For when the object is determined by distinction, the thought of desire arises immediately after reflection.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: yadā vai saṃkalpayate kartavyādiviṣayānvibhajata idaṃ kartuṃ yuktamiti /
analyzed: yadā vai saṃkalpayate kartavya ādi viṣayān vibhajate idam kartum yuktam iti
translated: When one resolves, distinguishing the objects of what should be done and so on, thinking this is proper to do,

analyzed: atha manasyati mantrān adhīyīya ityādi
translated: then one reflects, I should recite the mantras, and so on.

analyzed: atha anantaram vācam īrayati mantra ādi uccāraṇe
translated: Then immediately after that, one utters speech in the recitation of mantras and so on.

original: tāṃ ca vācamu nāmni nāmoccāraṇanimittaṃ vivakṣāṃ kṛtverayati nāmni nāmasāmānye mantrāḥ śabdaviśeṣāḥ santa ekaṃ bhavantyantarbhavantītyarthaḥ
analyzed: tām ca vācam u nāmni nāma uccāraṇa nimittam vivakṣām kṛtvā īrayati nāmni nāma sāmānye mantrāḥ śabda viśeṣāḥ santaḥ ekam bhavanti antarbhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: And having made the desire to speak the cause of uttering the name in the name, one utters that speech. In the name, in the general class of names, the mantras, which are specific words, become one, become included. This is the meaning.

analyzed: sāmānye hi viśeṣaḥ
translated: For the specific is included in the general.

analyzed: mantreṣu karmāṇi ekam bhavanti
translated: In the mantras, the actions become one.

analyzed: mantra prakāśitāni karmāṇi kriyante na amantrakam asti karma
translated: The actions illuminated by the mantras are performed. There is no action without mantras.

original: yaddhi mantraprakāśanena labdhasattākaṃ satkarma brāhmaṇenedaṃ kartavyamasmai phalāyeti vidhīyate /
analyzed: yat hi mantra prakāśanena labdha sattākam sat karma brāhmaṇena idam kartavyam asmai phalāya iti vidhīyate
translated: For the action which has obtained existence by the illumination of the mantras is enjoined by the Brāhmaṇa as follows: This should be done for this result.

original: yāpyutpattirbrāhmaṇeṣu karmaṇāṃ dṛśyate sāpi mantreṣu labdhasattākānāmeva karmaṇāṃ spaṣṭīkaraṇam /
analyzed: yā api utpattiḥ brāhmaṇeṣu karmaṇām dṛśyate sā api mantreṣu labdha sattākānām eva karmaṇām spaṣṭīkaraṇam
translated: And that origin of rites which is seen among Brahmins, that also is the clarification of rites which have already attained existence in the mantras.

original: na hi mantrāprakāśitaṃ karma kiñcidbrāhmaṇa utpannaṃ dṛśyate /
analyzed: na hi mantra a prakāśitam karma kiñcid brāhmaṇe utpannam dṛśyate
translated: For no rite that is not revealed by the mantras is seen to have originated in the Brahmanas.

analyzed: trayī vihitam karma iti prasiddham loke
translated: It is well known in the world that the rite is enjoined by the three Vedas.

analyzed: trayī śabdaḥ ca ṝk yajuḥ sāma samākhyā
translated: And the word trayi (three) refers to the Rig, Yajur, and Sama Vedas.

analyzed: mantreṣu karmāṇi kavayaḥ yāni apaśyan iti ca ātharvaṇe
translated: And in the Atharva Veda it is said: The wise ones saw the rites in the mantras.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam mantreṣu karmāṇi ekam bhavanti iti
translated: Therefore it is proper that the rites should be one in the mantras.

original: tāni ha vā etāni saṃkalpaikāyanāni saṃkalpātmakāni saṃkalpe pratiṣṭhitāni /
analyzed: tāni ha vai etāni saṃkalpa ekāyanāni saṃkalpa ātmakāni saṃkalpe pratiṣṭhitāni
translated: Indeed, these (rites) have their sole basis in resolve, they are of the nature of resolve, they are established in resolve.

analyzed: samakḷpatām dyāvāpṛthivī  samakalpetām vāyuḥ ca ākāśam ca
translated: Heaven and earth resolved together.🔽Wind and space resolved together.

original: samakalpantāpaś ca tejaś ca /🔽teṣāṃ saṃkḷptyai varṣaṃ saṃkalpate /
analyzed: samakalpanta āpaḥ ca tejaḥ ca  teṣām saṃkḷptyai varṣam saṃkalpate
translated: Water and fire resolved together.🔽For their resolution, rain resolves.

original: varṣasya saṃkḷptyā annaṃ saṃkalpate /🔽annasya saṃkḷptyai prāṇāḥ saṃkalpante /🔽prāṇānāṃ saṃkḷptyai mantrāḥ saṃkalpante /
analyzed: varṣasya saṃkḷptyai annam saṃkalpate  annasya saṃkḷptyai prāṇāḥ saṃkalpante  prāṇānām saṃkḷptyai mantrāḥ saṃkalpante
translated: For the resolution of rain, food resolves.🔽For the resolution of food, the vital breaths resolve.🔽For the resolution of the vital breaths, the mantras resolve.

analyzed: mantrāṇām saṃkḷptyai karmāṇi saṃkalpante
translated: For the resolution of the mantras, the rites resolve.

analyzed: karmaṇām saṃkḷptyai lokaḥ saṃkalpate
translated: For the completion of actions, the world is completed.

analyzed: lokasya saṃkḷptyai sarvam saṃkalpate
translated: For the completion of the world, everything is completed.

analyzed: saḥ eṣa saṃkalpaḥ
translated: This is that completion.

analyzed: saṃkalpam upāssva iti
translated: Meditate upon completion.

original: tāni ha vā etāni mana ādīni saṃkalpaikāyanāni saṃkalpa eko 'yanaṃ gamanaṃ
analyzed: tāni ha vai etāni manaḥ ādīni saṃkalpa eka ayanāni saṃkalpaḥ ekaḥ yanam gamanam
translated: Indeed, these, beginning with mind, have completion as their one abode. Completion is the one abode, the one going,

original: pralayo yeṣāṃ tāni saṃkalpaikāyanāni saṃkalpātmakānyutpattau saṃkalpe pratiṣṭhitāni🔽sthitau samakḷpatāṃ saṃkalpaṃ kṛtavatyāviva hi dyauśca pṛthivī ca dyāvāpṛthivyau niścale lakṣyete /🔽tathā samakalpetāṃ vāyuścā'kāśaṃ caitāvapi saṃkalpaṃ kṛtavantāviva tathā samakalpantāmāpaśca tejaśca svena rūpema niścalāni lakṣyante /
analyzed: pralayaḥ yeṣām tāni saṃkalpa ekāyanāni saṃkalpa ātmakāni utpattau saṃkalpe pratiṣṭhitāni  sthitau samakḷpatām saṃkalpam kṛtavatyau iva hi dyauḥ ca pṛthivī ca dyāvāpṛthivyau niścale lakṣyete  tathā samakalpetām vāyuḥ ca ākāśam ca etau api saṃkalpam kṛtavantau iva tathā samakalpantām āpaḥ ca tejaḥ ca svena rūpema niścalāni lakṣyante
translated: the one dissolution, of those which have completion as their one abode, which are of the nature of completion, which are established in completion at the time of origination,🔽which are established in completion at the time of persistence. The heaven and earth, indeed, appear to be fixed upon an immovable object, as if they had made completion.🔽Similarly, the air and space, these two also, appear as if they had made completion. Similarly, the water and fire, these two, appear to be fixed in their own forms.

original: yatasteṣāṃ dyāvāpṛthivyādīnāṃ saṃkḷptyai saṃkalpanimittaṃ varṣaṃ saṃkalpante /
analyzed: yatas teṣām dyāvāpṛthivya ādīnām saṃkḷptyai saṃkalpa nimittam varṣam saṃkalpante
translated: For the completion of those, the heaven and earth, etc., the rain completes itself for the sake of completion.

analyzed: anna mayāḥ hi prāṇāḥ anna upaṣṭambhakāḥ
translated: For the vital breaths are made of food, supported by food.

analyzed: annam dāma eti hi śrutiḥ
translated: For the scripture says, Food is the bond.

analyzed: teṣām saṃkḷptyai mantrāḥ saṃkalpante
translated: For their completion, the mantras complete themselves.

analyzed: prāṇāvān hi mantrān adhīte na abalaḥ
translated: For only one who has life studies the Mantras, not one who is powerless.

original: mantrāṇāṃ hi saṃkḷptyai karmāṇyagnihotrādīni saṃkalpante 'nuṣṭhīyamānāni mantraprakāśitāni samarthībhavanti phalāya /
analyzed: mantrāṇām hi saṃkḷptyai karmāṇi agnihotra ādīni saṃkalpante nuṣṭhīyamānāni mantra prakāśitāni samarthībhavanti phalāya
translated: For the sake of the accomplishment of the Mantras, the rites such as Agnihotra are accomplished, when performed, they become capable of bearing fruit, being illuminated by the Mantras.

original: tato lokaḥ phalaṃ saṃkalpate karmakartṛsamavāyitayā samarthībhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatas lokaḥ phalam saṃkalpate karma kartṛ samavāyi tayā samarthībhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the world is accomplished, becoming capable of bearing fruit by being associated with the agent of the action. This is the meaning.

analyzed: lokasya saṃkḷptyai sarvam jagat saṃkalpate sva rūpa a vaikalyāya
translated: For the accomplishment of the world, the entire universe is accomplished for the sake of not being deficient in its own nature.

analyzed: etat hi idam sarvam jagat yat phala avasānam tat sarvam saṃkalpa mūlam
translated: For this entire universe, which ends with fruits, all that is rooted in resolve.

analyzed: atas viśiṣṭaḥ saḥ eṣa saṃkalpaḥ
translated: Therefore, that resolve is distinguished.

analyzed: atas saṃkalpam upāḥsva iti uktvā phalam āha tad upāsakasya
translated: Having said Meditate upon resolve, he states the result for one who meditates upon it.

analyzed: sa yaḥ saṃkalpam brahma iti upāste
translated: One who meditates upon resolve as Brahman

original: kḷptān vai sa lokān dhruvān dhruvaḥ pratiṣṭhitān pratiṣṭhito 'vyathamānān avyathamāno 'bhisidhyati /
analyzed: kḷptān vai sa lokān dhruvān dhruvaḥ pratiṣṭhitān pratiṣṭhitaḥ vyathamānān a vyathamānaḥ bhisidhyati
translated: attains the accomplished, firm, well-established, unshakable worlds, being himself unshakable.

original: yāvat saṃkalpasya gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati yaḥ saṃkalpaṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: yāvat saṃkalpasya gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ saṃkalpam brahma iti upāste
translated: Wherever resolve goes, there one has freedom of action, who meditates upon resolve as Brahman.

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ saṃkalpāt bhūyaḥ iti
translated: Venerable Sir, is there anything greater than resolve?

analyzed: saṃkalpāt vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: 'Verily, there is something greater than will.'

analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti
translated: 'May the Blessed One tell me that.'

original: sa yaḥ saṃkalpaṃ brahmeti brahmabuddhyopāstekḷptānvai dhātrāsyeme lokāḥ
analyzed: sa yaḥ saṃkalpam brahma iti brahma buddhyā upāste kḷptān vai dhātrā asya ime lokāḥ
translated: He who worships will as Brahman with the idea of Brahman, for these worlds are indeed willed by the Creator.

analyzed: phalam iti kḷptān samarthitān saṃkalpitān sa vidvān dhruvān nityān atyanta adhruva apekṣayā dhruvaḥ ca svayam
translated: The fruit is said to be the willed, the accomplished, the imagined. The knower of this, being himself permanent in relation to the ultimately impermanent, and being permanent, is said to be established, i.e. endowed with the necessary means.

analyzed: lokinaḥ hi adhruva tve loke dhruva kḷptiḥ vyarthā iti dhruvaḥ san pratiṣṭhitān upakaraṇa saṃpannān iti arthaḥ
translated: For the establishment of the world, which is impermanent, by the permanent is useless. Being permanent himself, he is said to be established, i.e. endowed with the necessary means.

original: paśuputrādibhiḥ pratitiṣṭhatīti darśanātsvayaṃ ca pratiṣṭhita ātmīyopakaraṇasaṃpanno 'vyathamānānamitrāditrāsarah itānavyathamānaśca svayamabhisidhyatyabhiprāpnotītyarthaḥ
analyzed: paśu putra ādibhiḥ pratitiṣṭhati iti darśanāt svayam ca pratiṣṭhitaḥ ātmīya upakaraṇa saṃpannaḥ itān a vyathamānaḥ ca svayam abhisidhyati abhiprāpnoti iti arthaḥ
translated: Because it is seen that one is established by cattle, sons, etc., and being himself established, endowed with one's own necessary means, he is said to be unperplexed, free from fear of enemies, etc. And being himself unperplexed, he succeeds, i.e. attains,

original: yāvatsaṃkalpasya gataṃ saṃkalpagocarastatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati ātmanaḥ saṃkalpasya na tu sarveṣāṃ saṃkalpasyeti /
analyzed: yāvat saṃkalpasya gatam saṃkalpa gocaraḥ tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati ātmanaḥ saṃkalpasya na tu sarveṣām saṃkalpasya iti
translated: as far as the range of will goes, i.e. as far as the domain of will extends, there he has freedom of action according to his own will, of his own will, not of the will of all.

analyzed: uttara phala virodhāt
translated: Because it contradicts the fruit of the next stage.

analyzed: yaḥ saṃkalpam brahma iti upāste ityādi pūrvavat
translated: He who worships will as Brahman, etc., as before.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya caturthaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth section in the seventh chapter of Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: cittam vāva saṃkalpāt bhūyaḥ
translated: The mind, verily, is greater than the will.

analyzed: yadā vai cetayate tha saṃkalpayate
translated: When one thinks, then one wills.

analyzed: atha manasyati
translated: Then one intends.

analyzed: atha vācam īrayati
translated: Then one utters speech.

analyzed: tām u nāmni īyūati
translated: That he utters in names.

analyzed: nāmni mantrāḥ ekam bhavanti
translated: In names the mantras are one.

analyzed: mantreṣu karmāṇi
translated: In the mantras the rites.

analyzed: cittam vāva saṃkalpāt bhūyaḥ
translated: The mind, verily, is greater than the will.

original: cittaṃ cetayitṛtvaṃ prāptakālānurūpabodhavattvamatītāna gataviṣayaprayojananirūpaṇasāmarthyaṃ ca tatsaṃkalpādapi bhūyaḥ /
analyzed: cittam cetayitṛ tvam prāpta kāla anurūpa bodhavat tvam atīta ana gata viṣaya prayojana nirūpaṇa sāmarthyam ca tad saṃkalpāt api bhūyaḥ
translated: The mind is the thinker, the possessor of knowledge appropriate to the time, and the ability to determine the past, present, and future purposes. It is greater than the will.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

original: yadā vai prāptamiti cetayate tadā dānāya vāpohāya vātha saṃkalpayate 'tha manasyatītyādi pūrvavat //
analyzed: yadā vai prāptam iti cetayate tadā dānāya vā apohāya vā atha saṃkalpayate manasyati ityādi pūrvavat
translated: When one thinks of what has been obtained, then one wills to give it away or to keep it. Then one intends, and so on as before.

original: tāni ha vā etāni cittaikāyanāni cittātmāni citte pratiṣṭhitāni /
analyzed: tāni ha vai etāni citta ekāyanāni citta ātmāni citte pratiṣṭhitāni
translated: These, verily, all have the mind as their refuge, the mind as their self, the mind as their support.

original: tasmād yady api bahuvid acitto bhavati nāyam astīty evainam āhuḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt yadi api bahu vid acittaḥ bhavati na ayam asti iti eva enam āhuḥ
translated: Therefore, even if one who knows much becomes mindless, they say of him, He does not exist.

original: yad ayaṃ veda yad vā ayaṃ vidvān nettham acittaḥ syād iti /
analyzed: yat ayam veda yat vai ayam vidvān na ittham acittaḥ syāt iti
translated: What he knows, or what he, knowing, would not be so mindless.

original: atha yady alpavic cittavān bhavati tasmā evota śuśrūṣante /
analyzed: atha yadi alpa vid cittavān bhavati tasmai eva uta śuśrūṣante
translated: Now, if he is one who has little knowledge and a distracted mind, they serve him just for that.

analyzed: cittam hi eva eṣām ekāyanam
translated: For the mind is their one path.

analyzed: cittam ātmā  cittam pratiṣṭhā
translated: The mind is the self.🔽The mind is the support.

analyzed: cittam upāssva iti
translated: Worship the mind.

original: tāni saṃkalpādīni karmaphalāntāni cittaikāyanāni cittātmāni cittotpattīni citte pratiṣṭhitāni cittasthitānītyapi pūrvavat /
analyzed: tāni saṃkalpa ādīni karma phala antāni citta ekāyanāni citta ātmāni citta utpattīni citte pratiṣṭhitāni citta sthitāni iti api pūrvavat
translated: Those beginning with intention and ending with the results of karma are one-way paths of the mind, have the mind as their self, originate from the mind, and are established in the mind, as before.

analyzed: kiñca cittasya māhātmyam
translated: Moreover, what is the greatness of the mind?

analyzed: yasmāt cittam saṃkalpa ādi mūlam tasmāt yadi api bahu vid bahu śāsra ādi parijñānavān sanna cittaḥ
translated: Since the mind is the root of intention and so on, even if one is learned, knowing many scriptures and so on, if one has a distracted mind,

original: bhavati prāptādicetayitṛtvasāmarthyavirahito bhavati taṃ nipuṇā laukikānāyamasti
analyzed: bhavati prāpta ādi cetayitṛ tva sāmarthya virahitaḥ bhavati tam nipuṇāḥ laukikān āyam asti
translated: one is devoid of the ability to think about what is obtained and so on. The skilled ones in the world say of him:

analyzed: vidyamānaḥ u pi asat samaḥ eva iti enam āhuḥ
translated: Although he exists, he is as if non-existent.

original: yaccāyaṃ kiñcicchāsrādi veda śrutavāṃstadapyasya vṛthaiveti kathayanti /
analyzed: yat ca ayam kiñcid śāsra ādi veda śrutavān tat api asya vṛthā evā iti kathayanti
translated: And whatever scripture and so on he has learned, they say that is also useless for him.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: yadi ayam vidvān syāt ittham evam acittaḥ na syāt tasmāt asya śrutam api aśrutam eva iti āhuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: If he were wise, he would not be like this, with a distracted mind. Therefore they say that even his learning is as if unlearned. This is the meaning.

original: athālpavidapi yadi cittavānbhavati tasmā etasmai taduktārthagrahaṇāyaivotāpi śuśrūṣante śrotumicchanti /
analyzed: atha alpa vid api yadi cittavān bhavati tasmai etasmai tad ukta artha grahaṇāya eva uta api śuśrūṣante śrotum icchanti
translated: Now, if one has a mind, even if he has little knowledge, from him, for the sake of grasping that meaning which has been spoken of, they listen, they desire to hear.

analyzed: tasmāt ca cittam hi eva eṣām saṃkalpa ādīnām ekāyanam ityādi pūrvavat
translated: And because of that, the mind alone is the one path of these, of intention and so on. The rest is as before.

analyzed: sa yaḥ cittam brahma iti upāste
translated: He who worships the mind as Brahman,

original: cittān vai sa lokān dhruvān dhruvaḥ pratiṣṭhitān pratiṣṭhito 'vyathamānān avyathamāno 'bhisidhyati /
analyzed: cittān vai sa lokān dhruvān dhruvaḥ pratiṣṭhitān pratiṣṭhitaḥ vyathamānān a vyathamānaḥ bhisidhyati
translated: he attains the worlds of the mind, the firm, the firm, the established, the established, the unsuffering, the unsuffering.

original: yāvac cittasya gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati yaś cittaṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: yāvat cittasya gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ cittam brahma iti upāste
translated: As far as the mind has gone, there he has freedom to act as he wishes, he who worships the mind as Brahman.

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ cittāt bhūyaḥ iti
translated: Is there anything greater than the mind, Revered Sir?

analyzed: cittāt vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: There is something greater than the mind, verily.

analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti
translated: May the Revered One tell me that.

analyzed: citta an upacitān huddhimat guṇaiḥ sa citta upāsakaḥ dhruvān ityādi ca ukta artham
translated: The worshipper of the mind, by the qualities of the wise one not accumulated in the mind, attains the firm and so on, the meaning of which has been stated.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya pañcamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifth section of the seventh chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: dhyānam vā ava cittāt bhūyaḥ  dhyāyati iva pṛthivī  dhyāyati iva antarikṣam
translated: Meditation, verily, is greater than the mind.🔽The earth, as it were, meditates.🔽The atmosphere, as it were, meditates.

analyzed: dhyāyati iva dyauḥ
translated: The sky, as it were, meditates.

analyzed: dhyāyanti iva apaḥ
translated: As if the waters were meditating.

analyzed: dhyāyanti iva parvatāḥ
translated: As if the mountains were meditating.

analyzed: dhyāyanti iva deva manuṣyāḥ
translated: As if the gods and men were meditating.

original: tasmād ya iha manuṣyāṇāṃ mahattāṃ prāpnuvanti dhyānāpādāṃśā ivaiva te bhavanti /
analyzed: tasmāt ye iha manuṣyāṇām mahat tām prāpnuvanti dhyāna āpāda aṃśāḥ iva eva te bhavanti
translated: Therefore, those among men who attain greatness here, they become as if they have attained a share in meditation.

original: atha ye 'lpāḥ kalahinaḥ piśunā upavādinas te /
analyzed: atha ye lpāḥ kalahinaḥ piśunāḥ upavādinaḥ te
translated: Then those who are few, quarrelsome, slanderous, and abusive,

original: atha ye prabhavo dhyānāpādāṃśā ivaiva te bhavanti /
analyzed: atha ye prabhavaḥ dhyānā pāda aṃśāḥ iva eva te bhavanti
translated: then those who are great become as if they have attained a share in meditation.

original: dhyānam upāssveti //🔽sa yo dhyānaṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: dhyānam upāssva iti  sa yaḥ dhyānam brahma iti upāste
translated: Meditate!🔽One who meditates on meditation as Brahman,

original: yāvad dhyānasya gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati yo dhyānaṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: yāvat dhyānasya gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ dhyānam brahma iti upāste
translated: as far as meditation has gone, there he has freedom to act as he wishes, one who meditates on meditation as Brahman.

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ dyānāt bhūyaḥ iti
translated: Is there anything greater than meditation, revered sir?

analyzed: dhyānāt vā ava bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: There is something greater than meditation, said he.

analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti
translated: May the revered one tell me that.

analyzed: dhyānam vā ava cittāt bhūyaḥ
translated: Meditation, indeed, is greater than the mind.

analyzed: dhyānam nāma śāsra ukta devatā ādi ālambaneṣu acalaḥ bhinna jātīyaiḥ anantaritaḥ pratyaya saṃtānaḥ
translated: Meditation is the uninterrupted stream of thoughts, unmixed with other kinds, on the objects taught in the scriptures such as the gods, etc.

analyzed: ekāgra tā iti yam āhuḥ
translated: What they call one-pointedness.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca dhyānasya māhātmyam phalataḥ
translated: And the greatness of meditation is seen from its fruits.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: yathā yogī dhyāyat niścalaḥ bhavati dhyāna phala lābhe
translated: As the yogi becomes motionless in attaining the fruits of meditation.

analyzed: evam dhyāyati iva niścalā dṛśyate pṛthivī
translated: Thus the earth is seen to be motionless as if meditating.

analyzed: dhyāyati iva antarikṣam ityādi samānam anyat
translated: The same applies to the other statements such as the sky is as if meditating.

original: devāśca manuṣyāśca devamanuṣyā manuṣyā eva vā devasamā devamanuṣyāḥ śamādiguṇasaṃpannā manuṣyā devasvarūpaṃ na jahatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: devāḥ ca manuṣyāḥ ca deva manuṣyāḥ manuṣyāḥ eva vā deva samāḥ deva manuṣyāḥ śama ādi guṇa saṃpannāḥ manuṣyāḥ deva sva rūpam na jahati iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, gods and humans are divine humans. Humans who are like gods are those endowed with the qualities of tranquility and so on. The meaning is that humans do not abandon the form of gods.

original: yasmādevaṃ viśiṣṭaṃ dhyānaṃ tasmādya iha loke manuṣyāṇāmeva dhanairvidyayā guṇairvā mahattāṃ mahattvaṃ prāpnuvanti dhanādimahattvahetuṃ labhanta
analyzed: yasmāt evam viśiṣṭam dhyānam tasmāt ye iha loke manuṣyāṇām eva dhanaiḥ vidyayā guṇaiḥ vā mahattām mahattvam prāpnuvanti dhana ādi mahattva hetum labhanta
translated: Because the meditation is thus distinguished, therefore those who attain greatness, i.e., greatness, among humans in this world by wealth, learning, or qualities, obtain the cause of the greatness of wealth and so on.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: dhyānāpādāṃśā iva dhyānasyā'pādanamāpādo dhyānaphalalābha ityetattasyāṃśo 'vayavaḥ kalā kāciddhyānaphalalābhakalāvanta ivaivetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: dhyāna āpāda aṃśāḥ iva dhyānasya āpādanam āpādaḥ dhyāna phala lābhaḥ iti etat tasya aṃśaḥ vayavaḥ kalā kācid dhyāna phala lābha kalāvantaḥ iva eva iti arthaḥ
translated: They are as if motionless, as if they are parts of meditation. Meditation is the attainment, the obtaining of the fruit of meditation. This is a part, a portion, a fraction of it. The meaning is that they are as if endowed with a fraction of the attainment of the fruit of meditation.

original: te bhavanti niścalā iva lakṣyante na kṣudrā iva /
analyzed: te bhavanti niścalāḥ iva lakṣyante na kṣudrāḥ iva
translated: They are seen as if motionless, not as if small.

original: atha ye punaralpāḥ kṣudrāḥ kiñcidapi dhanādimahattvaikadeśamaprāptāste pūrvoktaviparītāḥ
analyzed: atha ye punar alpāḥ kṣudrāḥ kiñcid api dhana ādi mahattva eka deśam aprāptāḥ te pūrva ukta viparītāḥ
translated: But those who are again small, insignificant, and have not attained even a part of the greatness of wealth and so on, they are the opposite of what was said before.

original: kalahinaḥ kalahaśīlāḥ piśunāḥ paradoṣodbhāsakā upavādinaḥ paradoṣaṃ sāmīpyayuktameva
analyzed: kalahinaḥ kalaha śīlāḥ piśunāḥ para doṣa udbhāsakāḥ upavādinaḥ para doṣam sāmīpya yuktam eva
translated: Quarrelsome means quarrelsome, slanderous means those who proclaim the faults of others, accusers means those who are accustomed to speak of the faults of others as if they were close by.

original: vadituṃ śīlaṃ yoṣāṃ ta upavādinaśca bhavanti /
analyzed: vaditum śīlam yoṣām te upavādinaḥ ca bhavanti
translated: They are slanderers.

original: atha ye mahattvaṃ prāptā dhanādinimittaṃ te 'nyānprati prabhavantīti prabhavo vidyācāryarājeśvarādayo dhyānāpādāṃśā ivetyādyuktārtham /
analyzed: atha ye mahat tvam prāptāḥ dhana ādi nimittam te nyān prati prabhavanti iti prabhavaḥ vidyā ācārya rāja īśvara ādayaḥ dhyāna āpāda aṃśāḥ iva ityādi ukta artham
translated: Now, those who have attained greatness, for the sake of wealth and so on, they are powerful with respect to others. Therefore, the powerful ones are the learned, teachers, kings, lords, etc., like the parts of the base of meditation. Thus, the meaning of what was said is understood.

original: ato dṛśyate dhyānasya mahattvaṃ phalato 'to bhūyaścittādatastadupāḥsvetyādyuktārtham //
analyzed: atas dṛśyate dhyānasya mahat tvam bhūyas cittāt atas tat upāḥsva ityādi ukta artham
translated: Therefore, the greatness of meditation is seen from its result. Therefore, it is more than mere thought. Therefore, you should meditate on it. Thus, the meaning of what was said is understood.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya ṣaṣṭhaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the sixth section of the seventh chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad

analyzed: vijñānam vāva dhyānāt bhūyaḥ
translated: Knowledge, verily, is greater than meditation.

original: vijñānena vā ṛgvedaṃ vijānāti yajurvedaṃ sāmavedam ātharvaṇaṃ caturtham itihāsapurāṇaṃ
analyzed: vijñānena vai ṛgvedam vijānāti yajurvedam sāmavedam ātharvaṇam caturtham itihāsa purāṇam
translated: By knowledge one knows the Ṛg Veda, the Yajur Veda, the Sāma Veda, the Atharva Veda as the fourth, the Itihāsa-Purāṇa

original: pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitryaṃ rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyam ekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ
analyzed: pañcamam vedānām vedam pitryam rāśim daivam nidhim vākovākyam ekāyanam deva vidyām
translated: as the fifth Veda of the Vedas, the science of genealogy, the science of omens, the science of treasures, the science of logic, the science of one path, the knowledge of the gods,

original: brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajanavidyāṃ divaṃ ca
analyzed: brahma vidyām bhūta vidyām kṣatra vidyām nakṣatra vidyām sarpa deva jana vidyām divam ca
translated: the knowledge of Brahman, the knowledge of beings, the knowledge of the warrior class, the knowledge of the stars, the knowledge of serpents and gods, heaven🔽and

original: pṛthivīṃ ca vāyuṃ cākāśaṃ cāpaś ca tejaś ca devāṃś ca manuṣyāṃś ca paśūṃś ca vayāṃsi🔽ca tṛṇavanaspatīñ chvāpadāny ākīṭapataṅgapipīlakam /
analyzed: pṛthivīm ca vāyum ca ākāśam ca āpaḥ ca tejaḥ ca devān ca manuṣyān ca paśūn ca vayāṃsi  ca tṛṇa vanaspatīm śvāpadāni ā kīṭa pataṅga pipīlakam
translated: grass, trees, beasts, insects, moths, and ants,

original: dharmaṃ cādharmaṃ ca satyaṃ cānṛtaṃ ca sādhu cāsādhu ca hṛdayajñaṃ cāhṛdayajñaṃ cānnaṃ ca rasaṃ cemaṃ ca lokam amuṃ ca vijñānenaiva vijānāti
analyzed: dharmam ca adharmam ca satyam ca anṛtam ca sādhu ca asādhu ca hṛdayajñam ca ahṛdayajñam ca annam ca rasam ca imam ca lokam amum ca vijñānena eva vijānāti
translated: righteousness and unrighteousness, truth and falsehood, the good and the bad, the heart-knower and the non-heart-knower, food and taste, this world and the next world, one knows only through knowledge.

analyzed: vijñānam upāssva iti
translated: Meditate on knowledge.

analyzed: vijñānam vāva dhyānāt bhūyaḥ
translated: Knowledge, indeed, is greater than meditation.

analyzed: vijñānam śāsra artha viṣayam jñānam tasya dhyāna kāraṇa tvāt dhyānāt bhūyaḥ tvam
translated: Knowledge is the knowledge of the meaning of the scriptures, and it is greater than meditation because it is the cause of meditation.

original: kathaṃ ca tasya bhūyastvamityāhavijñānena vā ṛgvedaṃ vijānātyayamṛgveda iti pramāṇatayā yasyārthajñānaṃ dhyānakāraṇam /
analyzed: katham ca tasya bhūyaḥ tvam iti āha vijñānena vai ṛgvedam vijānāti ayam ṛgvedaḥ iti pramāṇa tayā yasya artha jñānam dhyāna kāraṇam
translated: And how is it greater? It is said: By knowledge one knows the Ṛg Veda as This is the Ṛg Veda, through the means of knowledge, whose knowledge of the meaning is the cause of meditation.

analyzed: tathā yajurvedam ityādi
translated: Similarly, the Yajur Veda, and so on.

analyzed: kiñca paśu ādīn ca dharma adharmau śāsra siddhau
translated: Moreover, animals and so on, righteousness and unrighteousness, are established by the scriptures.

analyzed: sādhu asādhunī lokataḥ siddhe
translated: The good and the bad are established by worldly consensus.

original: smārte vā dṛṣṭādṛṣṭāviṣayaṃ ca sarvaṃ vijñānenaiva vijānātītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: smārte vā dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa aviṣayam ca sarvam vijñānena eva vijānāti iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, all that is seen and unseen is known only through knowledge, this is the meaning.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam dhyāna ādi jñānasya bhūyaḥ tvam atas vijñānam upāḥsva iti
translated: Therefore, it is proper that the knowledge of meditation etc. is greater. Hence, meditate on consciousness.

analyzed: sa yaḥ vijñānam brahma iti upāste
translated: He who meditates on consciousness as Brahman,

analyzed: vijñānavataḥ vai sa lokān jñānavataḥ bhisidhyati
translated: he attains worlds full of consciousness and knowledge.

original: yāvad vijñānasya gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati yo vijñānaṃ brahmety upāste /🔽asti bhagavo vijñānād bhūya iti /
analyzed: yāvat vijñānasya gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ vijñānam brahma iti upāste  asti bhagavaḥ vijñānāt bhūyaḥ iti
translated: Wherever consciousness goes, there he has freedom to act as he wishes, he who meditates on consciousness as Brahman.🔽O revered one, is there anything greater than consciousness?

analyzed: vijñānāt vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: There is something greater than consciousness, he said.

original: tan me bhagavān bravītv iti //🔽śṛṇūpāsanaphalaṃ vijñānavato vijñānaṃ yeṣu lokeṣu tānvijñānavato lokāñjñānavataścābhisidhyatyabhiprāpnoti /
analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti  śṛṇu upāsana phalam vijñānavataḥ vijñānam yeṣu lokeṣu tān vijñānavataḥ lokān jñānavataḥ ca abhisidhyati abhiprāpnoti
translated: Please tell me that, revered one.🔽Listen to the result of meditation: he who has consciousness attains worlds full of consciousness and knowledge.

analyzed: vijñānam śāsra artha viṣayam jñānam anya viṣayam naipuṇyam tadvadbhiḥ yuktān lokān na a prāpnoti iti arthaḥ
translated: Worlds full of consciousness means worlds full of knowledge of the meaning of scriptures. Worlds full of knowledge means worlds full of skill in other matters. He does not fail to attain worlds endowed with those.

analyzed: yāvat vijñānasya ityādi pūrvavat
translated: Wherever consciousness goes, etc. as before.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya saptamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the seventh section of the seventh chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad

original: balena vai pṛthivī tiṣṭhati balenāntarikṣaṃ balena dyaur balena parvatā balena devamanuṣyā balena paśavaś ca vayāṃsi ca tṛṇavanaspatayaḥ śvāpadāny
analyzed: balena vai pṛthivī tiṣṭhati balena antarikṣam balena dyauḥ balena parvatāḥ balena deva manuṣyāḥ balena paśavaḥ ca vayāṃsi ca tṛṇa vanaspatayaḥ śvāpadāni
translated: By strength the earth stands, by strength the atmosphere, by strength the sky, by strength the mountains, by strength the gods and men, by strength the cattle and birds, the grass and trees, the snakes and insects,

translated: the worms and flies and ants.

analyzed: balena lokaḥ tiṣṭhati  balam upāssva iti

analyzed: sa yaḥ balam upāste

translated: has freedom to do as he wishes wherever strength goes, for him who worships strength as Brahman.

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ balāt bhūyaḥ iti
translated: 'Is there anything greater than strength, revered sir?'

analyzed: balāt vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: 'Strength indeed is greater.'

original: tan me bhagavān bravītv iti //🔽balaṃ vāva vijñānādbhūyaḥ /
analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti  balam vāva vijñānāt bhūyaḥ
translated: 'The revered one should tell me that.'🔽'Strength indeed is greater than knowledge.

analyzed: balam iti anna upayoga janitam manasaḥ vijñeye pratibhāna sāmarthyam
translated: 'Strength' is the mental ability to understand an object produced by the use of food.

original: anaśanādṛgādīni na vai mā pratibhānti bho iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: an aśanāt ṛc ādīni na vai mā pratibhānti bho iti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic text, O, hunger, thirst, cold, heat, and other things do not appear to me.

original: śarīre 'pi tadevotthānādisāmarthyaṃ yasmādvijñānavatāṃ śatamapyekaḥ prāṇī balavānā kampayate yathā hastī matto manuṣyāṇāṃ śataṃ samuditamapi
analyzed: śarīre tat eva utthāna ādi sāmarthyam yasmāt vijñānavatām śatam api ekaḥ prāṇī kampayate yathā hastī mattaḥ manuṣyāṇām śatam samuditam api
translated: Even in the body, that very ability to rise up, etc. is from consciousness, since a single strong animal shakes even a hundred conscious ones, just as an intoxicated elephant shakes a hundred united men.

original: yasmādevamannādyupayoganimittaṃ balaṃ tasmātsa puruṣo yadā balī balena tadvānbhavatyathotthātotthānasya
analyzed: yasmāt evam annādi upayoga nimittam balam tasmāt sa puruṣaḥ yadā balī balena tadvān bhavati atha utthātā utthānasya
translated: Since strength is for the purpose of using food, etc., therefore that person, when strong, having strength, then becomes a riser, the doer of rising.

original: kartottiṣṭhaṃśca gurūṇāmācāryasya ca paricaritā paricaraṇasya śuśrūṣāyāḥ kartā bhavati
analyzed: kartā uttiṣṭhan ca gurūṇām ācāryasya ca paricaritā paricaraṇasya śuśrūṣāyāḥ kartā bhavati
translated: Rising, he becomes a server of elders and the teacher, the doer of service, of attendance.

analyzed: paricaran upasattā teṣām samīpa gaḥ ntaraṅgaḥ prayaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Serving, he becomes a sitter near them, one who has gone near, an intimate, the meaning is.

analyzed: upasīdan ca samīpyam gacchan ekāgra tayā ācāryasya anyasya ca upadeṣṭuḥ guroḥ draṣṭā bhavati
translated: And sitting near, going near, with one-pointedness, he becomes a seer of the teacher and of any other instructor, a guru.

analyzed: tatas tad uktasya śrotā bhavati

original: tata idamebhiruktamevamupapadyata ityupapattito mantā bhavati manvānaśca boddhā bhavatyevamevedamiti /

translated: Then, thinking, This is established by these, he becomes a thinker by inference. And thinking, It is indeed so, he becomes a knower.

original: tata evaṃ niścitya taduktārthasya kartānuṣṭhātā bhavati vijñātānuṣṭhānaphalasyānubhavitā bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatas evam niścitya tad ukta arthasya kartā anuṣṭhātā bhavati vijñāta anuṣṭhāna phalasya anubhavitā bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Having thus ascertained, he becomes the doer, the performer, of the act whose meaning has been thus declared. The meaning is: he becomes the experiencer of the fruit of the performance known.

original: kiñca balasya māhātmyaṃ balena vai pṛthivī tiṣṭhatītyādyujvartham //
analyzed: kiñca balasya māhātmyam balena vai pṛthivī tiṣṭhati ityādi uju artham
translated: Moreover, the greatness of strength is the meaning of such statements as the earth stands by strength and so on.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya aṣṭamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eighth section of the seventh chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: annam vāva balāt bhūyaḥ
translated: Food, indeed, is greater than strength.

original: tasmād yady api daśa rātrīr nāśnīyāt /
analyzed: tasmāt yadi api daśa rātrīḥ na aśnīyāt
translated: Therefore, even if one were to fast for ten nights,

analyzed: yadi u ha jīvet  bhavati
translated: if he were to live,🔽then he would be a seer, a hearer, a thinker, an understander, an actor, and a knower.

original: athānnasyāye draṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati boddhā bhavati kartā bhavati vijñātā bhavati /
analyzed: atha annasya āye draṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati boddhā bhavati kartā bhavati vijñātā bhavati
translated: But when food comes, he becomes a seer, a hearer, a thinker, an understander, an actor, and a knower.

analyzed: annam upāssva iti
translated: Worship food.

analyzed: annam vāva balāt bhūyaḥ
translated: Food, indeed, is greater than strength.

analyzed: bala hetu tvāt
translated: Because it is the cause of strength.

analyzed: katham annasya bala hetu tvam iti ucyate
translated: How food is the cause of strength is being stated.

original: yasmādbalakāraṇamannaṃ tasmādyadyapi kaściddaśa rātrīrnāśnīyātso 'nnopayogānimittasya balasya hānyā mriyate na cenmriyate yadyu ha jīvet /
analyzed: yasmāt bala kāraṇam annam tasmāt yadi api kaścid daśa rātrīḥ na aśnīyāt saḥ nna upayoga a nimittasya balasya hānyā mriyate na ced mriyate yadi u ha jīvet
translated: Since food is the cause of strength, therefore, even if someone were to fast for ten nights, he would die due to the loss of strength caused by the absence of food, if he does not die. If he were to live,

translated: For people are seen to live even for a month without eating.

original: athavā sa jīvannapyadraṣṭā bhavati gurorapi tata evāśrotetyādi pūrvaviparītaṃ sarvaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: athavā sa jīvan api adraṣṭā bhavati guroḥ api tatas eva aśrotā ityādi pūrva viparītam sarvam bhavati
translated: Or, even while living, he becomes one who does not see, does not hear, etc., the opposite of all that was said before, even from the teacher.

original: atha yadā bahūnyahānyanaśito darśanādikriyāsvasamarthaḥ sannannasyā'yī /🔽āgamanamāyo 'nnasya prāptirityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atha yadā bahūni ahāni anaśitaḥ darśana ādi kriyāsu asamarthaḥ san anna syāyī  āgamanam āyaḥ nasya prāptiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Then, when he is unable to perform the acts of seeing, etc., after many days without eating, he comes to food.🔽The coming of food is the attainment of food, that is the meaning.

analyzed: sā yasya vidyate saḥ u nasyāyī
translated: He who has that is one who comes to food.

analyzed: āyaḥ iti etat varṇa vyatyayena

analyzed: draṣṭā ityādi kārya śravaṇāt

analyzed: dṛśyate hi anna upayoge darśana ādi sāmarthyam na tad aprāptau atas nnam upāḥsva iti
translated: For the ability to see, etc. is seen when food is used, not when it is not obtained. Therefore, worship food.

analyzed: sa yaḥ nnam brahma iti upāste
translated: He who worships food as Brahman,

analyzed: annavataḥ vai sa lokān pānavataḥ bhisidhyati

analyzed: phalam ca annavataḥ prabhūta annān vai sa lokān pānavataḥ prabhūta udakān ca anna pānayoḥ nitya saṃbandhān lokān abhisi dhyati

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya navamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ

analyzed: āpaḥ vāva annāt bhūyasyaḥ

original: āpa evemā mūrtā yeyaṃ pṛthivī yad antarikṣaṃ yad dyaur yat parvatā yad devamanuṣyā yat paśavaś ca vayāṃsi ca tṛṇavanaspatayaḥ śvāpadāny ākīṭapataṅgapipīlakam
analyzed: āpaḥ eva imāḥ mūrtāḥ yā iyam pṛthivī yat antarikṣam yat dyauḥ yat parvatāḥ yat deva manuṣyāḥ yat paśavaḥ ca vayāṃsi ca tṛṇa vanaspatayaḥ śvāpadāni ā kīṭa pataṅga pipīlakam
translated: These embodied beings in this world, namely the earth, the atmosphere, the sky, the mountains, the gods and men, the cattle, the birds, the grass, the trees, the beasts, the insects, the moths, the ants,

analyzed: āpaḥ eva imāḥ mūrtāḥ
translated: these embodied beings are indeed water.

analyzed: apaḥ upāssva iti
translated: Meditate on water.

analyzed: āpaḥ vāva annāt bhūyasyaḥ nna kāraṇa tvāt

translated: But when again there is good rain, then the vital airs, the living beings, become delighted, happy, and cheerful, thinking 'it will be abundant, it will be plentiful.'

translated: Because of the origination from water, the food which is in a gross form, the water itself has become transformed into the forms of gross and subtle distinctions. 'These are the gross ones, this earth, this atmosphere,' and so on.

analyzed: āpaḥ eva imāḥ mūrtāḥ atas paḥ upāḥsva iti

analyzed: sa yaḥ poḥ brahma iti upāste

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ dbhyaḥ bhūyaḥ iti

analyzed: adbhyaḥ vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: 'Indeed, there is something greater than water.'

analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti
translated: 'The revered one should tell me that.'

analyzed: ap saṃbhava tvāt ca tṛpteḥ ambu pāsanāt tṛptimān ca bhavati
translated: And because satisfaction is produced from water, he becomes satisfied by meditating on water.

analyzed: samānam anyat

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya daśamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ

analyzed: tejaḥ vāva adbhyaḥ bhūyaḥ

analyzed: tejaḥ eva tat pūrvam darśayitvā atha apaḥ sṛjate
translated: Having first shown fire, then it creates water.

translated: Those are the flashes of lightning that move upwards and diagonally. Therefore they say, It is lightning, it is thundering, it will rain.

analyzed: tejaḥ eva tat pūrvam darśayitvā atha apaḥ sṛjate
translated: Having first shown fire, then it creates water.

analyzed: tejaḥ upāssva iti  tejaḥ vāva adbhyaḥ bhūyaḥ

translated: How is it the cause? It is said:

translated: Because fire is the source of water, therefore that fire, having seized the wind, having held it fast, having made it unmoving by itself,

translated: When the air heats the space, and the space is pervaded and heated, then people say, 'It is hot, it is burning.'

translated: In general, they say, 'The world is being heated, or it will rain,'

analyzed: tejaḥ eva tat pūrvam ātmānam udbhūtam darśayitvā atha anantaram apaḥ sṛjate

analyzed: kiñca anyat tat etat tejaḥ eva stanayitnu rūpeṇa varṣa hetuḥ bhavati

translated: The flashes of lightning, moving upwards and downwards, and the sounds of thunder move along with the flashes of lightning moving upwards and downwards.

translated: Therefore, seeing that, people say, 'It is lightning, it is thundering, it will rain,' and so on. The meaning has been stated before.

analyzed: atas tejaḥ upāṣva iti

analyzed: sa yaḥ tejaḥ brahma iti upāste
translated: One who meditates upon fire as Brahman

translated: And from radiance, he attains worlds that are radiant, luminous, full of light, and free from darkness, both externally and internally, through the knowledge of the self and other things.
