translated: The other meanings are straightforward.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya ekādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eleventh section in the seventh chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ vāva tejasaḥ bhūyān
translated: Space, verily, is greater than fire.

original: ākāśe vai sūryācandramasāv ubhau vidyun nakṣatrāṇy agniḥ /
analyzed: ākāśe vai sūryācandramasau ubhau vidyut nakṣatrāṇi agniḥ
translated: In space are the sun and the moon, lightning, the stars, and fire.

analyzed: ākāśena āhvāyati  ākāśena sṛṇoti
translated: By space one calls.🔽By space one hears.

analyzed: ākāśena pratisṛṇoti  ākāśe ramate
translated: By space one hears back.🔽In space one delights.

analyzed: ākāśe na ramate  ākāśe jāyate
translated: In space one does not delight.🔽In space one is born.

analyzed: ākāśam abhijāyate
translated: One is born in space.

analyzed: ākāśam upāssva iti
translated: Meditate on space.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ vāva tejasaḥ bhūyān
translated: Space, verily, is greater than fire.

original: vāyusahitasya tejasaḥ kāraṇatvādvyomno vāyumāgṛhyeti tejasā sahokto vāyuriti pṛthagiha noktastejasaḥ /
analyzed: vāyu sahitasya tejasaḥ kāraṇa tvāt vyomnaḥ vāyum āgṛhya iti tejasā saha uktaḥ vāyuḥ iti pṛthak iha na uktaḥ tejasaḥ
translated: Because air is the cause of fire along with air, therefore, having grasped air, it is said along with fire. Air is not mentioned separately here from fire.

analyzed: kāraṇam hi loke kāryāt bhūyaḥ dṛṣṭam
translated: For in the world, a cause is seen to be greater than its effect.

original: yathā ghaṭādibhyo mṛttathā'kāśo vāyusahitasya tejasaḥ kāraṇamiti tato bhūyān /
analyzed: yathā ghaṭa ādibhyaḥ mṛd tathā ākāśaḥ vāyu sahitasya tejasaḥ kāraṇam iti tatas bhūyān
translated: Just as clay is greater than pots etc., so space is the cause of fire along with air, therefore it is greater.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: ākāśo vai sūryācandramasāvubhau tejorūpau vidyunnakṣatrāṇyagniśca tejorūpāṇyākāśe 'ntaḥ /
analyzed: ākāśaḥ vai sūryācandramasau ubhau tejaḥ rūpau vidyut nakṣatrāṇi agniḥ ca tejaḥ rūpāṇi ākāśe ntar
translated: Space contains both the sun and the moon, which are of the form of fire, lightning, stars, and fire, which are of the form of fire, within space.

analyzed: yat ca yasya antar varti tat alpam bhūyaḥ itarat
translated: And that which is contained within something else is less, the other is greater.

original: kiñcā'kāśenā'hvayati cānyamanya āhūtaścetara ākāśena śṛṇotyanyoktaṃ ca śabdamanyaḥ
analyzed: kiñca ākāśena āhvayati ca anyam anyaḥ āhūtaḥ ca itaraḥ ākāśena śṛṇoti anya uktam ca śabdam anyaḥ
translated: Moreover, one calls out to another through space, and when called by another, one hears the sound through space. One hears the words spoken by another.

original: pratiśṛṇotyākāśe ramate krīḍatyanyonyaṃ sarvastathā na ramate cā'kāśe vadhvādiviyoga🔽ākāśe jāyate na mūrtenāvaṣṭabdhe /
analyzed: pratiśṛṇoti ākāśe ramate krīḍati anyonyam sarvaḥ tathā na ramate ca ākāśe vadhvā ādi viyoga  ākāśe jāyate na mūrtena avaṣṭabdhe
translated: One delights in space, plays with another, and all do not delight in space as much as a bride and others do when separated.🔽One is not born in space, as it is not obstructed by a physical body.

analyzed: tathā ākāśam abhilakṣya aṅkura ādi jāyate na pratilomam
translated: Similarly, a sprout etc. is born aiming at space, not in the opposite direction.

analyzed: atas ākāśam upāḥsva
translated: Therefore, meditate on space.

analyzed: sa yaḥ ākāśam brahma iti upāste
translated: He who meditates on space as Brahman,

original: ākāśavato vai sa lokān prakāśavato 'saṃbādhān urugāyavato 'bhisidhyati /
analyzed: ākāśavataḥ vai sa lokān prakāśavataḥ saṃbādhān urugāyavataḥ bhisidhyati
translated: He attains worlds that are full of space, full of light, free from obstruction, and vast.

original: yāvad ākāśasya gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati ya ākāśaṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: yāvat ākāśasya gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ ākāśam brahma iti upāste
translated: As far as space has gone, there he has freedom to act as he wishes, he who meditates on space as Brahman.

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ ākāśāt bhūyaḥ iti
translated: O revered one, is there anything greater than space?

analyzed: ākāśāt vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: There is something greater than space, indeed.

original: tan me bhagavān bravītv iti //🔽phalaṃ śṛṇvākāśavato vai vistārayuktānsa vidvāṃllokānprakāśavataḥ /🔽prakāśākāśayornityasaṃbandhātprakāśavataśca lokānasaṃbādhānsaṃbādhanaṃ saṃbādhaḥ
analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti  phalam śṛṇu ākāśavataḥ vai vistāra yuktān sa vidvān lokān prakāśavataḥ  prakāśa ākāśayoḥ nitya saṃbandhāt prakāśavataḥ ca lokān a saṃbādhāt saṃbādhanam saṃbādhaḥ
translated: May the revered one tell me that.🔽The result is: He attains worlds that are full of space, vast, full of light,

analyzed: saṃbādhaḥ nyonya pīḍā tad rahitān a saṃbādhān urugāyavataḥ vistīrṇa gatīn vistīrṇa pracārān lokān abhisidhyati
translated: and free from obstruction, because of the eternal connection between light and space. Obstruction is mutual affliction. He attains worlds free from obstruction, vast, with vast paths and vast movements.

analyzed: yāvat ākāśasya ityādi ukta artham
translated: As far as space has gone, etc. has been explained.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya dvādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twelfth section in the seventh chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: smaraḥ vai ākāśāt bhūyaḥ
translated: Memory, verily, is greater than space.

original: tasmād yady api bahava āsīrann a smaranto naiva te kaṃcana śṛṇuyur na manvīran na vijānīran /
analyzed: tasmāt yadi api bahavaḥ āsīran a smarantaḥ na eva te kaṃcana śṛṇuyuḥ na manvīran na vijānīran
translated: Therefore, even if many were to be present, if they did not remember, they would not hear anything, would not think, would not know anything.

original: yadā vāva te smareyur atha śṛṇuyur atha manvīrann atha vijānīran /
analyzed: yadā vāva te smareyuḥ atha śṛṇuyuḥ atha manvīran atha vijānīran
translated: As long as they remember, then they hear, then they reflect, then they know.

original: smareṇa vai putrān vijānāti smareṇa paśūn /
analyzed: smareṇa vai putrān vijānāti smareṇa paśūn
translated: By memory one knows one's sons, by memory one knows one's cattle.

original: smaram upāssveti //🔽sa yaḥ smaraṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: smaram upāssva iti  sa yaḥ smaram brahma iti upāste
translated: Meditate on memory.🔽One who meditates on memory as Brahman

original: yāvat smarasya gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati yaḥ smaraṃ brahmety upāste /
analyzed: yāvat smarasya gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ smaram brahma iti upāste
translated: has freedom to do as he wishes in the sphere of memory, for one who meditates on memory as Brahman.

analyzed: asti bhagavaḥ smarāt bhūyaḥ iti
translated: Venerable Sir, is there anything greater than memory?

analyzed: smarāt vāva bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: Memory is indeed greater.

original: tan me bhagavān bravītv iti //🔽smaro vāvā'kākāśādbhūyaḥ /
analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti  smaraḥ vāvāka ākāśāt bhūyaḥ
translated: Venerable Sir, please tell me that.🔽Memory is indeed greater than space.

analyzed: smaraṇam smaraḥ ntaḥkaraṇa dharmaḥ
translated: Memory is the quality of the internal organ.

original: sa ākāśādbhūyāniti draṣṭavyaṃ liṅgavyatyayena smartuḥ smaraṇe hi satyākāśādi sarvamarthavatsmaraṇavato bhogyatvāt /
analyzed: saḥ ākāśāt bhūyān iti draṣṭavyam liṅga vyatyayena smartuḥ smaraṇe hi sati ākāśa ādi sarvam arthavat smaraṇavataḥ bhogya tvāt
translated: It should be seen as greater than space, by changing the gender. For when the knower has memory, all things like space etc. become meaningful to him, because they are to be enjoyed by one who has memory.

analyzed: asati tu sma rame sat api asat eva
translated: But when there is no memory, even what exists is as good as non-existent.

analyzed: sattva kārya abhāvāt
translated: Because the effect of existence is absent.

analyzed: nā api sattvam smṛti abhāve śakyam ākāśa ādīnām avagantum iti atas smaraṇasya ākāśāt bhṛyaḥ tvam
translated: Nor is it possible to understand the existence of space etc. in the absence of memory. Therefore, memory is greater than space.

original: dṛśyate hi loke smaraṇasya bhūyastvaṃ yasmāttasmādyadyapi samuditā bahava ekasminnāsīrannupaviśeyuste
analyzed: dṛśyate hi loke smaraṇasya bhūyaḥ tvam yasmāt tasmāt yadi api samuditāḥ bahavaḥ ekasmin āsīran upaviśeyuḥ te
translated: For in the world, memory is seen to be more abundant. Therefore, even if many people were to sit together in one place,

original: tatrā'sīnā anyonyabhāṣitamapi na smarantaścetsyurnaiva te kañcana śabdaṃ śṛṇuyustathā
analyzed: tatra āsīnāḥ anyonya bhāṣitam api na smarantaḥ ced syuḥ nā eva te kañcana śabdam śṛṇuyuḥ tathā
translated: if they were to sit there and not remember each other's words, they would not hear any sound at all.

original: na manvīranmantavyaṃ cetsmareyustadā manvīransmṛtyabhāvānna manvīraṃstathā na vijānīran /
analyzed: na manvīran mantavyam ced smareyuḥ tadā manvīran smṛti abhāvāt na manvīran tathā na vijānīran
translated: If they were not to think what should be thought, they would not remember when they remembered. Due to the absence of memory, they would not think. They would not know.

original: yadā vāva te smareyurmantavyaṃ vijñātavyaṃ śrotavyaṃ cātha śṛṇuyuratha manvīrannatha vijānīran /
analyzed: yadā vāva te smareyuḥ mantavyam vijñātavyam śrotavyam ca atha śṛṇuyuḥ atha manvīran atha vijānīran
translated: When they do remember what should be thought, what should be known, and what should be heard, then they would hear, then they would think, then they would know.

original: tathā smareṇa vai mama putrā eta iti putrānvijānāti smareṇa paśūn /
analyzed: tathā smareṇa vai mama putrāḥ ete iti putrān vijānāti smareṇa paśūn
translated: Thus, he knows his sons by memory, thinking These are my sons. He knows his cattle by memory.

analyzed: atas bhūyaḥ tvāt smaram upāṃsva iti
translated: Therefore, because of its abundance, meditate on memory.

analyzed: ukta artham anyat
translated: The rest is of the same meaning as stated before.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya trayodaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the thirteenth section of the seventh chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: āśā vāva smarāt bhūyasī
translated: Hope, verily, is greater than memory.

original: āśeddho vai smaro mantrān adhīte karmāṇi kurute putrāṃś ca paśūṃś cecchata imaṃ ca lokaṃ amuṃ cecchate /
analyzed: āśā iddhaḥ vai smaraḥ mantrān adhīte karmāṇi kurute putrān ca paśūn ca icchate imam ca lokam amum ca icchate
translated: For memory is impelled by hope. One studies the mantras, performs actions, desires sons and cattle, desires this world and the next.

analyzed: āśām upāssva iti
translated: Meditate on hope.

analyzed: āśā vāva smarāt bhūyasī
translated: Hope, verily, is greater than memory.

original: āśāprāptavastvākāṅkṣā'śā tṛṣṇā kāma iti yāmāhuḥ paryāyaiḥ sā ca smarādbhūyasī /
analyzed: āśā prāpta vastu ākāṅkṣā āśā tṛṣṇā kāmaḥ iti yām āhuḥ paryāyaiḥ sā ca smarāt bhūyasī
translated: Hope is the desire for an object that is to be obtained, called by synonyms such as thirst, craving, desire. And that is greater than memory.

analyzed: katham  āśayā
translated: How?

analyzed: hi antaḥkaraṇa sthayā smarati smartavyam
translated: For one remembers the object to be remembered by hope residing in the internal organ.

original: āśāviṣayarūpaṃ smarannasau smaro bhavatyata āśeddha āśayābhivardhitaḥ smarabhūtaḥ
analyzed: āśā viṣaya rūpam smaran asau smaraḥ bhavati atas āśā iddhaḥ āśaya abhivardhitaḥ smara bhūtaḥ
translated: Remembering the form that is the object of hope, he becomes memory. Thus memory is kindled, increased by hope.

original: smarannṛgādīnmantrānadhīte 'dhītya ca tadarthaṃ brāhmaṇebhyo vidhīṃśca śrutvā karmāṇi
analyzed: smaran nṛga ādīn mantrān adhīte dhītya ca tad artham brāhmaṇebhyaḥ vidhīn ca śrutvā karmāṇi
translated: Remembering the Rg and other mantras, he studies them. Having studied, he hears the injunctions from Brahmins regarding their meaning and performs the rites.

analyzed: kurute tad phala āśayā eva putrān ca karma phala bhūtān icchate tad sādhanāni anutiṣṭhati
translated: With the hope for their fruits, he desires sons, which are the fruits of his actions. He desires them with hope alone. He performs their means with hope alone.

analyzed: imam ca lokam āśeddhaḥ eva smaran loka saṃgraha hetubhiḥ icchate
translated: Remembering this world kindled by hope, he desires it with the means of its attainment.

original: amuṃ ca lokamāśeddhaḥ smaraṃstatsādhanānuṣṭhānenecchate 'ta āśāraśānāvabaddhaṃ smarākāśādināmaparyantaṃ jagaccakrībhūtaṃ pratiprāṇi /
analyzed: amum ca lokam āśā iddhaḥ smaran tad sādhana anuṣṭhānena icchate te āśā raśāna avabaddham smara ākāśa ādi nāma paryantam jagat cakrībhūtam pratiprāṇi
translated: And remembering the other world kindled by hope, he desires it by performing its means. Thus the world, from the sky kindled by hope up to the name, is bound by the arrow of hope, and is like a wheel for each living being.

original: atra āśa āyāḥ smarādapi bhūyastvamityata āśāmupāḥsva //
analyzed: atra āśaḥ āyāḥ smarāt api bhūyas tvam iti atas āśām upāḥsva
translated: Here, hope is greater than memory. Therefore, one should meditate on hope.

analyzed: sa yaḥ āśām brahma iti upāste
translated: He who worships Hope as Brahman,

analyzed: āśayā asya sarve kāmāḥ samṛdhyanti
translated: through Hope all his desires are fulfilled.

analyzed: amoghāḥ ha asya āśiṣaḥ bhavanti
translated: His prayers are never fruitless.

original: yāvad āśāyā gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati ya āśāṃ brahmety upāste /🔽asti bhagava āśāyā bhūya iti /
analyzed: yāvat āśāyāḥ gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati yaḥ āśām brahma iti upāste  asti bhagavaḥ āśāyāḥ bhūyaḥ iti
translated: As far as Hope extends, there he has freedom to act as he wishes, he who worships Hope as Brahman.🔽O revered one, is there anything greater than Hope?

analyzed: āśāyāḥ bhūyaḥ sti iti
translated: There is something greater than Hope, he said.

analyzed: tat me bhagavān bravītu iti
translated: Please tell me that, revered one.

analyzed: yaḥ tu āśām brahma iti upāste śṛṇu tasya phalam
translated: Listen to the fruit of him who worships Hope as Brahman.

original: āśayā sadopāsitayāsyopāsakasya sarve kāmāḥ samṛdhyanti samṛddhiṃ gacchanti /
analyzed: āśayā sadā upāsitayā asya upāsakasya sarve kāmāḥ samṛdhyanti samṛddhim gacchanti
translated: Through Hope, always worshipped, all the desires of that worshipper are fulfilled, they become prosperous.

original: amoghā hāsyā'śiṣaḥ prārthanāḥ sarvā bhavanti yatprārthitaṃ sarvaṃ tadavaśyaṃ bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: amoghāḥ ha asya āśiṣaḥ prārthanāḥ sarvāḥ bhavanti yat prārthitam sarvam tat avaśyam bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: His prayers, his wishes, are never fruitless. Everything that he wishes for, all that necessarily happens, is the meaning.

analyzed: yāvat āśāyāḥ gatam ityādi pūrvavat
translated: As far as Hope extends, etc., as before.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya caturdaśa khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Fourteenth Section in the Seventh Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ vāva āśāyāḥ bhūyān
translated: Prana, indeed, is greater than Hope.

original: yathā vā arā nābhau samarpitā evam asmin prāṇe sarvaṃ samarpitam /🔽prāṇaḥ prāṇena yāti /
analyzed: yathā vai arāḥ nābhau samarpitāḥ evam asmin prāṇe sarvam samarpitam  prāṇaḥ prāṇena yāti
translated: Just as the spokes are fixed in the nave, so everything is fixed in this Prana.🔽Prana moves by Prana.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ prāṇam dadāti
translated: Prana gives Prana.

analyzed: prāṇāya dadāti  prāṇaḥ ha pitā  prāṇaḥ mātā
translated: He gives to the life-breath.🔽For the life-breath is the father.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ bhrātā  prāṇaḥ svasā
translated: The life-breath is the mother.🔽The life-breath is the brother.🔽The life-breath is the sister.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ ācāryaḥ
translated: The life-breath is the teacher.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: The life-breath is the Brahmin.

analyzed: nāma upakramam āśāntam kārya kāraṇa tvena nimitta naimittika tvena ca uttara uttara bhūyaḥ tayā avasthitam
translated: Beginning with the name and ending with peace, existing as cause and effect, as the cause and the effect, and as more and more,

analyzed: smṛti nimitta sadbhāvam āśā raśanā pāśaiḥ vipāśitam sarvam sarvatas bisam iva tantubhiḥ yasmin prāṇe samarpitam
translated: all is attached to the life-breath like a lotus to its stalk, with the bonds of hope and desire.

original: yena ca sarvato vyāpināntarbahirgatena sūtre maṇigaṇā iva sūtreṇa grathitaṃ vidhṛtaṃ ca /
analyzed: yena ca sarvatas vyāpinā antar bahis gatena sūtre maṇi gaṇāḥ iva sūtreṇa grathitam vidhṛtam ca
translated: And by which everything is held together and sustained like gems on a string, by the all-pervading one, going within and without.

original: sa eṣa prāṇo vā āśāyā bhūyān /
analyzed: saḥ eṣa prāṇaḥ vai āśāyāḥ bhūyān
translated: That life-breath is greater than hope.

analyzed: katham asya bhūyaḥ tvam iti āha dṛṣṭāntena samarthayan tad bhūyaḥ tvam
translated: How is its greatness? He says, supporting that greatness with an example.

original: yathā vai loke rathacakrasyārā rathanābhau samarpitāḥ saṃprotāḥ saṃpraveśitā ityetat /
analyzed: yathā vai loke ratha cakrasya arāḥ ratha nābhau samarpitāḥ saṃprotāḥ saṃpraveśitāḥ iti etat
translated: Just as in the world, the spokes of a chariot wheel are fixed, woven, and inserted into the nave of the chariot.

original: evamasmiṃlliṅgasaṃghātarūpe prāṇe prajñātmani dehike mukhye yasminparā devatā nāmarūpavyākaraṇāyā'darśādau pratibimbivajjīvenā'tmanānupratiṣṭā
analyzed: evam asmin liṅga saṃghāta rūpe prāṇe prajñā ātmani dehike mukhye yasmin parā devatā nāma rūpa vyākaraṇāya ādarśa ādau pratibimbi vat jīvena ātmanā anupratiṣṭā
translated: In the same way, in this vital air, which is of the nature of a collection of principles, which is the Self of wisdom, which is embodied, and which is the principal one, in which the supreme deity is established with the individual soul, like a reflection in a mirror, for the purpose of manifesting names and forms,

analyzed: yaḥ ca mahā rājasya iva sarva adhikāri īśvarasya
translated: and which is like the all-authorizing lord of a great king,🔽as stated in the Vedic text In whom shall I be established when I depart, in whom shall I be established when I depart? He created the vital air.

original: kasminnannvahamutkrānta utkrānto baviṣyāmi kasminvā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmīti sa prāṇamasṛjataiti śruteḥ yastu cchāyevānugata īśvaram
analyzed: kasmin annu aham utkrāntaḥ utkrāntaḥ baviṣyāmi kasmin vā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmi iti sa prāṇam asṛjata eti śruteḥ yaḥ tu chāyā iva anugataḥ īśvaram
translated: He who is like a shadow following the Lord,

original: tadyathā rathasyāreṣu nemirarpito nābhāvarā arpitā evamevaitā bhūtamātrāḥ prajñāmātrāsvarpitāḥ prajñāmātrāḥ prāṇe 'rpitāḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā rathasya areṣu nemiḥ arpitaḥ nābhau arāḥ arpitāḥ evam eva etāḥ bhūtamātrāḥ prajñāmātrāsu arpitāḥ prajñāmātrāḥ prāṇe rpitāḥ
translated: just as the nave is fixed in the spokes of a chariot, and the spokes are fixed in the felly, in the same way these elemental parts are fixed in the parts of wisdom, and the parts of wisdom are fixed in the vital air.

original: sa eṣa prāṇa eva prajñātmāiti kauṣītakinām /
analyzed: saḥ eṣa prāṇaḥ eva prajñā ātmā iti kauṣītakinām
translated: This is the vital air itself, which is the Self of wisdom, according to the Koushitakas.

analyzed: atas evam asmin prāṇe sarvam yathā uktam samarpitam
translated: Therefore, everything mentioned above is dedicated to this vital air.

original: ataḥ sa eṣa prāṇo 'paratantraḥ prāṇena svaśaktyaiva yāti nānyakṛtaṃ gamanādikriyāsvasya sāmarthyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas saḥ eṣa prāṇo paratantraḥ prāṇena sva śaktyā eva yāti na anya kṛtam gamana ādi kriyāsu asya sāmarthyam iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, this vital air is independent. It moves by its own power, not by the agency of others in the activities of going and so on. The meaning is that it has the ability in those actions.

original: sarvaṃ kriyākārakaphalabhedajātaṃ prāṇa eva na prāṇādbahirbhūtamastīti prakaraṇārthaḥ /🔽prāṇaḥ prāṇaṃ dadāti yaddadāti tatsvītmabhūtameva /
analyzed: sarvam kriyā kāraka phala bheda jātam prāṇaḥ eva na prāṇāt bahis bhūtam asti iti prakaraṇa arthaḥ  prāṇaḥ prāṇam dadāti yat dadāti tat svītma bhūtam eva
translated: The meaning of the section is that everything, the entire class of actions, agents, and results, is indeed just the vital breath, there is nothing external to the vital breath.🔽The vital breath gives the vital breath. What it gives is indeed its own self.

analyzed: yasmai dadāti tat api prāṇāya eva
translated: To whom it gives, that also is for the vital breath itself.

analyzed: atas pitṛ ādi ākhyaḥ pi prāṇaḥ eva
translated: Therefore, even one called father and so on is indeed the vital breath itself.

original: sa yadi pitaraṃ vā mātaraṃ vā bhrātaraṃ vā svasāraṃ vācāryaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā kiṃcid bhṛśam iva pratyāha /
analyzed: sa yadi pitaram vā mātaram vā bhrātaram vā svasāram vā ācāryam vā brāhmaṇam vā kiṃcid bhṛśam iva pratyāha
translated: If he speaks harshly to his father or mother or brother or sister or teacher or brahmin, saying

analyzed: dhik tvā astu iti eva enam āhuḥ
translated: Shame on you! they say to him.

original: pitṛhā vai tvam asi mātṛhā vai tvam asi bhrātṛhā vai tvam asi svasṛhā vai tvam asy ācāryahā vai tvam asi brāhmaṇahā vai tvam asīti //
analyzed: pitṛ hā vai tvam asi mātṛ hā vai tvam asi bhrātṛ hā vai tvam asi svasṛ hā vai tvam asi ācārya hā vai tvam asi brāhmaṇa hā vai tvam asi iti
translated: You are indeed a father-killer, you are indeed a mother-killer, you are indeed a brother-killer, you are indeed a sister-killer, you are indeed a teacher-killer, you are indeed a brahmin-killer.

analyzed: katham pitṛ ādi śabdānām prasiddha artha utsargeṇa prāṇa viṣaya tvam iti
translated: How is it that the words father and so on, abandoning their well-known meanings, refer to the vital breath?

original: ucyate sati prāṇe pitrādiṣu pitrādiśabdaprayogāttadutkrāntau ca prayogābhāvāt /
analyzed: ucyate sati prāṇe pitṛ ādiṣu pitṛ ādi śabda prayogāt tad utkrāntau ca prayoga abhāvāt
translated: It is said that because the words father and so on are used for father and so on when the vital breath is present, and because they are not used when it has departed.

analyzed: katham tat iti āha
translated: How is that? It is said:

original: sa yaḥ kaścitpitrādīnāmanyatamaṃ yadi taṃ bhṛśamiva tadananurūpamiva kiñcidvacanaṃ tvaṅkārādiyuktaṃ pratyāha tadainaṃ pārśvasthā āhurvivekino
analyzed: sa yaḥ kaścid pitṛ ādīnām anyatamam yadi tam bhṛśam iva tad ananurūpam iva kiñcid vacanam tvaṅkāra ādi yuktam pratyāha tadā enam pārśva sthāḥ āhuḥ vivekinaḥ
translated: He who, for some reason, speaks harshly to any one of his parents, etc., as if he were a stranger, with words accompanied by contempt, etc., then those who are by his side, the discerning ones,

analyzed: dhik tvā astu dhik astu tvām iti evam
translated: say to him: Fie on you! Fie on you! in this way.

analyzed: pitṛ hā vai tvam pituḥ hantā ityādi
translated: You are a father-killer, a father's murderer, and so on.

original: atha yady apy enān utkrāntaprāṇāñ chūlena samāsaṃ vyatiṣaṃdahet /
analyzed: atha yadi api enān utkrānta prāṇām śūlena samāsam vyatiṣaṃdahet
translated: Now, even if he were to burn them together on a spit, having their life departed,

original: naivainaṃ brūyuḥ pitṛhāsīti na mātṛhāsīti na bhrātṛhāsīti na svasṛhāsīti nācāryahāsīti na brāhmaṇahāsīti //
analyzed: na eva enam brūyuḥ pitṛ hā asi iti na mātṛ hā asi iti na bhrātṛ hā asi iti na svasṛ hā asi iti na ācārya hā asi iti na brāhmaṇa hā asi iti
translated: they would not call him a father-killer, a mother-killer, a brother-killer, a sister-killer, a teacher-killer, or a brahmin-killer.

analyzed: atha enān eva utkrānta prāṇān tyakta dehān atha yadi api śūlena samāsam samasya
translated: Now, even if he were to burn them together on a spit, having their life departed and their body abandoned,

analyzed: vyatidahet vyatyasya saṃdahet evam api ati krūram karma samāsa vyatyāsa ādi prakāreṇa dahana lakṣaṇam
translated: even so, by the method of burning together and interchanging, he would be doing an extremely cruel deed characterized by burning,

analyzed: tad deha saṃbaddham eva kurvāṇam na eva enam brūyuḥ pitṛ hā ityādi
translated: connected only with that body. They would not call him a father-killer, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt anvaya vyatirekābhyām avagamyate etat pitṛ ādi ākhyā pi prāṇaḥ eva iti
translated: Therefore, it is understood by positive and negative concomitance that the one called father, etc. is also the vital air itself.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ hi eva etāni sarvāṇi bhavati
translated: For all these are indeed just prāṇa.

original: sa vā eṣa evaṃ paśyann evaṃ manvāna evaṃ vijānann ativādī bhavati /🔽taṃ ced brūyur ativādy asīti /
analyzed: sa vai eṣaḥ evam paśyan evam manvānaḥ evam vijānan ati vādī bhavati  tam ced brūyuḥ ati vādī asi iti
translated: He who sees thus, thinks thus, and knows thus, becomes a great talker.🔽If they were to say to him, 'You are a great talker,'

analyzed: ati vādī asmi iti brūyāt
translated: he should say, 'I am a great talker.'

analyzed: na apahnuvīta
translated: He should not deny it.

original: tasmātprāṇo hyevaitāni pitrādīni sarvāṇi bhavati calāni sthirāṇi ca /
analyzed: tasmāt prāṇaḥ hi eva etāni pitṛ ādīni sarvāṇi bhavati calāni sthirāṇi ca
translated: Therefore, indeed, all these, the ancestors and so on, moving and unmoving, are just prāṇa.

original: sa vā eṣa prāṇavidevaṃ yathoktaprakāreṇa paśyanphalato 'nubhavannevaṃ manvāna upapattibhiścintayannevaṃ vijānannupapattibhiḥ saṃyojyaivameveti
analyzed: sa vai eṣa prāṇa vid evam yathā ukta prakāreṇa paśyan phalataḥ nubhavan evam manvānaḥ upapattibhiḥ cintayan evam vijānan upapattibhiḥ saṃyojya evam eva iti
translated: He who knows prāṇa thus, seeing it in this way described, experiencing it as a result, thinking about it in this way with reasoning, knowing it in this way by connecting it with reasoning,

analyzed: niścayam kurvan iti arthaḥ
translated: determining it thus, this is the meaning.

original: mananavijñānābhyāṃ hi saṃbhūtaḥ śāsrārtho niścito dṛṣṭo bhavet /
analyzed: manana vijñānābhyām hi saṃbhūtaḥ śāsra arthaḥ niścitaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ bhavet
translated: For the meaning of the scriptures, which has arisen from reflection and knowledge, would be seen and determined.

original: ata evaṃ paśyannativādī bhavati nāmādyāśāntamatītya vadanaśīlo bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas evam paśyan ativādī bhavati nāma ādya aśāntam atītya vadana śīlaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, seeing thus, he becomes a great talker, one who speaks beyond name and so on up to non-existence, this is the meaning.

original: taṃ cedbrūyustaṃ yadyevamativādinaṃ sarvadā sarvaiḥ śabdairnāmādyāśāntamatītya vartamānaṃ
analyzed: tam ced brūyuḥ tam yadi evam ativādinam sarvadā sarvaiḥ śabdaiḥ nāma ādya aśāntam atītya vartamānam
translated: If they were to say to him, if they were to say to that great talker who always exists beyond name and so on up to non-existence with all words,

analyzed: prāṇam evam vadantam evam paśyantam ativadana śīlam ativādinam brahma ādi stamba paryantasya
translated: When they say to him who speaks thus, who sees thus, who is of the habit of speaking much, who speaks much, 'You are speaking too much,'

original: hi jagataḥ prāṇa ātmāhamiti bruvāṇaṃ yadi brūyurativādyasīti /🔽bāḍhamativādyasmīti brūyānnāpahnuvīta /
analyzed: hi jagataḥ prāṇaḥ ātmā aham iti bruvāṇam yadi brūyuḥ ativādyasi iti  bāḍham ativādī asmi iti brūyāt na apahnuvīta
translated: if he were to say, 'I am indeed speaking too much,' he would not deny (it).

analyzed: kasmāt hi asau apahnuvīta
translated: For how could he deny (it)?

analyzed: yad prāṇam sarveśvara mayam aham asmi iti ātma tvena upagataḥ
translated: Since he has approached the self as the all-pervading supreme self, the life-breath.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya pañcadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifteenth section in the seventh chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: eṣa tu vā ativadati yaḥ satyenātivadati /
analyzed: eṣa tu vai ativadati yaḥ satyena ativadati
translated: But he who speaks with truth speaks too much.

original: so 'haṃ bhagavaḥ satyenātivadānīti /🔽satyaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyam iti /
analyzed: sa u ham bhagavaḥ satyena ativadāni iti  satyam tu eva vijijñāsitavyam iti
translated: 'I speak too much with truth, O revered one.'🔽'Truth indeed should be known.'

analyzed: satyam bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: 'Truth, O revered one, I wish to know.'

original: sa eṣa nāradaḥ sarvātiśayaṃ prāṇaṃ svamātmānaṃ sarvātmānaṃ śrutvā nātaḥ paramastītyupararāma /
analyzed: saḥ eṣa nāradaḥ sarva atiśayam prāṇam svam ātmānam sarva ātmānam śrutvā na atas param asti iti upararāma
translated: Having heard that his own self, Nārada, is the supreme life-breath, the self of all, he ceased, thinking there is nothing higher than this.

original: na pūrvavatkimasti bhagavaḥ prāṇādbhūya iti papraccha /
analyzed: na pūrvavat kim asti bhagavaḥ prāṇāt bhūyaḥ iti papraccha
translated: Unlike before, he did not ask, 'Is there anything greater than the life-breath, O revered one?'

original: yatastamevaṃ vikārānṛtabrahmavijñānena parituṣṭamakṛtārthaṃ paramārthasatyātivādinamātmānaṃ manyamānaṃ yogyaṃ śiṣyaṃ mithyāgrahaviśeṣādvipracyāvayannāha
analyzed: yatas tam evam vikāra anṛta brahma vijñānena parituṣṭam akṛtārtham paramārtha satya ativādinam ātmānam manyamānam yogyam śiṣyam mithyā graha viśeṣāt vipracyāvayan āha
translated: Because the disciple who is satisfied with the knowledge of the changing, unreal Brahman, who has not attained his goal, who considers himself to be the highest truth, who is fit [to receive the true knowledge], is being led astray by a particular false conception, he says:

analyzed: bhagavān sanatkumāraḥ
translated: Because the Blessed One Sanatkumāra, finding the disciple fit, who was satisfied with the knowledge of the changing, unreal Brahman, who was not content, who considered himself to be speaking the highest truth, was removing him from a particular false conception, he said:

original: eṣa tu vā ativadati yamahaṃ vakṣyāmi na prāṇavidativādī paramārthataḥ /
analyzed: eṣa tu vai ativadati yam aham vakṣyāmi na prāṇa vid ativādī paramārthataḥ
translated: But he indeed speaks too much who will speak of what I will tell, not the speaker of the truth about the vital airs.

analyzed: nāma ādi apekṣam tu tasya ativādi tvam
translated: But his speaking too much is in relation to the name, etc.

original: yastu bhūmākhyaṃ sarvātikrāntaṃ tattvaṃ paramārthasatyaṃ veda so 'tivādītyata āhaeṣa tu vā ativadati yaḥ sateyana paramārthasatyavijñānavattayātivadati
analyzed: yaḥ tu bhūma ākhyam sarva atikrāntam tattvam paramārtha satyam veda saḥ u tivādī iti atas āha eṣa tu vai ativadati yaḥ paramārtha satya vijñānavat tayā ativadati
translated: But he who knows the truth called the Infinite, which transcends all, that is the highest truth, he is the speaker of the truth. Therefore it is said: But he indeed speaks too much who speaks of what I will tell, not the speaker of the truth about the vital airs.

original: so 'haṃ tvāṃ prapanno bhagavansatyenātivadāni tathāmāṃ niyunaktu bhagavānyathāhaṃ satyenātivadānītyabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ ham tvām prapannaḥ bhagavan satyena ativadāni tathā amām niyunaktu bhagavān yathā aham satyena ativadāni iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: I have come to you, O Blessed One, I will speak the truth too much. May the Blessed One direct me thus, so that I may speak the truth too much. This is the intention.

original: yadyevaṃ satyenātivaditumicchasi satyameva tu tāvadvijijñāsitavyamityukta āha nāradaḥ /
analyzed: yadi evam satyena ativaditum icchasi satyam eva tu tāvat vijijñāsitavyam iti uktaḥ āha nāradaḥ
translated: If you wish to speak the truth too much in this way, then truth itself should first be investigated. Thus spoken to, Nārada said:

original: tathāstu tarhi satya bhagavo vijijñāse viśeṣeṇa jñātumiccheyaṃ tvatto 'hamiti //
analyzed: tathā astu tarhi satya bhagavaḥ vijijñāse viśeṣeṇa jñātum iccheyam tvattaḥ ham iti
translated: If so, then let it be so, O revered one. I wish to know the truth in particular, from you.

original: iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi saptamādhyāyasya ṣoḍaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ🔽yadā vai vijānāty atha satyaṃ vadati /
analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya ṣoḍaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ  yadā vai vijānāti atha satyam vadati
translated: Thus ends the sixteenth section in the seventh chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.🔽When one knows, then one speaks the truth.

analyzed: na a vijānan satyam vadati
translated: Not without knowing does one speak the truth.

analyzed: vijānan eva satyam vadati
translated: Only knowing does one speak the truth.

analyzed: vijñānam tu eva vijijñāsitavyam iti
translated: But knowledge itself should be desired to be known.

analyzed: vijñānam bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: Revered one, I desire to know knowledge.

original: yadā vai satyaṃ paramārthato vijānātīdaṃ paramārthaḥ satyamiti /
analyzed: yadā vai satyam paramārthataḥ vijānāti idam paramārthaḥ satyam iti
translated: When one knows the truth, the highest reality, as this is the highest truth,

original: tato 'nṛtaṃ vikārajātaṃ vācārambhaṇaṃ hitvā sarvavikārāvasthaṃ sadevaikaṃ satyamiti tadevātha vadati yadvadati /
analyzed: tatas vikāra jātam vācā ārambhaṇam hitvā sarva vikāra avastham sat eva ekam satyam iti tat eva atha vadati yat vadati
translated: then one speaks the truth, leaving aside the untruth, the creation of modifications, which is mere verbal expression. The truth is the one Self alone, in all its states of modification.

analyzed: nanu satyam eva
translated: But is not modification also true?

analyzed: nāma rūpe satyam tābhyaḥ mayam prāṇaḥ channaḥ
translated: Name and form are true, and the Self is concealed by them.

original: prāṇā vai satyaṃ teṣāmeṣa satyamiti śrutyantarāt /
analyzed: prāṇāḥ vai satyam teṣām eṣa satyam iti śruti antarāt
translated: The Self is indeed the truth, for the scriptures say, The Self is the truth of all things.

original: satyamuktaṃ satyatvaṃ śrutyantare vikārasya na tu paramārthāpekṣamuktaṃ kiṃ tarhīndriyaviṣayatvāpekṣaṃ
analyzed: satyam uktam satya tvam śruti antare vikārasya na tu paramārtha apekṣam uktam kim tarhi indriya viṣaya tva apekṣam
translated: The truth of modification is stated in another scripture, but not in relation to the highest reality. What then? It is stated in relation to being the object of the senses.

original: sacca tyacceti satyamityuktaṃ taddvāreṇa ca paramārthasatyasyopalabdhirvivakṣiteti /
analyzed: sat ca tyad ca iti satyam iti uktam tad dvāreṇa ca paramārtha satyasya upalabdhiḥ vivakṣitā iti
translated: Truth is said to be that which is and that which is not, and it is intended that the ultimate truth is known by means of that.

original: prāṇā vai satyaṃ teṣāmeṣa satyamiti coktam /
analyzed: prāṇāḥ vai satyam teṣām eṣa satyam iti ca uktam
translated: And it is said that the vital breaths are truth, and this is their truth.

analyzed: iha api tat iṣṭam eva
translated: Here also, that is accepted.

original: iha tu praṇaviṣayātparamārthasatyavijñānābhimānādvyutthāpya nāradaṃ yatsadeva satyaṃ paramārthato bhūmākhyaṃ tadvijñāpayiṣyāmītyeṣa viśeṣato
analyzed: iha tu praṇa viṣayāt paramārtha satya vijñāna abhimānāt vyutthāpya nāradam yat sat eva satyam paramārthataḥ bhūma ākhyam tat vijñāpayiṣyāmi iti eṣa
translated: But here, after disabusing Narada of the conceit that he knows the ultimate truth about the vital breaths, it is intended to make him understand that which is truly the ultimate truth, which is called the Absolute. This is the specific

analyzed: vivakṣitaḥ ūrthaḥ
translated: meaning intended.

original: nāvijānansatyaṃ vadati yastvavijānanvadati so 'gnyādiśabdenāgnyadīnparamārthasadrūpānmanyamāno vadati na tu te rūpatrayavyatirekeṇa paramārthaḥ🔽santi /
analyzed: na avijānān satyam vadati yaḥ tu avijānan vadati saḥ gni ādi śabdena agni ādīn paramārtha sat rūpān manyamānaḥ vadati na tu te rūpa traya vyatirekeṇa paramārthaḥ  santi
translated: One who does not know the truth does not speak the truth. But one who speaks without knowing, thinking that the words like fire refer to things that are ultimately real like fire, speaks, but they do not exist in reality apart from the three forms.

original: tathā tānyapi rūpāṇi sadapekṣayā naiva santītyato nāvijānansatyaṃ vadati /
analyzed: tathā tāni api rūpāṇi sat apekṣayā nā eva santi iti atas na avijānan satyam vadati
translated: Thus, those forms also do not exist in relation to existence. Therefore, one who does not know does not speak the truth.

analyzed: vijānan eva satyam vadati
translated: One who knows speaks the truth.

original: na ca tatsatyavijñānamavijijñāsitamaprārthitaṃ jñāyata ityāhavijñānaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyamiti /
analyzed: na ca tat satya vijñānam a vijijñāsitam a prārthitam jñāyate iti āha vijñānam tu eva vijijñāsitavyam iti
translated: And that knowledge of the truth is not known without desire to know and without seeking. Therefore it is said: But knowledge itself is to be desired to be known.

analyzed: yadi evam vijñānam bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: If it is so, I desire to know knowledge, O Lord.

original: evaṃ satyādīnāṃ cottarottarāṇāṃ karotyantānāṃ pūrvapūrvahetutvaṃ vyākhyeyam //
analyzed: evam satya ādīnām ca uttara uttarāṇām karoti antānām pūrva pūrva hetu tvam vyākhyeyam
translated: In the same way, the truth and so on, the latter and latter, should be explained as the cause of the former and former, ending with the doer.

original: iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi saptamādhyāyasya saptadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ🔽yadā vai manute 'tha vijānāti /🔽nāmatvā vijānāti /
analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya saptadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ  yadā vai manute tha vijānāti  na a matvā vijānāti
translated: Thus ends the seventeenth section in the seventh chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.🔽When one reflects, then one knows.🔽Having reflected, one knows.

analyzed: matvā eva vijānāti
translated: Having reflected, one knows.

analyzed: matiḥ tu eva vijijñāsitavyā iti
translated: But understanding itself should be investigated.

analyzed: matim bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: Sir, I want to investigate understanding.

analyzed: yadā vai manute iti
translated: When one reflects.

analyzed: matiḥ mananam tarkaḥ mantavya viṣayaḥ ādaraḥ
translated: Understanding is reflection, reasoning, respect towards the object to be reflected upon.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya aṣṭadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eighteenth section in the seventh chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: yadā vai śraddadhāti atha manute
translated: When one has faith, then one reflects.

analyzed: na a śraddadhat manute  śraddadhat eva manute
translated: One who does not have faith does not reflect.🔽One who has faith reflects.

analyzed: śraddhā tu eva vijijñāsitavyā iti
translated: But faith itself should be investigated.

analyzed: śraddhām bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: Sir, I want to investigate faith.

analyzed: āstikya buddhiḥ śraddhā

analyzed: na a nistiṣṭham śraddadhāti

analyzed: nistiṣṭhan eva śraddadhāti

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya viṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ

analyzed: yadā vai karoti atha nistiṣṭhati

analyzed: na a kṛtvā nistiṣṭhati

analyzed: kṛtvā eva nistiṣṭhati

analyzed: kṛtiḥ tu eva vijijñāsitavyā iti
