analyzed: kṛtim bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: Sir, I wish to investigate action.

analyzed: yadā vai karoti
translated: When one acts.

analyzed: kṛtiḥ indriya saṃyamaḥ citta ekāgra tā karaṇam ca
translated: Action means control of the senses and concentration of the mind.

original: satyāṃ hi tasyāṃ niṣṭhādīni yathoktāni bhavanti vijñānāvasānāni //
analyzed: satyām hi tasyām niṣṭhā ādīni yathā uktāni bhavanti vijñāna avasānāni
translated: For when that exists, the aforementioned things up to knowledge exist.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya ekaviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-first section in the seventh chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: yadā vai sukham labhate karoti
translated: When one obtains happiness, then one acts.

analyzed: na a sukham labdhvā karoti
translated: One does not act without obtaining happiness.

analyzed: sukham eva labdhvā karoti
translated: One acts only after obtaining happiness.

analyzed: sukham tu eva vijijñāsitavyam iti
translated: But happiness itself should be investigated.

analyzed: sukham bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: Sir, I wish to investigate happiness.

original: sāpi kṛtiryadā sukhaṃ labhate sukhaṃ niratiśayaṃ vakṣyamāṇaṃ labdhavyaṃ mayeti manyate tadā bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: sā api kṛtiḥ yadā sukham labhate sukham niratiśayam vakṣyamāṇam labdhavyam mayā iti manyate tadā bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: And that action also becomes when one obtains happiness and thinks that the unsurpassed happiness to be obtained, as will be described, is obtained by me.

original: yathā dṛṣṭaphalasukhā kṛtistathehāpi nāsukhaṃ labdhvā karoti /
analyzed: yathā dṛṣṭa phala sukhā kṛtiḥ tathā iha api na asukham labdhvā karoti
translated: Just as an action that has seen the result as happiness, so here also one does not perform it without obtaining happiness.

analyzed: bhaviṣyat api phalam labdhvā iti ucyate
translated: The future result is also said to be obtained.

analyzed: tat uddiśya pravṛtti upapatteḥ
translated: Because engagement towards that is possible.

original: athedānīṃ kṛtyādiṣūttarottareṣu satsu satyaṃ svayameva pratibhāsata iti na tadvijñānāya pṛthagyatnaḥ kārya iti prāptaṃ tata idamucyate /
analyzed: atha idānīm kṛtyā ādiṣu uttarottareṣu satsu satyam svayam eva pratibhāsate iti na tad vijñānāya pṛthak yatnaḥ kāryaḥ iti prāptam tatas idam ucyate
translated: Now, if it is argued that when the subsequent things like action are present, the self itself appears by itself, and no separate effort is to be made for the knowledge of that, then this is said:

analyzed: sukham tu eva vijijñāsitavyam ityādi
translated: But happiness alone is to be desired to be known, etc.

analyzed: sukham bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti abhimukhībhūtāya āha
translated: I desire to know happiness, O revered one, - to one who has approached in this way, it is said:

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya dvāviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-second section of the seventh chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: yaḥ vai bhūmā tat sukham
translated: That which is the infinite, that is happiness.

analyzed: na alpe sukham asti
translated: There is no happiness in the finite.

analyzed: bhūmā eva sukham
translated: The infinite alone is happiness.

analyzed: bhūmā tu eva vijijñāsitavyaḥ iti
translated: The infinite alone is to be desired to be known.

analyzed: bhūmānam bhagavaḥ vijijñāse iti
translated: I desire to know the infinite, O revered one.

original: yo vai bhūmā mahanniratiśayaṃ bahviti paryāyāstatsukham /
analyzed: yaḥ vai bhūmā mahat niratiśayam bahu iti paryāyāḥ tat sukham
translated: That which is the highest, the great, the unsurpassed, the much, are synonyms for that bliss.

analyzed: tatas u vāc sātiśaya tvāt alpam
translated: Below that, it is lesser due to being surpassed.

analyzed: atas tasmin alpe sukham na asti
translated: Therefore, there is no bliss in that lesser thing.

analyzed: alpasya adhika tṛṣṇā hetu tvāt
translated: Because the lesser thing is the cause of greater craving.

analyzed: tṛṣṇā ca duḥkha bījam
translated: And craving is the seed of suffering.

original: na hi duḥkhabījaṃ sukhaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ jvarādi loke /
analyzed: na hi duḥkha bījam sukham dṛṣṭam jvara ādi loke
translated: For in the world, suffering is not seen to be bliss, such as fever, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam na alpe sukham asti iti
translated: Therefore, it is right to say that there is no bliss in the lesser thing.

analyzed: atas bhūmā eva sukham
translated: Therefore, only the highest is bliss.

analyzed: tṛṣṇā ādi duḥkha bīja tva asaṃbhavāt bhūmnaḥ
translated: Because the highest cannot be the seed of suffering such as craving, etc.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya trayoviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-third section of the seventh chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad

original: yatra nānyat paśyati nānyac chṛṇoti nānyad vijānāti sa bhūmā /
analyzed: yatra na anyat paśyati na anyat śṛṇoti na anyat vijānāti sa bhūmā
translated: Where one sees nothing else, hears nothing else, understands nothing else, that is the highest.

original: atha yatrānyat paśyaty anyac chṛṇoty anyad vijānāti tad alpam /
analyzed: atha yatra anyat paśyati anyat śṛṇoti anyat vijānāti tat alpam
translated: But where one sees something else, hears something else, understands something else, that is the lesser.

analyzed: yaḥ vai bhūmā tat amṛtam
translated: That which is the highest is the immortal.

analyzed: atha yat alpam tat martyam
translated: But that which is the lesser is mortal.

analyzed: sa bhagavaḥ kasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti
translated: Sir, on what is it established?

original: sve mahimni yadi vā na mahimnīti //
analyzed: sve mahimni yadi vā na mahimni iti
translated: Either on its own greatness or on no greatness at all.

original: kiṃlakṣaṇo 'sau bhūmetyāhayatra yasminbhūmni tattve nānyaddraṣṭavyamanyena karaṇena draṣṭānyo vibhakto dṛśyātpaśyati /
analyzed: kiṃlakṣaṇaḥ sau bhūmā iti āha yatra yasmin bhūmni tattve na anyat draṣṭavyam anyena karaṇena draṣṭā anyaḥ vibhaktaḥ dṛśyāt paśyati
translated: What is the characteristic of that state? He says: Where, in which state, in which reality, one does not see anything else with another instrument of knowledge, one sees separate from the object of sight.

analyzed: tathā na anyat śṛṇoti
translated: Similarly, one does not hear anything else.

analyzed: nāma rūpayoḥ eva antarbhāvāt viṣaya bhedasya tad grāhakayoḥ eva iha darśana śravaṇayoḥ grahaṇam anyeṣām ca upalakṣaṇa artha tvena
translated: Because the difference of objects is included in name and form, only seeing and hearing that grasp them are mentioned here, and the others are mentioned for the sake of illustration.

analyzed: mananam ca atra uktam draṣṭavyam na anyat manute iti
translated: And reflection should be seen here as stated, one does not reflect on anything else.

analyzed: prāyaśas manana pūrvaka tvāt vijñānasya
translated: Because knowledge is mostly preceded by reflection.

analyzed: tathā na anyat vijānāti
translated: Similarly, one does not know anything else.

analyzed: evaṃlakṣaṇaḥ yaḥ sa bhūmā
translated: Such is the characteristic of the state.

analyzed: kim atra prasidra anya darśana abhāvaḥ bhūmni ucyate na anyat paśyati ityādinā
translated: What is meant here by the absence of seeing anything else? By saying one does not see anything else, etc.

analyzed: atha anyat na paśyati ātmānam paśyati iti etat
translated: Or is it that one does not see anything else, one sees the self?

analyzed: kiñca atas
translated: And what follows from that?

analyzed: yadi anya darśana ādi abhāva mātram iti ucyate tadā dvaita saṃvyavahāra vilakṣaṇaḥ bhūmā iti uktam bhavati
translated: If it is said that it is merely the absence of seeing anything else, then it is said that the state is different from the conventional usage of duality.

analyzed: atha anyat raśanā viśeṣa pratiṣedhena ātmānam paśyati iti ucyate tadā ekasmin eva kriyā kāraka phala bhedaḥ bhyupagataḥ bhavet
translated: If, on the other hand, it is said that one sees the Self by the denial of another seer, then a difference of action, instrument, and result would be admitted in the very same thing.

analyzed: yadi evam kaḥ doṣaḥ syāt
translated: If that is so, what fault would there be?

analyzed: nanu ayam eva doṣaḥ saṃsāra anivṛttiḥ
translated: Is this not the very fault that the cycle of births and deaths does not cease?

original: kriyākārakaphalabhedo hi saṃsāra iti /🔽ātmaikatva eva kriyākārakaphalabhedaḥ saṃsāravilakṣaṇa iti cet / na /
analyzed: kriyā kāraka phala bhedaḥ hi saṃsāraḥ iti  ātma eka tve eva kriyā kāraka phala bhedaḥ saṃsāra vilakṣaṇaḥ iti ced na
translated: For the difference of action, instrument, and result is the cycle of births and deaths.🔽If it is argued that the difference of action, instrument, and result is different from the cycle of births and deaths only in the case of the oneness of the Self, it is not so.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ nirviśeṣa ekatva abhyupagame darśana ādi kriyā kāraka phala bheda abhyupagamasya śabda mātra tvāt
translated: For, if the oneness of the Self without any distinction is admitted, the admission of the difference of action, instrument, and result is mere words.

original: anyadarśanādyabhāvoktipakṣe 'pi yatretyanyanna paśyatīti ca viśeṣaṇe anarthake syātāmiti cet /
analyzed: anya darśana ādi abhāva ukti pakṣe yatra iti anyat na paśyati iti ca viśeṣaṇe anarthake syātām iti ced
translated: If it is argued that even in the case of the statement of the non-existence of another seeing, etc., the words where and does not see another would be meaningless,

original: dṛśyate hi loke yatra śūnye gṛhe 'nyanna paśyatītyukte stambhādīnātmānaṃ ca na na paśyatīti gamyate /
analyzed: dṛśyate hi loke yatra śūnye gṛhe paśyati iti ukte stambha ādīn ātmānam ca na na paśyati iti gamyate
translated: for in the world it is seen that when it is said one does not see anything else in an empty house, it is understood that one does not see the pillars, etc. and one's own self,

analyzed: evam iha api iti ced na
translated: so it is here also, it is not so.

analyzed: tat tvam asi iti ekatva upadeśāt adhikaraṇa adhikartavya bheda anupapatteḥ
translated: Because of the teaching of oneness in That thou art, the difference of the locus and the object of injunction is not possible.

analyzed: tathā sat ekam eva advitīyam satyam iti ṣaṣṭhe nirdhārita tvāt
translated: And because in the sixth chapter it has been determined that Brahman is one, without a second, and real.

original: adṛśye 'nātmyena saṃdṛśe tiṣṭhati rūpamasyavijñātāramare kena vijānīyātityādiśrutibhyaḥ svātmani darśanādyanupapattiḥ /
analyzed: adṛśye na ātmyena saṃdṛśe tiṣṭhati rūpam asya vijñātāram are kena vijānīyāt iti ādi śrutibhyaḥ svātmani darśana ādi anupapattiḥ
translated: And because, according to such scriptural passages as, 'It stands, unseen, because of its subtlety; its form is seen in all things,' 'Who could know Him? By whom could He be known?' the perception, etc. of Brahman in itself are impossible.

analyzed: yatra iti viśeṣaṇam anarthakam prāptam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the qualifying word 'there' is meaningless, because it is already known that Brahman is one, without a second, and real, we reply: Not so.

analyzed: avidyā kṛta bheda apekṣa tvāt
translated: Because it is in reference to the difference produced by Nescience.

analyzed: yathā sati ekatva advitīya tva buddhim prakṛtām apekṣya sat ekam eva advitīyam iti saṃkhyā ādi anarham api ucyate
translated: Just as, in reference to the idea of unity, which is true, and of non-duality, already present, it is said that Brahman is one, without a second, and not to be qualified by number, etc.;

analyzed: evam bhūmni ekasmin eva yatra iti viśeṣaṇam
translated: so the qualifying word 'there' is used in reference to the one, all-pervading Brahman.

analyzed: avidyā avasthāyām anya darśana anuvādena ca bhūmnaḥ tad abhāva tva lakṣaṇasya vivakṣita tvāt na anyat paśyati iti viśeṣaṇam
translated: And because, in the state of Nescience, the non-existence of that, i.e. of the all-pervading Brahman, is intended to be described, by the denial of the perception of anything else, the qualifying word 'it sees nothing else' is used.

analyzed: tasmāt saṃsāra vyavahāraḥ bhūmni na asti iti samudāya arthaḥ
translated: Therefore the general sense is that the empirical state does not exist in Brahman.

analyzed: atha yatra avidyā viṣaye nyaḥ nyena anyat paśyati iti tat alpam avidyā kāla bhāvi iti arthaḥ
translated: But that which is in the sphere of Nescience, where one sees another in another, is small, and exists only during the time of Nescience.

original: yathā svapnadṛśyaṃ vastu prāk prabodhāttatkālabhāvīti tadvat /
analyzed: yathā svapna dṛśyam vastu prāk prabodhāt tad kāla bhāvi iti tadvat
translated: Just as the object seen in a dream exists only before waking, so is it.

original: tata eva tanmartyaṃ vināśi svapnavastuvadeva tadviparoto bhūmā yastadamṛtam /
analyzed: tatas eva tat martyam vināśi svapna vastu vat eva tat viparotaḥ bhūmā yaḥ tat amṛtam
translated: That is mortal, perishable, like a dream object, and different from that is the infinite, which is immortal.

analyzed: tad śabdaḥ mṛta tva paraḥ
translated: The word 'tat' refers to immortality.

original: sa tarhyevaṃlakṣaṇo bhūmā he bhagavankasminpratiṣṭhita ityuktavantaṃ nāradaṃ pratyāha sanatkimāraḥ /
analyzed: sa tarhi evaṃlakṣaṇaḥ bhūmā he bhagavan kasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti uktavantam nāradam pratyāha sanatkimāraḥ
translated: Then, O Lord, in what is that infinite, which has such a nature, established? To Narada, who said this, Sanatkumara replied:

original: sve mahimnīti sva ātmīye mahimni māhātmye vibhūtau pratiṣṭhito bhūmā /
analyzed: sve mahimni iti sve ātmīye mahimni māhātmye vibhūtau pratiṣṭhitaḥ bhūmā
translated: The infinite is established in its own greatness, in its own greatness, in its own glory, in its own abundance.

original: yadi pratiṣṭhāmicchasi kvacidyadi vā paramārthameva pṛcchasi na mahimnyapi pratiṣṭhita iti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: yadi pratiṣṭhām icchasi kvacid yadi vā paramārtham eva pṛcchasi na mahimni api pratiṣṭhite iti brūmaḥ
translated: If you wish to establish it somewhere, or if you ask about the ultimate truth itself, we say it is not even established in greatness.

analyzed: apratiṣṭhitaḥ na āśritaḥ bhūmā kvacid api iti arthaḥ
translated: The infinite is not established anywhere, it is not dependent on anything, is the meaning.

original: go 'śvam iha mahimety ācakṣate hastihiraṇyaṃ dāsabhāryaṃ kṣetrāṇy āyatanānīti /
analyzed: go śvam iha mahimā iti ācakṣate hasti hiraṇyam dāsa bhāryam kṣetrāṇi āyatanāni iti
translated: Here they call cow, horse, etc. greatness, and elephant, gold, slave, wife, fields, and temples.

analyzed: na aham evam bravīmi
translated: I do not say this.

analyzed: bravīmi iti ha uvāca
translated: He said:

analyzed: anyaḥ hi anyasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti
translated: One is established in another.

original: yadi svamahimni pratiṣṭhito bhūmā kathaṃ tarhyapratiṣṭha ucyate /
analyzed: yadi sva mahimni pratiṣṭhitaḥ bhūmā katham tarhi apratiṣṭhaḥ ucyate
translated: If the infinite is established in its own greatness, then how is it said to be unestablished?

analyzed: śṛṇu
translated: Listen.

analyzed: go śva ādi iha mahimā iti ācakṣate
translated: Here they call cow, horse, etc. greatness.

analyzed: gāvaḥ ca aśvāḥ ca go śvam dvandva eka vat bhāvaḥ
translated: Cows and horses are 'go-aśva', the dvandva compound being treated as a Bahuvrīhi.

original: sarvatra gavāśvādi mahimeti prasiddhaṃ tadāśritastatpratiṣṭhaścaitro bhavati /
analyzed: sarvatra gavāśva ādi mahimā iti prasiddham tad āśritaḥ tad pratiṣṭhaḥ caitraḥ bhavati
translated: Everywhere, the greatness of cows, horses, etc. is well-known. Caitra is dependent on that and has that as his support.

original: yathā nāhamevaṃ svato 'nyaṃ mahimānamāśrito bhūmā caitravaditi bravīmyatra hetutvenānyo hyanyasminpratiṣṭhita iti vyavahitena sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: yathā na aham evam svatas mahimānam āśritaḥ bhūmā caitra vat iti bravīmi atra hetu tvena anyaḥ hi anyasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti vyavahitena sambandhaḥ
translated: Just as I say, 'I am not dependent on any other greatness than my own', so here the connection is with the indirect object 'because one is indeed established in another'.

analyzed: kintu evam bravīmi iti ha uvāca eva ityādi
translated: But I speak thus - he said, 'That One' and so on.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya caturviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-fourth section of the seventh chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: sa evādhastāt sa upariṣṭāt sa paścāt sa purastāt sa dakṣiṇataḥ sa uttarataḥ /
analyzed: saḥ eva adhastāt saḥ upariṣṭāt sa paścāt sa purastāt sa dakṣiṇatas saḥ uttaratas
translated: He is below, he is above, he is behind, he is in front, he is to the right, he is to the left.

analyzed: saḥ eva idam sarvam iti
translated: He alone is all this.

analyzed: atha atas haṃkāra ādeśaḥ eva
translated: Now, therefore, the teaching of the ego.

original: aham evādhastād aham upariṣṭād ahaṃ paścād ahaṃ purastād ahaṃ dakṣiṇato 'ham uttarato 'ham evedaṃ sarvam iti //
analyzed: aham eva adhastāt aham upariṣṭāt aham paścāt aham purastāt aham dakṣiṇatas ham uttaratas ham eva idam sarvam iti
translated: I alone am below, I am above, I am behind, I am in front, I am to the right, I am to the left, I alone am all this.

analyzed: kasmāt punar kvacid na pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Why, then, is it said that he is not established anywhere?

original: yasmātsa eva bhūmādhastānna tadvyatirekeṇānyadvidyate yasminpratiṣṭhitaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yasmāt saḥ eva bhūmā adhastāt na tad vyatirekeṇa anyat vidyate yasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ syāt
translated: Because that alone is the Absolute, there is nothing else below it apart from it, in which it could be established.

analyzed: tathā upariṣṭāt ityādi samānam
translated: Similarly, above it, etc., is the same.

original: sati bhūmno 'nyasminbhūmā hi pratiṣṭhitaḥ syānna tu tadasti /
analyzed: sati bhūmnaḥ nyasmin bhūmā hi pratiṣṭhitaḥ syāt na tu tat asti
translated: If there were anything else apart from the Absolute, then the Absolute would indeed be established in that. But that does not exist.

analyzed: saḥ eva tu sarvam
translated: But that alone is everything.

original: atastasmādasau na kvacitpratiṣṭhitaḥ /🔽yatra nānyatpaśyatītyadhikaraṇādhikartavyatānirdeśātsa evādhastāditi ca parokṣanirdeśāddraṣṭarjīvādanyobhūmā
analyzed: atas tasmāt asau na kvacid pratiṣṭhitaḥ  yatra na anyat paśyati iti adhikaraṇa adhikartavya tā nirdeśāt saḥ eva adhastāt iti ca parokṣa nirdeśāt draṣṭar jīvāt anyaḥ bhūmā
translated: Therefore, it is not established anywhere.🔽Since the seer is indicated as different from the individual soul, by the statement where one sees nothing else, and since the Absolute is indicated indirectly by the statement that alone is below,

analyzed: syāt iti āśaṅkā kasyacid mā bhūt iti atha atas nantaram ahaṅkāra ādeśaḥ haṅkāreṇa ādiśyate iti ahaṅkāra ādeśaḥ
translated: there might be the doubt in someone that the Absolute might be different from the seer, the individual soul. To prevent this, the instruction regarding the I is given next. It is the instruction regarding the I because it is instructed by the I.

analyzed: draṣṭuḥ ananya tva darśana artham bhūmā eva nirdiśyate haṅkāreṇa aham eva adhastāt ityādinā
translated: In order to show that the seer is not different, the Absolute itself is indicated by the I as I alone am below, etc.

analyzed: atha atas ātma ādeśaḥ eva
translated: Now, the instruction regarding the Self is indeed next.

original: ātmaivādhastād ātmopariṣṭād ātmā paścād ātmā purastād ātmā dakṣiṇata ātmottarata ātmaivedaṃ sarvam iti /
analyzed: ātmā eva adhastāt ātmā upariṣṭāt ātmā paścāt ātmā purastāt ātmā dakṣiṇatas ātmā uttaratas ātmā eva idam sarvam iti
translated: The Self alone is below, the Self is above, the Self is behind, the Self is in front, the Self is to the right, the Self is to the left, the Self alone is all this.

original: sa vā eṣa evaṃ paśyann evaṃ manvāna evaṃ vijānann ātmaratir ātmakrīḍa ātmamithuna ātmānandaḥ sa svarāḍ bhavati /
analyzed: sa vai eṣaḥ evam paśyan evam manvānaḥ evam vijānan ātma ratiḥ ātma krīḍaḥ ātma mithunaḥ ātma ānandaḥ sa svarāj bhavati
translated: He, seeing thus, thinking thus, understanding thus, finds delight in the Self, sports in the Self, has the Self for his friend, and is satisfied with the Self. He becomes the Self-sovereign.

analyzed: tasya sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati
translated: He has freedom of action in all worlds.

original: atha ye 'nyathāto vidur anyarājānas te kṣayyalokā bhavanti /
analyzed: atha ye nyathātas viduḥ anya rājānaḥ te kṣayya lokāḥ bhavanti
translated: But those who know otherwise, whose king is another [than the Self], they have worlds that perish.

analyzed: teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu akāma cāraḥ bhavati
translated: They have no freedom of action in any world.

original: ahaṅkāreṇa dehādisaṃghāto 'pyādiśyate 'vivekibhirityatastadāśaṅkā mā bhūdityathānantaramātmādeśa ātmanaiva kevalena satsvarūpeṇa🔽śuddhenā'diśyate /
analyzed: ahaṅkāreṇa deha ādi saṃghātaḥ pi ādiśyate vivekibhiḥ iti atas tad āśaṅkā mā bhūt iti atha anantaram ātma ādeśaḥ ātmanā eva kevalena sat svarūpeṇa  śuddhena ādiśyate
translated: The aggregate of body etc. is also designated by the non-discriminating ones as the Self through the sense of 'I'. Therefore, lest there be doubt about that, after that, the Self is designated by the Self alone, by its own pure nature as the real.

original: ātmaiva sarvataḥ sarvamityevamekamajaṃ sarvato vyomavatpūrṇamanyaśūnyaṃ paśyansa vā eṣa vidvānmananavijñānābhyāmātmaratirātmanyeva ratī ramaṇaṃ
analyzed: ātmā eva sarvatas sarvam iti evam ekam ajam sarvatas vyoma vat pūrṇam anya śūnyam paśyan sa vai eṣa vidvān manana vijñānābhyām ātma ratiḥ ātmani eva ratiḥ ramaṇam
translated: The Self alone is all, everywhere. Thus seeing the unborn One as full everywhere like the all-pervading space, devoid of anything else, he, the knower, finds delight in the Self, sports in the Self, has the Self for his friend, and is satisfied with the Self.

analyzed: yasya saḥ yam ātma ratiḥ
translated: He in whom there is delight, the enjoyment, in the Self alone, he is one who finds delight in the Self.

analyzed: tathā ātma krīḍaḥ
translated: Similarly, he sports in the Self.

analyzed: deha mātra sādhanā ratiḥ bāhya sādhanā krīḍā
translated: Delight is accomplished by the body alone, sport is accomplished by external means.

original: loke srībhiḥ sakhibhiśca krīḍatīti darśanāt na tathā viduṣaḥ kiṃ tarhyātmavijñānanimittamevobhayaṃ bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: loke srībhiḥ sakhibhiḥ ca krīḍati iti darśanāt na tathā viduṣaḥ kim tarhi ātma vijñāna nimittam eva ubhayam bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Because it is seen that one who is not a knower of the Self sports with women and friends in the world, but not so the knower. What then? Both pleasure and pain come to him only on account of the knowledge of the Self.

original: mithunaṃ dvaṃndvajanitaṃ sukhaṃ tadapi dvandvanirapekṣaṃ yasya viduṣaḥ /
analyzed: mithunam dvaṃndva janitam sukham tat api dvandva nirapekṣam yasya viduṣaḥ
translated: That pleasure which is born of a couple, that also is independent of a couple, of him who is a knower.

original: tathā'tmānandaḥ śabdādinimitta ānando 'viduṣāṃ na tathāsya viduṣaḥ kiṃ tarhyātmanimittameva sarvaṃ sarvadā sarvaprakāreṇa ca dehajīvitabhogādinimittabāhyavastunirapekṣa
analyzed: tathā ātma ānandaḥ śabda ādi nimittaḥ ānandaḥ viduṣām na tathā asya viduṣaḥ kim tarhi ātma nimittam eva sarvam sarvadā sarva prakāreṇa ca deha jīvita bhoga ādi nimitta bāhya vastu nirapekṣa
translated: Similarly, the bliss of the Self, which is the bliss of one who is not a knower, is due to sound etc., but not so of him who is a knower. What then? All that is only on account of the Self, at all times and in all ways, independent of external objects such as body, life, enjoyment etc. which are the causes.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: sa evaṃlakṣaṇo vidvāñjīvanneva svārājye 'bhiṣiktaḥ patite 'pi dehe svarāḍeva bhavati /
analyzed: saḥ evaṃlakṣaṇaḥ vidvān jīvan eva svārājye bhiṣiktaḥ patite dehe svarāj eva bhavati
translated: That knower who is of such a nature, is anointed in his own kingdom even while living, and becomes his own king even when the body falls.

original: yata evaṃ bhavati tata eva tasya sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavati /
analyzed: yatas evam bhavati tatas eva tasya sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati
translated: Since this is so, therefore he has unrestricted freedom in all the worlds.

analyzed: prāṇa ādiṣu pūrva bhūmiṣu tatra asya iti tāvat mātra paricchinna kāmacāra tvam uktam anrājatvam
translated: In the previous stages such as Prāṇa etc., it has been said that his freedom is restricted to that much only, and he is not a king.

analyzed: ca artha prāptam sa atiśaya tvāt yathā prāpta svārājya kāma cāra tva anuvādena iha ucyate sa svarāj ityādinā
translated: The attainment of wealth is spoken of here as the cessation of that, by way of the repetition of the sovereignty and independence attained according to one's desire, by saying 'He becomes the sovereign of self' and so on.

original: atha punarye 'nyathāta uktadarśanādanyathā vaiparītyena yathoktameva vā samyaṅna viduste 'nyarājāno bhavanti anyaḥ paro rājā svāmī yeṣāṃ te
analyzed: atha punar ye nyathā atas ukta darśanāt anyathā vaiparītyena yathā uktam eva vā samyak na viduḥ te bhavanti anyaḥ paraḥ rājā svāmī yeṣām te
translated: But those who, otherwise than as described, i.e. in a contrary way or exactly as described, do not know correctly, they are others' sovereigns, i.e. they have another, a higher, sovereign, a master.

analyzed: nyarājānaḥ te
translated: They are others' sovereigns.

original: kiñca kṣayyo loko yeṣāṃ te kṣayylokāḥ /
analyzed: kiñca kṣayyaḥ lokaḥ yeṣām te kṣayi lokāḥ
translated: Moreover, they have a perishable world, they are of a perishable world.

analyzed: bheda darśanasya alpa viṣaya tvāt alpam ca tat martyam iti avocāma
translated: Because the view of difference has a limited scope, and that is small, we said it is mortal.

original: tasmādye dvaitadarśinaste kṣayyalokāḥ svadarśanānurūpyeṇaiva bhavantyata eva teṣāṃ sarveṣu lokeṣvakāmacāro bhavati //
analyzed: tasmāt ye dvaita darśinaḥ te kṣayya lokāḥ sva darśana ānurūpyeṇa eva bhavanti atas eva teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu akāma cāraḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, those who see duality, they have a perishable world in accordance with their own view. For this very reason, they have no independence in all worlds.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya pañcaviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Twenty-fifth Section in the Seventh Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: tasya ha vā etasyaivaṃ paśyata evaṃ manvānasyaivaṃ vijānata ātmataḥ prāṇa ātmata
analyzed: tasya ha vai etasya evam paśyataḥ evam manvānasya evam vijānataḥ ātmataḥ prāṇaḥ ātmataḥ
translated: For one who sees thus, thinks thus, and knows thus, from the Self, the vital breath is the Self.

original: āśātmataḥ smara ātmata ākāśa ātmatas teja ātmata āpa ātmata āvirbhāvatirobhāvāv ātmato
analyzed: āśā ātmataḥ smaraḥ ātmataḥ ākāśaḥ ātmataḥ tejaḥ ātmataḥ apaḥ ātmataḥ āvirbhāva tirobhāvau ātmataḥ
translated: From the Self of desire, from the Self of memory, from the Self of space, from the Self of fire, from the Self of water, from the Self of appearance and disappearance,

original: 'nnam ātmato balam ātmato vijñānam ātmato dhyānam ātmataś cittam ātmataḥ saṃkalpa
analyzed: ātmataḥ balam ātmataḥ vijñānam ātmataḥ dhyānam ātmataḥ cittam ātmataḥ saṃkalpa
translated: from the Self of food, from the Self of strength, from the Self of knowledge, from the Self of meditation, from the Self of mind, from the Self of resolve,

original: ātmato mana ātmato vāg ātmato nāmātmato mantrā ātmataḥ karmāṇy ātmata evedaṃ sarvam
analyzed: ātmataḥ manaḥ ātmataḥ vāc ātmataḥ nāma ātmataḥ mantrāḥ ātmataḥ karmāṇi ātmataḥ eva idam sarvam
translated: from the Self of mind, from the Self of speech, from the Self of name, from the Self of mantras, from the Self of actions, from the Self of all this.

original: iti //🔽tasya ha vā etasyetyādi svārājyaṃ prāptasya prakṛtasya viduṣa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti  tasya ha vai etasya ityādi svārājyam prāptasya prakṛtasya viduṣaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus.🔽The meaning is: Of him, the one who has attained self-sovereignty, the one who is the subject matter, the knower, before the knowledge of the Self as Being.

analyzed: prāk sat ātma vijñānāt sva ātmanaḥ nyasmāt sataḥ prāṇa ādeḥ nāma antasya utpatti pralayau abhūtām
translated: Before the knowledge of the Self as Being, the origination and dissolution of all else, from the Self to Prāṇa and so on, up to name, took place.

original: sadātmāvijñāne tu satīdānīṃ svātmata eva saṃvṛttau tathā sarvo 'pyanyo vyavahāra
analyzed: tu sati idānīm svātmataḥ eva saṃvṛttau tathā sarvaḥ pi anyaḥ vyavahāra
translated: But when there is the knowledge of the Self as Being, now everything has become the Self itself, and so also all other transactions

analyzed: ātmataḥ eva viduṣaḥ
translated: of the knower are from the Self itself.

analyzed: tat eṣa ślokaḥ
translated: This is the verse on that:

original: na paśyo mṛtyuṃ paśyati na rogaṃ nota duḥkhatām /
analyzed: na paśyaḥ mṛtyum paśyati na rogam na uta duḥkha tām
translated: The seer does not see death, nor disease, nor suffering.

original: sarvaṃ ha paśyaḥ paśyati sarvam āpnoti sarvaśaḥ /
analyzed: sarvam ha paśyaḥ paśyati sarvam āpnoti sarvaśas
translated: The seer sees everything, and attains everything in every way.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: sa ekadhā bhavati tridhā bhavati pañcadhā /
analyzed: saḥ ekadhā bhavati tridhā bhavati pañcadhā
translated: He becomes one, he becomes three, he becomes five,

original: saptadhā navadhā caiva punaś caikādaśa smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: saptadhā navadhā ca eva punar ca ekādaśa smṛtaḥ
translated: It is said to be sevenfold, ninefold, and again elevenfold.

original: śataṃ ca daśa caikaś ca sahasrāṇi ca viṃśatiḥ /
analyzed: śatam ca daśa ca ekaḥ ca sahasrāṇi ca viṃśatiḥ
translated: And one hundred and ten, and twenty thousand.

analyzed: āhāra śuddhau sattva śuddhiḥ
translated: When there is purity of food, there is purity of mind.

analyzed: sattva śuddhau dhruvā smṛtiḥ
translated: When there is purity of mind, memory is firm.

analyzed: smṛti lambhe sarva granthīnām vipramokṣaḥ
translated: When memory is attained, all the knots are untied.

original: tasmai mṛditakaṣāyāya tamasas pāraṃ darśayati bhagavān sanatkumāraḥ /
analyzed: tasmai mṛdita kaṣāyāya tamasaḥ pāram darśayati bhagavān sanatkumāraḥ
translated: To him whose defilements are crushed, the Blessed One Sanatkumāra shows the other side of darkness.

analyzed: tam skandaḥ iti ācakṣate
translated: Him they call Skanda.

original: kiñca tadetasminnartha eṣa śloko mantro 'pi bhavati /
analyzed: kiñca tat etasmin arthe eṣa ślokaḥ bhavati
translated: And moreover, on this very subject, there is this verse and mantra:

original: na paśyaḥ paśyatīti paśyo yathoktadarśī vidvānityarthaḥ /
analyzed: na paśyaḥ paśyati iti paśyaḥ yathā ukta darśī vidvān iti arthaḥ
translated: The seer does not see - the seer is one who sees as described, i.e., the knower.

original: mṛtyuṃ maraṇaṃ rogaṃ jvarādi duḥkhatāṃ duḥkhabhāvaṃ cāpi na paśyati /
analyzed: mṛtyum maraṇam rogam jvara ādi duḥkhatām duḥkha bhāvam ca api na paśyati
translated: He does not see death, i.e., dying, nor disease, nor fever, nor even suffering, i.e., the state of suffering.

original: sarvaṃ ha sarvameva sa paśyaḥ paśyatyātmānameva sarvaṃ tataḥ sarvamāpnoti sarvaśaḥ sarvaprakārairiti /
analyzed: sarvam ha sarvam eva sa paśyaḥ paśyati ātmānam eva sarvam tatas sarvam āpnoti sarvaśas sarva prakāraiḥ iti
translated: That seer sees everything, i.e., the Self alone as everything. Therefore he obtains everything, i.e., all things, in every way.

original: kiñca sa vidvānprāksṛṣṭiprabhedādekadhaiva bhavatyekadhaiva ca saṃsridhādibhedairanantabhedaprakāro bhavati sṛṣṭikāle /
analyzed: kiñca sa vidvān prāk sṛṣṭi prabhedāt ekadhā eva bhavati ekadhā eva ca saṃsridha ādi bhedaiḥ ananta bheda prakāraḥ bhavati sṛṣṭi kāle
translated: And moreover, that knower is one only before the creation, and at the time of creation he becomes many in the forms of the endless distinctions such as the sun and so on.

original: punaḥ saṃhārakāle mūlameva svaṃ pāramārthakamekadhābhāvaṃ pratipadyate svatantra eveti vidyāṃ phalena prarocayanstauti /
analyzed: punar saṃhāra kāle mūlam eva svam pāramārthakam ekadhābhāvam pratipadyate svatantraḥ eva iti vidyām phalena prarocayan stauti
translated: Again, at the time of dissolution, it attains its own original ultimate oneness, being independent alone. Thus, extolling the knowledge with its fruit, he praises it.

original: athedānīṃ yathoktāyā vidyāyāḥ samyagavabhāsakāraṇaṃ mukhāvabhāsakāraṇasyevā'darśasya viśuddhikāraṇaṃ sādhanamupadiśyateāhāraśuddhau /🔽āhriyata ityāhāraḥ śabdādiviṣayavijñānaṃ bhokturbhogāyā'hriyate viśuddhikāraṇaṃ sādhanamupadiśyateāhāraśuddhau /
analyzed: atha idānīm yathā uktāyāḥ vidyāyāḥ samyak avabhāsa kāraṇam mukha avabhāsa kāraṇasya iva ādarśasya viśuddhi kāraṇam sādhanam upadiśyate āhāra śuddhau  āhriyate iti āhāraḥ śabda ādi viṣaya vijñānam bhoktuḥ bhogāya āhriyate viśuddhi kāraṇam sādhanam upadiśyate āhāra śuddhau
translated: Now, the means of purification is taught, which is the cause of the proper manifestation of the knowledge as described, like the cause of the manifestation of the face, the cause of the purification of the mirror. In the purification of food.🔽Food is that which is eaten. The consciousness of objects like sound is eaten for the enjoyment of the experiencer. The means of purification is taught. In the purification of food.

original: āhriyata ityāharaḥ śabdādiviṣayavijñānaṃ bhokturbhogāyā'hriyate tasya viṣayopalabdhilakṣaṇasya vijñānasya śuddhirāhāraśuddhī rāgadveṣamohadoṣairasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ
analyzed: āhriyate iti āharaḥ śabda ādi viṣaya vijñānam bhoktuḥ bhogāya āhriyate tasya viṣaya upalabdhi lakṣaṇasya vijñānasya śuddhiḥ āhāra śuddhiḥ rāga dveṣa moha doṣaiḥ asaṃsṛṣṭam
translated: Food is that which is eaten. The consciousness of objects like sound is eaten for the enjoyment of the experiencer. The purification of that consciousness, which is characterized by the perception of objects, is the purification of food. It is the consciousness of objects unmixed with the faults of attachment, aversion, and delusion.

analyzed: viṣaya vijñānam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the consciousness of objects.

original: tasyāmāhārāśuddhau satyāṃ tadvato 'ntaḥkaraṇasya sattvasya śuddhirnairmalyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasyām āhāra aśuddhau satyām tadvataḥ ntaḥkaraṇasya sattvasya śuddhiḥ nairmalyam bhavati
translated: When there is that purification of food, there is the purification, the clarity, of the internal organ, the sattva that possesses it.

original: sattvaśuddhau ca satyāṃ yathāvagate bhūmātmani dhruvāvicchinnā smṛtiravismaramaṃ bhavati /🔽tasyāṃ ca labdhāyāṃ smṛtilambhe sati sarveṣāmavidyākṛtānarthapāśarūpāṇāmanekajanmāntarānubhavabhāvanākaṭhinīkṛtānāṃ
analyzed: sattva śuddhau ca satyām yathā avagate bhūma ātmani dhruvā avicchinnā smṛtiḥ avismaramam bhavati  tasyām ca labdhāyām smṛti lambhe sati sarveṣām avidyā kṛta anartha pāśa rūpāṇām aneka janma antara anubhava bhāvanā kaṭhinīkṛtānām
translated: And when there is purity of the Self, then there is firm and unbroken memory of the Self as understood, without forgetfulness.

original: hṛdayākṣayāṇāṃ granthīnāṃ vipramokṣo viśeṣeṇa pramokṣaṇaṃ vināśo bhavatīti /
analyzed: hṛdaya akṣayāṇām granthīnām vipramokṣaḥ viśeṣeṇa pramokṣaṇam vināśaḥ bhavati iti
translated: And when that is attained, when memory is attained, then there is complete liberation, special liberation, destruction, of all the knots in the heart, which are like the nooses of misfortune created by ignorance, hardened by the experience and cultivation of many lifetimes,

analyzed: yatas etat uttarottaram yathā uktam āhāra śuddhi mūlam tasmāt sā kāryā iti arthaḥ
translated: Because this, as stated above, is the root of the purity of food, therefore it should be done - this is the meaning.

original: sarvaṃ śāsrārthamaśeṣata uktvā'khyāyikāmupasaṃharati śrutiḥtasmai mṛditakaṣāyāya🔽vārkṣādiriva kaṣāyo rāgadveṣādidoṣaḥ sattvasya rañjanārūpatvātsa jñānavairāgyābhyāsarūpakṣāreṇa
analyzed: sarvam śāsra artham aśeṣatas uktvā ākhyāyikām upasaṃharati śrutiḥ tasmai mṛdita kaṣāyāya  vārkṣa ādiḥ iva kaṣāyaḥ rāga dveṣa ādi doṣaḥ sattvasya rañjanā rūpa tvāt sa jñāna vairāgya abhyāsa rūpa kṣāreṇa
translated: Having stated the entire meaning of the scriptures, the scripture concludes the narrative: To him whose impurities have been removed,

original: kṣālito mṛdito vināśito yasya nāradasya tasmai yogyāya mṛditakaṣāyāya tamaso 'vidyālakṣaṇātpāraṃ
analyzed: kṣālitaḥ mṛditaḥ vināśitaḥ yasya nāradasya tasmai yogyāya mṛdita kaṣāyāya tamasaḥ vidyā lakṣaṇāt pāram
translated: Impurity is like the impurities of wood etc., which are the faults of attachment, aversion etc., because they have the form of staining the mind. He whose impurities have been washed, removed, destroyed, by the alkali in the form of knowledge, non-attachment, and practice, to him, Narada, who is fit, whose impurities have been removed, he shows, he has shown, the other shore of darkness, which is characterized by ignorance,

analyzed: paramārtha tattvam darśayati darśitavān iti arthaḥ
translated: the truth of the highest reality.

original: ko 'sau / bhagavānutpattiṃ pralayaṃ caiva bhūtānāmāgatiṃ gatim /
analyzed: kaḥ sau bhagavān utpattim pralayam ca eva bhūtānām āgatim gatim
translated: Who is he? The Blessed One, who knows the origin, dissolution, and destiny of beings,

original: vetti vidyāmavidyāṃ ca sa vācyo bhagavāniti //
analyzed: vetti vidyām avidyām ca sa vācyaḥ bhagavān iti
translated: and who knows knowledge and ignorance, he is called the Blessed One.

analyzed: evandharmā sanatkumāraḥ
translated: Sanatkumara has such a nature.

original: tameva sanatkumāraṃ devaṃ skanda ityācakṣate kathayanti tadvidaḥ /
analyzed: tam eva sanatkumāram devam skandaḥ iti ācakṣate kathayanti tad vidaḥ
translated: The knowers of Brahman call that very Sanatkumara the god Skanda.

analyzed: dvirvacanam adhyāya parisamāpti artham
translated: The repetition is for the purpose of concluding the chapter.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi saptama adhyāyasya ṣaḍviṃśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twenty-sixth section in the seventh chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣad brahmaṇe saptamaḥ adhyāyaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus ends the seventh chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad-Brāhmaṇa.

analyzed: atha aṣṭamaḥ dhyāyaḥ om
translated: Now, the eighth chapter. Om

original: atha yad idam asmin brahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma daharo 'sminn antarākāsaḥ /
analyzed: atha yat idam asmin brahma pure daharam puṇḍarīkam veśma daharaḥ u smin antarākāsaḥ
translated: Now, this small lotus-house in this Brahman-city, and this small space within it,

original: tasmin yad antas tad anveṣṭavyaṃ tad vāva vijijñāsitavyam iti //
analyzed: tasmin yat antar tat anveṣṭavyam tat vāva vijijñāsitavyam iti
translated: in that which is within, that should be sought, that indeed should be desired to be known.

original: yadyapi digdeśakālādibhedaśūnyaṃ brahma sadekamevādvitīyamātmaivedaṃ sarvamiti ṣaṣṭhasaptamayoradhigataṃ
analyzed: yadi api diś deśa kāla ādi bheda śūnyam brahma sat ekam eva advitīyam ātmā eva idam sarvam iti ṣaṣṭha saptamayoḥ adhigatam
translated: Even though Brahman, which is devoid of distinctions of direction, place, time, etc., is truly one without a second, and is the Self of all this, as understood in the sixth and seventh chapters,

original: tathāpīha mandabuddhīnāṃ digdeśādibhedavadvastvityevaṃ bhāvitā buddhirna śakyate
analyzed: tathā api iha manda buddhīnām diś deśa ādi bhedavat vastu iti evam bhāvitā buddhiḥ na śakyate
translated: Still, in this world, the intellect of those of dull understanding, which is accustomed to think of things as having distinctions of direction, place, etc.,

original: sahasā paramārthaviṣayā kartumityanadhigamya ca brahma na puruṣārthasiddhiriti tadadhigamāya
analyzed: sahasā paramārtha viṣayā kartum iti an adhigamya ca brahma na puruṣa artha siddhiḥ iti tad adhigamāya
translated: cannot be suddenly made to have the Supreme Reality for its object. And without the realization of Brahman, there is no accomplishment of the human goal. Therefore, for the realization of that,

original: hṛdayapuṇḍarīkadeśa upadeṣṭavyaḥ /🔽yadyapi satsamyakpratyayaikaviṣayā kartumityānadhigamya ca brahma na puruṣārthasiddhiriti tadadhigamāya hṛdayapuṇḍarīkadeśa upadeṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: hṛdaya puṇḍarīka deśaḥ upadeṣṭavyaḥ  yadi api sat samyak pratyaya eka viṣayā kartum iti ān adhigamya ca brahma na puruṣa artha siddhiḥ iti tad adhigamāya hṛdaya puṇḍarīka deśaḥ upadeṣṭavyaḥ
translated: the region of the lotus of the heart should be taught.

original: yadyapi satsamyakpratyayaikaviṣayaṃ nirguṇaṃ cā'tmatattvaṃ tathāpi mandabuddhīnāṃ guṇavattvasyeṣṭatvātsatyakāmādiguṇavattvaṃ ca vaktavyam /
analyzed: yadi api sat samyak pratyaya eka viṣayam nirguṇam ca ātma tattvam tathā api manda buddhīnām guṇavat tvasya iṣṭa tvāt satya kāma ādi guṇavat tvam ca vaktavyam
translated: Although the truth of the Self is the object of right knowledge alone, and is devoid of qualities, still, because those of dull intellect desire it to have qualities, its possession of qualities like having true desires, etc., should be stated.

original: tathā yadyapi brahmavidāṃ stryādiviṣayebhyaḥ svayamevoparamo bhavati tathāpyanekajanmaviṣayasevābhyāsajanitā
analyzed: tathā yadi api brahma vidām strī ādi viṣayebhyaḥ svayam eva uparamaḥ bhavati tathā api aneka janma viṣaya sevā abhyāsa janitā
translated: Although for those who know Brahman, cessation from objects like women, etc. happens naturally, still, the craving for objects, which is produced by the practice of service to objects over many births,

original: viṣayaviṣayā tṛṣṇā na sahasā nivartayituṃ śakyata iti brahmacaryādisādhanaviśeṣo vidhātavyaḥ /
analyzed: viṣaya viṣayā tṛṣṇā na sahasā nivartayitum śakyate iti brahmacarya ādi sādhana viśeṣaḥ vidhātavyaḥ
translated: cannot be suddenly stopped. Therefore, special means like celibacy should be prescribed.

analyzed: tathā yadi api ātma ekatva vidām gantṛ gamana gantavya abhāvāt avidyā viśeṣa sthiti nimitta kṣaye
translated: Similarly, although for those who know the oneness of the Self, with the absence of goer, going, and destination, with the destruction of the cause of the persistence of particular ignorance,

original: gagana iva vidyududbhūta iva vāyurdagdhendhana ivāgniḥ svātmanyeva nivṛttistathāpi
analyzed: gagane iva vidyut udbhūtaḥ iva vāyuḥ dagdha indhanaḥ iva agniḥ sva ātmani eva nivṛttiḥ tathā api
translated: there is cessation in the Self alone, like in the sky, like the wind arisen like lightning, like the fire with burnt fuel, still

analyzed: gantṛ gamana ādi vāsita buddhīnām hṛdaya deśa guṇa viśiṣṭa brahma upāsakānām mūrdhanyayā nāḍyā
translated: for those whose intellect is imbued with the notion of goer, going, etc., who meditate on Brahman as having the qualities of the heart region,

analyzed: gatiḥ vaktavyā iti aṣṭamaḥ prapāṭhakaḥ ārabhyate
translated: the path through the Brahmapura channel must be described. Thus the eighth section begins.

analyzed: diś deśa guṇa gati phala bheda śūnyam hi paramārtha sat advayam brahma manda buddhīnām asat iva pratibhāti
translated: For Brahman, which is ultimately real, non-dual, devoid of distinctions of direction, place, quality, motion, and result, appears as if unreal to those of slow intellect.

original: sanmārgasthāstāvadbhavantu tataḥ śanaiḥ paramārthasadapi grāhayiṣyāmīti manyate śrutiḥ /
analyzed: sat mārga sthāḥ tāvat bhavantu tatas śanais paramārtha sat api grāhayiṣyāmi iti manyate śrutiḥ
translated: The Śruti thinks, Let them first abide in the true path, and then I will gradually make them understand the ultimately real also.

original: athānantaraṃ yadidaṃ vakṣyamāṇaṃ daharamalpaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ puṇḍarīkasadṛśaṃ veśmeva veśma dvārapālādimattvāt /
analyzed: atha anantaram yat idam vakṣyamāṇam daharam alpam puṇḍarīkam puṇḍarīka sadṛśam veśma iva veśma dvārapāla ādimat tvāt
translated: Now, after this, the small, limited lotus-like abode, which is to be described, is like a lotus, with doorkeepers and so on.

original: asminbrahmapure brahmaṇaḥ parasya puraṃ rājño 'nekaprakṛtimadyathāpuraṃ tathedamanekendriyamanobuddhibhiḥ svāmyarthakāribhiryuktamiti brahmapuram
analyzed: asmin brahma pure brahmaṇaḥ parasya puram rājñaḥ neka prakṛtimat yathā puram tathā idam aneka indriya manaḥ buddhibhiḥ svāmi artha kāribhiḥ yuktam iti brahma puram
translated: In this Brahman-city, the city of the supreme Brahman, just as a king's city has many constituents, so this [body] is endowed with many senses, mind, and intellect, which serve the purpose of the Self. Thus it is the Brahman-city.

original: pure ca veśma rājño yathā tathā tasminbrahmapure śarīre daharaṃ veśma brahmaṇa upalabdhyadhiṣṭhānamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: pure ca veśma rājñaḥ yathā tathā tasmin brahma pure śarīre daharam veśma brahmaṇaḥ upalabdhi adhiṣṭhānam iti arthaḥ
translated: And just as in a city there is the king's palace, so in that Brahman-city, in the body, there is the small palace, the abode of Brahman, the basis of realization, is the meaning.

analyzed: yathā viṣṇoḥ śālagrāmaḥ
translated: Just as Śālagrāma is of Viṣṇu.

original: asminhi svavikāraśiṅge dehe nāmarūpavyākaraṇāya praviṣṭaṃ sadākhyaṃ braṅma jīvenā'tmanetyuktam /
analyzed: asmin hi sva vikāra śiṅge dehe nāma rūpa vyākaraṇāya praviṣṭam sat ākhyam braṅma jīvena ātmanā iti uktam
translated: For it has been said that the Brahman called Sat, having entered this body, which is a fragment of its own modifications, for the purpose of endowing it with name and form, is united with the individual soul.

analyzed: tasmāt asmin hṛdaya puṇḍarīke veśmani upasaṃhṛta karaṇaiḥ bāhya viṣaya viraktaiḥ viśeṣataḥ
translated: Therefore, in this palace of the lotus of the heart, by those who have withdrawn the organs, who are detached from external objects, especially

analyzed: brahmacarya satya sādhanābhyām yukteḥ vakṣyamāṇa guṇavat dhyāyamānaiḥ brahma upalabhyata
translated: by those who are endowed with celibacy and truth, the means of realization, meditating on Brahman endowed with the qualities to be described, Brahman is perceived.

analyzed: iti prakaraṇa arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the section.

analyzed: daharaḥ lpataraḥ smin dahare veśmani veśmanaḥ lpa tvāt tad antarvartinaḥ lpatara tvam veśmanaḥ
translated: The smaller one, which is smaller than this small palace, is smaller than the palace because of its smallness.

analyzed: antarākāśe ākāśa ākhyam brahma
translated: The inner space is Brahman, called Ākāśa.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ vai nāma iti hi vakṣyati
translated: For it will be said later, Ākāśa indeed is the name.

analyzed: ākāśe iva aśarīra tvāt sūkṣma tva sarvagata tva sāmānyāt ca
translated: Because it is bodiless like space, and because of the similarity of subtlety and omnipresence.

analyzed: tasmin ākāśa ākhye yat antar madhye tat anveṣṭavyam
translated: In that Ākāśa, which is called Ākāśa, what is within, in the middle, that should be sought.

original: tadvāva tadeva ca viśeṣeṇa jijñāsitavyaṃ gurvāśrayaśravaṇādyupāyairanviṣya ca sākṣātkaraṇīyamityarthaḥ //
analyzed: tat vāva tat eva ca viśeṣeṇa jijñāsitavyam guru āśraya śravaṇa ādi upāyaiḥ anviṣya ca sākṣāt karaṇīyam iti arthaḥ
translated: That indeed, that alone, should be specially desired to be known, and having sought it by means of the means such as studying under a teacher, it should be realized - this is the meaning.

original: taṃ ced brūyur yad idam asmin brahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma daharo 'sminn antarākāśaḥ kiṃ tad atra vidyate yad anveṣṭavyaṃ yad vāva vijijñāsitavyam
analyzed: tam ced brūyuḥ yat idam asmin brahma pure daharam puṇḍarīkam veśma daharaḥ u smin antarākāśaḥ kim tat atra vidyate yat anveṣṭavyam yat vāva vijijñāsitavyam
translated: If they were to say to him: In this Brahman-city, the small lotus-house, and the small space within it, what is there to be sought, what is indeed to be desired to be known?

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: sa brūyāt
translated: He should say.

analyzed: tam ced evam uktavantam ācāryam yadi brūyuḥ antevāsinaḥ codayeyuḥ
translated: If the disciples were to speak thus to the teacher who has spoken in this way, they would urge him.

original: kathaṃ /🔽yadidamasminbrahmapure paricchinne 'ntardaharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma tato 'pyantaralpatara evā'kāśaḥ /
analyzed: katham  yat idam asmin brahmapure paricchinne ntar daharam puṇḍarīkam veśma tatas u pi antar alpataraḥ eva ākāśaḥ
translated: How?

analyzed: puṇḍarīke eva veśmani tāvat kim syāt
translated: If this small lotus-house within this limited Brahman-city, and even smaller than that, is the space, what could be there in the lotus itself, in the house?

analyzed: kim tatas lpatare khe yat bhavet iti āhuḥ
translated: What could be smaller than that in the space? They say.

original: daharo 'sminnantarākāśaḥ kiṃ tadatra vidyate na kiñcana vidyata ityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: daharaḥ smin antarākāśaḥ kim tat atra vidyate na kiñcana vidyate iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The small space within it - what is there? The idea is that nothing exists there.

original: yadi nāma badaramātraṃ kimapi vidyate kiṃ tasyānveṣaṇena vijijñāsanena vā phalaṃ vijijñāsituḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi nāma badara mātram kim api vidyate kim tasya anveṣaṇena vijijñāsanena vā phalam vijijñāsituḥ syāt
translated: If there is something there, even if it is just the size of a jujube fruit, what benefit would there be for the seeker in searching for it or desiring to know it?

original: ato yatttrānveṣṭavyaṃ vijijñāsitavyaṃ vā na tena prayojanamityuktavataḥ sa ācāryo brūyāditi śrutervacanam //
analyzed: atas yattra anveṣṭavyam vijijñāsitavyam vā na tena prayojanam iti uktavataḥ saḥ ācāryaḥ brūyāt iti śruteḥ vacanam
translated: Therefore, the teacher, having said that what is to be searched for or desired to be known is of no use, would say this, as stated in the scripture.

original: yāvān vā ayam ākāśas tāvān eṣo 'ntarhṛdaya ākāśaḥ /
analyzed: yāvān vai ayam ākāśaḥ tāvān eṣaḥ ntar hṛdayaḥ ākāśaḥ
translated: As vast as this space is, so vast is this space within the heart.

analyzed: ubhe smin dyāvāpṛthivī antar eva samāhite
translated: Both heaven and earth are contained within it.

original: ubhāv agniś ca vāyuś ca sūryācandramasāv ubhau vidyun nakṣatrāṇi /
analyzed: ubhau agniḥ ca vāyuḥ ca sūryācandramasau ubhau vidyut nakṣatrāṇi
translated: Both fire and wind, both the sun and the moon, lightning and the stars,

original: yac cāsyehāsti yac ca nāsti sarvaṃ tad asmin samāhitam iti //
analyzed: yat ca asya iha asti yat ca na asti sarvam tat asmin samāhitam iti
translated: and whatever exists here and does not exist, all that is contained within it.

analyzed: śṛṇuta
translated: Listen.

analyzed: tatra yat brūtha puṇḍarīka antar khasya alpa tvāt tad stham alpataram syāt iti
translated: There, what you say - that because the space within the lotus is small, what is contained there would be even smaller -

analyzed: tat asat
translated: that is not so.

original: na hi khaṃ puṇḍarīkaveśamagataṃ puṇḍarīkādalpataraṃ matvāvocaṃ daharo 'rsminnantarākāśa iti /
analyzed: na hi kham puṇḍarīka veśam a gatam puṇḍarīkāt alpataram matvā avocam daharaḥ ṛsmin antarākāśaḥ iti
translated: For I did not say the small space within it, thinking that the space, having become the form of the lotus, is smaller than the lotus.

original: kiṃ tarhi puṇḍarīkamalpaṃ tadanuvidhāyi tatsthamantaḥkaraṇaṃ puṇḍarīkākāśaparicchinnaṃ🔽tasminviśuddhe saṃhṛtakaraṇānāṃ yogināṃ svaccha ivodake pratibimbarūpamādarśa iva
analyzed: kim tarhi puṇḍarīkam alpam tad anuvidhāyi tad stham antaḥkaraṇam puṇḍarīka ākāśa paricchinnam  tasmin viśuddhe saṃhṛta karaṇānām yoginām svacche iva udake pratibimba rūpam ādarśe iva
translated: What then? The lotus is small, and the internal organ which is in conformity with it is limited by the space in the lotus.🔽When that is purified, to the yogis who have withdrawn the organs, the light of consciousness, which is as clear as in water, appears as a reflection, and in the pure one, like a mirror,

original: ca śuddhe svacchaṃ vijñānajyotiḥ svarūpāvabhāsaṃ tāvanmātraṃ brahmopalabhyata iti
analyzed: ca śuddhe svaccham vijñāna jyotiḥ sva rūpa avabhāsam tāvat mātram brahma upalabhyate iti
translated: only that much Brahman is perceived, the manifestation of its own nature.

analyzed: daharaḥ smin antarākāśaḥ iti avocāma antaḥkaraṇa upādhi nimittam
translated: Therefore, we said that the small space within is due to the limiting adjunct of the internal organ.

original: svatastu yāvānvai prasiddhaḥ parimāṇato 'yamākāśo bhautikastāvāneṣo 'ntarhṛdaya ākāśo yasminnanveṣṭavyaṃ vijijñāsitavyaṃ cāvocāma /
analyzed: svatas tu yāvān vai prasiddhaḥ parimāṇataḥ yam ākāśaḥ bhautikaḥ tāvān eṣaḥ ntar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ yasmin anveṣṭavyam vijijñāsitavyam ca avocāma
translated: But as much as this space is known to be in extent, so much is this space within the heart, where we said one should search and desire to know.

analyzed: na api ākāśa tulya parimāṇa tvam abhipretya tāvān iti ucyate  kim tarhi brahmaṇaḥ nurūpasya dṛṣṭānta antarasya abhāvāt
translated: Nor is it said to be so much with the intention that its extent is equal to that of space.🔽What then? Because there is no other example suitable for Brahman.

analyzed: katham punar na ākāśa samam eva brahma iti avagamyate
translated: How then is it understood that Brahman is not equal to space?

original: yenā'vṛtaṃ khaṃ ca divaṃ mahīṃ ca /
analyzed: yena āvṛtam kham ca divam mahīm ca
translated: By which the sky, heaven and earth are covered.

original: tasmādvā etasmādātmana ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥetasminnu khalvakṣare gārgyākāśaḥityādiśrutibhyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ etasmin nu khalu akṣare gārgi ākāśaḥ ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: Therefore, from this Self, Ākāśa came into being; because of such Vedic texts as ‘Ākāśa was born from that Self’ (Taitt. Up. 2. 1), ‘In this imperishable, O Gārgya, is Ākāśa’ (Chānd. Up. 6. 3. 2), and so on.

original: kiñcobhe 'smindyāvāpṛthivī brahmākāśe buddhyupādhiviśiṣṭe 'ntareva samāhite samyagāhite sthite yathā vā arā nābhāvityuktaṃ hi /
analyzed: kiñca ubhe smin dyāvāpṛthivī brahma ākāśe buddhi upādhi viśiṣṭe ntar eva samāhite samyak āhite sthite yathā vai arāḥ nābhau iti uktam hi
translated: Moreover, in this Brahman, Ākāśa, qualified by the limiting adjunct of the intellect, both heaven and earth are well-contained, well-placed, as if within a pot. As it has been said:

original: tathobhāvagniśca vāyuścetyādi samānam /🔽yaccāsyā'tmana ātmīyatvena dehavato 'sti vidyata iha loke /
analyzed: tathā ubhau agniḥ ca vāyuḥ ca ityādi samānam  yat ca asya ātmanaḥ ātmīya tvena dehavataḥ sti vidyate iha loke
translated: ‘So also both fire and wind, etc.’ is the same.🔽And what is there in this world that belongs to this embodied Self, that exists,

analyzed: tatā yat ca ātmīya tvena na vidyate
translated: and what does not exist as belonging to the Self,

analyzed: naṣṭam bhaviṣyat ca na asti iti ucyate
translated: is said to be lost and will be lost.

analyzed: na tu atyantam eva asat
translated: But it is not absolutely non-existent.

analyzed: tasya hṛdi ākāśe samādhāna anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for it to be contained in the Ākāśa of the heart.

original: taṃ ced brūyur asmiṃś cedaṃ brahmapure sarvaṃ samāhitaṃ sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni sarve ca kāmā yad enaj jarā vāpnoti pradhvaṃsate vā kiṃ tato 'tiśiṣyata
analyzed: tam ced brūyuḥ asmin ca idam brahma pure sarvam samāhitam sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni sarve ca kāmāḥ yat enat jarā vāpnoti pradhvaṃsate vā kim tatas atiśiṣyata
translated: If they were to say: ‘If all this in this city of Brahman, all beings and all desires, is well-contained in this, and if it is destroyed by old age or perishes, what then remains over and above it?’

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: taṃ cedevamuktavantaṃ brūyuḥ punarantevāsinaḥ asmiṃścedyathokte cedyadi brahmapuropalakṣitāntarākāśa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tam ced evam uktavantam brūyuḥ punar antevāsinaḥ asmin ced yathā ukte ced yadi brahmapura upalakṣita antar ākāśe iti arthaḥ
translated: If they were to say this to him, the disciples might again say: 'If in this, as stated, if in the inner space indicated by the city of Brahman, meaning the body,

original: idaṃ sarvaṃ samāhitaṃ sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni sarve ca kāmāḥ /
analyzed: idam sarvam samāhitam sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni sarve ca kāmāḥ
translated: all this is collected, all beings and all desires,

analyzed: katham ācāryeṇa anuktāḥ kāmāḥ antevāsibhiḥ ucyante
translated: how is it that desires, not mentioned by the teacher, are mentioned by the disciples?

original: naiṣa doṣaḥ yaccāsyehāsti yacca nāstītyuktā eva hyācāryeṇa kāmāḥ /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ yat ca asya iha asti yat ca na asti iti uktāḥ eva hi ācāryeṇa kāmāḥ
translated: This is not a fault. What is here and what is not, the desires are indeed mentioned by the teacher.

original: api ca sarvaśabdena coktā eva kāmāḥ /
analyzed: api ca sarva śabdena ca uktāḥ eva kāmāḥ
translated: Moreover, the desires are indeed mentioned by the word 'all'.

original: yadā yasminkāla etaccharīraṃ brahmapurākhyaṃ jarāvalīpalitādilakṣaṇā vayohānirvā'pnoti śasrādinā vā vṛkṇaṃ pradhvaṃsate visraṃsate vinaśyati
analyzed: yadā yasmin kāle etat śarīram brahmapura ākhyam jarā valī palita ādi lakṣaṇā vayaḥ hāniḥ vāpnoti śasra ādinā vā vṛkṇam pradhvaṃsate visraṃsate vinaśyati
translated: When, at that time, this body called the city of Brahman attains old age, characterized by wrinkles, gray hair, etc., or is cut off by weapons, etc., and perishes, dissolves, is destroyed,

analyzed: kim tatas
translated: what else remains over and above that?

analyzed: ghaṭa āśrita kṣīra dadhi sneha ādi vat ghaṭa nāśe deha nāśe deha āśrayam uttarottaram pūrva pūrva nāśāt naśyati iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that like milk, curd, oil, etc. residing in a pot, the subsequent is destroyed by the destruction of the previous.

original: evaṃ prāpte nāśe kiṃ tato 'nyadyathoktādatiśiṣyate 'vatiṣṭhate na kiñcanāvatiṣṭhata ityabhīprāyaḥ //
analyzed: evam prāpte nāśe kim tatas nyat yathā uktāt atiśiṣyate vatiṣṭhate na kiñcana avatiṣṭhate iti abhīprāyaḥ
translated: When this is the case, when destruction occurs, what else remains over and above that, as stated? Nothing remains, this is the intention.

analyzed: sa brūyāt
translated: He should say:

original: nāsya jarayaitaj jīryati na vadhenāsya hanyate /
analyzed: na asya jarayā etat jīryati na vadhena asya hanyate
translated: This does not decay by the decay of the body, nor is it killed by the killing of the body.

original: etat satyaṃ brahmapuram asmin kāmāḥ samāhitāḥ /
analyzed: etat satyam brahma puram asmin kāmāḥ samāhitāḥ
translated: This is the truth, the city of Brahman, in which desires are fulfilled.

original: eṣa ātmāpahatapāpmā vijaro vimṛtyur viśoko vijighatso 'pipāsaḥ satyakāmaḥ satyasaṃkalpaḥ /
analyzed: eṣaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā vijaraḥ vimṛtyuḥ viśokaḥ vijighatsaḥ pipāsaḥ satya kāmaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ
translated: This is the Self, free from evil, free from old age, free from death, free from grief, free from hunger and thirst, having true desires, having true resolves.

original: yathā hy eveha prajā anvāviśanti yathānuśāsanam /
analyzed: yathā hi eva iha prajāḥ anvāviśanti yathānuśāsanam
translated: Just as the people here enter according to the teaching,

original: yaṃ yam antam abhikāmā bhavanti yaṃ janapadaṃ yaṃ kṣetrabhāgaṃ taṃ tam evopajīvanti //
analyzed: yam yam antam abhikāmāḥ bhavanti yam janapadam yam kṣetra bhāgam tam tam eva upajīvanti
translated: whatever end they desire, whatever country, whatever field they desire, they live on just that.

analyzed: evam antevāsibhiḥ coditaḥ saḥ ācāryaḥ brūyāt tad matim apanayan
translated: Thus, urged by the students, the teacher, removing their notion, should say this.

original: katham /🔽asya dehasya jarayaitadyathoktamantarākāśākhyaṃ braṅma yasminsarva samāhitaṃ na jīryati dehavanna vikriyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: katham  asya dehasya jarayā etat yathā uktam antar ākāśa ākhyam yasmin sarva samāhitam na jīryati deha vat na vikriyate iti arthaḥ
translated: How?

original: na cāsya vadhena śasrādighātenaitaddhanyate yathā'kāśaṃ kimu tato 'pi sūkṣmataramaśabdamasparśaṃ
analyzed: na ca asya vadhena śasra ādi ghātena etat hanyate yathā ākāśam kimu sūkṣmataram aśabdam asparśam
translated: This Brahman called space within, as stated, does not decay by the decay of this body. It is not destroyed by the killing of the body, just as space is not. What to speak of it being even subtler than that, being without sound, without touch,

original: brahma dehendriyādidoṣairna spṛśyata ityetasminnavasare vaktavyaṃ prāptaṃ tatprakṛtavyāsaṅgo
analyzed: brahma deha indriya ādi doṣaiḥ na spṛśyate iti etasmin avasare vaktavyam prāptam tad prakṛta vyāsaṅgaḥ
translated: It is proper to speak now of how Brahman is not touched by the faults of the body, senses, etc. This is the occasion. The connection with the main topic is established.

analyzed: mā bhūt iti na ucyate
translated: It is proper to speak at this juncture that Brahman is not touched by the faults of the body, senses, etc., but that is not stated lest there be a digression from the main topic.

analyzed: indravirocana ākhyāyikāyām upariṣṭāt vakṣyāmaḥ yuktitaḥ
translated: It will be stated later in the story of Indra and Virochana, using reasoning.

original: etatsatyamavitathaṃ brahmapuraṃ brahmaiva puraṃ brahmapuraṃ śarīrākhyaṃ tu brahmapuraṃ brahmopalakṣaṇārthatvāt /
analyzed: etat satyam avitatham brahma puram brahma eva puram brahma puram śarīra ākhyam tu brahma puram brahma upalakṣaṇa artha tvāt
translated: This is the truth, the undeceiving Brahman-city. Brahman itself is the city, the Brahman-city. But the body-named Brahman-city is Brahman-city for the purpose of illustrating Brahman.

analyzed: tat tu anṛtam eva
translated: That is indeed the truth.

analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam iti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic statement Name is a verbal designation of modification.

original: tadvikāre 'nṛte 'pi dehaśuṅge brahmopalabhyata iti brahmapuramityuktaṃ vyāvahārikam /
analyzed: tad vikāre deha śuṅge brahma upalabhyate iti brahmapuram iti uktam vyāvahārikam
translated: Even in that modification, the untruth, the body-sheath, Brahman is perceived, so it is said to be the Brahman-city conventionally.

analyzed: satyam tu brahma puram etat eva brahma
translated: But the true Brahman-city is this very Brahman.

analyzed: sarva vyavahāra āspada tvāt
translated: Because it is the basis of all transactions.

original: ato 'sminpuṇḍarīkopalakṣite brahmapure sarve kāmā ye bahirbhavadbhiḥ prārthyante te 'sminneva svātmani samāhitāḥ /
analyzed: atas smin puṇḍarīka upalakṣite brahma pure sarve kāmāḥ ye bahis bhavadbhiḥ prārthyante te smin eva sva ātmani samāhitāḥ
translated: Therefore, in this Brahman-city illustrated by the lotus, all desires that are sought by you outside are contained in this very self.

analyzed: atas tad prāpti upāyam eva anutiṣṭhata bāhya viṣaya tṛṣmām tyajata iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that you should follow only the means to attain that and abandon craving for external objects.

analyzed: eṣaḥ ātmā bhavatām svarūpam
translated: This is your own nature.

analyzed: śṛṇuta tasya lakṣaṇam
translated: Listen to its characteristics.

analyzed: apahata pāpmā
translated: He is free from sin.

analyzed: apahataḥ pāpmā dharma adharma ākhyaḥ yasya saḥ yam apahata pāpmā
translated: He whose sin, called virtue and non-virtue, is removed, he is free from sin.

analyzed: tathā vijaraḥ vigata jaraḥ vimṛtyuḥ ca
translated: Similarly, he is free from old age, free from death.

original: taduktaṃ pūrvameva na vadhenāsya hanyata iti /
analyzed: tat uktam pūrvam eva na vadhena asya hanyate iti
translated: This has already been stated before: He is not killed by death.

analyzed: kimartha punar ucyate
translated: But why is it said again?

original: yadyapi dehasaṃbandhibhyāṃ jarāmṛtyubhyāṃ na saṃbadhyate 'nyathāpi saṃbandhastābhyāṃ syādityāśaṅkānivṛttyartham /
analyzed: yadi api deha saṃbandhibhyām jarā mṛtyubhyām na saṃbadhyate nyathā api saṃbandhaḥ tābhyām syāt iti āśaṅkā nivṛtti artham
translated: Even though he is not connected with old age and death related to the body, there might be some other kind of connection with them. To remove this doubt,

analyzed: viśokaḥ vigata śokaḥ  śokaḥ nāma iṣṭa ādi viyoga nimittaḥ mānasaḥ saṃtāpaḥ
translated: he is free from grief, free from sorrow.🔽Sorrow is mental anguish caused by separation from loved ones and so on.

analyzed: vijighatsaḥ vigata aśana icchaḥ
translated: He is free from hunger, free from the desire for food.

analyzed: a pipāsoḥ pāna icchaḥ
translated: He is free from thirst, free from the desire to drink.

original: nanvapahatapāpmatvena jarādayaḥ śokāntāḥ pratiṣiddhā eva bhavanti /
analyzed: nanu apahata pāpma tvena jarā ādayaḥ śoka antāḥ pratiṣiddhāḥ eva bhavanti
translated: But aren't old age and so on, up to grief, already prohibited by being free from sin?

analyzed: kāraṇa pratiṣedhāt
translated: Because the cause is prohibited.

analyzed: dharma adharma kāryāḥ hi te iti
translated: For they are the effects of virtue and non-virtue.

original: jarādipratiṣedhena vā dharmādharmayoḥ kāryābhāve vidyamānayorapyasatsamatvamiti pṛthakpratiṣedho 'narthakaḥ syāt /
analyzed: jarā ādi pratiṣedhena vā dharma adharmayoḥ kārya abhāve vidyamānayoḥ api asat sama tvam iti pṛthak pratiṣedhaḥ narthakaḥ syāt
translated: Or by prohibiting old age and so on, even if virtue and non-virtue exist, their effects are non-existent, so the separate prohibition would be meaningless.

original: satyamevaṃ tathāpi dharmakāryā nandavyatirekeṇa svābhāvikānando yatheśvare vijñānamānandaṃ brahmeti śruteḥ /🔽tathādharmakāryajarādivyatirekeṇāpi jarādiduḥkhasvarūpaṃ svābhāvikaṃ syādityāśaṅkyeta /
analyzed: satyam evam tathā api dharma kāryā ānanda vyatirekeṇa svābhāvika ānandaḥ yathā īśvare vijñānam ānandam brahma iti śruteḥ  tathā adharma kārya jarā ādi vyatirekeṇa api jarā ādi duḥkha svarūpam svābhāvikam syāt iti āśaṅkyeta
translated: Although this is true, still, lest it be supposed that, just as there is natural bliss in God, apart from the bliss of dharma, as declared in the Vedic text, “Brahman is knowledge and bliss,”

analyzed: atas yuktaḥ tad nivṛttaye jarā ādīnām dharma adharmābhyām pṛthak pratiṣedhaḥ
translated: so also there may be natural misery in the form of old age, etc., apart from the misery caused by adharma, the text denies old age, etc., separately by dharma and adharma.

analyzed: jarā ādi grahaṇam sarva duḥkha upalakṣaṇa artham
translated: The mention of old age, etc., is for the purpose of indicating all misery.

analyzed: pāpa nimittānām tu duḥkhānām ānantyāt pratyekam ca tad pratiṣedhasya aśakya tvāt sarva duḥkha pratiṣedha artham yuktam eva apahata pāpma tva vacanam
translated: But since the miseries caused by sin are endless, and since it is impossible to deny each one of them, the statement of being free from sin is proper for the purpose of denying all misery.

original: satyā avitathāḥ kāmā yasya so 'yaṃ satyakāmaḥ /
analyzed: satyāḥ avitathāḥ kāmāḥ yasya saḥ yam satya kāmaḥ
translated: He whose desires are true, not false, is this Satyakāma.

analyzed: vitathāḥ hi saṃsāriṇām kāmāḥ
translated: For the desires of worldly beings are false.

analyzed: īśvarasya tad viparītāḥ
translated: But those of God are the opposite of that.

original: tathā kāmahetavaḥ saṃkalpā api satyā yasya sa satyasaṃkalpaḥ /
analyzed: tathā kāma hetavaḥ saṃkalpāḥ api satyāḥ yasya sa satya saṃkalpaḥ
translated: Similarly, he whose intentions, which are the causes of desires, are true, is this Satyasankalpa.

analyzed: saṃkalpāḥ kāmāḥ ca śuddha sattva upādhi nimittāḥ īśvarasya citragu vat
translated: The intentions and desires of God, which are due to the limiting adjunct of pure Sattva, are like the variegated color of a picture.

analyzed: na svatas na iti na iti iti ukta tvāt
translated: Not by themselves, because it has been said, “Not so, not so!”

original: yathoktalakṣaṇa evā'tmā vijñeyo gurubhyaḥ śāstrataścā'tmasaṃvedyatayā ca svārājyakāmaiḥ /
analyzed: yathā ukta lakṣaṇaḥ evā ātmā vijñeyaḥ gurubhyaḥ śāstrataḥ ca ātma saṃvedya tayā ca svārājya kāmaiḥ
translated: The Self, which has the characteristics described, should be known from the teachers, from the scriptures, and from one's own experience, by those who desire self-sovereignty.

analyzed: na ced vijñāyate kaḥ doṣaḥ syāt iti
translated: If it is not known, what fault would there be?

original: śṛṇutātra doṣaṃ dṛṣṭāntena /🔽yathā hyeveha loke prajā anvāviśantyanuvartante /
analyzed: śṛṇuta atra doṣam dṛṣṭāntena  yathā hi eva iha loke prajāḥ anvāviśanti anuvartante
translated: Listen to the fault here through an example.🔽Just as in this world, people enter and follow,

original: yathānuśāsanaṃ yatheha prajā anyaṃ svāminaṃ manyamānāḥ svasya svāmino yathā yathānuśāsanaṃ tathā tathānvāviśanti /
analyzed: yathā anuśāsanam yathā iha prajāḥ anyam svāminam manyamānāḥ svasya svāminaḥ yathā yathā anuśāsanam tathā tathā anvāviśanti
translated: just as in this world, people who consider someone else as their master enter according to the instructions of their own master.

analyzed: kim
translated: What?

analyzed: yam yam antam pratyantam janapadam kṣetra bhāgam ca abhikāmāḥ arthinyaḥ bhavanti ātma buddhi anurūpam tam tam eva ca pratyanta ādim upajīvanti iti
translated: They depend on that very distant place etc. according to their own understanding and desire.

analyzed: eṣa svātantrya deṣam prati puṇya phala upabhoge
translated: This is the example for the fault of lack of independence in the enjoyment of the fruits of merit.

original: tad yatheha karmajito lokaḥ kṣīyata evam evāmutra puṇyajito lokaḥ kṣīyate /
analyzed: tat yathā iha karma jitaḥ lokaḥ kṣīyate evam eva amutra puṇya jitaḥ lokaḥ kṣīyate
translated: Just as the world conquered by action here perishes, so also the world conquered by merit perishes in the next world.

original: tad ya ihātmānam ananuvidya vrajanty etāṃś ca satyān kāmāṃs teṣāṃ sarveṣu lokeṣv akāmacāro bhavati /
analyzed: tat ye iha ātmānam an anuvidya vrajanti etān ca satyān kāmān teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu akāma cāraḥ bhavati
translated: Those who go forth here without understanding the Self and these true desires, for them there is no freedom of desire in all the worlds.

original: atha ya ihātmānam anivudya vrajanty etaṃś ca satyān kāmāṃs teṣāṃ sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavati //
analyzed: atha ye iha ātmānam a nivudya vrajanti etan ca satyān kāmān teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati
translated: Now, those who depart from here without knowing the Self and those desires which are true, for them there is freedom to enjoy as they wish in all the worlds.

analyzed: atha anyaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ tad kṣayam prati tat yathā iha ityādiḥ
translated: Now, another example is given for the exhaustion of that, beginning with just as here.

original: tattatra yatheha loke tāsāmeva svāmyanuśāsanānuvartinīnāṃ prajānāṃ sevādijito lokaḥ parādhīnopabhogaḥ kṣīyate 'ntavānbhavati /

translated: Just as in this world, the world obtained by serving etc. of those subjects who follow the instructions of their lord, which is enjoyed under the control of others, is exhausted, it has an end.

original: athedānīṃ dārṣṭāntikamupasaṃharatievamevāmutrāgnihotrādipuṇyaj ito lokaḥ parādhīnopabhogaḥ kṣīyata evetyukto doṣa eṣāmiti viṣayaṃ darśayatitadya
analyzed: atha idānīm dārṣṭāntikam upasaṃharati evam eva amutra agnihotra ādi puṇya j itaḥ lokaḥ para adhīna upabhogaḥ kṣīyate eva iti uktaḥ doṣaḥ eṣām iti viṣayam darśayati tat yad
translated: Now, he concludes the example - In the same way, in the next world, the world obtained from the merit of Agnihotra etc. is enjoyed under the control of others and is exhausted. This fault has been stated. He shows the scope of this with that

analyzed: ityādinā  tat tatra iha asmin loke jñāna karmaṇoḥ adhikṛtāḥ yogyāḥ santaḥ ātmānam yathā ukta lakṣaṇam śāstra ācārya upadiṣṭam an anuvidya
translated: and so on.🔽There, in this world, those who are entitled to knowledge and action, being fit, without knowing the Self with the characteristics described,🔽without making it known to themselves according to the teaching, depart from this body, go away. Those who do not know these desires which are true,

analyzed: yathopadeśam anu sva saṃvedya tām a kṛtvā vrajanti dehāt asmāt prayanti ye etān ca yathā uktān
translated: and those who depart from here without knowing the Self, for them there is freedom to enjoy as they wish in all the worlds.

analyzed: satyān satya saṃkalpa kāryān ca sva ātma sthān kāmān an anuvidya vrajanti teṣām sarveṣu

analyzed: yathā rāja anuśāsana anuvartinīnām prajānām iti arthaḥ

analyzed: saṃkalpāt eva asya sakhāyaḥ samuttiṣṭhanti
translated: from his mere will, his friends arise.

analyzed: tena sakhi lokena saṃpannaḥ mahīyate
translated: Endowed with that world of friends, he becomes great.

original: atha yadi gandhamālyalokakāmo bhavati /🔽saṃkalpād evāsya gandhamālye samuttiṣṭhataḥ /
analyzed: atha yadi gandha mālya loka kāmaḥ bhavati  saṃkalpāt eva asya gandha mālye samuttiṣṭhataḥ
translated: Now, if he desires the world of perfumes and garlands,🔽from his mere will, perfumes and garlands arise.

analyzed: tena gandha mālya lokena saṃpannaḥ mahīyate
translated: Endowed with that world of perfumes and garlands, he becomes great.

original: atha yady annapānalokakāmo bhavati /🔽saṃkalpād evāsyānnapāne samuttiṣṭhataḥ /
analyzed: atha yadi anna pāna loka kāmaḥ bhavati  saṃkalpāt eva asya anna pāne samuttiṣṭhataḥ
translated: Now, if he desires the world of food and drink,🔽from his mere will, food and drink arise.

analyzed: tena anna pāna lokena saṃpannaḥ mahīyate
translated: Endowed with that world of food and drink, he becomes great.

analyzed: atha yadi gīta vādita loka kāmaḥ bhavati
translated: Now, if he desires the world of singing and music,

analyzed: saṃkalpāt eva asya gīta vādite samuttiṣṭhataḥ
translated: from his mere will, singing and music arise.

analyzed: tena gīta vādita lokena saṃpannaḥ mahīyate
translated: Endowed with that world of singing and music, he becomes great.

analyzed: atha yadi strī loka kāmaḥ bhavati
translated: Now, if he desires the world of women,

analyzed: saṃkalpāt eva asya striyaḥ samuttiṣṭhanti
translated: from his mere will, women arise.

analyzed: tena strī lokena saṃpannaḥ mahīyate
translated: Endowed with that world of women, he becomes great.

analyzed: samānam anyat
translated: The rest is the same.

analyzed: mātaraḥ janayitryaḥ tītāḥ sukha hetu bhūtāḥ sāmardhyāt
translated: The mothers who have given birth to us in the past are the causes of our happiness, by their efficiency.

original: na hi duḥkhahetubhūtāsu grāmasūkarādijanmanimittāsu mātṛṣu viśuddhasattvasya yogina icchā tatsaṃbandho vā yuktaḥ //
analyzed: na hi duḥkha hetu bhūtāsu grāma sūkara ādi janma nimittāsu mātṛṣu viśuddha sattvasya yoginaḥ icchā tad saṃbandhaḥ vā yuktaḥ
translated: For one of pure mind, a yogi, it is not proper to desire or have any connection with those mothers who are the causes of suffering, such as those who give birth to pigs in a village.

analyzed: yam yam antam abhikāmaḥ bhavati
translated: Whatever end one desires,

analyzed: yam kāmam kāmayate
translated: whatever desire one wishes for,

analyzed: saḥ sya saṃkalpāt eva samuttiṣṭhati
translated: that arises for him by mere thought.

original: tena saṃpanno mahīyate //🔽yaṃ yanamtaṃ pradeśamabhikāmo bhavati /
analyzed: tena saṃpannaḥ mahīyate  yam yanam tam pradeśam abhikāmaḥ bhavati
translated: Endowed with that, he is honored.🔽Whatever region one desires,

original: yaṃ ca kāmaṃ kāmayate yathoktavyatirekeṇāpi so 'syāntaḥ prāptumiṣṭaḥ kāmaśca saṃkalpādeva samuttiṣṭhatyasya /
analyzed: yam ca kāmam kāmayate yathā ukta vyatirekeṇa api saḥ sya antaḥ prāptum iṣṭaḥ kāmaḥ ca saṃkalpāt eva samuttiṣṭhati asya
translated: and whatever desire one wishes for, even apart from what has been mentioned, that which is desired to be attained within him, and that desire arises for him by mere thought.

analyzed: tena icchā vighāta tayā abhipreta artha prāptyā ca saṃpannaḥ mahīyate iti ukta artham
translated: Endowed with that, by the fulfillment of his wishes and the attainment of his intended goal, he is honored. The meaning has been stated.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the second section of the eighth chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: te ime satyāḥ kāmāḥ anṛta apidhānāḥ
translated: These desires are true, but they are covered by untruth.

analyzed: teṣām satyānām satām anṛtam apidhānam
translated: For them, the true ones, untruth is the covering.

original: yo yo hy asyetaḥ praiti na tam iha darśanāya labhate //
analyzed: yaḥ yaḥ hi asya itas praiti na tam iha darśanāya labhate
translated: For whoever departs from here, he cannot be seen here again.

original: yathoktātmadhyānasādhanānuṣṭhānaṃ prati sādhakānāmutsāhajananārthamanukrośantyāhakaṣṭamidaṃ🔽khalu vartate yatsvātmasthāḥ śakyaprāpyā api ta ime satyāḥ kāmā anṛtāpidhānāsteṣāmātmasthānāṃ
analyzed: yathā ukta ātma dhyāna sādhana anuṣṭhānam prati sādhakānām utsāha janana artham anukrośantī āha kaṣṭam idam  khalu vartate yat sva ātma sthāḥ śakya prāpyāḥ api te ime satyāḥ kāmāḥ anṛta apidhānāḥ teṣām ātma sthānām
translated: In order to generate enthusiasm in practitioners to perform the means of meditation on the self as taught, she laments: Alas, this indeed is difficult to bear, that these true desires, though residing in the self and attainable, are obstructed by falsehood.🔽Those desires that reside in the self,

original: svāśrayāṇāmeva satāmanṛtaṃ bahyaviṣayeṣu stryannabhojanācchādanādiṣu tṛṣṇā tannimittaṃ
analyzed: sva āśrayāṇām eva satām anṛtam strī anna bhojana ācchādana ādiṣu tṛṣṇā tad nimittam
translated: existing in their own basis, are obstructed by falsehood, i.e. craving for external objects such as women, food, drink, clothing, etc., and the freedom to roam as one wishes on account of that,

analyzed: ca sva icchā pracāra tvam mithyājñāna nimitta tvāt anṛtam iti ucyate
translated: is called false because it is caused by false knowledge.

analyzed: tad nimittam satyānām kāmānām aprāptiḥ iti apidhānam iva apidhānam
translated: On account of that, the non-attainment of the true desires is like an obstruction, hence it is called an obstruction.

analyzed: katham anṛta apidhāna nimittam teṣām alābhaḥ iti
translated: How is it that the non-attainment of those is caused by the obstruction of falsehood?

original: ucyateyo yo hi yasmādasya jantoḥ putro bhrātā veṣṭa ito 'smāllokātpraiti pragacchati
analyzed: ucyate yaḥ yaḥ hi yasmāt asya jantoḥ putraḥ bhrātā itas smāt lokāt praiti pragacchati
translated: It is said: Whoever, from whom this person is a son or brother, when he departs from this world, dies,

original: mriyate tamiṣṭaṃ putraṃ bhrātaraṃ vā svahṛdayākāśe vidyamānamapīha punardarśanāyecchannapi na labhate //
analyzed: mriyate tam iṣṭam putram bhrātaram vā sva hṛdaya ākāśe vidyamānam api iha punar darśanāya icchan api na labhate
translated: that beloved son or brother, though existing in the space of one's own heart, is not obtained again, though desired to be seen.
