original: atha ye cāsyeha jīvā ye ca pretā yac cānyad icchan na labhate sarvaṃ tad atra gatvā vindate /
analyzed: atha ye ca asya iha jīvāḥ ye ca pretāḥ yat ca anyat icchan na labhate sarvam tat atra gatvā vindate
translated: Now, all those who are his living relatives here, and those who are dead, and whatever else he desires but does not get, all that he obtains by going there.

original: atra hy asyaite satyāḥ kāmā anṛtāpidhānāḥ /
analyzed: atra hi asya ete satyāḥ kāmāḥ anṛta apidhānāḥ
translated: For here, his desires are true, though obstructed by untruth.

original: tad yathāpi hiraṇyanidhiṃ nihitam akṣetrajñā upary upari sañcaranto na vindeyuḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā api hiraṇya nidhim nihitam akṣetrajñāḥ upari upari sañcarantaḥ na vindeyuḥ
translated: Just as a treasure of gold, though buried underground, is not found by those who walk above it,

original: evam evemāḥ sarvāḥ prajā ahar ahar gacchantya etaṃ brahmalokaṃ na vindanty anṛtena hi pratyūḍhāḥ //
analyzed: evam eva imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ ahar ahar gacchantyaḥ etam brahma lokam na vindanti anṛtena hi pratyūḍhāḥ
translated: in the same way, all these beings go to this world of Brahman day after day, but do not find it, for they are obstructed by untruth.

original: atha punarye cāsya viduṣo jantorjīvā jīvantīha putrā bhrātrādayo vā
analyzed: atha punar ye ca asya viduṣaḥ jantoḥ jīvāḥ jīvanti iha putrāḥ bhrātṛ ādayaḥ vā
translated: Now, again, those who are his living relatives, the living sons, brothers, etc. of this wise person,

original: ye ca pretā mṛtā iṣṭāḥ saṃbandhino yaccānyadiha loke vastrānnapānādi ratnādi vā vastvicchanna
analyzed: ye ca pretāḥ mṛtāḥ iṣṭāḥ saṃbandhinaḥ yat ca anyat iha loke vastra anna pāna ādi ratna ādi vā vastu icchan na
translated: and those who are dead, the deceased relatives, and whatever else he desires in this world, such as clothes, food, drink, jewels, etc.,

original: labhate tatsarvamatra hṛdayākāśākhye brahmaṇi gatvā yathoktena vidhinā vindate labhate /
analyzed: labhate tat sarvam atra hṛdaya ākāśa ākhye brahmaṇi gatvā yathā uktena vidhinā vindate labhate
translated: he obtains all that by going there, to that Brahman called the space of the heart, by the aforementioned method.

original: atrāsminhārdākāśe hi yasmādasyaite yathoktāḥ satyāḥ kāmā vartante 'natāpidhānāḥ /
analyzed: atra asmin hārd ākāśe hi yasmāt asya ete yathā uktāḥ satyāḥ kāmāḥ vartante nata apidhānāḥ
translated: For here, in this space of the heart, his desires are true, though obstructed by untruth.

original: kathamiva tadanyāyyamityucyatetattatra yathā hiraṇyanidhiṃ hiraṇyameva punargrahaṇāya
analyzed: katham iva tat anyāyyam iti ucyate tat tatra yathā hiraṇya nidhim hiraṇyam eva punargrahaṇāya
translated: How is that unreasonable? It is said: Just as a treasure of gold is again buried by the treasure-seekers for the purpose of taking it back,

original: nidhātṛbhirnidhīyata iti nidhistaṃ hiraṇyanidhiṃ nihitaṃ bhūmeradhastānnikṣiptamakṣetrajñā
analyzed: nidhātṛbhiḥ nidhīyate iti nidhiḥ tam hiraṇyanidhim nihitam bhūmeḥ adhastāt nikṣiptam akṣetrajñā
translated: so that is a treasure. That treasure of gold, when buried, placed under the ground, those who do not know the field of the treasure,

original: nidhiśāsrairnidhikṣetramajānantaste nidheruparyupari saṃcaranto 'pi nidhiṃ na vindeyuḥ śakyavedanamapi /
analyzed: nidhi śāsraiḥ nidhi kṣetram a jānantaḥ te nidheḥ upari upari saṃcarantaḥ nidhim na vindeyuḥ śakya vedanam api
translated: even though they move about above the treasure, would not find the treasure, even though it is capable of being known.

original: evamevemā avidyavatyaḥ sarvā imāḥ prajā yathoktaṃ hṛdayākāśākhyaṃ brahmalokaṃ brahmaiva
analyzed: evam eva imāḥ avidyavatyaḥ sarvāḥ imāḥ prajāḥ yathoktam hṛdaya ākāśa ākhyam brahma lokam brahmā eva
translated: In the same way, all these people who are in ignorance, as stated, the world of Brahman called the space in the heart, Brahman itself

original: loko brahmalokastamaharahaḥ pratyahaṃ gacchantyo 'pi suṣuptakāle na vidandanti na
analyzed: lokaḥ brahma lokaḥ tam aharahar pratyaham gacchantyaḥ suṣupta kāle na vidandanti na
translated: is the world, that is the world of Brahman. Even though they go to that every day, at the time of deep sleep they do not know,

analyzed: labhante eṣaḥ ham brahma loka bhāvam āpannaḥ u smi adya iti
translated: they do not obtain the state of being in the world of Brahman, thinking Today I have attained the state of being in the world of Brahman.

original: anṛtena hi yathoktena hi yasmātpratyūḍhā hṛtāḥ svarūpādavidyādidoṣairbahipakṛṣṭā ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: anṛtena hi yathā uktena hi yasmāt pratyūḍhāḥ hṛtāḥ sva rūpāt avidyā ādi doṣaiḥ bahis apakṛṣṭāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: For, indeed, by the untruth, by the aforementioned, since they are carried away, taken away from their own nature by the faults of ignorance and so on, they are pushed outside, this is the meaning.

original: ataḥ kaṣṭamidaṃ vartate jantūnāṃ yatsvāyattamapi brahma na labhyata ityabhiprāyaḥ //
analyzed: atas kaṣṭam idam vartate jantūnām yat svāyattam api brahma na labhyate iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is a difficult situation for beings, that even their own Brahman is not obtained. This is the intention.

analyzed: sa vai eṣaḥ ātmā hṛdi
translated: He is this Self in the heart.

original: tasyaitad eva niruktaṃ hṛdy ayam iti tasmād dhṛd ayam /
analyzed: tasya etat eva niruktam hṛdi ayam iti tasmāt hṛd ayam
translated: The derivation of the word 'hṛdaya' is this: 'hṛdi ayaṃ' (is in the heart), therefore it is 'hṛdaya'.

original: ahar ahar vā evaṃvit svargaṃ lokam eti //
analyzed: ahar ahar vai evaṃvid svargam lokam eti
translated: Day after day, one who knows thus goes to the heavenly world.

original: sa vai ya ātmāpahatapāpmeti prakṛto vaiśabdena taṃ smārayatyeṣa vivakṣita ātmā hṛdi hṛdayapuṇḍarīka ākāśaśabdenābhihitaḥ /
analyzed: sa vai yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā iti prakṛtaḥ vaiśabdena tam smārayati eṣa vivakṣitaḥ ātmā hṛdi hṛdaya puṇḍarīke ākāśa śabdena abhihitaḥ
translated: The Self that has been referred to as 'the one free from evil' is recalled by the word 'that' (in the text). This intended Self is in the heart, in the lotus of the heart, and is referred to by the word 'space'.

analyzed: tasya etasya hṛdayasya etat eva niruktam nirvacanam
translated: The derivation of this heart is this, and nothing else.

original: hṛdyayamātmā vartata iti yasmāt tasmāddhṛdayaṃ hṛdayanāmanirvacanaprasiddhyāpi svahṛdaya ātmetyavagantavyamityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: hṛdi ayam ātmā vartate iti yasmāt tasmāt hṛdayam hṛdaya nāma nirvacana prasiddhyā api sva hṛdaye ātmā iti avagantavyam iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Since this Self is in the heart, therefore the heart is so called. Even by the well-known derivation of the name 'heart', it should be understood that the Self is in one's own heart. This is the intention.

original: aharaharvai pratyahamevaṃviddhṛdyayamātmeti jānansvargaṃ lokaṃ hārdaṃ brahmaiti pratipadyate /
analyzed: ahar ahar vai pratyaham evaṃvid hṛdi ayam ātmā iti jānan svargam lokam hārdam brahma eti pratipadyate
translated: Day after day, one who knows thus that this Self is in the heart, goes to the heavenly world, which is the heart, the Brahman.

original: nanvanevaṃvidapi suṣuptakāle hārdaṃ brahma pratipadyata eva suṣuptakāle satā somya tadā saṃpanna ityuktatvāt /
analyzed: nanu anevaṃvid api suṣupta kāle hārdam brahma pratipadyate eva suṣupta kāle satā somya tadā saṃpannaḥ iti ukta tvāt
translated: But even one who does not know thus enters the heart, Brahman, at the time of deep sleep, because it has been said, 'Then, O Somya, he becomes united with the existent.'

analyzed: bāḍham evam tathā api asti viśeṣaḥ
translated: Indeed, so it is. But there is a difference.

original: yathā jānannajānaṃśca sarvo jantuḥ sadbrahmaiva tathāpi tattvamasīti pratibodhito vidvānsadeva nānyo 'smīti jānansadeva bhavati /
analyzed: yathā jānan a jānan ca sarvaḥ jantuḥ sat brahma eva tathā api tat tvam asi iti pratibodhitaḥ vidvān sat eva na anyaḥ smi iti jānan sat eva bhavati
translated: As a matter of fact, every creature, whether he knows it or not, is really Brahman; still, when he is taught by the text ‘That thou art’, that he is really Brahman, and not something else, then he comes to know that he is really Brahman, and becomes one with Brahman.

original: evameva vidvānavidvāṃścasuṣupte yadyapi satsaṃpadyate tathāpyevaṃvideva svargaṃ lokametītyucyate /
analyzed: evam eva vidvān avidvān ca suṣupte yadi api sat saṃpadyate tathā api evaṃvid eva svargam lokam eti iti ucyate
translated: In the same manner, though the man of knowledge and the ignorant man alike become united with Being at the time of deep sleep, yet it is only the man who knows this that is said to ‘go to the heavenly world’;

analyzed: dehapāte pi vidyā phalasya avaśyaṃbhāvi tvāt iti eṣa viśeṣaḥ
translated: because the result of his knowledge is sure to come about, even after the fall of the body; this is the difference between the two cases.

original: atha ya eṣa saṃprasādo 'smāc charīrāt samutthāya paraṃ jyotir upasaṃpadya svena rūpenābhiniṣpadyata eṣa ātmeti hovāca /
analyzed: atha yaḥ eṣa saṃprasādaḥ u smāt śarīrāt samutthāya param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpena abhiniṣpadyate eṣaḥ ātmā iti ha uvāca
translated: ‘Now, this serene Being, having risen from out of this body, and having attained the Supreme Light, manifests itself in its own form; this is the Self’, said he.

analyzed: etat amṛtam abhayam etat brahma iti
translated: ‘This is the Immortal, the Fearless; this is Brahman.’

original: tasya ha vā etasya brahmaṇo nāma satyam iti //
analyzed: tasya ha vai etasya brahmaṇaḥ nāma satyam iti
translated: And the name of this Brahman is ‘Truth.’

original: suṣuptakāle svenā'manā satā saṃpannaḥ sansamyakprasīdatīti jāgratsvapnayorviṣayendriyasaṃyogajātaṃ
analyzed: suṣupta kāle svena amanā satā saṃpannaḥ san samyak prasīdati iti jāgrat svapnayoḥ viṣaya indriya saṃyoga jātam
translated: At the time of deep sleep, he becomes united with his own Self, and becomes serene; and he shakes off the impurities born of the contact of the senses with their objects during the states of waking and dreaming;

original: kāluṣyaṃ jahātīti saṃprasādaśabdo yadyapi sarvajantūnāṃ sādhāraṇastathāpyevaṃvitsvargaṃ
analyzed: kāluṣyam jahāti iti saṃprasāda śabdaḥ yadi api sarva jantūnām sādhāraṇaḥ tathā api evaṃvid svargam
translated: though the term ‘sampraśānta’, ‘serene’, is applicable to all living beings, yet it is only the man who knows this who goes to the heavenly world;

original: lokametīti prakṛtatvādeṣa saṃprasāda iti saṃnihitavadyatnaviśeṣātso 'thedaṃ śarīraṃ
analyzed: lokam eti iti prakṛta tvāt eṣa saṃprasādaḥ iti saṃnihita vat yatna viśeṣāt saḥ u thā idam śarīram
translated: Because the context is about one who goes to the world, this 'one who is well-disposed' is as if present due to the special effort, and then this body,

analyzed: hitvā asmāt śarīrāt samutthāya śarīra ātma bhāvanām parityajya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: He goes to the world - this is the context. He attains is like something nearby due to the special effort. Then, having left this body, having abandoned the notion of the body as the self.

analyzed: na tu āsanāt iva samutthāya iti iha yuktam
translated: But it is not appropriate here to say having risen from a seat, etc.

analyzed: svena rūpeṇa iti viśeṣaṇāt
translated: Because of the qualification in his own form.

analyzed: na hi anyatas utthāya sva rūpam saṃpattavyam
translated: For one cannot rise from another and attain one's own form.

original: svarūpameva hi tanna bhavati pratipattavyaṃ cetsyāt /
analyzed: sva rūpam eva hi tat na bhavati pratipattavyam ced syāt
translated: If it were to be attained, it would not be one's own form.

original: paraṃ paramātmalakṣaṇaṃ vijñaptisvabhāvaṃ jyotirupasaṃpadya svāsthyamupagamyetyetat /🔽svena ātmīyena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyate prāgetasyāḥ svarūpasaṃpatteravidyayā dehamevāparaṃ rūpamātmatvenopagata iti tadapekṣayedamucyate svena rūpeṇeti
analyzed: param paramātma lakṣaṇam vijñapti svabhāvam jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svāsthyam upagamya iti etat  svena ātmīyena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate prāk etasyāḥ sva rūpa saṃpatteḥ avidyayā deham eva aparam rūpam ātma tvena upagataḥ iti tad apekṣayā idam ucyate svena rūpeṇa iti
translated: Having attained the supreme, which has the nature of the supreme self and the nature of manifestation, light, he attains well-being - this is the meaning.🔽He is produced in his own, i.e., his own, form. Prior to this attainment of his own form, due to ignorance, he has taken the body alone as his other form and as the self. In relation to that, this is said: in his own form.

original: aśarīratā hyātmanaḥ svarūpaṃ yatsvaṃ paraṃ jyotiḥsvarūpamāpadye saṃprasāda eṣa ātmeti hovāca /
analyzed: aśarīra tā hi ātmanaḥ sva rūpam yat svam param jyotiḥ sva rūpam āpadye saṃprasādaḥ eṣaḥ ātmā iti ha uvāca
translated: For the state of being bodiless is the own form of the self. Having attained the form of the supreme light, he is the self who is at peace - this is what he said.

analyzed: sa brūyāt iti yaḥ śrutyā niyuktaḥ antevāsibhyaḥ
translated: He should say - he who is appointed by scripture to his students.

original: kiñcaitadamṛtamavināśi bhūmā yo vai bhūmā tadamṛtamityuktam /🔽ata evābhayaṃ bhūmno dvitīyābhāvādata etadbrahmeti /
analyzed: kiñca etat amṛtam avināśi bhūmā yaḥ vai bhūmā tat amṛtam iti uktam  atas eva abhayam bhūmnaḥ dvitīya abhāvāt atas etat brahma iti
translated: Moreover, this is the immortal, the imperishable, the all-pervading. He who is the all-pervading is the immortal, as stated.🔽For this very reason, it is fearless, because there is no second to the all-pervading. For this very reason, it is Brahman.

original: tasya ha vā etasya brahmaṇo nāmābhidhānam /
analyzed: tasya ha vai etasya brahmaṇaḥ nāma abhidhānam
translated: Now, this Brahman has a name.

analyzed: kim tat satyam iti
translated: What is that? It is Satya (Truth).

analyzed: satyam hi avitatham brahma
translated: For Brahman is true, not false.

analyzed: tat satyam saḥ ātmā iti hi uktam
translated: That is Satya, that is the Self, as stated.

analyzed: atha kimartham idam nāma punar ucyate
translated: Now, for what purpose is this name mentioned again?

analyzed: tad upāsana vidhi stuti artham
translated: For the purpose of praising the injunction to meditate on it.

original: tāni ha vā etāni trīṇyakṣarāṇi satīyamiti tadyatsattdamṛtamatha yatti tanmartyamatha
analyzed: tāni ha vai etāni trīṇi akṣarāṇi satī iyam iti tat yat sat tat amṛtam atha yat ti tat martyam atha
translated: Those three syllables, Sat, I, and Am, of which Sat is the immortal, and I is mortal,

original: yadyaṃ tenobhe yacchati yadanenobhe yacchati tasmādyamaharaharvā evaṃvitsvargaṃ lokameti //
analyzed: yat yam tena ubhe yacchati yat anena ubhe yacchati tasmāt yam ahar ahar vai evaṃvid svargam lokam eti
translated: and by Am he controls both. Since he controls both by this, therefore one who knows thus daily goes to the heavenly world.

original: tāni ha vā etāni brahmaṇo nāmākṣarāṇi trīṇyetāni satīyāmati sakārastakāro yamiti ca /🔽takāra īkāraḥ uccāraṇārtho 'nubandhaḥ /
analyzed: tāni ha vai etāni brahmaṇaḥ nāma akṣarāṇi trīṇi etāni satīyām ati sakāraḥ takāraḥ yam iti ca  takāraḥ īkāraḥ uccāraṇa arthaḥ nubandhaḥ
translated: Those are indeed the syllables of Brahman's name, three of them: Sat, I, and Am. Sat is the syllable Sa, Ta is the syllable Ta, and Am is the syllable Ya.🔽The syllable Ta is the syllable I, the vowel is a suffix for pronunciation.

analyzed: hrasvena eva akṣareṇa punar pratinirdeśāt teṣām
translated: Because they are referred to again with a short syllable.

original: tattatra yatsatsakārastadamṛtaṃ sadbrahmāmṛtavācakatvādamṛta eva sakārastakāranto nirdiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tat tatra yat sat sakāraḥ tat amṛtam sat brahma amṛta vācaka tvāt amṛtaḥ eva sakāraḥ takāra antaḥ nirdiṣṭaḥ
translated: Now, that which is real and good is the immortal, the real Brahman. The letter S, which denotes immortality, is indicated as the letter S with the letter T added.

analyzed: atha yat ti takāraḥ tat martyam
translated: Now, that which is the letter T is mortal.

original: atha yadyamakṣaraṃ tenākṣareṇāmṛtamartyākhye pūrve ubhe 'kṣare yacchati yamayati niyamayati vaśīkarotyātmana ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atha yat yam akṣaram tena akṣareṇa amṛta martya ākhye pūrve ubhe kṣare yacchati yamayati niyamayati vaśīkaroti ātmanaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Now, by that syllable, he controls the two previous syllables called immortal and mortal, he regulates, he brings under control, he makes his own. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yat yasmāt anena yam iti etena ubhe yacchati tasmāt yām
translated: Since by this he controls the two, therefore it is YAM.

analyzed: saṃyate iva hi etena yamā lakṣyete
translated: For by this the two YAMs are indeed seen as controlled.

analyzed: braṅma nāma akṣarasya api idam amṛta tva ādi dharmavat tvam mahābhāgyam kim uta nāmavataḥ iti upāsya tvāya stūyate
translated: This Brahman, which has the name of a syllable, has the quality of immortality, etc., what to speak of the named one. Thus it is praised for the purpose of being meditated upon.

analyzed: brahma nāma nirvacanena eva nāmavataḥ vettā evaṃvid
translated: By the very definition of the name Brahman, one who knows thus knows the named one.

analyzed: ahar ahar vai evaṃvid svargam lokam eti iti ukta artham
translated: Or, day after day, one who knows thus goes to the heavenly world. The meaning has been stated.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya tṛtīyaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the Third Section of the Eighth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha ya ātmā sa setur dhṛtir eṣāṃ lokānām asaṃbhedāya /
analyzed: atha yaḥ ātmā sa setuḥ dhṛtiḥ eṣām lokānām a saṃbhedāya
translated: Now, that Self is the dam, the support, of these worlds, for the sake of their non-mixing.

original: naitaṃ setum ahorātre tarato na jarā na mṛtyur na śoko na sukṛtam /
analyzed: na etam setum ahar rātre tarataḥ na jarā na mṛtyuḥ na śokaḥ na sukṛtam
translated: Neither day and night, nor old age, nor death, nor grief, nor good deeds, can cross this bridge.

analyzed: sarve pāpmānaḥ tasmāt nivartante
translated: From this all evils turn away.

analyzed: apahata pāpmā hi eṣa brahma lokaḥ
translated: For this world of Brahman is indeed free from evil.

analyzed: atha yaḥ ātmā iti
translated: Now, that which is the Self,

original: uktalakṣaṇo yaḥ saṃprasādastasya svarūpaṃ vakṣyamāṇairuktaiśca guṇaiḥ punaḥ stūyate brahmacaryasādhanasaṃbandhārtham /
analyzed: ukta lakṣaṇaḥ yaḥ saṃprasādaḥ tasya svarūpam vakṣyamāṇaiḥ uktaiḥ ca guṇaiḥ punar stūyate brahmacarya sādhana saṃbandha artham
translated: That which is the tranquillity described above, its nature is praised again with the qualities to be described and those already mentioned, for the purpose of connecting it with the means of attaining Brahman.

original: ya eṣa yathoktalakṣaṇa ātmā sa seturiva setuḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ eṣa yathā ukta lakṣaṇaḥ ātmā sa setuḥ iva setuḥ
translated: That which is the Self described above is like a bridge, a dam.

analyzed: vidhṛtiḥ vidharaṇaḥ
translated: It is the supporter, the sustainer.

original: anena hi sarvaṃ jagadvarṇāśramādikriyākārakaphalādibhedaniyamaiḥ karturanurūpaṃ vidadhatā vidhṛtam /
analyzed: anena hi sarvam jagat varṇa āśrama ādi kriyā kāraka phala ādi bheda niyamaiḥ kartuḥ anurūpam vidadhatā vidhṛtam
translated: For by this, the entire world is sustained with the distinctions of caste, life-stage, action, agent, result, etc., by arranging them in accordance with the doer.

analyzed: a dhriyamāṇam hi īśvareṇa idam viśvam vinaśyet yatas tasmāt sa setuḥ vidhṛtiḥ
translated: For if this universe were not sustained by God, it would perish. Therefore, it is the bridge, the sustainer.

analyzed: kimartham sa setuḥ iti āha eṣām bhūḥ ādīnām a saṃbhedāya a vidāraṇāya a vināśāya iti etat
translated: For what purpose is it a bridge? It is said: for the non-separation, non-disruption, non-destruction of these, the earth and others, which are the abodes of agents, actions, and results.

original: kiṃviśṣṭaścāsau seturityāhanaitam setumātmānamahorātre sarvasya janimataḥ paricchedake satī naitaṃ tarataḥ /
analyzed: kiṃviśṣṭaḥ ca asau setuḥ iti āha na etam setum ātmānam ahar rātre sarvasya janimataḥ paricchedake satī na etam tarataḥ
translated: And what kind of a bridge is it? He says: This bridge, the Self, the day and night, which delimit all that is born, do not cross over.

original: yathānye saṃsāriṇaḥ kālenāhorātrādilakṣaṇena paricchedyā na tathāyaṃ kālaparicchedya ityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā anye saṃsāriṇaḥ kālena ahar rātra ādi lakṣaṇena paricchedyāḥ na tathā ayam kāla paricchedyaḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that, unlike other transmigrators who are delimited by time characterized by day and night, etc., this [Self] is not to be delimited by time.

analyzed: yasmāt arvāk saṃvatsaraḥ hobhiḥ parivartate iti śruti antarāt
translated: For it is said in another scriptural passage: The year turns back by days.

original: ata evainaṃ na jarā tarati na prāpnoti /
analyzed: atas eva enam na jarā tarati na prāpnoti
translated: For this very reason, old age does not cross over it, does not reach it.

original: tathā na mṛtyurna śoko na sukṛtaṃ na dṛṣkṛtaṃ sukṛtaduṣkṛte dharmādharmai /
analyzed: tathā na mṛtyuḥ na śokaḥ na sukṛtam na dṛṣkṛtam sukṛta duṣkṛte dharma adharmaiḥ
translated: Similarly, death, grief, good deeds, and bad deeds - good and bad deeds, i.e., dharma and adharma -

analyzed: prāptiḥ atra taraṇa śabdena abhipretā na atikramaṇam
translated: do not reach it. The idea is that reaching is meant by the word crossing over, not going beyond.

analyzed: kāraṇam hi ātmā
translated: For the Self is the cause.

original: na śakyaṃ hi kāraṇātikramaṇaṃ kartuṃ kāryeṇa /
analyzed: na śakyam hi kāraṇa atikramaṇam kartum kāryeṇa
translated: For it is not possible for an effect to go beyond its cause.

analyzed: ahar rātra ādi ca sarvam sataḥ kāryam
translated: And all this, such as day and night, is an effect of the existent [Self].

analyzed: anyena hi anyasya prāptiḥ atikramaṇam vā kriyeta
translated: For the reaching or going beyond of one thing by another is done.

analyzed: na tu tena eva tasya
translated: But not by that very [thing] of that [thing].

analyzed: na hi ghaṭena mṛd prāpyate tikramyate vā
translated: For a pot is not reached or gone beyond by clay.

original: yadyapi pūrvaṃ ya ātmāpahatapāpmetyādinā pāpmādipratiṣedha ukta eva tathāpīhāyaṃ viśeṣo na taratīti prāptiviṣayatvaṃ pratiṣidhyate /
analyzed: yadi api pūrvam yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā ityādinā pāpma ādi pratiṣedhaḥ uktaḥ eva tathā api iha ayam viśeṣaḥ na tarati iti prāpti viṣaya tvam pratiṣidhyate
translated: Although the negation of sin, etc. has already been stated before by the Self which is free from sin, etc., still here this is the difference: the state of being the object of attainment is denied by he does not cross over.

analyzed: tatra viśeṣeṇa jarā ādi abhāva mātram uktam
translated: There, in the previous statement, only the mere absence of old age, etc. was mentioned.

original: ahorātrādyā uktā anuktāścānye sarve pāpmāna ucyante 'to 'smādātmanaḥ setornivartante 'prāpyaivetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: ahar rātra ādyāḥ uktāḥ anuktāḥ ca anye sarve pāpmānaḥ ucyante smāt ātmanaḥ setoḥ nivartante prāpya eva iti arthaḥ
translated: All the sins mentioned and unmentioned, such as day and night, etc., are said to be sin. Therefore, from this Self, which is a dam, they turn back, i.e., they do not reach it.

original: apahatapāpmā hyeṣa brahmaiva loko brahmaloka uktaḥ //
analyzed: apahata pāpmā hi eṣa brahma eva lokaḥ brahma lokaḥ uktaḥ
translated: For this world of Brahman is said to be the world of Brahman, which is free from sin and is Brahman itself.

original: tasmād vā etaṃ setuṃ tīrtvā andhaḥ sann anandho bhavati /🔽viddhaḥ sann aviddho bhavati /
analyzed: tasmāt vai etam setum tīrtvā andhaḥ san an andhaḥ bhavati  viddhaḥ san a viddhaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, having crossed over this dam, he, being blind, becomes not blind.🔽Being pierced, he becomes not pierced.

analyzed: upatāpī san an upatāpī bhavati
translated: Being afflicted, he becomes not afflicted.

original: tasmād vā etaṃ setuṃ tīrtvā api naktam ahar evābhiniṣpadyate /
analyzed: tasmāt vai etam setum tīrtvā api naktam ahar eva abhiniṣpadyate
translated: Therefore, having crossed over this dam, even at night, the day manifests itself.

original: sakṛd vibhāto hy evaiṣa brahmalokaḥ //🔽yasmācca pāpmakārya māndhyādi śarīravataḥ syānna tvaśarīrasya tasmādvā etamātmānaṃ setuṃ tīrvā prāpyānandho bhavati dehavattve
analyzed: sakṛt vibhātaḥ hi eva eṣa brahma lokaḥ  yasmāt ca pāpma kārya māndhya ādi śarīravataḥ syāt na tu aśarīrasya tasmāt vai etam ātmānam setum tīḥ vā prāpya an andhaḥ bhavati dehavat tve
translated: For this world of Brahman is indeed always illuminated.

analyzed: pūrvam andhaḥ pi san
translated: And because the effects of sin, such as blindness, would belong to one who has a body, but not to one who is bodiless, therefore, having reached this Self, which is a dam, he becomes not blind, even though he was blind before, when he had a body.

original: tatā viddhaḥ sandehavattve sa dehaviyoge setuṃ tīrtvā prāpyānandho bhavati dehavattve pūrvamandho 'pi san /
analyzed: tatā viddhaḥ sandehavat tve sa deha viyoge setum tīrtvā prāpya anandhaḥ bhavati dehavat tve pūrvam andhaḥ san
translated: Thus, one who is pierced with doubt, on separation from the body, having crossed the bridge, attains the state of being not pierced, even if he was blind before.

original: tathā viddhaḥ sandehavattve sa dehaviyogo setuṃ prāpyāviddho bhavati /
analyzed: tathā viddhaḥ sandehavat tve sa setum prāpya āviddhaḥ bhavati
translated: Similarly, one who is pierced with doubt, on separation from the body, having reached the bridge, becomes not pierced.

analyzed: tathā upatāpī roga ādi upatāpavān san anupatāpī bhavati
translated: Similarly, one who is afflicted by disease and other afflictions becomes free from affliction.

original: kiñca yasmādahorātre na staḥ setau tasmādvā etaṃ setuṃ tīrtvā prāpya naktamapi tamorūpaṃ rātrirapi sarvamaharevābhiniṣpadyate /
analyzed: kiñca yasmāt ahar rātre na staḥ setau tasmāt vai etam setum tīrtvā prāpya naktam api tamaḥ rūpam rātriḥ api sarvam ahar eva abhiniṣpadyate
translated: Moreover, since there is no day and night on the bridge, therefore, having crossed that bridge and reached it, even the night in the form of darkness becomes only day.

original: vijñaptyātmajyotiḥ svarūpamaharivāhaḥ sadaikarūpaṃ viduṣaḥ saṃpadyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vijñapti ātma jyotiḥ sva rūpam aharivāhaḥ sadā eka rūpam viduṣaḥ saṃpadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that for the wise one, the self-luminous nature of consciousness, always of the same form as the day, becomes always manifest.

original: sakṛdvibhātaḥ sadā vibhātaḥ sadaikarūpaḥ svena rūpeṇaiṣa brahmalokaḥ //
analyzed: sakṛt vibhātaḥ sadā vibhātaḥ sadā ekarūpaḥ svena rūpeṇa eṣa brahma lokaḥ
translated: This Brahmaloka shines forth once and always shines forth, always of the same form with its own nature.

original: tad ya evaitaṃ brahmalokaṃ brahmacaryeṇānuvindanti teṣām evaiṣa brahmalokaḥ /
analyzed: tat ye eva etam brahma lokam brahmacaryeṇa anuvindanti teṣām eva eṣa brahma lokaḥ
translated: Those who find this Brahmaloka through celibacy, for them this is the Brahmaloka.

analyzed: teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati
translated: For them there is freedom to go as they wish in all the worlds.

original: tattatraivaṃ satyetaṃ yathoktaṃ brahmalokaṃ brahmacaryeṇa srīviṣayatṛṣṇātyāgena
analyzed: tat tatra evam satī etam yathā uktam brahma lokam brahmacaryeṇa srī viṣaya tṛṣṇā tyāgena
translated: Thus, when this is so, they who, by celibacy, by renouncing the thirst for sensual objects,🔽find, i.e., realize in their own experience, this Brahman-world as described, according to the teachings of the scriptures and the teacher,

analyzed: śāsra ācārya upadeśam anuvindanti sva ātma saṃvedya tām āpādayanti ye teṣām eva brahmacarya sādhanavatām
translated: for them alone who possess the means of celibacy,

analyzed: brahma vidām eṣa brahma lokaḥ na anyeṣām srī viṣaya saṃparka jāta tṛṣṇānām brahma vidām api iti arthaḥ
translated: for the knowers of Brahman, this is the Brahman-world, not for others who have generated thirst through contact with sensual objects, even though they may be knowers of Brahman. This is the meaning.

analyzed: teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati iti ukta artham
translated: It has been said that for them there is freedom to go to all the worlds as they please.

analyzed: tasmāt paramam etat sādhanam brahmacaryam brahma vidām iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, celibacy is the highest means for the knowers of Brahman - this is the idea.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya caturthaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth section of the eighth chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha yad yajña ity ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat /
analyzed: atha yat yajñaḥ iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, what they call sacrifice, that is indeed celibacy.

original: brahmacaryeṇa hy eva yo jñātā taṃ vindate /
analyzed: brahmacaryeṇa hi eva yaḥ jñātā tam vindate
translated: For by celibacy one finds the knower.

original: atha yad iṣṭam ity ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat /
analyzed: atha yat iṣṭam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, what they call worship, that is indeed celibacy.

analyzed: brahmacaryeṇa hi eva iṣṭvā ātmānam anuvindate
translated: For by celibacy, having worshipped, one finds the self.

original: ya ātmā setutvādiguṇaiḥ stutastatprāptaye jñānasahakārisādhanāntaraṃ brahmacaryākhyaṃ vidātavyamityāha /
analyzed: yaḥ ātmā setu tva ādi guṇaiḥ stutaḥ tad prāptaye jñāna sahakāri sādhana antaram brahmacarya ākhyam vidātavyam iti āha
translated: The Self, which has been praised for its qualities of being a bridge, etc., in order to attain that, another means, called celibacy, which is a co-operating factor with knowledge, is to be known.

original: yajñādibhiśca tatstauti kartavyārtham atha yadyajña ityācakṣate loke paramapuruṣārthasādhanaṃ kathayanti śiṣṭāstadbrahmacaryameva /
analyzed: yajña ādibhiḥ ca tat stauti kartavya artham atha yat yajñaḥ iti ācakṣate loke parama puruṣa artha sādhanam kathayanti śiṣṭāḥ tat brahmacaryam eva
translated: And it praises that with sacrifices, etc., for the purpose of being done. Now, if they call it a sacrifice in the world, the cultured ones say it is the means of attaining the highest human goal, that is celibacy itself.

original: yajñasyāpi yatphalaṃ tadbrahmacaryavāllaṃbhate 'to yajño 'pi brahmacaryaṃ bhavati pratipattavyam /
analyzed: yajñasya api yat phalam tat brahmacaryavān laṃbhate brahmacaryam bhavati pratipattavyam
translated: One who practices celibacy obtains the fruit of the sacrifice also, therefore the sacrifice should also be understood to be celibacy.

original: kathaṃ brahmacaryaṃ yajña ityāhabrahmacaryeṇaiva hi yasmādyo jñātāsa taṃ brahmalokaṃ yajñasyāpi pāramparyeṇa phalabhūtaṃ vindate labhate tato
analyzed: katham brahmacaryam yajñaḥ iti āha brahmacaryeṇa eva hi yasmāt yaḥ jñātā āsa tam brahma lokam yajñasya api pāramparyeṇa phala bhūtam vindate labhate
translated: How is celibacy a sacrifice? It is said: because by celibacy alone one who knows finds that world of Brahman, which is indirectly the fruit of the sacrifice.

analyzed: yajñaḥ brahmacaryam eva iti  yaḥ jñātā iti akṣara anuvṛtteḥ yajñaḥ brahmacaryam eva
translated: Therefore the sacrifice is also celibacy itself.🔽The word who is repeated. The sacrifice is celibacy itself.

analyzed: atha yat iṣṭam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, if they call it a sacrifice, that is celibacy itself.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: brahmacaryeṇaiva sādhanena tamīśvaramiṣṭvā pūjayitvāthavaiṣaṇāmātmaviṣayāṃ kṛtvā tamātmānamanuvindate /
analyzed: brahmacaryeṇa eva sādhanena tam īśvaram iṣṭvā pūjayitvā athavā eṣaṇām ātma viṣayām kṛtvā tam ātmānam anuvindate
translated: By the means of Brahmacharya alone, having worshipped, having honoured that Lord, or having made the desire for the Self, he finds that Self.

analyzed: eṣaṇā ādiṣṭam api brahmacaryam eva
translated: Even the desire, etc., are Brahmacharya itself.

original: atha yat sattrāyaṇam ity ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat /
analyzed: atha yat sattrāyaṇam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, what they call Sattrayana, that is Brahmacharya itself.

original: brahmacaryeṇa hy eva sata ātmanas trāṇaṃ vindate /
analyzed: brahmacaryeṇa hi eva sataḥ ātmanaḥ trāṇam vindate
translated: For, by Brahmacharya alone, one finds the protection of the existing Self.

original: atha yan maunam ity ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat /
analyzed: atha yat maunam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, what they call Mauna, that is Brahmacharya itself.

analyzed: brahmacaryeṇa hi eva ātmānam anuvidya manute
translated: For, by Brahmacharya alone, having known the Self, one thinks (of it).

original: atha yatsattrāyaṇamityācakṣate brahmacaryameva tattathā sataḥ parasmādātmana ātmanasrāṇaṃ rakṣaṇaṃ brahmacaryasādhanena vindate
analyzed: atha yat sattrāyaṇam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat tathā sataḥ parasmāt ātmanaḥ ātmanaḥ rāṇam rakṣaṇam brahmacarya sādhanena vindate
translated: Now, what they call Sattrayana, that is Brahmacharya itself. Thus, by the means of Brahmacharya, one finds the protection of the existing Self from the Supreme Self.

analyzed: atas sattrāyaṇa śabdam api brahmacaryam eva sat
translated: Therefore, even the word Sattrayana refers to Brahmacharya itself.

original: atha yanmaunamityācakṣate brahmacaryameva tadbrahmacaryeṇaiva sādhanena yuktaḥ sannātmānaṃ śāsrācāryābhyāmanuvidya paścānmanute dhyāyati /
analyzed: atha yat maunam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat brahmacaryeṇa eva sādhanena yuktaḥ san ātmānam śāsra ācāryābhyām anuvidya paścāt manute dhyāyati
translated: Now, what they call Mauna, that is Brahmacharya itself. Being engaged in Brahmacharya alone as the means, having known the Self through scriptures and teachers, one thinks (of it) afterwards, one meditates on it.

analyzed: atas mauna śabdam api brahmacaryam eva
translated: Therefore, even the word Mauna refers to Brahmacharya itself.

original: atha yad anāśakāyanam ity ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat /
analyzed: atha yat anāśakāyanam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, what they call the 'going to the non-perishing', that is indeed celibacy.

original: eṣa hy ātmā na naśyati yaṃ brahmacaryeṇānuvindate /
analyzed: eṣa hi ātmā na naśyati yam brahmacaryeṇa anuvindate
translated: For this Self, which one finds through celibacy, does not perish.

original: atha yad araṇyāyanam ity ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat /
analyzed: atha yat araṇyāyanam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, what they call the 'going to the forest', that is indeed celibacy.

original: tat araś ca ha vai ṇyaś cārṇavau brahmaloke tṛtīyasyām ito divi /
analyzed: tat araḥ ca ha vai ṇyaḥ ca arṇavau brahma loke tṛtīyasyām itas divi
translated: For Ara and Nya are two oceans in the world of Brahman, in the third heaven from here.

analyzed: tat airaṃmadīyam saraḥ
translated: That is the lake of Airāvata.

analyzed: tat aśvatthaḥ somasavanaḥ
translated: That is the Aśvattha tree, the Soma-presser.

original: tad aparājitā pūr brahmaṇaḥ prabhuvimitaṃ hiraṇmayam //🔽atha yadanāśakāyanamityācakṣate brahmacaryameva tat /
analyzed: tat aparājitā pūḥ brahmaṇaḥ prabhu vimitam hiraṇmayam  atha yat anāśakāyanam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: That is the imperishable, the golden one, measured by the power of Brahman.🔽Now, what they call the 'going to the non-perishing', that is indeed celibacy.

original: yamātmānaṃ brahmacaryeṇānuvindate sa eṣa hyātmā brahmacaryasādhanavato na naśyati tasmādanāśakāyanamapi brahmacaryameva /
analyzed: yam ātmānam brahmacaryeṇa anuvindate saḥ eṣa hi ātmā brahmacarya sādhanavataḥ na naśyati tasmāt anāśaka ayanam api brahmacaryam eva
translated: For the Self which one finds through celibacy, that Self does not perish for one who has attained celibacy. Therefore, the 'going to the non-perishing' is also celibacy.

analyzed: atha yat araṇyāyanam iti ācakṣate brahmacaryam eva tat
translated: Now, what they call the 'going to the forest', that is indeed celibacy.

analyzed: araṇya śabdayoḥ arṇavayoḥ brahmacaryavataḥ yanāt araṇyāyanam brahmacaryam
translated: Because one who practices celibacy goes to the two oceans called Ara and Nya, the 'going to the forest' is celibacy.

analyzed: yaḥ jñānāt yajñaḥ eṣaṇāt iṣṭam satasrāṇāt sattrāyaṇam mananāt maunam anaśanāt anāśaka ayanam araṇyayoḥ gamanāt araṇyāyanam ityādibhiḥ mahadbhiḥ
translated: Because it has been praised by the great means of attaining human goals such as knowledge, ignorance, desire, the desired, the sacrificer, the sacrifice, the protector, the protected, meditation, silence, non-eating, the non-eater, and going to the forest, going to the forest, etc.

original: puruṣārthasādhanaiḥ stutatvādbrahmacaryaṃ paramaṃ jñānasya sahakārikāraṇaṃ sādhanamityato
analyzed: puruṣa artha sādhanaiḥ stuta tvāt brahmacaryam paramam jñānasya sahakāri kāraṇam sādhanam iti atas
translated: Therefore, celibacy is the supreme auxiliary cause of knowledge, a means of attaining the goal.

analyzed: brahma vidā yatnataḥ rakṣaṇīyam iti arthaḥ
translated: Hence, it is the meaning that should be carefully protected by one who knows Brahman.

original: tattatra hi brahmaloke 'raśca ha vai prasiddho ṇyaścārṇavau samudropame vā sarasī
analyzed: tat tatra hi brahma loke raḥ ca ha vai prasiddhaḥ ṇyaḥ ca arṇavau samudra upame vā sarasī
translated: There, in that world of Brahman, there is a sea and a lake, like the ocean.

original: tṛtīyasyāṃ bhuvamantarikṣaṃ cāpekṣya tṛtīyā dyaustasyāṃ tṛtīyasyāmito 'smāllokādārabhya gaṇyamānāyāṃ divi /
analyzed: tṛtīyasyām bhuvam antarikṣam ca apekṣya tṛtīyā dyauḥ tasyām tṛtīyasyām itas smāt lokāt ārabhya gaṇyamānāyām divi
translated: The third heaven, in relation to the third earth and sky, is the heaven of the third heaven, counted from this world.

original: tattatraiva cairamirānnaṃ tanmaya airo maṇḍastena pūrṇamairaṃ madīyaṃ tadupayogināṃ madakaraṃ harṣotpādakaṃ saraḥ /
analyzed: tat tatra eva cairam irā annam tad mayaḥ airaḥ maṇḍaḥ tena pūrṇam airam madīyam tad upayoginām mada karam harṣa utpādakam saraḥ
translated: There, in that very place, is the lake of Airavata, full of that nectar, the lake that produces joy and delight for those who use it.

original: tatraiva cāśvattho vṛkṣaḥ somasavano nāmataḥ somo 'mṛtaṃ tanniḥsravo 'mṛtasrava iti vā /
analyzed: tatra eva ca aśvatthaḥ vṛkṣaḥ somasavanaḥ nāmataḥ somaḥ mṛtam tad niḥsravaḥ mṛta sravaḥ iti vā
translated: And there itself is the tree named Soma-savana, which exudes nectar, or which exudes immortality.

original: tatraiva ca brahmaloke brahmacaryasādhanarahitairbrahmacaryasādhanavadbhyo 'nyairna jīyata ityaparājitā nāma pūḥ purī brahmaṇo hiraṇyagarbhasya
analyzed: tatra eva ca brahma loke brahmacarya sādhana rahitaiḥ brahmacarya sādhanavadbhyaḥ nyaiḥ na jīyate iti aparājitā nāma pūḥ purī brahmaṇaḥ hiraṇyagarbhasya
translated: And in that very world of Brahman, it is not conquered by others who are devoid of the means of celibacy, but by those who have the means of celibacy. Thus, the city is named Aparajita, the city of Brahman Hiranyagarbha.

original: brahmaṇā ca prabhuṇā viśeṣeṇa mitaṃ nirmitaṃ tacca hiraṇmayaṃ sauvarṇaṃ prabhuvimitaṃ maṇḍapamiti vākyaśeṣaḥ //
analyzed: brahmaṇā ca prabhuṇā viśeṣeṇa mitam nirmitam tat ca hiraṇmayam sauvarṇam prabhu vimitam maṇḍapam iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: And that golden, golden, measured, created by the lord Brahman. The rest of the sentence is: The pavilion is measured by the lord.

original: tad ya evaitāv araṃ ca ṇyaṃ cārṇavau brahmaloke brahmacaryeṇānuvindanti teṣām evaiṣa brahmalokaḥ /
analyzed: tat ye eva etau aram ca ṇyam ca arṇavau brahma loke brahmacaryeṇa anuvindanti teṣām eva eṣa brahma lokaḥ
translated: Those who find these two oceans, Ar and Nya, in the world of Brahman by celibacy, for them this is the world of Brahman.

original: teṣāṃ sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavati //🔽tattatra hi brahmaloka etāvarṇavau yāvaraṇyākhyāvuktau brahmacaryeṇa
analyzed: teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati  tat tatra hi brahma loke etau arṇavau yau araṇī ākhyau uktau brahmacaryeṇa
translated: For them there is freedom to go to all the worlds as they wish.🔽For there, in that world of Brahman, these two oceans named Ar and Nya are found by those who have celibacy

original: sādhanenānuvindanti ye teṣāmevaiṣa yo vyākhyāto brahmalokasteṣāṃ ca brahmacaryasādhavanatāṃ
analyzed: sādhanena anuvindanti ye teṣām eva eṣa yaḥ vyākhyātaḥ brahma lokaḥ teṣām ca brahmacarya sādhavana tām
translated: as a means. For them, this world of Brahman, which has been explained, is theirs. And for those who have celibacy as a means

analyzed: brahma vidām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati
translated: and who know Brahman, there is freedom to go to all the worlds as they wish.

analyzed: na anyeṣām abrahmacarya parāṇām bāhya viṣaya āsakta buddhīnām kadācid api iti arthaḥ
translated: Not for others who are devoted to non-celibacy and whose minds are attached to external objects, ever.

original: nanvatra tvamindrastvaṃ yamastvaṃ varuṇa ityādibhiryathā kaścitstūyate mahārha evamiṣṭādibhiḥ🔽śabdairna stryādiviṣayatṛṣṇānivṛttimātraṃ stutyarhaṃ kiṃ tarhi jñānasya mokṣasādhanatvāttadeveṣṭādibhiḥ stūyata iti kecit / na /
analyzed: nanu atra tvam indraḥ tvam yamaḥ tvam varuṇaḥ ityādibhiḥ yathā kaścid stūyate mahārhaḥ evam iṣṭa ādibhiḥ  śabdaiḥ na strī ādi viṣaya tṛṣṇā nivṛtti mātram stuti arham kim tarhi jñānasya mokṣa sādhana tvāt tat eva iṣṭa ādibhiḥ stūyate iti kecid na
translated: But some people say: Just as a person is praised by such expressions as 'You are Indra,' 'You are Yama,' 'You are Varuna,' etc., in the same way, by the words 'desired' etc.,🔽it is not merely the cessation of craving for women etc. that is worthy of praise, but rather that very knowledge is praised by 'desired' etc., because it is the means of attaining liberation. No.

analyzed: strī ādi bāhya viṣaya tṛṣṇā apahṛta cittānām pratyagātma viveka vijñāna anupapatteḥ
translated: Because for those whose minds are carried away by craving for external objects like women etc., the knowledge of discriminating the inner self is not possible.

analyzed: parāñci khāni vyatṛṇat svayaṃbhūḥ tasmāt parāṅ paśyati na antarātma nitya ādi śruti smṛti śatebhyaḥ
translated: From hundreds of Vedic texts and Smritis such as The Self-Existent One has cut out the external doors, therefore one sees externally, not internally, etc.

analyzed: jñāna sahakāri kāraṇam strī ādi viṣaya tṛṣṇā nivṛtti sādhanam vidhātavyam eva iti yuktā eva tad stutiḥ
translated: The praise of that (cessation of craving) is indeed proper, because the means of attaining the cessation of craving for objects like women etc., which is a contributory cause of knowledge, must be enjoined.

original: nanu ca yajñādibhiḥ stutaṃ brahmacaryamiti yajñādīnāṃ puruṣārthasādhanatvaṃ gamyate /
analyzed: nanu ca yajña ādibhiḥ stutam brahmacaryam iti yajña ādīnām puruṣa artha sādhana tvam gamyate
translated: But it is understood that celibacy is praised by sacrifices etc., so sacrifices etc. are the means of attaining human goals.

analyzed: satyam gamyate
translated: It is indeed understood.

original: na tviha brahmalokaṃ prati yajñādīnāṃ sādhanatvamabhipretya yajñādibhirbrahmacaryaṃ stūyate kiṃ tarhi teṣāṃ prasiddhaṃ puruṣārthasādhanatvamapekṣya
analyzed: na tu iha brahma lokam prati yajña ādīnām sādhanatvam abhipretya yajña ādibhiḥ brahmacaryam stūyate kim tarhi teṣām prasiddham puruṣa artha sādhanatvam apekṣya
translated: But here, the Brahmacarya is not praised by sacrifices etc. with the idea that sacrifices etc. are the means of attaining the world of Brahman. Rather, it is praised with reference to their well-known status as means of attaining the human goal.

original: yathendrādibhī rājā na tu yatrendrādīnāṃ vyāpārastatraiva rājña iti tadvat /
analyzed: yathā indra ādibhiḥ rājā na tu yatra indra ādīnām vyāpāraḥ tatra eva rājñaḥ iti tadvat
translated: Just as the king is praised by Indra etc., but not where the king is himself engaged in the activities of Indra etc.

original: ya imer'ṇavādayo brāhmalaukikāḥ saṃkalpajāśca pitrādayo bhogāste kiṃ pārthivā āpyāśca yatheha loke dṛśyante taddhadarṇavavṛkṣapūḥsvarṇamaṇḍapānyāhosvinmānasapratyayamātrāṇīti
analyzed: ye imā irṇava ādayaḥ brāhma laukikāḥ saṃkalpa jāḥ ca pitṛ ādayaḥ bhogāḥ te kim pārthivāḥ āpyāḥ ca yathā iha loke dṛśyante tat hat arṇava vṛkṣa pūḥ svarṇa maṇḍapāni āhosvit mānasa pratyaya mātrāṇi iti
translated: These worlds beginning with the golden egg, and the enjoyments of the ancestors etc. born of thought in the world of Brahman, are they earthly and watery as they are seen in this world, like the golden egg, tree, pond, and pavilion? Or are they mere mental concepts?

original: kiñcātaḥ / yadi pārthivā āpyāśca sthūlāḥ syurhṛdyākāśe samādhānānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: kiñca atas yadi pārthivāḥ āpyāḥ ca sthūlāḥ syuḥ hṛdi ākāśe samādhāna anupapattiḥ
translated: What follows from this? If they were gross, earthly and watery, it would be impossible to place them in the space of the heart.

original: purāṇe camanomayāni brahmaloke śarīrādīnīti vākyaṃ virudhyeta /
analyzed: purāṇe camanaḥ mayāni brahma loke śarīra ādīni iti vākyam virudhyeta
translated: And the statement in the Purana that the bodies etc. in the world of Brahman are made of mind would be contradicted.

analyzed: aśoka mahimam ityādyāḥ ca śrutayaḥ
translated: And the Shrutis beginning with Ashokamahita would be contradicted.

original: nanusamudrāḥ saritaḥ sarāṃsi vāpyaḥ kūpā yajñā vedā mantrādayaśca mūrtimanto brahmāṇamupatiṣṭhantaiti mānasatvai virudhyeta purāṇasmṛtiḥ
analyzed: nanu samudrāḥ saritaḥ sarāṃsi vāpyaḥ kūpāḥ yajñāḥ vedāḥ mantra ādayaḥ ca mūrtimantaḥ brahmāṇam upatiṣṭhante eti mānasa tvaiḥ virudhyeta purāṇa smṛtiḥ
translated: But the Purāṇa Smṛti would be contradicted by the fact that the oceans, rivers, lakes, wells, sacrifices, Vedas, Mantras, etc., having forms, worship Brahmā, if they are mental.

analyzed: na
translated: No.🔽🔽

analyzed: mūrtimat tve prasiddha rūpāṇām eva tatra gamana anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for those well-known forms to go there if they have forms.

analyzed: tasmāt prasiddha mūrti vyatirekeṇa sāgara ādīnām mūrti antaram sāgara ādibhiḥ upāttam brahma loka gantṛ
translated: Therefore, the forms of the oceans, etc., other than the well-known forms, which are taken by the oceans, etc., go to the world of Brahmā.

original: kalpanāyāṃ yathāprasiddhā eva mānasya ākāravatyaḥ puṃstryādyā mūrtayo yuktāḥ kalpayituṃ
analyzed: kalpanāyām yathā prasiddhāḥ eva mānasyaḥ ākāravatyaḥ pum strī ādyāḥ mūrtayaḥ yuktāḥ kalpayitum
translated: In the assumption, it is proper to imagine the well-known forms themselves, which have shapes such as male, female, etc., as mental.

analyzed: mānasa deha ānurūpya saṃbandha upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible to connect them with the body of the mind.

original: dṛṣṭā hi mānasya evā'kāravatyaḥ puṃstryādyā mūrtayaḥ svapne /
analyzed: dṛṣṭāḥ hi mānasyaḥ eva ākāravatyaḥ pum strī ādyāḥ mūrtayaḥ svapne
translated: For forms such as male, female, etc., which have shapes, are seen in the mind itself in a dream.

analyzed: nanu tāḥ anṛtāḥ eva
translated: But are they not false?

original: ta ime satyāḥ kāmā iti śrutistathā sati virudhyeta / na /
analyzed: te ime satyāḥ kāmāḥ iti śrutiḥ tathā sati virudhyeta na
translated: If so, the Vedic statement These desires of yours are true would be contradicted. No.

analyzed: mānasa pratyayasya sattva upapatteḥ
translated: Because the existence of mental concepts is possible.

original: mānasā hi pratyayāḥ srīpuruṣādyākārāḥ svapne dṛśyante /
analyzed: mānasāḥ hi pratyayāḥ srī puruṣa ādi ākārāḥ svapne dṛśyante
translated: For mental concepts in the form of female, male, etc., are seen in a dream.

original: nanu jāgradvāsanārūpāḥ svapnadṛśyā na tu tatra stryādayaḥ svapne vidyante /
analyzed: nanu jāgrat vāsanā rūpāḥ svapna dṛśyāḥ na tu tatra strī ādayaḥ svapne vidyante
translated: But the objects of dream-experience are of the nature of the impressions of the waking state, and the women and other things do not exist in the dream.

analyzed: ati alpam idam ucyate
translated: This is said to be very little.

analyzed: jāgrat viṣayāḥ api mānasa pratyaya abhinirvṛttāḥ eva sa dīkṣā abhinirvṛtta tejaḥ banna maya tvāt jāgrat viṣayāṇām
translated: The objects of the waking state are also produced by mental concepts alone, because the objects of the waking state are composed of light, water, and food produced by initiation.

original: saṃkalpamūlā hi lokā iti coktamsamakḷpatāṃ dyāvāpṛthivīityatra /
analyzed: saṃkalpa mūlāḥ hi lokāḥ iti ca uktam samakḷpatām dyāvāpṛthivī iti atra
translated: And it has been said that the worlds have imagination as their root, in the passage Let them imagine heaven and earth.

original: sarvaśrutiṣu ca pratyagātmana utpattiḥ pralayaśca tatraiva sthitiścayathā vā arā nābhauityādinocyate /
analyzed: sarva śrutiṣu ca pratyagātmanaḥ utpattiḥ pralayaḥ ca tatra eva sthitiḥ ca yathā vai arāḥ nābhau ityādinā ucyate
translated: And in all the Upaniṣads, the origin, dissolution, and existence of the inner self are described, as in the passage beginning As the spokes on the hub of a wheel.

original: tasmānmānasānāṃ bāhyānāṃ ca viṣayāṇāmitaretarakāryakāraṇamiṣyata eva bījāṅkuravat /
analyzed: tasmāt mānasānām bāhyānām ca viṣayāṇām itaretara kārya kāraṇam iṣyate eva bīja aṅkura vat
translated: Therefore, it is accepted that the mental and external objects are mutually cause and effect, like a seed and a sprout.

original: yadyapi bāhyā eva mānasā mānasā eva ca bāhyā nānṛtatvaṃ teṣāṃ kadācidapi svātmani bhavati /
analyzed: yadi api bāhyāḥ eva mānasāḥ mānasāḥ eva ca bāhyāḥ na anṛta tvam teṣām kadācid api sva ātmani bhavati
translated: Even though the external are mental and the mental are external, their unreality never occurs in their own nature.

original: nanu svapne dṛṣṭāḥ pratibuddhasyānṛtā bhavanti viṣayāḥ /
analyzed: nanu svapne dṛṣṭāḥ pratibuddhasya anṛtāḥ bhavanti viṣayāḥ
translated: But the objects seen in a dream are false to one who has awakened.

analyzed: satyam eva
translated: This is indeed true.

analyzed: jāgrat bodha apekṣam tu tat anṛta tvam na svatas
translated: But that unreality is in relation to the waking state, not intrinsically.

original: tathā svapnabodhāpekṣaṃ ca jāgraddṛṣṭaviṣayānṛtatvaṃ na svataḥ /
analyzed: tathā svapna bodha apekṣam ca jāgrat dṛṣṭa viṣaya anṛta tvam na svatas
translated: Similarly, the unreality of the objects seen in the waking state is dependent on the waking state, not inherent in itself.

original: viśeṣākāramātraṃ tu sarveṣāṃ mithyāpratyayanimittamiti vācā'rambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyamanṛtaṃ trīṇi rūpāṇītyeva satyam /
analyzed: viśeṣa ākāra mātram tu sarveṣām mithyā pratyaya nimittam iti vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam anṛtam trīṇi rūpāṇi iti eva satyam
translated: But the mere form of particulars is the cause of all false cognitions. Name is a verbal designation, unreal. The three forms are alone real.

original: tānyapyākāraviśeṣato 'nṛtaṃ svataḥ sanmātrarūpatayā satyam prāksadātmapratibodhātsvaviṣaye 'pi sarvaṃ styameva svapnadṛśyā iveti na kaścidvirodhaḥ
analyzed: tāni api ākāra viśeṣataḥ svatas sat mātra rūpatayā satyam prāk sat ātma pratibodhāt sva viṣaye sarvam styam eva svapna dṛśyāḥ iva iti na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: Even those are unreal from the point of view of particular forms, but real from the point of view of mere existence, as before the realization of the Self as real, everything is real even in one's own experience, like the objects seen in a dream. There is no contradiction at all.

original: tasmānmānasā eva brāhmalaukikā araṇyādayaḥ pitrādayaḥ kāmāḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt mānasāḥ eva brāhma laukikāḥ araṇya ādayaḥ pitṛ ādayaḥ kāmāḥ
translated: Therefore, the Brahmic worlds, forests, etc., the desires for father, etc., are mental only.

analyzed: bāhya viṣaya bhoga vat aśuddhi rahita tvāt śuddha sattva saṃkalpa janyāḥ iti niratiśaya sukhāḥ satyāḥ ca īśvarāṇām bhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: Being devoid of impurity like the enjoyment of external objects, they are produced by the pure thoughts of pure beings. Thus they are of unsurpassed happiness and are true for the lords. This is the meaning.

original: satsatyātmapratibodhe 'pi rajjvāmiva kalpitāḥ sarpādayaḥ sadātmasvarūpatāmeva pratipadyanta iti sadātmanā satyā eva bhavanti //
analyzed: sat satya ātma pratibodhe rajjvām iva kalpitāḥ sarpa ādayaḥ sat ātma svarūpa tām eva pratipadyante iti sat ātmanā satyāḥ eva bhavanti
translated: Even after the realization of the Self as real, the imagined serpents in a rope attain the nature of the real Self itself. Thus they become true only as the real Self.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya pañcamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifth section in the eighth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: atha yā etā hṛdayasya nāḍyas tāḥ piṅgalasyāṇimnas tiṣṭhanti śuklasya nīlasya pītasya lohitasyeti /
analyzed: atha yāḥ etāḥ hṛdayasya nāḍyaḥ tāḥ piṅgalasya aṇimnaḥ tiṣṭhanti śuklasya nīlasya pītasya lohitasya iti
translated: Now, those channels of the heart stand in the subtle essence of the tawny, the white, the blue, the yellow, and the red.

original: asau vādityaḥ piṅgala eṣa śukla eṣa nīla eṣa pīta eṣa lohitaḥ //
analyzed: asau vā ādityaḥ piṅgalaḥ eṣa śuklaḥ eṣa nīlaḥ eṣa pītaḥ eṣa lohitaḥ
translated: This sun is tawny, this is white, this is blue, this is yellow, this is red.

analyzed: yaḥ tu hṛdaya puṇḍarīka gatam yathā ukta guṇa viśiṣṭam brahma brahmacarya ādi sādhana saṃpannaḥ tyakta bāhya viṣaya anṛta tṛṣṇaḥ
translated: Now, for one who, endowed with the means such as celibacy, worships the Brahman endowed with the qualities mentioned, which is located in the lotus of the heart, and who has abandoned external false desires for objects,

original: sannupāste tasyeyaṃ mūrdhanyayā nāḍyā gatirvaktavyeti nāḍīkhaṇḍa ārabhyate atha
analyzed: san upāste tasya iyam mūrdhanyayā nāḍyāḥ gatiḥ vaktavyā iti nāḍīkhaṇḍaḥ ārabhyate atha
translated: it is to be stated that his path is through the channel at the top of the head. Thus, the section on the channels begins. Now,

original: yā etā vakṣyamāṇā hṛdayasya puṇḍarīkākārasya brahmopāsanasthānasya saṃbandhinyo nāḍyo🔽hṛdayamāṃsapiṇḍātsarvato viniḥsṛtā ādityamaṇḍalādiva raśmayastāścaitāḥ piṅgalasya
analyzed: yāḥ etāḥ vakṣyamāṇāḥ hṛdayasya puṇḍarīka ākārasya brahma upāsana sthānasya saṃbandhinyaḥ nāḍyaḥ  hṛdaya māṃsa piṇḍāt sarvatas viniḥsṛtāḥ āditya maṇḍalāt iva raśmayaḥ tāḥ ca etāḥ piṅgalasya
translated: those channels which will be mentioned, which are connected with the heart, which is shaped like a lotus and is the place of meditation on Brahman,🔽emerge from the fleshy lump of the heart in all directions, like rays from the orb of the sun. And those channels stand, that is, exist, in the form of the subtle essence, which is distinguished by the particular color tawny,

original: varṇaviśeṣaviśiṣṭasyāṇimnaḥ sūkṣmarasasya rasena pūrṇāstadākārā eva tiṣṭhanti vartanta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: varṇa viśeṣa viśiṣṭasya aṇimnaḥ sūkṣma rasasya rasena pūrṇāḥ tad ākārāḥ eva tiṣṭhanti vartante iti arthaḥ
translated: filled with the essence, which is the essence of taste.

original: tathā śuklasya nīlasya pītasya lohitasya ca rasasya pūrṇā iti sarvatrādhyāhāryam /
analyzed: tathā śuklasya nīlasya pītasya lohitasya ca rasasya pūrṇāḥ iti sarvatra adhyāhāryam
translated: Similarly, it should be supplied everywhere that they are filled with the essence of white, blue, yellow, and red.

original: saureṇa tejasā pittākhyena pākābhinirvṛttena kaphenālpena saṃparkātpiṅgalaṃ bhavati sauraṃ tejaḥ pittākhyām tadeva ca vātabhūyastvānnīlaṃ bhavati
analyzed: saureṇa tejasā pitta ākhyena pāka abhinirvṛttena kaphena alpena saṃparkāt piṅgalam bhavati sauram tejaḥ pitta ākhyām tat eva ca vāta bhūyaḥ tvāt nīlam bhavati
translated: By the contact of the solar heat called bile, which is produced by digestion, with a small amount of phlegm, it becomes tawny. The solar heat is called bile. That itself becomes blue due to an excess of wind.

analyzed: tat eva ca kapha bhūyaḥ tvāt śuklam  kaphena sama tāyām pītam
translated: And that itself becomes white due to an excess of phlegm.🔽It is yellow when equal to phlegm.

analyzed: śoṇita bāhulyena lohitam
translated: It is red due to an abundance of blood.

analyzed: vaidyakāt vā varṇa viśeṣāḥ anveṣṭavyāḥ katham bhavanti iti
translated: Or the specific colors should be sought from medical texts, as to how they occur.

analyzed: śrutiḥ tu āha āditya saṃbandhāt eva tat tejasaḥ nāḍīṣu anugatasya ete varṇa viśeṣāḥ iti
translated: But the Śruti says that these specific colors of that light which follows in the channels is due to its connection with the sun alone.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

original: asau vā ādityaḥ piṅgalo varṇata eṣa ādityaḥ śuklo 'pyeṣa nīla eṣa pīta eṣa lohita āditya eva //
analyzed: asau vai ādityaḥ piṅgalaḥ varṇataḥ eṣaḥ ādityaḥ śuklaḥ u pi eṣa nīlaḥ eṣa pītaḥ eṣa lohitaḥ ādityaḥ eva
translated: This sun is tawny in color. This sun is white. This is blue. This is yellow. This is red. The sun itself.

original: tad yathā mahāpatha ātata ubhau grāmau gacchatīmaṃ cāmuṃ caivam evaitā ādityasya raśmaya ubhau lokau gacchantīmaṃ cāmuṃ ca /
analyzed: tat yathā mahā pathaḥ ātataḥ ubhau grāmau gacchati imam ca amum ca evam eva etāḥ ādityasya raśmayaḥ ubhau lokau gacchanti imam ca amum ca
translated: Just as a great road extends to both villages, to this one and to that one, in the same way, these rays of the sun go to both worlds, to this one and to that one.

original: amuṣmād ādityāt pratāyante tā āsu nāḍīṣu sṛptāḥ /
analyzed: amuṣmāt ādityāt pratāyante tāḥ āsu nāḍīṣu sṛptāḥ
translated: From that sun they spread out, and enter those channels.

original: ābhyo nāḍībhyaḥ pratāyante te 'muṣminn āditye sṛptāḥ //
analyzed: ābhyaḥ nāḍībhyaḥ pratāyante te muṣmin āditye sṛptāḥ
translated: From those channels they spread out, and enter that sun.

original: tasyādhyātmaṃ nāḍībhiḥ kathaṃ saṃbandha ityatra dṛṣṭāntamāhatattatra
analyzed: tasya adhyātmam nāḍībhiḥ katham saṃbandhaḥ iti atra dṛṣṭāntam āha tat tatra
translated: How is it connected with the channels internally? Here he gives an example: That there

original: yathā loke mahānvistīrṇaḥ panthā mahāpatha ātato vyāpta ubhau gacchatīmaṃ ca saṃnihitamamuṃ
analyzed: yathā loke mahān vistīrṇaḥ panthāḥ mahā pathaḥ ātataḥ vyāptaḥ ubhau gacchati imam ca saṃnihitam amum
translated: Just as in the world, a great, extensive path is a great path, extended, both go to this nearby and that

original: ca viprakṛṣṭaṃ dūrasthamevaṃ yathā dṛṣṭānto mahāpatha ubhau grāmau praviṣṭa evamevaitā
analyzed: ca viprakṛṣṭam dūra stham evam yathā dṛṣṭāntaḥ mahāpathaḥ ubhau grāmau praviṣṭaḥ evam eva etā
translated: distant, far away, just as the example is a great path, both villages are entered, just so

original: ādityasya raśmaya ubhau lokāvamuṃ cā'dityamaṇḍalamimaṃ ca puruṣaṃ gacchantyubhayatra praviṣṭāḥ /
analyzed: ādityasya raśmayaḥ ubhau lokau amum ca āditya maṇḍalam imam ca puruṣam gacchanti ubhayatra praviṣṭāḥ
translated: these rays of the sun go to both worlds, that sun-disk and this person, they enter both places.

analyzed: yathā mahā pathaḥ
translated: Like a great path.

original: katham /🔽amuṣmādādityamaṇḍalātpratāyante saṃtatā bhavanti /🔽tā adhyātmamāsu piṅgalādivarṇāsu yathoktāsu nāḍīṣu sṛptā gatāḥ praviṣṭā ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: katham  amuṣmāt āditya maṇḍalāt pratāyante saṃtatāḥ bhavanti  tāḥ adhyātmamāsu piṅgala ādi varṇāsu yathā uktāsu nāḍīṣu sṛptāḥ gatāḥ praviṣṭāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: How?🔽From that sun-disk they spread out, become continuous.🔽Those, internally, enter the mentioned channels such as the yellow one, the meaning is they go, they enter.

original: ābhyo nāḍībhyaḥ pratāyante pravṛttāḥ santānabhūtāḥ satyaste 'muṣmin /
analyzed: ābhyaḥ nāḍībhyaḥ pratāyante pravṛttāḥ santāna bhūtāḥ satyaḥ te muṣmin
translated: From those channels they spread out, become continuous, being so, they enter that.

analyzed: raśmīnām ubhaya liṅga tvāt te iti ucyante
translated: They are called rays because they have both meanings.

original: tad yatraitat suptaḥ samastaḥ saṃprasannaḥ svapnaṃ na vijānāti /
analyzed: tat yatra etat suptaḥ samastaḥ saṃprasannaḥ svapnam na vijānāti
translated: When one is deeply asleep, composed, and at peace, not dreaming,

analyzed: āsu tadā nāḍīṣu sṛptaḥ bhavati
translated: then one has entered those channels.

analyzed: tam na kaścana pāpmā spṛśati
translated: No evil touches him.

analyzed: tejasā hi tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati
translated: For then he is endowed with radiance.

original: tattatraivaṃ sati yatra yasminkāla etatsvapanamayaṃ jīvaḥ supto bhavati /
analyzed: tat tatra evam sati yatra yasmin kāle etat svapanam ayam jīvaḥ suptaḥ bhavati
translated: When this happens, when one is asleep, the individual soul is asleep.

analyzed: svāpasya dvi prakāra tvāt viśeṣaṇam samastaḥ iti
translated: Since sleep is of two kinds, the qualification composed is given.

analyzed: upasaṃhṛta sarva karaṇa vṛttiḥ iti etat
translated: This means the functioning of all the sense organs is withdrawn.

analyzed: atas bāhya viṣaya saṃparka janita kāluṣya abhāvāt samyak
translated: Therefore, being free from turbidity generated by contact with external objects, he is well-composed.

analyzed: prasannaḥ saṃprasannaḥ bhavati
translated: He is at peace, fully at peace.

original: ata eva svapnaṃ viṣayākārābhāsaṃ mānasaṃ svapnapratyayaṃ na vijānāti nānubhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva svapnam viṣaya ākāra ābhāsam mānasam svapna pratyayam na vijānāti na anubhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: For this very reason, he does not know, does not experience, the dream, which is a mental perception with the form of an object.

original: yadaivaṃ supto bhavatyāsu sauratejaḥpūrṇāsu yathoktāsu nāḍīṣu tadā sṛptaḥ praviṣṭo nāḍībhirdvārabhūtābhirhṛdayākāśaṃ gato bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yadā evam suptaḥ bhavati āsu saura tejaḥ pūrṇāsu yathā uktāsu nāḍīṣu tadā sṛptaḥ praviṣṭaḥ nāḍībhiḥ dvāra bhūtābhiḥ hṛdaya ākāśam gataḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: When one is asleep in this way, in those channels filled with the sun's radiance as described, then one has entered, has gone into, the space of the heart through the channels which are like doors.

original: na hyanyatra satsaṃpatteḥ svapnādarśanamastīti sāmarthyānnāḍīṣviti saptamī tṛtīyayā pariṇamyate /
analyzed: na hi anyatra sat saṃpatteḥ svapna adarśanam asti iti sāmarthyāt nāḍīṣu iti saptamī tṛtīyayā pariṇamyate
translated: For, apart from the attainment of Being, there is no seeing of dreams. Therefore, by implication, the locative case in 'in the arteries' is changed to the instrumental case.

original: taṃ satā saṃpannaṃ na kaścana na kaścidapi dharmādharmarūpaḥ pāpmā spṛśatīti svarūpāvasthitatvāttadā'tmanaḥ /
analyzed: tam satā saṃpannam na kaścana na kaścid api dharma adharma rūpaḥ pāpmā spṛśati iti sva rūpa avasthita tvāt tad ātmanaḥ
translated: When he has attained Being, no sin in the form of virtue or vice touches him, because the Self then abides in its own nature.

original: dehendriyaviśiṣṭaṃ hi sukhaduḥkhakāryapradānena pāpmā spṛśatīti na tu satsaṃpannaṃ svarūpāvasthaṃ kaścidapi pāpmā spraṣṭumutsahate /
analyzed: deha indriya viśiṣṭam hi sukha duḥkha kārya pradānena pāpmā spṛśati iti na tu sat saṃpannam svarūpa avastham kaścid api pāpmā spraṣṭum utsahate
translated: For sin touches one only when one is distinguished by a body and senses, by bestowing the fruits of pleasure and pain, but no sin whatsoever dares to touch one who has attained Being and abides in his own nature.

analyzed: aviṣaya tvāt
translated: Because it has no object.

original: anyo hyanyasya viṣayo bhavati na tvanyatvaṃ kenacitkutaścidapi satsaṃpannasya /
analyzed: anyaḥ hi anyasya viṣayaḥ bhavati na tu anya tvam kenacid kutaścid api sat saṃpannasya
translated: For one thing can be the object of another, but Being, which is attained, is not different from anything at all.

original: svarūpapracyavanaṃ tvātmano jāgratsvapnāvasthāṃ prati gamanaṃ bāhyaviṣayapratibodho
analyzed: sva rūpa pracyavanam tu ātmanaḥ jāgrat svapna avasthām prati gamanam bāhya viṣaya pratibodhaḥ
translated: And we have said that the falling away of the Self from its own nature, its going to the states of waking and dreaming, and the arousal of external objects,

analyzed: vidyā kāma karma bījasya brahma vidyā hutāśā dāha nimittam iti avocāma ṣaṣṭhe eva tat iha api pratyetavyam
translated: are the causes for the burning by the fire of Brahman-knowledge of the seed of ignorance, desire and action. This should be understood here also.

original: yadaivaṃ suptaḥ saureṇa tejasā hi nāḍyantargatena sarvataḥ saṃpanno vyāpto bhavati /
analyzed: yadā evam suptaḥ saureṇa tejasā hi nāḍī antargatena sarvatas saṃpannaḥ vyāptaḥ bhavati
translated: When one is thus asleep, he becomes completely pervaded and filled by the solar radiance within the arteries.

analyzed: atas viśeṣeṇa cakṣuḥ ādi nāḍī dvāraiḥ bāhya viṣaya bhogāya aprasṛtāni karaṇāni asya tadā bhavanti
translated: Therefore, at that time, his organs are not engaged in enjoying external objects through the doors of the channels of the eye etc.

original: tasmādayaṃ karaṇānāṃ nirodhātsvātmanyevāvasthitaḥ svapnaṃ na vijānātīti yuktam //
analyzed: tasmāt ayam karaṇānām nirodhāt sva ātmani eva avasthitaḥ svapnam na vijānāti iti yuktam
translated: Hence, it is proper that he does not perceive dreams, because of the cessation of the organs, remaining in his own Self alone.

analyzed: atha yatra etat a balimānam nītaḥ bhavati
translated: Now, when he is brought to weakness,

original: tam abhita āsīnā āhur jānāsi māṃ jānāsi mām iti /
analyzed: tam abhitas āsīnāḥ āhuḥ jānāsi mām jānāsi mām iti
translated: those sitting around him say, Do you know me? Do you know me?

original: sa yāvad asmāc charīrād anutkrānto bhavati /
analyzed: sa yāvat asmāt śarīrāt an utkrāntaḥ bhavati
translated: As long as he has not departed from this body,

original: tāvaj jānāti //🔽tatraivaṃ satyatha yatra yasminkāle 'balimānamabalabhāvaṃ dehasya rogādinimittaṃ
analyzed: tāvat jānāti  tatra evam sati atha yatra yasmin kāle balimānam abala bhāvam dehasya roga ādi nimittam
translated: he knows.🔽In that case, when, at what time, Devadatta is brought to weakness, to the state of weakness of the body, caused by disease etc.,

original: jarādinimittaṃ vā kṛśībhāvametannayanaṃ nītaḥ prāpito devadatto bhavati mumūrṣaryadā bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: jarā ādi nimittam vā kṛśībhāvam etat nayanam nītaḥ prāpitaḥ devadattaḥ bhavati bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: or caused by old age etc., is made to attain that state of emaciation, when he is about to die, that is the meaning.

original: tamabhitaḥ sarvato veṣṭayitvā'sīnā jñātaya āhurjānāsi māṃ tava putraṃ jānāsi māṃ pitaraṃ cetyādi /
analyzed: tam abhitas sarvatas veṣṭayitvā āsīnāḥ jñātayaḥ āhuḥ jānāsi mām tava putram jānāsi mām pitaram ca ityādi
translated: Those relatives sitting around him on all sides say, Do you know me, your son? Do you know me, your father? and so on.

analyzed: sa mumūrṣuḥ yāvat asmāt śarīrāt an utkrāntaḥ nirgataḥ bhavati tāvat putra ādīn jānāti
translated: As long as he has not departed, not gone out, from this body, he knows his son and so on.

analyzed: atha yatra etat asmāt śarīrāt utkrāmati
translated: Now, when it departs from this body,

analyzed: atha etaiḥ eva raśmibhiḥ ūrdhvam ākramate
translated: then it ascends upwards by those very rays.

original: sa om iti vā hod vā mīyate /
analyzed: saḥ om iti vā ha ud vā mīyate
translated: It goes either by 'Om' or by 'Om'.

original: sa yāvat kṣipyen manas tāvad ādityaṃ gacchati /
analyzed: sa yāvat kṣipyet manaḥ tāvat ādityam gacchati
translated: It goes to the sun as far as the mind can be cast.

original: etad vai khalu lokadvāraṃ viduṣāṃ prapadanaṃ nirodho 'viduṣām //
analyzed: etat vai khalu loka dvāram viduṣām prapadanam nirodhaḥ viduṣām
translated: This indeed is the door to the worlds for the wise, the entrance for the ignorant.

analyzed: atha yatra yadā etat kriyā viśeṣaṇam iti asmāt śarīrāt utkrāmati
translated: Now, when and where it departs from this body, that is a qualification of the action.

original: atha tadaitaireva yathoktābhī raśmibhirūrdhvamākramate yathākarmārjitaṃ lokaṃ pratyavidvān /🔽itarastu vidvānyathoktasādhanasaṃpannaḥ sa omityoṅkāreṇā'tmānaṃ dhyāyanyathāpūrvaṃ vā haiva /
analyzed: atha tadā etaiḥ eva yathā uktābhiḥ raśmibhiḥ ūrdhvam ākramate yathā karma arjitam lokam pratyavidvān  itaraḥ tu vidvān yathā ukta sādhana saṃpannaḥ saḥ om iti oṅkāreṇa ātmānam dhyāyan yathāpūrvam vā ha eva
translated: Then at that time, the ignorant one ascends upwards by those very rays as mentioned, towards the world earned by his actions.🔽But the wise one, endowed with the means as described, meditating on the Self with 'Om', goes either as before or upwards.

analyzed: udvā ūrdhvam vā vidvān ced itaraḥ tiryaṅ vā iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that the other one goes sideways.

analyzed: mīyate pramīyate gacchati iti arthaḥ
translated: It goes, it proceeds, this is the meaning.

original: sa vidvānutkramiṣyanyāvatkṣipyenmano yāvatā kālena manasaḥ kṣepaḥ syāttāvatā kālenā'dityaṃ gacchati prapnoti kṣipraṃ gacchatītyartho na tu
analyzed: sa vidvān utkramiṣyan yāvat kṣipyet manaḥ yāvatā kālena manasaḥ kṣepaḥ syāt tāvatā kālena ādityam gacchati prapnoti kṣipram gacchati iti arthaḥ na tu
translated: That wise one, about to depart, goes to the sun in as much time as the mind can be cast, in as much time as the mind can be cast, he reaches the sun quickly, this is the meaning, but not

analyzed: tāvatā eva kālena iti vivakṣitam
translated: It is meant that in just that much time.

original: kimarthamādityaṃ gacchatītyucyateetadvai khalu prasiddhaṃ brahmalokasya dvāraṃ ya ādityastena dvārabhūtena brahmaloka gacchati vidvān /
analyzed: kimartham ādityam gacchati iti ucyate etat vai khalu prasiddham brahma lokasya dvāram yaḥ ādityaḥ tena dvāra bhūtena brahma loka gacchati vidvān
translated: For what purpose does he go to the sun? It is said: This sun is indeed well-known as the door to the world of Brahman. Through that which is the door, the knower goes to the world of Brahman.

original: ato viduṣāṃ prapadanaṃ prapadyate brahmalokamanena dvāreṇeti prapadanam /
analyzed: atas viduṣām prapadanam prapadyate brahma lokam anena dvāreṇa iti prapadanam
translated: Therefore, the going of the knowers is the going to the world of Brahman through this door.

analyzed: nirodhanam nirodhaḥ u smāt ādityāt a viduṣām bhavati iti nirodhaḥ
translated: The obstruction is the obstruction from this sun for the non-knowers. Thus it is the obstruction.

original: saureṇa tejasā deha eva niruddhāḥ santo mūrdhanyayā nāḍyā notkramanta evetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: saureṇa tejasā dehe eva niruddhāḥ santaḥ mūrdhanyayā nāḍyā na utkramante eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are obstructed in the body itself by the sun's radiance and do not depart through the cranial aperture.

analyzed: viṣvaṅ anyāḥ iti ślokāt
translated: From the verse The others in all directions.

analyzed: tat eṣa ślokaḥ
translated: This is the verse.

original: śataṃ caikā ca hṛdayasya nāḍyas tāsāṃ mūrdhānam abhiniḥsṛtaikā /
analyzed: śatam ca ekā ca hṛdayasya nāḍyaḥ tāsām mūrdhānam abhiniḥsṛtā ekā
translated: There are a hundred and one channels of the heart. Of them, one goes out through the top of the head.

original: tayordhvam āyann amṛtatvam eti viṣvaṅṅ anyā utkramaṇe bhavanty utkramaṇe bhavanti //
analyzed: tayā ūrdhvam āyan amṛta tvam eti viṣvaṅ anyāḥ utkramaṇe bhavanti utkramaṇe bhavanti
translated: Going upwards through that, one attains immortality. The others are for departing, for departing.

analyzed: tat etasmin yathā ukti ṛthe eṣa ślokaḥ mantraḥ bhavati
translated: This verse is a mantra on this aforementioned meaning.

original: śataṃ caikā caikottaraśataṃ nāḍyo hṛdayasya māṃsapiṇḍabhūtasya saṃbandhinyaḥ pradhānato bhavanti /
analyzed: śatam ca ekā ca ekottaraśatam nāḍyaḥ hṛdayasya māṃsa piṇḍa bhūtasya saṃbandhinyaḥ pradhānataḥ bhavanti
translated: And there are one hundred and one nāḍīs connected with the fleshy heart, which are principal.

analyzed: ānantyāt deha nāḍīnām
translated: Because of the infinity of the body's nāḍīs.

analyzed: tāsām ekā mūrdhānam abhiniḥsṛtā vinirgatā tayā ūrdhvam āyan gacchan amṛta tvam amṛta bhāvam eti
translated: Of those, one nāḍī emerges from the head, goes upwards, and he who goes by that attains immortality, the state of being immortal.

analyzed: viṣvak nānā gatayaḥ tiryagvisarpiṇyaḥ ūrdhva gāḥ ca anyāḥ nāḍyaḥ bhavanti saṃsāra gamana dvāra bhūtā
translated: Other nāḍīs go in various directions, horizontally spreading out, and upwards, serving as the doors for going in saṃsāra.

original: na tvamṛtatvāya kiṃ tarhyatkamaṇa evotkrāntyarthameva bhavantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: na tu amṛta tvāya kim tarhi eva utkrānti artham eva bhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: But not for immortality. Rather, they exist only for the purpose of going out, for the purpose of departing. This is the meaning.

analyzed: dvis abhyāsaḥ prakaraṇa samāpti arthaḥ
translated: The repetition twice is for the completion of the section.

analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya ṣaṣṭhaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the sixth section of the eighth chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad

original: ya ātmā apahatapāpmā vijaro vimṛtyur viśoko vijighatso 'pipāsaḥ satyakāmaḥ satyasaṃkalpaḥ so 'nveṣṭavyaḥ sa vijijñāsitavyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā vijaraḥ vimṛtyuḥ viśokaḥ vijighatsaḥ pipāsaḥ satya kāmaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ saḥ nveṣṭavyaḥ sa vijijñāsitavyaḥ
translated: The Self that is free from evil, free from old age, free from death, free from grief, free from hunger and thirst, with true desires, with true resolves, He should be sought, He should be desired to be known.

original: sa sarvāṃś ca lokān āpnoti sarvāṃś ca kāmān yas tam ātmānam anuvidya vijānātīti ha prajāpatir uvāca //
analyzed: sa sarvān ca lokān āpnoti sarvān ca kāmān yaḥ tam ātmānam anuvidya vijānāti iti ha prajāpatiḥ uvāca
translated: He who knows that Self obtains all the worlds and all the desires. Thus did Prajāpati declare.

original: atha ya eṣa saṃprasādo 'smāccharīrātsamutthāya paraṃ jyotirupasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyata eṣa ātmeti hovācaitadamṛtamabhayametadbrahmaityuktam
analyzed: atha yaḥ eṣa saṃprasādaḥ u smāt śarīrāt samutthāya param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate eṣaḥ ātmā iti ha uvāca etat amṛtam abhayam etat brahma eti uktam
translated: Now, as to that tranquillity which, rising from this body, attains to the supreme light, and manifests itself in its own form, that is the Self, he said; that is the immortal, the fearless, that is Brahman, it has been said.

analyzed: tatra kaḥ sau saṃprasādaḥ
translated: What is that tranquillity?

original: kathaṃ vā tasyādhigamo yathā so 'smāccharīrātsavijijñāsitavya iti caiṣa niyamavidhireva nāpūrvavidhiḥ /
analyzed: katham vā tasya adhigamaḥ yathā saḥ smāt śarīrāt sa vijijñāsitavyaḥ iti ca eṣa niyama vidhiḥ eva na apūrva vidhiḥ
translated: Or how is its attainment? So that it may be desired to be known from this body. This is only a restrictive injunction, not an injunction of what is not already known.

analyzed: evam anveṣṭavyaḥ vijijñāsitavyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is to be sought and desired to be known in this way.

analyzed: dṛṣṭārtha tvāt anveṣaṇa vijijñāsanayoḥ
translated: Because seeking and desiring to know have a visible purpose.

original: dṛṣṭārthatvaṃ ca darśayiṣyati nāhamātra bhogyaṃ paśyāmītyanenāsakṛt /
analyzed: dṛṣṭārtha tvam ca darśayiṣyati na aham ātra bhogyam paśyāmi iti anena asakṛt
translated: And he will show that the purpose is visible by repeatedly saying, I do not see anything to be enjoyed here.

analyzed: para rūpeṇa ca deha ādi dharbhaiḥ avaganyamānasya ātmanaḥ svarūpa adhigame viparīta adhigama nivṛttiḥ dṛṣṭam
translated: And for the Self which is known through the qualities of the body etc. in another form, the cessation of the knowledge of what is contrary to its own nature is the visible result.

original: phalamiti niyamārthataivāsya vidheryuktā na tvāgnihotrādīnāmibāpūrvavidhitvamiha saṃbhavati //
analyzed: phalam iti niyama artha tā eva asya vidheḥ yuktā na tu ā agnihotra ādīnām iba apūrva vidhi tvam iha saṃbhavati
translated: Therefore, it is proper that this injunction should have only a restrictive meaning, and not the nature of an injunction of what is not already known, as in the case of the Agnihotra etc.

analyzed: tat ha ubhaye deva asurāḥ anububudhire
translated: That indeed was understood by both the gods and the demons.

original: te hocur hanta tam ātmaānam anvecchāmo yam ātmānam anviṣya sarvāṃś ca lokān āpnoti sarvāṃś ca kāmān iti /
analyzed: te ha ūcuḥ hanta tam ātmaānam anvecchāmaḥ yam ātmānam anviṣya sarvān ca lokān āpnoti sarvān ca kāmān iti
translated: They said, 'Let us seek that Self, having sought which one obtains all worlds and all desires.'

analyzed: indraḥ ha eva devānām abhipravavrāja virocanaḥ surāṇām
translated: Indra, indeed, of the gods, and Virocana, of the Asuras,

original: tau hāsaṃvidānāv eva samitpāṇī prajāpatisakāśam ājagmatuḥ //
analyzed: tau ha a saṃvidānau eva samidh pāṇī prajāpati sakāśam ājagmatuḥ
translated: both of them, not in agreement, with fuel in their hands, approached Prajapati.

analyzed: tat ha ubhaye ityādi ākhyāyikā prayojanam uktam
translated: The purpose of the introductory story beginning with 'that' has been stated.

original: taddha kila prajāpatervacanamubhaye devāsurā devāścāsurāśca devāsurā anu paramparāgataṃ svakarṇagocarāpannamanububudhire 'nubuddhavantaḥ /
analyzed: tat ha kila prajāpateḥ vacanam ubhaye deva asurāḥ devāḥ ca asurāḥ ca deva asurāḥ anu paramparā gatam sva karṇa gocara āpannam anububudhire nubuddhavantaḥ
translated: That, indeed, is the statement of Prajapati which both the gods and the Asuras, the gods and the demons, heard by word of mouth, having come down by tradition, and understood.

original: te caitatprajāpativaco buddhvā kimakurvannityucyatete hocuruktavanto 'nyonyaṃ devāḥ
analyzed: te ca etat prajāpati vacaḥ buddhvā kim akurvan iti ucyate te ha ūcuḥ uktavantaḥ nyonyam devāḥ
translated: And having understood this statement of Prajapati, what did they do? It is said: They said, having spoken to each other, the gods

analyzed: sva pariṣadi asurāḥ ca hanta yadi anumatiḥ bhavatām prajāpatinā uktam tam ātmānam anvicchāmaḥ
translated: in their assembly and the Asuras, 'If you agree, we will seek that Self which Prajapati has spoken of,

original: 'nveṣaṇaṃ kurmo yamātmānamanviṣya sarvāṃśca lokānāpnoti sarvāśca kāmānityuktvendro
analyzed: nveṣaṇam kurmaḥ yam ātmānam anviṣya sarvān ca lokān āpnoti sarvāḥ ca kāmān iti uktvā indraḥ
translated: we will undertake the search, having sought which Self one obtains all worlds and all desires.' Having said this, Indra,

original: haiva rājaiva svayaṃ devānāmitarāndevāṃśca bhogaparicchadaṃ ca sarvaṃ sthāpayitvā
analyzed: ha eva rājā eva svayam devānām itarān devān ca bhoga paricchadam ca sarvam sthāpayitvā
translated: The king himself, having set aside all other gods and all the enjoyments and belongings,

analyzed: śarīra mātreṇa eva prajāpatim pratyabhipravavrāja pragatavān tathā virocano surāṇām
translated: with his body alone went forth to Prajapati. Similarly Virochana to the demons.

analyzed: vinayena guravaḥ bhigantavyāḥ iti etat darśayati
