translated: And they explain the purpose of teaching through the Self in the form of shadow etc.

original: ādāvevocyamāne kila durvijñeyatvātparasyā'tmano 'tyantabāhyaviṣayāsaktacetaso 'tyantasūkṣmavastuśravaṇe vyāmoho mā bhūditi /
analyzed: ādau eva ucyamāne kila durvijñeya tvāt parasya ātmanaḥ tyanta bāhya viṣaya āsakta cetasaḥ tyanta sūkṣma vastu śravaṇe vyāmohaḥ mā bhūt iti
translated: When it is taught at the very beginning, there may be confusion in the mind of one whose mind is attached to extremely external objects upon hearing about the extremely subtle reality, because the supreme Self is indeed difficult to understand.

original: yathā kila dvitīyāyāṃ sūkṣmaṃ candraṃ didarśayiṣurvṛkṣaṃ kañcitpratyakṣamādau darśayati paśyāmumeṣa candra iti /
analyzed: yathā kila dvitīyāyām sūkṣmam candram didarśayiṣuḥ vṛkṣam kañcid pratyakṣam ādau darśayati paśya amum eṣa candraḥ iti
translated: Just as, in order to show the subtle moon in the second month, one first points to a visible tree and says, Look, this is the moon.

original: tato 'nyaṃ tato 'pyanyaṃ girimūrdhānaṃ ca candrasamīpasthaṃ eṣa candra iti tato 'sau candraṃ paśyati /
analyzed: tatas tatas pi anyam girimūrdhānam ca candra samīpa stham eṣa candraḥ iti tatas sau candram paśyati
translated: Then another, then another, and the peak of a mountain near the moon, saying This is the moon, then he sees the moon.

original: evametadya eṣo 'kṣiṇītyādyuktaṃ prajāpatinā tribhiḥ paryāyairna para iti /
analyzed: evam etat yaḥ eṣa u kṣiṇi ityādi uktam prajāpatinā tribhiḥ paryāyaiḥ na paras iti
translated: In the same way, this has been said by Prajapati through three stages, This is the Self within the eye etc., but not the supreme Self.

analyzed: caturthe tu paryāye dehāt martyāt samutthāya aśarīra tām āpannaḥ jyotiḥ svarūpam
translated: But in the fourth stage, having risen from the mortal body and attained a bodiless state, it is the form of light.

original: yasminnuttamapuruṣe stryādibhirjakṣatkrīḍanramamāṇo bhavati sa uttmaḥ puruṣaḥ para ukta iti cā'huḥ /
analyzed: yasmin uttama puruṣe strī ādibhiḥ jakṣat krīḍan ramamāṇaḥ bhavati saḥ uttmaḥ puruṣaḥ paraḥ uktaḥ iti ca āhuḥ
translated: In which the supreme person, eating, playing, and delighting with women etc., that is the supreme person, the supreme one, has been said.

analyzed: satyam ramaṇīyā tāvat iyam vyākhyā śrotum
translated: This is true. This explanation is indeed delightful to hear.

analyzed: na tu arthaḥ sya granthasya evam saṃbhavati
translated: But such a meaning is not possible for this text.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: akṣiṇi puruṣo dṛśyata ityupanyasya śiṣyābhyāṃ chāyātmani gṛhīte tayostadviparītagrahaṇaṃ
analyzed: akṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyate iti upanyasya śiṣyābhyām chāyā ātmani gṛhīte tayoḥ tad viparīta grahaṇam
translated: Having presented the statement The person is seen in the eye, when the disciples grasped the shadow-self, thinking they had grasped the opposite of that,

original: matvā tadapanayāyodaśarāvopanyāsaḥ kiṃ paśyatha iti ca praśnaḥ sādhvalaṅkāropadeśaścānarthakaḥ
analyzed: matvā tad apanayāya uda śarāva upanyāsaḥ kim paśyatha iti ca praśnaḥ sādhu alaṅkāra upadeśaḥ ca anarthakaḥ
translated: the statement of the ten-platter, the question What do you see? and the teaching of good ornaments would be meaningless

original: syāt yadi cchāyātmaiva prajāpatinākṣiṇi dṛśyata ityupadiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: syāt yadi chāyā ātmā eva prajāpatinā akṣiṇi dṛśyate iti upadiṣṭaḥ
translated: if the shadow-self alone were taught by Prajapati as The person is seen in the eye.

original: kiñca yadi svayamupadiṣṭa iti grahaṇasyāpyapanayakāraṇaṃ vaktavyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: kiñca yadi svayam upadiṣṭaḥ iti grahaṇasya api apanaya kāraṇam vaktavyam syāt
translated: Moreover, if it is taught by himself, a reason for the removal of the grasping would have to be stated.

original: svapnasuṣuptātmagrahaṇayorapi tadapanayakāraṇaṃ ca svayaṃ brūyāt na coktaṃtenaṭatena manyāmahe nākṣiṇi cchāyātmā prajāpatinopadiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: svapna suṣupta ātma grahaṇayoḥ api tad apanaya kāraṇam ca svayam brūyāt na ca uktam tena ṭatena manyāmahe na akṣiṇi chāyā ātmā prajāpatinā upadiṣṭaḥ
translated: And he would himself state a reason for the removal of the grasping of the self in dream and deep sleep, but it is not stated. Therefore we think that the shadow-self was not taught by Prajapati in the eye.

original: kiṃ cānyadakṣiṇi draṣṭā ceddṛśyata ityupadiṣṭaḥ syāttata idaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: kim ca anya dakṣiṇi draṣṭā ced dṛśyate iti upadiṣṭaḥ syāt tatas idam yuktam
translated: What else? If the seer in the eye were taught as The person is seen, then this would be appropriate.

original: etaṃ tveva ta ityuktvā svapne 'pi draṣṭurevopadeśaḥ /
analyzed: etam tu eva te iti uktvā svapne draṣṭuḥ eva upadeśaḥ
translated: Having said This very one is yours, the teaching of the seer alone in dream would be appropriate.

analyzed: svapne na draṣṭā upadiṣṭaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the seer is not taught in dream, that is not so.

analyzed: api roditi iva apriya vettā iva iti upadeśāt
translated: Because of the teaching He weeps as if knowing what is unpleasant.

analyzed: na ca draṣṭuḥ anyaḥ kaścid svapne mahīyamānaḥ carati
translated: And no one other than the seer moves about, being honoured in the dream.

original: atrāyaṃ puruṣaḥ svayañjyotiriti nyāyataḥ śrutyantare siddhatvāt /
analyzed: atra ayam puruṣaḥ svayan jyotiḥ iti nyāyataḥ śruti antare siddha tvāt
translated: Here, this person is self-luminous, as is established by reasoning in another Upanisadic text.

original: yadyapi svapne sadhīrbhavati tathāpi na dhīḥ svapnabhogopalabdhiṃ prati karaṇatvaṃ bhajate /
analyzed: yadi api svapne sa dhīḥ bhavati tathā api na dhīḥ svapna bhoga upalabdhim prati karaṇa tvam bhajate
translated: Even though he has cognition in the dream, still the cognition does not serve as an instrument for the perception of the enjoyment in the dream.

original: kiṃ tarhi paṭacitravajjāgradvāsanāśrayā dṛśyaiva dhīrbhavatīti na draṣṭuḥ svayañjyotiṣṭvabādhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: kim tarhi paṭa citra vat jāgrat vāsanā āśrayā dṛśyā eva dhīḥ bhavati iti na draṣṭuḥ svayañjyotiṣṭva bādhaḥ syāt
translated: What then? The cognition, like a picture on a cloth, is only seen as the substratum of the impressions of the waking state. Thus there would be no contradiction of the self-luminosity of the seer.

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: And further,

analyzed: jāgrat svapnyoḥ bhūtāni ca ātmānam ca jānāti imāni bhūtāni ayam aham asmi iti
translated: in the waking and dream states, he knows the elements and himself, 'these are the elements, I am this.'

original: prāptau satyāṃ pratiṣedho yuktaḥ syānnāha khalvayamityādi /
analyzed: prāptau satyām pratiṣedhaḥ yuktaḥ syāt na āha khalu ayam ityādi
translated: When this is attained, the prohibition would be appropriate, 'He indeed is not this,' etc.

original: tathā cetanasyaivāvidyānimittayoḥ śarīratve sati priyāpriyayorapahatirnāstītyuktvā🔽tasyaivāśarīrasya sato vidyāyāṃ satyāṃ saśarīratve prāptayoḥ pratiṣedho yukto 'śarīraṃ
analyzed: tathā cetanasya eva avidyā nimittayoḥ śarīra tve sati priya apriyayoḥ apahatiḥ na asti iti uktvā  tasya eva aśarīrasya sataḥ vidyāyām satyām sa śarīra tve prāptayoḥ pratiṣedhaḥ śarīram
translated: And thus, when the intelligent self alone, due to ignorance, becomes the body, there is no removal of the agreeable and disagreeable. Having said this,

original: vāva santaṃ na priyāpriye spṛśata iti /
analyzed: vāva santam na priya apriye spṛśataḥ iti
translated: when for that very disembodied self, in the state of knowledge, the attainment of embodiment occurs, the prohibition is appropriate, 'The disembodied one, indeed, the agreeable and disagreeable do not touch.'

analyzed: ekaḥ ca ātmā svapna buddhāntayoḥ mahā matsya vat asaṅgaḥ saṃcarati iti śruti antare siddham
translated: And that the one Self, like a great fish, moves on unattached from dream to the waking state, is established by another Vedic text.

original: yaccoktaṃ saṃprasādaḥ śarīrātsamutthāya yasminstryādibhī ramamāṇo bhavati so 'nyaḥ saṃprasādādadhikaraṇanirdiṣṭa uttamaḥ puruṣa iti /
analyzed: yat ca uktam saṃprasādaḥ śarīrāt samutthāya yasmin strī ādibhiḥ ramamāṇaḥ bhavati saḥ nyaḥ saṃprasādāt adhikaraṇa nirdiṣṭaḥ uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ iti
translated: And what has been said, that the person who, rising from the body, enjoys himself with women etc., is the other, the best person, indicated by the word ‘pratiṣṭhā’ (in Chānd.

analyzed: tat api asat
translated: That also is not correct.

original: caturthe 'pi paryāya eta tveva ta iti vacanāt /
analyzed: caturthe pi paryāye eta tu eva te iti vacanāt
translated: Because in the fourth section also, it is said ‘That thou art’ (Chānd.

original: yadi tato 'nyo 'bhipretaḥ syātpūrvavadetaṃ tveva ta iti na brūyānmṛṣā prajāpatiḥ /🔽kiñcānyattejobannādīnāṃ sraṣṭuḥ sataḥ svavikāradehaśuṅge praveśaṃ darśayitvā praviṣṭāya puvastattvamasītyupadeśo mṛṣā prasajyeta /
analyzed: yadi tatas nyaḥ bhipretaḥ syāt pūrvavat etam tu eva te iti na brūyāt mṛṣā prajāpatiḥ  kiñca anyat tejaḥ banna ādīnām sraṣṭuḥ sataḥ sva vikāra deha śuṅge praveśam darśayitvā praviṣṭāya puvaḥ tat tvam asi iti upadeśaḥ mṛṣā prasajyeta
translated: If it were intended to be different from that, Prajāpati would not say falsely ‘That thou art’, as he did before.🔽Moreover, after showing the entry of the existent creator of fire, food etc. into the sprout-like body consisting of its own evolutes, the teaching ‘That thou art’ to the one who has entered would be false.

original: tasmiṃstvaṃ stryādibhī rantā bhaviṣyasīti yukta upadeśo 'bhaviṣyadyadi saṃprasādādanya uttamaḥ puruṣo bhavet /
analyzed: tasmin tvam strī ādibhiḥ rantā bhaviṣyasi iti yuktaḥ upadeśaḥ bhaviṣyat yadi saṃprasādāt anyaḥ uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ bhavet
translated: And the teaching would have been proper if the best person were different from the one who is pleased.

original: tathā bhūmnyahamevetyādiśyā'tmaivedaṃ sarvamiti nopasamahariṣyadyadi bhūmā jīvādanyo 'bhaviṣyat /
analyzed: tathā bhūmni aham eva iti ādiśya ātmā eva idam sarvam iti na upasamahariṣyat yadi bhūmā jīvāt anyaḥ bhaviṣyat
translated: Similarly, after saying ‘I am that bliss’ etc., he would not have concluded with ‘The Self is all this’ if the blissful one were different from the living being.

analyzed: na anyaḥ taḥ sti draṣṭā ityādi śruti antarāt ca
translated: And also from another Vedic text, ‘There is no other seer but he.’

original: sarvaśrutiṣu ca parasminnātmaśabdaprayogo nābhaviṣyatpratyagātmā cetsarvajantūnāṃ para ātmā na bhavettasmādeka evā'tmā prakaraṇī siddhaḥ /
analyzed: sarva śrutiṣu ca parasmin ātma śabda prayogaḥ na abhaviṣyat pratyagātmā ced sarva jantūnām paraḥ ātmā na bhavet tasmāt ekaḥ eva ātmā prakaraṇī siddhaḥ
translated: And if the Supreme Self were not the inner Self of all living beings, then the word ‘Self’ would not be used in all the Vedic texts with reference to the Supreme Self. Therefore, the conclusion is that there is only one Self, as established by the topic.

analyzed: na ca ātmanaḥ saṃsāri tvam
translated: And the Self does not transmigrate.

analyzed: avidyā adhyasta tvāt ātmani saṃsārasya
translated: Because the transmigration of the Self is superimposed by ignorance.

original: na hi rajjuśuktikāgaganādiṣu sarparajatamalādīni mithyājñānādhyastāni teṣāṃ bhavantīti /
analyzed: na hi rajju śuktikā gagana ādiṣu sarpa rajata mala ādīni mithyā jñāna adhyastāni teṣām bhavanti iti
translated: For the snake, silver, and darkness, which are superimposed by false knowledge on the rope, shell, and sky, do not belong to them.

analyzed: etena sa śarīrasya priya apriyayoḥ apahatiḥ na asti iti vyākhyātam
translated: By this, the explanation that ‘there is no removal of the loved and the unloved for one who has a body’ is explained.

analyzed: yat ca sthitam apriya vettā iva iti na apriya vettā eva iti siddham
translated: And it is established that ‘he is not one who knows the unloved’ means ‘he is not one who knows only the unloved.’

analyzed: evam ca sati sarva paryāyeṣu etat amṛta bhayam etat brahma iti prajāpateḥ vacanam
translated: And when this is so, then the statement of Prajapati in all the contexts is true, ‘This is the immortal and fearless, this is Brahman.’

original: yadi vā prajāpaticchadbharūpāyāḥ śrutervacanaṃ satyameva bhavet /
analyzed: yadi vā prajāpati chadbha rūpāyāḥ śruteḥ vacanam satyam eva bhavet
translated: Or it may be the true statement of the Vedic text, which is like Prajapati’s form.

analyzed: na catat kutarka buddhyā mṛṣā kartum yuktam
translated: And it cannot be made false by the intellect of false reasoning.

analyzed: tatas gurutarasya pramāṇa antarasya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because there is no other means of knowledge more authoritative than that.

analyzed: nanu pratyakṣam duḥkha ādi apriya vettṛ tvam avyabhicāri anubhūyate iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the direct perception of the fact of the knower of pain, etc., which is not agreeable, is experienced without fail, we say no.

original: jarādirahito jīrṇo 'haṃ jāto 'hamāyuṣmāngauraḥ kṛṣṇo mṛta ityādipratyakṣānubhavavattadupapatteḥ /
analyzed: jarā ādi rahitaḥ jīrṇaḥ ham jātaḥ ham āyuṣmān gauraḥ kṛṣṇaḥ mṛtaḥ ityādi pratyakṣa anubhava vat tad upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible that the direct perception of the fact of the knower of pain, etc., which is not agreeable, is experienced without fail, just as the direct perception of the fact that one is free from old age, etc., that one is old, that one is born, that one is long-lived, that one is fair, that one is dark, that one is dead, etc., is experienced without fail.

original: sarvamapyetatsatyamiti cedastyevaitadevaṃ duravagamaṃ yena devarājo 'pyudaśarāvādidarśitāvināśayuktirapi mumohaivātra vināśamevāpīto bhavatīti
analyzed: sarvam api etat satyam iti ced asti eva etat evam duravagamam yena devarājaḥ u pi uda śarāva ādi darśita a vināśa yuktiḥ api mumoha eva atra vināśam evā api itas bhavati iti
translated: If it be said that all this is true, we say that this is indeed so, but difficult to understand, by which even the king of the gods, even though shown the doctrine of imperishability by the udana-vessel, etc., was indeed deluded, thinking it goes to destruction itself.

original: tathā virocano mahāprājñaḥ prājāpatyo 'pi dehamātrātmadarśano babhūva /
analyzed: tathā virocanaḥ mahā prājñaḥ prājāpatyaḥ deha mātra ātma darśanaḥ babhūva
translated: Similarly, Virochana, the greatly wise son of Prajapati, had the view of the self as being just the body.

analyzed: tathā indrasya ātma vināśa bhaya sāgare eva vaināśikāḥ nyamajjan
translated: Similarly, the followers of annihilation were drowned in the very ocean of fear of the destruction of the self of Indra.

original: tathā sāṃkhyā draṣṭāraṃ dehādivyatiriktamavagamyāpi tyaktāgamapramāṇatvānmṛtyuviṣaya evānyatvadarśane tasthuḥ /
analyzed: tathā sāṃkhyāḥ draṣṭāram deha ādi vyatiriktam avagamya api tyakta āgama pramāṇa tvāt mṛtyu viṣaye eva anya tva darśane tasthuḥ
translated: Similarly, the Samkhyas, though understanding the seer to be distinct from the body, etc., remained in the view of difference with regard to death itself, due to the lack of the authority of the abandoned scriptures.

original: tathānye kāṇādādidarśanāḥ kaṣāyaraktamiva kṣārādibhirvasraṃ navabhirātmaguṇairyuktamātmadravyaṃ viśodhayituṃ pravṛttāḥ /
analyzed: tathā anye kāṇāda ādi darśanāḥ kaṣāya raktam iva kṣāra ādibhiḥ vasram navabhiḥ ātma guṇaiḥ yuktam ātma dravyam viśodhayitum pravṛttāḥ
translated: Similarly, others, such as the followers of Kanada, set out to purify the substance of the self endowed with nine qualities, like a cloth stained with red dye with alkaline substances, etc.

original: tathānye karmiṇo bāhyaviṣayāpahṛtacetaso vedapramāṇā api paramārthasatyamātmaikatvaṃ vināśamivendravanmanyamānā ghaṭīyantravadārohāvarohaprakārairaniśaṃ
analyzed: tathā anye karmiṇaḥ bāhya viṣaya apahṛta cetasaḥ veda pramāṇāḥ api paramārtha satyam ātma ekatvam vināśam iva indra vat manyamānāḥ ghaṭīyantra vat āroha avaroha prakāraiḥ aniśam
translated: Similarly, other ritualists, whose minds are carried away by external objects, even though they are authoritative in the Vedas, considering the ultimate truth of the non-duality of the Self to be like destruction, like Indra, wander

analyzed: bambhramati
translated: unceasingly in various ways of ascent and descent, like a waterwheel.

original: kimanye kṣudrajantavo vivekahīnāḥ svabhāvata eva bahirviṣayāpahṛtacetasaḥ /🔽tasmādidaṃ tyaktasarvabāhyaiṣaṇairananyaśaraṇaiḥ paramahaṃsaparivrājakairatyāśramibhirvedāntavijñānaparaireva
analyzed: kim anye kṣudra jantavaḥ viveka hīnāḥ svabhāvataḥ eva bahis viṣaya apahṛta cetasaḥ  tasmāt idam tyakta sarva bāhya eṣaṇaiḥ ananya śaraṇaiḥ paramahaṃsa parivrājakaiḥ atyāśramibhiḥ vedānta vijñāna paraiḥ eva
translated: What to speak of other small creatures, devoid of discrimination, whose minds are naturally carried away by external objects?🔽Therefore, this [truth] should be realized by those who have given up all external desires, who have no other refuge, who are great renunciant mendicants, who are in the stage of renunciation, who are solely devoted to the knowledge of the Vedanta,

original: vedanīyaṃ pūjyatamaiḥ prājāpatyaṃ cemaṃ saṃpradāyamanusaradbhirupanibaddhaṃ prakaraṇacatuṣṭayena /
analyzed: vedanīyam pūjyatamaiḥ prājāpatyam ca imam saṃpradāyam anusaradbhiḥ upanibaddham prakaraṇa catuṣṭayena
translated: and who follow this tradition, which is most venerable, like the sacrificial fire, and which is set forth in four chapters.

analyzed: tathā anuśāsati adya api te eva na anye iti
translated: And they alone are instructed even today, not others.

analyzed: aśarīraḥ vāyuḥ
translated: The wind is bodiless.

analyzed: abhram vidyut stanayitnuḥ aśarīrāṇi etāni
translated: The cloud, lightning, and thunder are bodiless.

original: tad yathaitāny amuṣmād ākāśāt samutthāya paraṃ jyotir upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyante //
analyzed: tat yathā etāni amuṣmāt ākāśāt samutthāya param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyante
translated: Just as these, having arisen from that space, attain the highest light and manifest in their own form,

analyzed: tatra aśarīrasya saṃprasādasya avidyayā śarīreṇa aviśeṣa tām sa sarīra tām eva
translated: There, the question is how the bodiless pure consciousness, which has become non-distinct from the body due to ignorance, having attained the state of having a body,

original: saṃprāptasya śarīrātsamutthāya svena rūpeṇa yathābhiniṣpattistathā vaktavyeti dṛṣṭānta
analyzed: saṃprāptasya śarīrāt samutthāya svena rūpeṇa yathā abhiniṣpattiḥ tathā vaktavyā iti dṛṣṭānta
translated: rises up from the body and manifests in its own form. To explain this, an example is given.

analyzed: ucyate aśarīraḥ vāyuḥ a vidyamānam śiraḥ pāṇi ādimat śarīram asya iti aśarīraḥ
translated: The bodiless wind is said to be so because it has no body with a head, hands, etc.

analyzed: kim ca abhram vidyut stanayitnuḥ iti etāni ca aśarīrāṇi
translated: Moreover, the cloud, lightning, and thunder are also bodiless.

analyzed: tat tatra evam sati varṣa ādi prayojana avasāne yathā
translated: In that case, when the purpose of rain, etc. is accomplished,

analyzed: amuṣmāt iti bhūmiṣṭhā śrutiḥ dyu loka saṃbandhinam ākāśa deśam vyapadiśati
translated: the statement from that made by one on the ground refers to the region of space connected with the heavenly world.

original: etāni yathoktānyākāśasamānarūpatāmāpannāni svena vāyvādirūpeṇāgṛhyamāṇānyākāśākhyatāṃ gatāni yathā saṃprasādo 'vidyāvasthāyāṃ śarīrātmabhāvamevāpannaḥ /
analyzed: etāni yathā uktāni ākāśa samāna rūpa tām āpannāni svena vāyu ādi rūpeṇa āgṛhyamāṇāni ākāśa ākhya tām gatāni yathā saṃprasādaḥ vidyā avasthāyām śarīra ātma bhāvam eva āpannaḥ
translated: Just as the mentioned things, having attained the same form as space, being imperceptible in their own form as wind, etc., become known as space, so does the pure consciousness, having attained the state of being the self of the body in the state of ignorance.

analyzed: tāni ca tathābhūtāni amuṣmāt dyu loka sambandhinaḥ ākāśa deśāt samuttiṣṭhanti varṣaṇa ādi prayojana abhinirvṛttaye
translated: And those things, being in that state, rise up from that region of space connected with the heavenly world for the accomplishment of the purpose of rain, etc.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: śiśirāpāye sāvitra paraṃ jyotiḥ prakṛṣṭaṃ graiṣmakamupasaṃpadya sāvitramabhitāpaṃ prāpyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: śiśira apāye sāvitra param jyotiḥ prakṛṣṭam graiṣmakam upasaṃpadya sāvitram abhitāpam prāpya iti arthaḥ
translated: When the cold season passes away, the light of the sun, which is the highest light, attains the excellent light of the summer sun, meaning it reaches the heat of the sun.

original: ādityābhitāpena pṛthagbhāvamāpāditāḥ santaḥ svena svena rūpeṇa purovātādivāyurūpeṇa
analyzed: āditya abhitāpena pṛthagbhāvam āpāditāḥ santaḥ svena svena rūpeṇa purovāta ādi vāyu rūpeṇa
translated: Having been separated by the heat of the sun, they manifest in their own forms, as the forms of the wind such as the east wind, etc.

original: stimitabhāvaṃ hitvābhramapi bhūmiparvatahastyādirūpeṇa vidyudapi svena jyotirlatādicapalarūpeṇa
analyzed: stimita bhāvam hitvā abhram api bhūmi parvata hasti ādi rūpeṇa vidyut api svena jyotiḥ latā ādi capala rūpeṇa
translated: Abandoning the state of stillness, the clouds also in the form of earth, mountains, elephants, etc., and lightning also in its own form of flickering light, etc.,

original: stanayitnurapi svena garjitāśanirūpeṇetyevaṃ prāvṛḍāgame svena svena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyante //
analyzed: stanayitnuḥ api svena garjita aśani rūpeṇa iti evam prāvṛṣ āgame svena svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyante
translated: And thunder also in its own form of roaring and lightning - thus they manifest in their own forms at the advent of the rainy season.

original: evam evaiṣa saṃprasādo 'smāc charīrāt samutthāya paraṃ jyotir upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyate /
analyzed: evam eva eṣa saṃprasādaḥ u smāt śarīrāt samutthāya param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate
translated: In the same way, this tranquil soul, rising from this body, attains the highest light and manifests in its own form.

analyzed: saḥ uttama puruṣaḥ
translated: That is the supreme person.

original: sa tatra paryeti jakṣat krīḍan ramamāṇaḥ strībhir vā yānair vā jñātibhir vā nopajanaṃ smarann idaṃ śarīram /
analyzed: sa tatra paryeti jakṣat krīḍan ramamāṇaḥ strībhiḥ vā yānaiḥ vā jñātibhiḥ vā na upajanam smaran idam śarīram
translated: There he wanders, eating, playing, and enjoying himself with women, vehicles, and relatives, not remembering the body here.

original: sa yathā prayogya ācaraṇe yukta evam evāyam asmiñ charīre prāṇo yuktaḥ //
analyzed: sa yathā prayogyaḥ ācaraṇe yuktaḥ evam eva ayam asmin śarīre prāṇaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Just as a puppet is connected to the mechanism, in the same way, the life force in this body is connected.

analyzed: yathā ayam dṛṣṭāntaḥ vāyu ādīnām ākāśa ādi sāmya gamana vat avidyayā saṃsāra avasthāyām
translated: As in this example, the wind, etc., become similar to space, etc., so the individual soul, in the state of worldly existence due to ignorance,

original: śarīrasāmyamāpanno 'hamamuṣya putro jāto jīrṇo mariṣya ityevaṃprakāraṃ prajāpatineva
analyzed: śarīra sāmyam āpannaḥ ham amuṣya putraḥ jātaḥ jīrṇaḥ mariṣye iti evaṃprakāram prajāpatinā iva
translated: having attained similarity with the body, thinks I am the son of so-and-so, born, old, will die, in this way, like Prajapati,

original: maghavānyathoktena krameṇa nāsi tvaṃ dehendriyādidharmā tattvamasīti pratibodhitaḥ
analyzed: maghavān yathā uktena krameṇa na asi tvam deha indriya ādi dharmā tattvam asi iti pratibodhitaḥ
translated: Maghavan (Indra) was enlightened by the above-mentioned process, You are not subject to the qualities of the body, senses, etc., you are That.

original: sansa eṣa saṃprasādo jīvo 'smāccharīrādākāśādiva vāyvādayaḥ samutthāya dehādivailakṣaṇyamātmano
analyzed: san saḥ eṣa saṃprasādaḥ samutthāya deha ādi vailakṣaṇyam ātmanaḥ
translated: Having been enlightened thus, that individual soul, like wind, etc. rising from space, having understood the nature of the self as different from the body, etc.,

analyzed: rūpam avagamya deha ātma bhāvanām hitvā iti etat
translated: having given up the notion of the body as the self, this is explained.

original: svena rūpeṇa sadātmanaivābhiniṣpadyata iti vyākhyātaṃ purastāt /🔽sa yena svena rūpeṇa saṃprasādo 'bhiniṣpadyate prākpratibodhāttadbhrāntinimittātsarpo bhavati yatā rajjuḥ paścātkṛtaprakāśā rajjvātmanā svena
analyzed: svena rūpeṇa sat ātmanā eva abhiniṣpadyate iti vyākhyātam purastāt  sa yena svena rūpeṇa saṃprasādaḥ bhiniṣpadyate prāk pratibodhāt tad bhrānti nimittāt sarpaḥ bhavati yatā rajjuḥ paścātkṛta prakāśā rajju ātmanā svena
translated: It is explained earlier that it becomes manifest in its own form as the Self alone.

analyzed: rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate
translated: By what form the individual soul becomes manifest as the Self after enlightenment, from that cause of delusion, it becomes like a snake, as a rope becomes a snake before, but after the light is shed, it becomes manifest in its own form as a rope.

original: evaṃ ca sa uttamapuruṣa uttamaścāsau puruṣaścetyuttamapuruṣaḥ sa evottamapuruṣo 'kṣisvapnapuruṣau vyaktāvavyaktaśca suṣuptaḥ samastaḥ saṃprasanno
analyzed: evam ca saḥ uttama puruṣaḥ uttamaḥ ca asau puruṣaḥ ca iti uttama puruṣaḥ saḥ eva uttama puruṣaḥ kṣi svapna puruṣau vyaktau avyaktaḥ ca suṣuptaḥ samastaḥ saṃprasannaḥ
translated: And thus He is the Supreme Person, and He is the best and a person, hence the Supreme Person. He alone is the Supreme Person, the manifest and unmanifest persons in the eye and dream, and the completely merged and tranquil one in deep sleep.

analyzed: śarīraḥ ca svena rūpeṇa iti
translated: He is bodiless in His own form.

original: eṣāmeṣa svena rūpeṇāvasthitaḥ kṣarākṣarau vyākṛtāvyākṛtāvapekṣyottamapuruṣaḥ kṛtanirvacano hyayaṃ gītāsu /
analyzed: eṣām eṣa svena rūpeṇa avasthitaḥ kṣara akṣarau vyākṛta avyākṛtau apekṣya uttamapuruṣaḥ kṛta nirvacanaḥ hi ayam gītāsu
translated: Among these, He, the Supreme Person, is established in His own form, in relation to the manifest and unmanifest, the perishable and the imperishable. For He has been defined as the Supreme Person in the Gita.

original: sa saṃprasādaḥ svena rūpeṇa tatra svātmani svasthatayā sarvātmabhūtaḥ paryeti kvacidindrādyātmanā
analyzed: sa saṃprasādaḥ svena rūpeṇa tatra sva ātmani svastha tayā sarva ātma bhūtaḥ paryeti kvacid indra ādi ātmanā
translated: That tranquil one, in His own form, moves about there in His own Self, as the Self of all, in a state of well-being. In some places, in the form of Indra and others,

analyzed: jakṣat hasan bhakṣayan vā bhakṣyān uccāvacān īpsitān kvacid manaḥ mātraiḥ saṃkalpāt eva samutthitaiḥ brāhma laukikaiḥ vā
translated: eating, laughing, consuming various desirable food items, in some places, with mere mental creations arisen from thought alone, or with Brahmic or worldly ones,

original: krīḍanstryādibhī ramamāṇaśca manasaiva nopajanaṃ srīpuṃsayoranyonyopagamena jāyata
analyzed: krīḍan strī ādibhiḥ ramamāṇaḥ ca manasā eva nā upajanam srīpuṃsayoḥ anyonya upagamena jāyata
translated: playing, enjoying with women and others, only mentally, not born from the union of male and female.

original: ityupajanamātmabhāvena vā'tmasāmīpyena jāyata ityupajanamidaṃ śarīraṃ tanna smaran /
analyzed: iti upajanam ātma bhāvena vā ātma sāmīpyena jāyate iti upajanam idam śarīram tat na smaran
translated: The born is either born in the form of the Self or in close proximity to the Self. This body is the born. He does not remember that.

analyzed: tad smaraṇe hi duḥkham eva syāt
translated: For remembering that would only lead to sorrow.

analyzed: duḥkha ātmaka tvāt tasya
translated: Because that is of the nature of sorrow.

analyzed: nanu anubhūtam ced na smaret asarvajña tvam muktasya
translated: If it were experienced but not remembered, the liberated one would not be omniscient.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: yena mithyājñānādinā janitaṃ tacca mithyājñānādi vidyayoccheditamatastannānubhūtameveti na tadasmaraṇe sarvajñatvahāniḥ /🔽na hyu nmattena grahagṛhītena vā yadanubhūtaṃ tadunmādādyapadame 'pi smartavyaṃ syāttathehāpi saṃsāribhiravidyādoṣavadbhiryadanubhūyate tatsarvātmānamaśarīraṃ
analyzed: yena mithyājñāna ādinā janitam tat ca mithyājñāna ādi vidyayā uccheditam atas tat na anubhūtam eva iti na tad asmaraṇe sarvajña tva hāniḥ  na hi u nmattena graha gṛhītena vā yat anubhūtam smartavyam syāt tathā iha api saṃsāribhiḥ avidyā doṣavadbhiḥ yat anubhūyate tat sarvātmānam aśarīram
translated: That which is produced by false knowledge etc., and that false knowledge etc. is cut off by knowledge. Therefore, it is not at all experienced. So there is no loss of omniscience in not remembering that.

analyzed: na spṛśati
translated: For what is experienced by one who is insane or possessed by a planet should not be remembered even when the insanity etc. has ceased. Similarly here also, what is experienced by those in saṃsāra, who are flawed by ignorance etc., does not touch the entire self, the bodiless one.

analyzed: avidyā nimitta abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no cause for ignorance.

original: ye tūcchinnadoṣairmṛditakaṣāyairmānasāḥ satyāḥ kāmā anṛtāpidhānā anubhūyante vidyābhivyaṅgyatvātta
analyzed: ye tu ucchinna doṣaiḥ mṛdita kaṣāyaiḥ mānasāḥ satyāḥ kāmāḥ anṛta apidhānāḥ anubhūyante vidyā abhivyaṅgya tvāt ta
translated: But those who have cut off the faults, whose minds are softened by the afflictions, who experience true desires and false concealments, because they are manifested by knowledge,

original: eva muktena sarvātmabhūtena saṃbadhyanta ityātmajñānastutaye nirdiśyante 'taḥ sādhvetadviśinaṣṭiya
analyzed: eva muktena sarva ātma bhūtena saṃbadhyante iti ātma jñāna stutaye nirdiśyante sādhu etat viśinaṣṭi
translated: they are connected by the liberated one who has become the entire self. Therefore, they are indicated for the praise of the knowledge of the self. Thus this is good. He distinguishes

analyzed: ete brahma loke iti
translated: these as the world of Brahman.

original: yatra kvacana bhavanto 'pi brahmaṇyeva hi te loke bhavantīti sarvātmatvādbrahmaṇa ucyante /
analyzed: yatra kvacana brahmaṇi eva hi te loke bhavanti iti sarva ātma tvāt brahmaṇaḥ ucyante
translated: In whatever place they may be, they are indeed in Brahman alone. They are said to be Brahman because it is the Self of all.

original: nanu kathamekaḥ'sannānyatpaśyati nānyadvijānāti sa bhūmā'kāmāṃśca brāhmalaukikān'paśyan ramata'iti ca viruddham /
analyzed: nanu katham ekaḥ san na anyat paśyati na anyat vijānāti sa bhūma a kāmān ca brāhma laukikān paśyan ramate eti ca viruddham
translated: But how can it be said that the one Brahman, 'being one, does not see another, does not know another', and that 'the all-pervading one, seeing the desires of the Brahmaloka, delights'? This is contradictory.

original: yathaiko yasminneva kṣaṇe paśyati sa tasminneva kṣaṇe na paśyati ceti /
analyzed: yathā ekaḥ yasmin eva kṣaṇe paśyati sa tasmin eva kṣaṇe na paśyati ca iti
translated: Just as one person sees at one moment and does not see at the same moment.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: śruti antare parihṛta tvāt
translated: Because it has been refuted in another Upanishad.

analyzed: draṣṭuḥ dṛṣṭeḥ a viparilopāt paśyan eva bhavati
translated: Because the seer's seeing is not destroyed, he becomes one who sees.

analyzed: draṣṭuḥ anya tvena kāmānām abhāvāt na paśyati ca iti
translated: Because there is no desire for another, he does not see.

original: yadyapi suṣupte taduktaṃ muktasyāpi sarvaikatvātsamāno dvitīyābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api suṣupte tat uktam muktasya api sarva eka tvāt samānaḥ dvitīya abhāvaḥ
translated: Even though this has been said about deep sleep, for the liberated one also, due to the oneness of all, the absence of a second is the same.

analyzed: kena kam paśyet iti ca uktam eva
translated: And 'by whom is whom seen' has been already stated.

original: aśarīrasvarūpo 'pahatapāpmādilakṣaṇaḥ sankathameṣa puruṣo 'kṣiṇi dṛśyata ityuktaḥ prajāpatinā /
analyzed: aśarīra svarūpa upahata pāpma ādi lakṣaṇaḥ san katham eṣa puruṣaḥ u kṣiṇi dṛśyate iti uktaḥ prajāpatinā
translated: How is this person, who is of the nature of the bodiless, characterized by being free from sin, etc., seen in the eye? Thus it has been stated by Prajapati.

analyzed: tatra yathā asau akṣiṇi sākṣāt dṛśyate tat vaktavyam iti idam ārabhyate
translated: There, it should be stated how he is directly seen in the eye. This is begun.

original: tatra ko heturakṣiṇi darśana ityāhasa dṛṣṭānto yathā prayogyaḥ prayogyaparo vā saśabdaḥ /
analyzed: tatra kaḥ hetuḥ akṣiṇi darśane iti āha sa dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā prayogyaḥ prayogya paraḥ vā sa śabdaḥ
translated: What is the cause of seeing in the eye? He says: The example is like a horse or a bull that is yoked, along with its sound.

analyzed: prayujyate iti śvas balīvarde vā
translated: One who is employed is a horse or a bull.

original: yathā loka ācaratyanenetyācaraṇo ratho 'no vā tasminnācaraṇe yuktastadākarṣaṇāya /
analyzed: yathā lokaḥ ācarati anena iti ācaraṇaḥ rathaḥ no vā tasmin ācaraṇe yuktaḥ tad ākarṣaṇāya
translated: Just as in the world one acts with this, so the chariot or cart is the means of action. When it is yoked to that means of action for the purpose of pulling,

original: evamasmiñcharīre rathasthānīye prāṇaḥ pañcavṛttirindriyamanobuddhisaṃyuktaḥ prajñātmā vijñānakriyāśaktidvayasaṃmūrchitātmā yuktaḥ svakarmaphalopabhoganimittaṃ
analyzed: evam asmin śarīre ratha sthānīye prāṇaḥ pañca vṛttiḥ indriya manaḥ buddhi saṃyuktaḥ prajñā ātmā vijñāna kriyā śakti dvaya saṃmūrchita ātmā yuktaḥ sva karma phala upabhoga nimittam
translated: in the same way, in this body which is like a chariot, the life-force with five functions, along with the sense organs, mind and intellect, the self with wisdom, the self merged with the two powers of knowledge and action, is yoked for the purpose of experiencing the fruits of one's own actions.

analyzed: niyuktaḥ
translated: It is engaged.

original: kasminnvahamutkrānta utkrānto bhavisaṣyāmi kasminvā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmīti /
analyzed: kasmin vaham utkrāntaḥ utkrāntaḥ kasmin vā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmi iti
translated: In whom, when I depart, shall I depart? In whom, when I am established, shall I be established?

analyzed: īśvareṇa rājñā iva sarva adhikārī darśana śravaṇa ceṣṭā vyāpāre dhikṛtaḥ
translated: By God, like a king, he is authorized in the affairs of seeing, hearing and activity.

analyzed: tasya eva tu mātrā eka deśaḥ cakṣuḥ indriyam rūpa upalabdhi dvāra bhūtam
translated: But the eye sense faculty is only a part of that, serving as the door for the perception of form.

original: atha yatraitad ākāśam anuviṣaṇṇaṃ cakṣuḥ sa cākṣuṣaḥ puruṣo darśanāya cakṣuḥ /
analyzed: atha yatra etat ākāśam anuviṣaṇṇam cakṣuḥ sa cākṣuṣaḥ puruṣaḥ darśanāya cakṣuḥ
translated: Now, where this eye is attached to space, that is the eye-person, the eye for seeing.

original: atha yo vededaṃ jighrāṇīti sa ātmā gandhāya ghrāṇam /
analyzed: atha yaḥ veda idam jighrāṇi iti saḥ ātmā gandhāya ghrāṇam
translated: Now, he who knows, 'I shall smell this,' that Self is the nose for the purpose of smelling.

original: atha yo vededam abhivyāharāṇīti sa ātmā abhivyāhārāya vāk /
analyzed: atha yaḥ veda idam abhivyāharāṇi iti saḥ ātmā abhivyāhārāya vāc
translated: Now, he who knows, 'I shall speak this,' that Self is the speech for the purpose of speaking.

original: atha yo vededaṃ śṛṇvānīti sa ātmā śravaṇāya śrotram //
analyzed: atha yaḥ veda idam śṛṇvāni iti saḥ ātmā śravaṇāya śrotram
translated: Now, he who knows, 'I shall hear this,' that Self is the ear for the purpose of hearing.

original: atha yatra kṛṣṇatāropalakṣitamākāśaṃ dehacchidramanuviṣaṇṇamanuṣaktamanugataṃ🔽tatra sa prakṛto 'śarīra ātmā cākṣuṣaścakṣuṣi bhava iti cākṣuṣastasya darśanāya rūpopalabdhaye
analyzed: atha yatra kṛṣṇa tāra upalakṣitam ākāśam deha chidram anuviṣaṇṇam anuṣaktam anugatam  tatra sa prakṛtaḥ śarīre ātmā cākṣuṣaḥ cakṣuṣi bhave iti cākṣuṣaḥ tasya darśanāya rūpa upalabdhaye
translated: Now, where the space marked by the black pupil is attached to, connected with, the hole in the body,🔽there, that Self, which is the subject, which is bodiless, which is the inner Self, is the eye, because it exists in the eye. It is the eye. For the purpose of seeing it, for the purpose of perceiving form,

original: cakṣuḥ karaṇaṃ yasya taddehādibhiḥ saṃhatatvātparasya draṣṭurarthe so 'tra cakṣuṣi
analyzed: cakṣuḥ karaṇam yasya tad deha ādibhiḥ saṃhata tvāt parasya draṣṭuḥ arthe saḥ tra cakṣuṣi
translated: the eye is the instrument. Because it is united with the body etc., the Supreme Seer is here in the eye.

analyzed: darśanena liṅgena dṛśyate paras śarīraḥ saṃhataḥ
translated: He is seen by the mark of seeing. The Supreme One, who is bodiless, who is not united,

analyzed: akṣiṇi dṛśyate iti prajāpatinā uktam sarva indriya dvāra upalakṣaṇa artham
translated: is seen in the eye. This is said by Prajapati for the purpose of indicating all the doors of the senses.

analyzed: sarva viṣaya upalabdhā hi saḥ eva iti
translated: For He alone is the perceiver of all objects.

analyzed: sphuṭa upalabdhi hetu tvāt tvakṣiṇi iti viśeṣa vacanam sarva śrutiṣu
translated: But the specific statement in all the scriptures is that the eyes are the cause of clear perception.

analyzed: aham adarśam iti tat satyam bhavati iti ca śruteḥ
translated: Because of the statement in the scriptures, 'I saw,' and 'That becomes true.'

original: athāpi yo 'smindehe veda kathamidaṃ sugandhi durgandhi vā jighrāṇītyasya gandhaṃ vijānīyāmiti sa ātmā tasya gandhāya gandhavijñānāya ghrāṇam
analyzed: atha api yaḥ smin dehe veda katham idam sugandhi durgandhi vā jighrāṇi iti asya gandham vijānīyām iti saḥ ātmā tasya gandhāya gandha vijñānāya ghrāṇam
translated: Now, if one knows in this body, how shall I smell this fragrant or foul-smelling thing, I shall know its smell, that Self, for the purpose of smelling its smell, the nose.

original: atha yo vededaṃ vacanamabhivyāharāṇīti vadiṣyāmīti sa ātmābhivyavaharaṇakriyāsiddhaye karaṇaṃ vāgindriyam /
analyzed: atha yaḥ veda idam vacanam abhivyāharāṇi iti vadiṣyāmi iti saḥ ātma abhivyavaharaṇa kriyā siddhaye karaṇam vāc indriyam
translated: Now, if one knows, I shall utter this speech, I shall speak, that Self, for the purpose of accomplishing the act of speaking, the organ of speech.

original: atha yo vededaṃ śṛṇavānīti sa ātmā śravaṇāya śrotram //
analyzed: atha yaḥ veda idam śṛṇavāni iti saḥ ātmā śravaṇāya śrotram
translated: Now, if one knows, I shall hear this, that Self, for hearing, the ear.

original: atha yo vededaṃ manvānīti sa ātmā /
analyzed: atha yaḥ veda idam manvāni iti saḥ ātmā
translated: Now, if one knows, I shall think this, that Self.

analyzed: manaḥ sya daivam cakṣuḥ
translated: The mind is his divine eye.

original: sa vā eṣa etena daivena cakṣuṣā manasaitān kāmān paśyan ramate ya ete brahmaloke //
analyzed: sa vai eṣaḥ etena daivena cakṣuṣā manasā etān kāmān paśyan ramate ye ete brahma loke
translated: He, verily, by that divine eye, by the mind, beholding those desires, delights, who are in the world of Brahman.

original: atha yo vedadaṃ manvānīti mananavyāpāramindriyāsaṃspṛṣṭaṃ kevalaṃ manvānīti veda sa ātmā mananāya manaḥ /
analyzed: atha yaḥ veda dam manvāni iti manana vyāpāram indriya a saṃspṛṣṭam kevalam manvāni iti veda saḥ ātmā mananāya manaḥ
translated: Now, if one knows, I shall think this, the function of thinking not in contact with the senses, I shall merely think, he knows, that Self, for the purpose of thinking, the mind.

original: yo veda sa ātmetyevaṃ sarvatra prayogādvedanamasya svarūpamityavagamyate /
analyzed: yaḥ veda saḥ ātmā iti evam sarvatra prayogāt vedanam asya svarūpam iti avagamyate
translated: One who knows, that is the Self. Thus, from the use of the word 'veda' everywhere, it is understood that knowing is its nature.

original: yathā yaḥ purastātprakāśayati sa ādityo yo dakṣiṇato yaḥ paścādya uttarato ya ūrdhvaṃ prakāśayati sa āditya ityukte prakāśasvarūpaḥ sa iti
analyzed: yathā yaḥ purastāt prakāśayati saḥ ādityaḥ yaḥ dakṣiṇatas yaḥ paścāt yaḥ uttaratas yaḥ ūrdhvam prakāśayati saḥ ādityaḥ iti ukte prakāśa svarūpaḥ saḥ iti
translated: Just as when it is said that he who illuminates in front is the sun, he who illuminates to the right, he who illuminates behind, he who illuminates to the left, he who illuminates above is the sun, it is said that he is of the nature of light.

analyzed: darśana ādi kriyā nirvṛtti arthāni tu cakṣuḥ ādi karaṇāni
translated: But the organs such as the eye are for the purpose of accomplishing the action of seeing etc.

analyzed: idam ca asya ātmanaḥ sāmarthyāt avagamyate
translated: And this is understood from the power of this Self.

original: ātmanaḥ sattāmātra eva jñānakartṛtvaṃ na tu vyāpṛtatayā /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ sattā mātre eva jñāna kartṛ tvam na tu vyāpṛta tayā
translated: The Self is the agent of knowledge merely by its existence, not by being engaged.

original: yathā savituḥ sattāmātra eva prakāśanakartṛtvaṃ na tu vyāpṛtatayeti tadvat /
analyzed: yathā savituḥ sattā mātre eva prakāśana kartṛ tvam na tu vyāpṛta tayā iti tadvat
translated: Just as the sun is the agent of illumination merely by its existence, not by being engaged, so is it.

analyzed: manaḥ sya ātmanaḥ daivam aprākṛtam itara indriyaiḥ asādhāraṇam cakṣuḥ caṣṭe paśyati anena iti cakṣuḥ
translated: The mind is the divine, non-material, and extraordinary organ of this Self, which is called the eye, because one sees through it.

analyzed: vartamāna kāla viṣayāṇi ca indriyāṇi atas daivāni tāni
translated: And the organs pertain to the present time, therefore they are not divine.

original: manastu trikālaviṣayopalabdhikaraṇaṃ mṛditadoṣaṃ ca sūkṣmavyavahitādisarvopalabdhikaraṇaṃ ceti daivaṃ cakṣurucyate /
analyzed: manaḥ tu tri kāla viṣaya upalabdhi karaṇam mṛdita doṣam ca sūkṣma vyavahita ādi sarva upalabdhi karaṇam ca iti daivam cakṣuḥ ucyate
translated: But the mind is the instrument of perception pertaining to the three times, and the instrument of the perception of all subtle, obstructed, etc., objects, being free from faults, therefore it is called the divine eye.

analyzed: sa vai muktaḥ sva rūpa āpannaḥ vidyā kṛta deha indriya manaḥ viyuktaḥ sarva ātma bhāvam āpannaḥ
translated: He, being liberated, having attained his own nature, being devoid of the body, senses, and mind created by ignorance, having attained the state of being all-Self,

analyzed: san eṣa vyoma vat viśuddhaḥ sarva īśvaraḥ manā upādhiḥ san etena eva īśvareṇa manasā etān kāmān savitṛ prakāśa vat nitya pratatena
translated: being thus pure like the sky, being the Lord of all, being limited by the mind, with that very Self, with the mind, which is ever-present like the light of the sun,

analyzed: darśanena paśyan ramate
translated: he sees these desires and delights.

original: kānkāmāniti viśinaṣṭiya ete brahmaṇi loke hiraṇyanidhivadbāhyaviṣayāsaṅgānṛtenāpihitāḥ saṃkalpamātralabhyāstānityarthaḥ //
analyzed: kān kāmān iti viśinaṣṭi ye ete brahmaṇi loke hiraṇyanidhi vat bāhya viṣaya āsaṅga anṛtena apihitāḥ saṃkalpa mātra labhyāḥ tān iti arthaḥ
translated: He specifies which desires: These desires are hidden in Brahman's world like a golden treasure by untruth, which can be obtained only by mere resolve. This is the meaning.

original: taṃ vā etaṃ devā ātmānam upāsate /
analyzed: tam vai etam devāḥ ātmānam upāsate
translated: The gods worship that Self.

original: tasmāt teṣāṃ sarve ca lokā āttāḥ sarve ca kāmāḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt teṣām sarve ca lokāḥ āttāḥ sarve ca kāmāḥ
translated: Therefore, all the worlds and all the desires are attained by them.

original: sa sarvāṃś ca lokān āpnoti sarvāṃś ca kāmān yas tam ātmānam anuvidya vijānāti /
analyzed: sa sarvān ca lokān āpnoti sarvān ca kāmān yaḥ tam ātmānam anuvidya vijānāti
translated: He obtains all the worlds and all the desires who, knowing that Self, understands it.

original: iti ha prajāpatir uvāca prajāpatir uvāca //
analyzed: iti ha prajāpatiḥ uvāca prajāpatiḥ uvāca
translated: Thus did Prajapati say. Prajapati said.

original: yasmādeṣa indrāya prajāpatinokta ātmā tasmāttataḥ śrutvā tamātmānamadyatve 'pi devā upāsate /
analyzed: yasmāt eṣaḥ indrāya prajāpatinā uktaḥ ātmā tasmāt tatas śrutvā tam ātmānam adya tve devāḥ upāsate
translated: Since this Self was spoken to Prajapati Indra by him, therefore, having heard it from him, the gods worship that Self even today.

original: tadupāsanācca teṣāṃ sarve ca lokā āttāḥ prāptāḥ sarve ca kāmāḥ /
analyzed: tad upāsanāt ca teṣām sarve ca lokāḥ āttāḥ prāptāḥ sarve ca kāmāḥ
translated: And by the worship of that, all the worlds are attained, and all desires are fulfilled.

original: yadarthaṃ hīndra ekaśataṃ varṣāṇi prajāpatau brahmacaryamuvāsa tatphalaṃ prāptaṃ devairityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: yad artham hi indraḥ ekaśatam varṣāṇi prajāpatau brahmacaryam uvāsa tat phalam prāptam devaiḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the gods have attained the fruit of that for which Indra lived the life of a celibate student with Prajapati for one hundred and one years.

original: tadyuktaṃ devānāṃ mahābhāgyatvānna tvidānīṃ manuṣyāṇāmalpajīvitatvānmandataraprajñatvācca saṃbhavatīti prāpta idamucyatesa sarvāṃśca lokānāpnoti
analyzed: tat yuktam devānām mahābhāgya tvāt na tu idānīm manuṣyāṇām alpa jīvita tvāt mandatara prajña tvāt ca saṃbhavati iti prāptaḥ idam ucyate sa sarvān ca lokān āpnoti
translated: This is proper for the gods because of their great fortune, but now it is not possible for humans because of their short life and duller intelligence. Having reached this conclusion, it is said: He attains all the worlds

analyzed: sarvān ca kāmān idānīntanaḥ pi
translated: and all the desires, even now.

analyzed: kaḥ sau
translated: Who is he?

original: indrādivadyastamātmānamanuvidya vijānātīti ha sāmānyena kila prajāpatiruvāca /
analyzed: indra ādi vat yaḥ tam ātmānam anuvidya vijānāti iti ha sāmānyena kila prajāpatiḥ uvāca
translated: Prajapati said this in general: He who, like Indra, having understood that Self, knows it.

analyzed: atas sarveṣām ātma jñānam tad phala prāptiḥ ca tulyā eva bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the knowledge of the Self and the attainment of its fruits are the same for all. This is the meaning.

analyzed: dvirvacanam prakaraṇa samāpti artham
translated: The repetition is for the sake of concluding the section.

original: iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭamādhyāyasya dvādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ🔽śyāmāc chabalaṃ prapadye /
analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya dvādaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ  śyāmāt śabalam prapadye
translated: Thus ends the twelfth section of the eighth chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad.🔽I take refuge in the variegated from the dark.

analyzed: śabalāt śyāmam prapadye
translated: I take refuge in the dark from the variegated.

original: aśva iva romāṇi vidhūya pāpaṃ candra iva rāhor mukhāt pramucya dhūtvā śarīram akṛtaṃ kṛtātmā brahmalokam abhisaṃbhavāmīty abhisaṃbhavāmīti
analyzed: aśvaḥ iva romāṇi vidhūya pāpam candraḥ iva rāhoḥ mukhāt pramucya dhūtvā śarīram a kṛtam kṛtātmā brahma lokam abhisaṃbhavāmi iti abhisaṃbhavāmi iti
translated: Shaking off evil like a horse shakes off its hairs, and being freed from the mouth of Rahu like the moon, having shaken off the uncreated body from the created self, I attain the world of Brahman, I attain the world of Brahman.

original: śyāmācchabalaṃ prapadya ityādimantrāmnāya pāvano japārthaśca dhyānārtho vā /
analyzed: śyāmāt śabalam prapadye ityādi mantra āmnāya pāvanaḥ japa arthaḥ ca dhyāna arthaḥ vā
translated: The purifying mantra recitation and meditation are for the purpose of japa and dhyana, beginning with I go from the dark to the variegated.

original: śyāmo gambhīro varṇaḥ śyāma iva śyāmo hārdaṃ brahmātyantaduravagāhyatvāttaddhārda
analyzed: śyāmaḥ gambhīraḥ varṇaḥ śyāmaḥ iva śyāmaḥ hārdam brahma atyanta duravagāhya tvāt tat hārda
translated: The dark color is deep, like a dark cloud. The heart of Brahman is extremely difficult to fathom, therefore the heart of Brahman.

original: brahma jñātvā dhyānena tasmācchyāmācchabalaṃ śabala iva śabalo 'raṇyādyanekakāmamiśratvādbrahmalokasya
analyzed: brahma jñātvā dhyānena tasmāt śyāmāt śabalam śabalaḥ iva śabalaḥ raṇya ādi aneka kāma miśra tvāt brahma lokasya
translated: Having known that heart of Brahman, by meditation, from that dark color I go to the variegated, like a variegated cloud. The world of Brahman is variegated because it is mixed with many desires such as the forest, etc.

original: śābalya taṃ brahmalokaṃ śabalaṃ prapadye manasā śarīrapātādvordhvaṃ gaccheyam /
analyzed: śābalya tam brahma lokam śabalam prapadye manasā śarīrapātāt vā ūrdhvam gaccheyam
translated: I go to that variegated world of Brahman. I will go upwards with my mind after the fall of the body.

original: yasmādahaṃ śabalādbrahmalokānnāmarūpavyākaraṇāya śyāmaṃ prapadye hārdabhāvaṃ prapanno 'smītyabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt aham śabalāt brahma lokāt nāma rūpa vyākaraṇāya śyāmam prapadye hārda bhāvam smi iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: From that variegated world of Brahman, I go to the dark color for the purpose of explaining name and form. The meaning is that I have gone to the state of the heart.

analyzed: atas tam eva prakṛti svarūpam ātmānam śabalam prapadye iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that I go to that very variegated self, which is of the nature of Prakruti.

original: kathaṃ śabalaṃ brahmalokaṃ prapadya ityucyateaśva iva svāni lomāni vidhūya kampanena
analyzed: katham śabalam brahma lokam prapadye iti ucyate aśvaḥ iva svāni lomāni vidhūya kampanena
translated: How does one go to the variegated Brahmaloka? It is said: Shaking off his own hairs like a horse,

original: śramaṃ pāṃsvādi ca romato 'panīya yathā nirmalo bhavatyevaṃ hārdabrahmajñānena vidhūya
analyzed: śramam pāṃsu ādi ca upanīya yathā nirmalaḥ bhavati evam hārda brahma jñānena vidhūya
translated: removing fatigue, dust, etc., and hair, becoming spotless, in the same way, by knowing the Brahman in the heart, shaking off

original: pāpaṃ dharmādharmākyaṃ candra iva ca rāhugrastastasmādrahormukhātmapramucya bhāsvaro
analyzed: pāpam dharma adharma ākyam candraḥ iva ca rāhu grastaḥ tasmāt rahoḥ mukha ātma pramucya
translated: sin, and the mixture of virtue and vice, like the moon released from Rahu's mouth, becoming radiant,

original: bhavati yathaivaṃ dhūtvā prahāra śarīraṃ sarvānarthāśrayamihaiva dhyānena kṛtātmā
analyzed: bhavati yathā evam dhūtvā prahāra śarīram sarva anartha āśrayam iha eva dhyānena kṛtātmā
translated: in the same way, having shaken off the body, the abode of all evils, having made the self

analyzed: kṛtakṛtyaḥ san akṛtam nityam brahma lokam abhisaṃbhavāmi iti
translated: complete by meditation here itself, having accomplished what was to be done, I shall always attain the unseen Brahmaloka.

analyzed: dvirvacanam mantra samāpti artham
translated: The repetition is for the completion of the mantra.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya trayodaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the thirteenth section of the eighth chapter in Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ vai nāma nāma rūpayoḥ nirvahitā
translated: Ākāśa, indeed, is the expander of name and form.

original: te yadantarā tad brahma tad amṛtaṃ sa ātmā /
analyzed: te yat antarā tat brahma tat amṛtam saḥ ātmā
translated: That which is between them is Brahman, that is the immortal, that is the self.

original: prajāpateḥ sabhāṃ veśma prapadye yaśo 'haṃ bhavāmi brāhmaṇānāṃ yaśo rājñām yaśo viśām /
analyzed: prajāpateḥ sabhām veśma prapadye yaśaḥ ham bhavāmi brāhmaṇānām yaśaḥ rājñām yaśaḥ viśām
translated: I enter the assembly hall and abode of Prajāpati. I become the glory of the Brahmins, the glory of the kings, the glory of the common people.

analyzed: yaśaḥ ham anuprāpatsi
translated: I attain glory.

analyzed: sa ha aham yaśasām yaśaḥ
translated: I am the glory of glories.

original: śyetam adatkam adatkaṃ śyetaṃ lindu mābhigāṃ lindu mābhigām //
analyzed: śyetam adatkam adatkam śyetam lindu mā abhigām lindu mā abhigām
translated: May I not go to the white, to the eater, to the eater, to the white, may I not go to the limping, to the limping.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ vai ityādi brahmaṇaḥ lakṣaṇa nirdeśa artham ādhyānāya
translated: The statement beginning with Space indeed is for the purpose of describing the characteristics of Brahman for meditation.

original: ākāśo vai nāma śrutiṣu prasiddha ātmā /
analyzed: ākāśaḥ vai nāma śrutiṣu prasiddhaḥ ātmā
translated: The Self known as Ākāśa is well-known in the scriptures.

analyzed: ākāśe iva a śarīra tva a sūkṣma tvāt ca
translated: And that Ākāśa is so called because of its being bodiless and subtle like space.

original: sa cā'kāśo nāmarūpayoḥ svātmasthayorjagadbījabhūtayoḥ salilasyeva phenasthānīyayornirvahitā nirvoḍhā vyākartā /
analyzed: sa ca ākāśaḥ nāma rūpayoḥ sva ātma sthayoḥ jagat bīja bhūtayoḥ salilasya iva phena sthānīyayoḥ nirvahitā nirvoḍhā vyākartā
translated: And that Ākāśa is the supporter, the upholder, the expander of name and form, which are the seeds of the world, existing in its own Self like water and foam.

original: te nāmarūpe yadantarā yasya brahmaṇo 'ntarā madhye vartete /
analyzed: te nāma rūpe yat antarā yasya brahmaṇaḥ ntarā madhye vartete
translated: Those name and form are within, in the middle of that Brahman.

original: tayorvā nāmarūpayorantarā madhye yannāmarūpābhyāmaspṛṣṭaṃ yadityetattadbrahma nāmarūpavilakṣaṇaṃ nāmarūpābhyāmaspṛṣṭaṃ tathāpi tayornirvoḍhutvaṃ
analyzed: tayoḥ vā nāma rūpayoḥ antarā madhye yat nāma rūpābhyām a spṛṣṭam yat iti etat tat brahma nāma rūpa vilakṣaṇam nāma rūpābhyām a spṛṣṭam tathā api tayoḥ nirvoḍhu tvam
translated: Or within those name and form, in the middle, that which is untouched by name and form, that which is so - that Brahman is different from name and form, untouched by name and form. Still, its being the upholder of those two

analyzed: lakṣaṇam brahma iti arthaḥ
translated: is the characteristic of Brahman, is the meaning.

original: idameva maitreyībrāhmaṇenoktaṃ cinmātrānugamātmasarvatra citsvarūpataiveti gamyata ekavākyatā /
analyzed: idam eva maitreyībrāhmaṇena uktam cit mātra anugama ātma sarvatra cit svarūpa tā eva iti gamyate ekavākyatā
translated: This very thing is stated in the Maitreyī Brāhmaṇa. It is understood that everywhere the nature of the Self is the nature of consciousness, as stated in the same sentence.

analyzed: tat avagamyate iti āha saḥ ātmā
translated: How is that understood? It is said: That is the Self.

original: ātmā hi nāma sarvajantūnāṃ pratyakcetanaḥ svasaṃvedyaḥ prasiddhastenaiva svarūpeṇonnīyāśarīro vyomavatsarvagata ātmā brahmetyavagantavyam /
analyzed: ātmā hi nāma sarva jantūnām pratyak cetanaḥ sva saṃvedyaḥ prasiddhaḥ tena eva svarūpeṇa unnīya aśarīraḥ vyoma vat sarva gataḥ ātmā brahma iti avagantavyam
translated: The Self, indeed, is well known to all living beings as the inward-turned consciousness, to be experienced by each one for himself. By that very nature of His, the bodiless Self, who is all-pervading like space, should be understood as Brahman.

analyzed: tat ca ātmā brahma amṛtam amaraṇa dharmā
translated: And that Self is Brahman, the immortal, having the nature of being undecaying.

analyzed: atas ūrdhva mantraḥ
translated: Above that, there is a mantra.

original: prajāpatiścaturmukhastasya sabhāṃ veśma prabhuvimitaṃ veśma prapadye gaccheyam /
analyzed: prajāpatiḥ caturmukhaḥ tasya sabhām veśma prabhu vimitam veśma prapadye gaccheyam
translated: I enter the assembly, the house, measured by the Lord, of Prajapati, the four-faced one.

original: kiñca yaśo 'haṃ yaśo nāmā'tmāhaṃ bhavāmi brāhmaṇānām /
analyzed: kiñca yaśaḥ ham yaśaḥ nāma ātmā aham bhavāmi brāhmaṇānām
translated: Moreover, I become the fame, the Self named fame, of the Brahmanas.

original: brāhmaṇā eva hi viśeṣatastamupāsate tatasteṣāṃ yaśo bhavāmi /
analyzed: brāhmaṇāḥ eva hi viśeṣataḥ tam upāsate tatas teṣām yaśaḥ bhavāmi
translated: For the Brahmanas alone especially worship Him, therefore I become their fame.

analyzed: tathā rājñām viśām ca
translated: Similarly, of the Kshatriyas and Vaishyas.

analyzed: te pi adhikṛtāḥ eva iti teṣām api ātmā bhavāmi
translated: They too are the rulers, therefore I become the Self of them also.

analyzed: tat yaśaḥ ham anuprāpatsi anuprāptum icchāmi sa ha aham yaśasām ātmanām deha indriya manaḥ buddhi lakṣaṇānām ātmā
translated: I desire to attain that fame, I desire to attain the Self of those who have the characteristics of body, senses, mind and intellect.

analyzed: kimartham aham evam prapadye iti
translated: For what purpose do I thus enter?

analyzed: ucyate śyetam varṇataḥ pakva badara samam rohitam
translated: It is said: That Self, who is red like a ripe jujube fruit in color,

original: tathādatkaṃ dantarahitamapyadatkaṃ bhakṣayitṛ srīvyañjanaṃ tatsevināṃ tejobalavīryavijñānadharmāṇāmapahantṛ vināśayitrityetat /
analyzed: tathā adatkam danta rahitam api adatkam bhakṣayitṛ srī vyañjanam tad sevinām tejaḥ bala vīrya vijñāna dharmāṇām apahantṛ vināśayitṛ iti etat
translated: And adataka, which is without teeth, is also adataka, which is the destroyer of the luster, strength, virility, knowledge, and virtues of those who indulge in it.

original: yadevaṃlakṣaṇaṃ śyetaṃ lindu picchilaṃ tanmābhigāṃ mābhigaccheyam /
analyzed: yat evaṃlakṣaṇam śyetam lindu picchilam tat mā abhigām mā abhigaccheyam
translated: I should not approach that which is of such a nature, which is white, slimy, and slippery.

analyzed: dvirvacanam atyanta anartha hetutva pradarśana artham
translated: The repetition is to show that it is the cause of extreme misfortune.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya caturdaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourteenth section in the eighth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

original: tad dhaitad brahmā prajāpataya uvāca prajāpatir manave manuḥ prajābhyaḥ /🔽ācāryakulād vedam adhītya yathāvidhānaṃ guroḥ karmātiśeṣeṇābhisamāvṛtya kuṭumbe śucau
analyzed: tat ha etat brahmā prajāpataye uvāca prajāpatiḥ manave manuḥ prajābhyaḥ  ācārya kulāt vedam adhītya yathā vidhānam guroḥ karma atiśeṣeṇa abhisamāvṛtya kuṭumbe śucau
translated: That, indeed, Brahman spoke to Prajāpati, Prajāpati to Manu, Manu to the people.🔽Having studied the Veda in the teacher's family according to the rules, having completed the duties to the teacher, in a pure household,

original: deśe svādhyāyam adhīyāno dharmikān vidadhad ātmani sarvendriyāṇi saṃpratiṣṭhāpyāhiṃsan
analyzed: deśe svādhyāyam adhīyānaḥ dharmikān vidadhat ātmani sarva indriyāṇi saṃpratiṣṭhāpya a hiṃsan
translated: in a clean place, studying the sacred texts, prescribing righteous conduct, establishing all the senses in the self, not harming

analyzed: sarva bhūtāni anyatra tīrthebhyaḥ
translated: any beings except at sacred fords.

original: sa khalv evaṃ vartayan yāvad āyuṣaṃ brahmalokam abhisaṃpadyate /
analyzed: sa khalu evam vartayan yāvat āyuṣam brahma lokam abhisaṃpadyate
translated: He, living thus as long as life lasts, attains the world of Brahman.

original: na ca punar āvartate na ca punar āvartate //
analyzed: na ca punar āvartate na ca punar āvartate
translated: And he does not return, he does not return again.

analyzed: tat ha etat ātma jñānam sa upakaraṇam om iti etat akṣaram ityādyaiḥ saha upāsanaiḥ tad vācakena
translated: That knowledge of the Self, along with its means, along with the meditations beginning with Om, this syllable,

original: granthenāṣṭādhyāyīlakṣaṇena saha brahmā hiraṇyagarbhaḥ parameśvaro vā taddvāreṇa
analyzed: granthena aṣṭa adhyāyī lakṣaṇena saha brahmā hiraṇyagarbhaḥ parameśvaraḥ vā tad dvāreṇa
translated: Brahmā, Hiraṇyagarbha, or the Supreme Lord, through that text characterized by eight chapters, which expresses that knowledge,

analyzed: prajāpataye kaśyapāya uvāca
translated: he taught to Prajāpati, to Kaśyapa.

analyzed: asau api manave sva putrāya
translated: He also to Manu, his son.

analyzed: manuḥ prajābhyaḥ iti evam śruti artha saṃpradāya paramparayā āgatam upaniṣad vijñānam adyā api vidvatsu avagamyate
translated: Manu to the people. Thus the knowledge of the Upaniṣads, which has come down through the succession of the tradition of the meaning of the Vedas, is even today understood by the wise.

original: yatheha ṣaṣṭhādyadhyāyatraye prakāśitātmavidyā saphalāvagamyate tathā karmaṇāṃ na🔽kaścanārtha iti prāpte tadānarthakyaprāptiparijihīrṣayedaṃ karmaṇo vidvadbhiranuṣṭhīyamānasya
analyzed: yathā iha ṣaṣṭha ādi adhyāya traye prakāśita ātma vidyā saphalā avagamyate tathā karmaṇām na  kaścana arthaḥ iti prāpte tad ānarthakya prāpti parijihīrṣayā idam karmaṇaḥ vidvadbhiḥ anuṣṭhīyamānasya
translated: Just as the knowledge of the Self, illuminated in the last three chapters beginning with the sixth, is understood to be fruitful, so it is concluded that no purpose is served by the performance of rites.🔽Desiring to avoid the consequence of their futility, it is said that the performance of rites by the wise,

analyzed: viśiṣṭa phalavat tvena arthavat tvam ucyate ācārya kulāt vedam adhītya saha arthataḥ dhyayanam
translated: being endowed with a special fruit, is meaningful. Having studied the Veda from the family of a teacher, having studied it along with its meaning,

analyzed: kṛtvā yathā vidhānam yathā smṛti uktaiḥ niyamaiḥ yuktaḥ san iti arthaḥ
translated: being endowed with the rules stated in the Smṛtis, according to the injunctions, is the meaning.

original: sarvasyāpi vidheḥ smṛtyuktasyopakaparvāṇakaṃ prati kartavyatve guruśuśrūṣāyāḥ prādhānyapradarśanārthamāhaguroḥ
analyzed: sarvasya api vidheḥ smṛti uktasya upaka parvāṇakam prati kartavya tve guru śuśrūṣāyāḥ prādhānya pradarśana artham āha guroḥ
translated: In order to show the pre-eminence of service to the Guru in the performance of all the duties enjoined by the Smritis, it is said:

original: karma yatkartavyaṃ tatkṛtvā karmaśūnyo yo 'tiśiṣṭaḥ kālastena kālena vedamadhītyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: karma yat kartavyam tat kṛtvā karma śūnyaḥ kālaḥ tena kālena vedam adhītya iti arthaḥ
translated: Having done the duties that are to be performed for the Guru, in the remaining time free from duties, he should study the Veda.

original: evaṃ hi niyamavatādhīto vedaḥ karmajñānaphalaprāptaye bhavati nānyathetyabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: evam hi niyamavatā adhītaḥ vedaḥ karma jñāna phala prāptaye bhavati na anyathā iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: For thus, when the Veda is studied by one who is regular, it becomes for the attainment of the fruits of actions and knowledge, not otherwise - this is the idea.

original: abhisamāvṛtya dharmajijñāsāṃ samāpayitvā gurukulannivṛtya nyāyato dārānāhṛtya kuṭumbe sthitvā gārhatthve vihite karmaṇi tiṣṭhannityarthaḥ /
analyzed: abhisamāvṛtya dharma jijñāsām samāpayitvā guru kulam nivṛtya nyāyataḥ dārān āhṛtya kuṭumbe sthitvā gārhatthve vihite karmaṇi tiṣṭhan iti arthaḥ
translated: Having completed the inquiry into Dharma by returning from the Guru's house, having taken a wife in the proper way, having settled in a household, he should remain in the duties prescribed for a householder.

analyzed: tatra api gārhasthya vihitānām karmaṇām svādhyāyasya prādhānya pradarśana artham ucyate śucau
translated: Even there, in order to show the pre-eminence of the study of one's own Veda among the duties prescribed for a householder, it is said: In a pure

original: vivikte 'medhyādirahite deśe yatāvadāsīnaḥ svādhyāyamadhīyāno naityakamadhikaṃ ca
analyzed: vivikte medhya ādi rahite deśe yata avadāsīnaḥ svādhyāyam adhīyānaḥ naityakam adhikam ca
translated: place free from impurity etc., sitting as much as possible, studying one's own Veda, the daily and additional

analyzed: yathāśakti ṛk ādi abhyāsam ca kurvan dhārmikān putrān śiṣyān ca dharma yuktān vidadhat dhārmika tvena
translated: recitations, and also studying the Rig and other Vedas as much as possible, he should engage virtuous sons and disciples in Dharma-related activities, by his own virtuous conduct.

analyzed: tān niyamayan ātmani sva hṛdaye hārde brahmaṇi sarva indriyāṇi saṃpratiṣṭhāpya upasaṃhṛtya indriya grahaṇāt karmāṇi
translated: Restraining them in the Self, in the heart, in the internal Brahman, having withdrawn all the senses by withdrawing the senses,

analyzed: ca saṃnyasya ahiṃsa hiṃnsām para pīḍām akurvan sarva bhūtāni sthāvara jaṅgamāni bhūtāni apīḍayan iti arthaḥ
translated: and having renounced actions, not injuring any beings, not causing pain to any beings, to all beings, both moving and unmoving. The meaning is: not causing pain to any beings.

analyzed: bhikṣā nimittam aṭana ādinā api para pīḍā syāt iti atas āha anyatra tīrthebhyaḥ
translated: There might be injury to others even by wandering for alms and so on, therefore he says: Except at sacred places.

analyzed: tīrtham nāma śāsra anujñā viṣayaḥ tatas nyatra iti arthaḥ
translated: A sacred place is the subject of scriptural permission. The meaning is: except at that.

analyzed: sarva āśramiṇām ca etat samānam tīrthebhyaḥ nyatra hiṃsā eva iti
translated: And this is common to all stages of life: except at sacred places, there is no injury.

original: anye varṇayanti kuṭumba evaitatsarvaṃ kurvansa khalvadhikṛto yāvadāyuṣaṃ yāvajjīvamevaṃyathoktena prakāreṇaiva vartayanbrahmalokamabhisaṃpadyatedehānte
analyzed: anye varṇayanti kuṭumbe eva etat sarvam kurvan sa khalu adhikṛtaḥ yāvadāyuṣam yāvajjīvam evam yathā uktena prakāreṇa eva vartayan brahma lokam abhisaṃpadyate dehānte
translated: Others describe it thus: One who performs all this in the family, indeed, being qualified, attaining the world of Brahman at the end of the body,

analyzed: na ca punar āvartate śarīra grahaṇāya
translated: does not return again to take up a body.

analyzed: punarāvṛtteḥ prāptāyāḥ pratiṣedhāt
translated: Because the prohibition of what has been attained to return again is stated.

original: arcirādinā mārgeṇa kāryabrahmalokabhisaṃpadya yāvadbrahmalokasthitistāvattatraiva tiṣṭhati prāktato nā'vartata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: arciḥ ādinā mārgeṇa kārya brahmaloka abhisaṃpadya yāvat brahmaloka sthitiḥ tāvat tatra eva tiṣṭhati prāk tatas na āvartate iti arthaḥ
translated: By the path beginning with light, he attains the world of Brahman, which is the effect, and as long as he remains in the world of Brahman, he does not return from there, this is the meaning.

original: dvirabhyāsa upaniṣadvidyāparisamāptyarthaḥ //🔽iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭamādhyāyasya pañcadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
analyzed: dvis abhyāsaḥ upaniṣad vidyā parisamāpti arthaḥ  iti chāndogyopaniṣadi aṣṭama adhyāyasya pañcadaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: The repetition twice is for the completion of the Upaniṣad knowledge.🔽Thus ends the fifteenth section in the eighth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti śrīmat govinda bhagavat pūjya pāda śiṣya paramahaṃsa par ivrājaka ācārya śrīmat śaṅkara bhagavat pāda kṛtau chāndogya upaniṣad vivaraṇe aṣṭamaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the eighth chapter composed by the illustrious Śaṅkara, the disciple of the venerable Govinda, the teacher of the highest truth, in the commentary on the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.
